HEADLINE: Pataki, Starting His 2d Term, Sees State as Model for Nation

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 1

 BODY:
George Elmer Pataki began his second term as Governor today by declaring that his success in scaling back government had rekindled New York's spirit, saying that the strides of the last four years showed that the state was ready to lead the nation into the next century.
"We the people of New York must light the way to a brighter future," Mr. Pataki said in a 14-minute inaugural address that often had the feel of a civic-minded pep talk. 
 Mr. Pataki, 53, a Republican who rose from a childhood on a Peekskill farm to become the state's 53d Governor, outlined no new proposals in the speech and did not refer to his ambitions beyond Albany, which have been the subject of growing speculation since he easily won re-election in November.
But the tirelessly upbeat oratory suggested he was honing a theme he plans to expound while traveling the country: that his brand of Republicanism -- fiscally conservative, with little emphasis on divisive social issues -- had worked in New York, and would work elsewhere.
"We charted a bold new course for this state," he said, "a course driven by our determination to see that government remains the people's servant and not their master."
As he often does, he referred to his idol, Theodore Roosevelt, who was inaugurated Governor of New York 100 years ago today. Mr. Pataki noted that both he and Roosevelt stood "at the edge of a new century, which is spread out before us like an undiscovered land of promise." Roosevelt also was the last New York Republican to win the Presidency.
Mr. Pataki has declined to say whether he will run for President next year, insisting only that he has not ruled it out and saying that as leader of a large state, he wants to help set his party's agenda. In recent weeks, he has uncharacteristically lashed out at the Republicans in Congress. He has asserted that they have damaged the party by neglecting core issues, like cutting taxes, in their zeal to impeach President Clinton.
A Presidential bid could prove daunting for Mr. Pataki, because while his support for abortion rights and views on other social issues play well in New York, they put him in conflict with the conservatives who hold sway in Republican Presidential primaries in other states.
Though he did not detail his agenda for his second term today, he plans to use his State of the State Message on Wednesday and his budget message later this month to announce new proposals. They will include a budget that is to be considerably more austere than his election-year one, which raised spending at more than the rate of inflation.
At the ceremony in the Convention Center here, Mr. Pataki took the oath of office from the state's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, while a 19-gun salute resounded in the piercing cold outside. Earlier, Judge Kaye swore in the new Lieutenant Governor, Mary O. Donohue, a former judge and prosecutor from upstate New York, who was recruited by Mr. Pataki to replace Betsy McCaughey Ross. Mr. Pataki had a long falling-out with Ms. McCaughey Ross. After he removed her from the re-election ticket, she became a Democrat, lost the party primary and ran against Mr. Pataki in the general election on the Liberal Party line.
The State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and the new Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, also took their oaths of office today.
Besides starting his second term, Mr. Pataki is now the most prominent Republican in the state, replacing his mentor, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who was defeated for re-election in November. Mr. D'Amato had anointed Mr. Pataki, then an obscure State Senator, as the party's nominee for governor in 1994.
The D'Amato defeat capped a disappointing election for the Republicans. Dennis C. Vacco was ousted as Attorney General by Mr. Spitzer, a wealthy former assistant district attorney from Manhattan, and the party failed to pick up seats in the Legislature, despite spending heavily. That showing tarnished Mr. Pataki's victory over the Democratic nominee, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker.
Mr. D'Amato sat in the front row during the inaugural ceremony, two rows in front of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican who spurned Mr. Pataki and endorsed the three-term Democratic incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo, in 1994, only to return to the fold in last fall's election and campaign for Mr. Pataki. Mr. Giuliani also has national aspirations, but publicly, he and Mr. Pataki say they get along. Privately, there is no affection between their camps.
Mr. Pataki's relatively short address today had little in common with his first in 1995, when he cited his upset victory over Mr. Cuomo as evidence that the public was angry with the state's condition. He attacked a "paid and pampered bureaucracy," pledging a smaller government, new work requirements for welfare recipients and tough criminal justice laws, including the death penalty, which Mr. Cuomo had blocked. He returned briefly to these issues today when he noted that he had followed through on his promises.
The tone of the speech was not the only difference. The inauguration this year was short and restrained, with none of the exuberance of 1995, when the Republicans held a weekend of parties to celebrate winning the governor's mansion for the first time in 20 years. About 2,100 people attended the swearing-in today, down from 13,000 in 1995.
The financing of the 1995 events turned into a major controversy of Mr. Pataki's first term when he refused to disclose which companies had made large donations to pay the cost. He later released some information after a court battle with the Democrats who control the State Assembly.
Mr. Pataki's campaign, as well as Mr. McCall's and Mr. Spitzer's, paid for this year's events.
Today, in addition to the swearing-in, Mr. Pataki attended an inaugural Mass at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, next to the Capitol, and held a reception at a hotel, with tickets costing $80.
In his speech, Mr. Pataki made no mention of the contrasts with his first inaugural. Instead, he concentrated on the inspirational, repeatedly returning to the idea that under his stewardship, New York's potential was limitless.
"We will keep our state moving forward," he said, "with policies that continue to fuel the passion, unleash the power and tap the vast reserves of strength, creativity and determination of New York's greatest resource: the spirit of our people."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Independent Oil Companies Suffer During Weak Market
Independent oil producers in the United States and the small companies that provide services to them have been hurt by low prices and foreign competition more than giants like Exxon and Mobil. Enshrined in fable for his enterprise and daring, the oilman in jeans and boots is giving way to the oilman in a suit. 
 Except for huge oilfields far offshore or in Alaska's wilds, major oil companies consider most of the United States too expensive or played out to bother with. Page A1.
 
For the fourth quarter, the contract drillers and oil-service companies, which do everything from making drill bits to flying the helicopters used to transport offshore workers, are expected to post falling earnings for the second quarter in a row. As oil prices languish at the lowest levels in more than a decade, contractors are taking rigs out of service as rents slide. C2.
 
China to Announce Debt Plan
The Chinese Government will soon announce how it plans to cover the debts of the nation's second-biggest financial company, which it closed in October, and the news for foreign bankers is likely to be bad. China closed the financial arm of the company, the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation, because it could not repay more than $2 billion of foreign debt. All told, Gitic, as the company is known, owes an estimated $10 billion to foreign banks. C4.
 
Preparing for Euro's Market Debut
One day after 11 European countries christened the euro as their new currency, financial institutions across the Continent began the enormous job of reprogramming their electronic networks before markets reopen for business on Monday morning. A5.
 
Surge in Hong Kong Real Estate
People in Hong Kong, from first-time buyers to the big development companies, have been trying to decide whether the strong housing sales of November were a sign that the worst recession in a generation is nearly over, or whether the market only found a false bottom and will continue to drop if the economy keeps contracting. Sales have been driven, in part, by falling interest rates. C3.
 
Insurers Expect Small Gains
The nation's property and casualty insurers are expected to report slim profit gains for the fourth quarter because competition has kept a lid on premiums. The group, including Allstate, CNA Financial and the St. Paul Companies, is expected to report an average earnings increase of only 1 percent for the quarter, far below the 28 percent gain for all of 1997. C2.
 
Windfall for E*Trade Employees
E*Trade Group Inc., the No. 2 on-line broker, reduced the exercise price on employee stock options two weeks after its stock traded at a 21-month low and began a three-month surge that increased its price sixfold. Employees who took advantage of the lower-priced options had total paper gains of more than $100 million by this week. C4.

HEADLINE: Religion Journal;
Group Sees Mixed Trend In Giving by Protestants

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
In the recessionary years of the early 1990's, some Protestant denominations faced budget shortfalls and were forced to downsize, cutting back staff at the national levels.
Such developments prompted a concern among some religious authorities about those denominations' financial futures. But in recent days, one organization that studies patterns of giving among Protestants has reported positive news -- although with limitations. 
 An annual survey of giving by members of 29 Protestant denominations has found that what they are putting into the collection plate, when measured as a percentage of their per capita income, has grown slightly for three consecutive years after falling for most of the previous 10.
The survey, by Empty Tomb Inc., a nonprofit organization dedicated to "Christian service and research," says members of those denominations increased their giving to about 2.6 percent of their disposable income in 1996, the last year for which statistics are available, from about 2.5 percent in 1994.
"We're cautiously optimistic," said Sylvia Ronsvalle, executive vice president of the organization, which is based in Champaign, Ill.
But Mrs. Ronsvalle said she was concerned that the proportion of members' money earmarked for purposes outside the local church (that is, money for seminaries, missionary work and other causes), had continued to decline, even as overall giving had risen.
The denominations included in the survey range from mainline Protestant bodies like the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) and the United Church of Christ to more conservative, evangelical denominations, like the Church of the Nazarene and the Southern Baptist Convention. The denominations account for about 29 million members in more than 100,000 congregations.
On average, members of the denominations gave $538 each in 1996, out of a per capita income of $20,840, as measured by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, a branch of the Commerce Department. Of the total given, $453 went to the local congregation to pay for budget items ranging from clergy members' salaries to the cost of utilities and to such in-house charitable activities as soup kitchens and food pantries.
Through denominational financial statistics, Empty Tomb has kept track of giving by Protestants since 1968 and has seen a fairly steady decline since then, measured against per capita income. In its surveys, the organization has reported that church members gave slightly more than 3.1 percent of their disposable income in 1968. That fell to slightly less than 2.5 percent in 1992 and 1993, the organization reported.
Mrs. Ronsvalle, whose husband, John, is president of the organization, said she was particularly concerned with the gradual decline in the proportion of giving to "benevolences," causes beyond the local congregation. By Empty Tomb's calculations, church members gave about seven-tenths of 1 percent of their per capita income to such causes in 1968, but that has fallen to four-tenths of 1 percent in the 1990's.
"If the church were helping church members integrate their faith, you would expect to see different patterns in the way they spend money," Mrs. Ronsvalle said. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Orange Shorts and Red Ink;
Hooters Chain, a Hit Elsewhere, Falters in Manhattan

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
As if more evidence were needed that Manhattan is not really part of America, consider this: The Hooters here is bankrupt.
Hooters, for those who have never ventured west of Hoboken, is a popular and fast-growing chain of restaurants known almost entirely for their waitresses, whom the company calls Hooters Girls. This is not because they look like owls. 
 A little more than a year ago, the first Hooters in Manhattan opened in a prime tourist area, on 56th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, a block away from the Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood. There was a bit of a splash at the time; David Letterman featured the new restaurant on his show, ordering chicken wings to go for his studio audience one night.
But in November, the restaurant filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, which means all the people to whom it owes more than a million dollars are on hold while the management tries to figure out how to stop the red ink. The restaurant is not closed, but it is in financial peril, losing something like $30,000 a month, according to court papers.
Exactly what went wrong? Richard Yudenfriend, the local businessman who owns this particular Hooters restaurant, is tight-lipped, to say the least. "We intend to be around for a long time, and are hopeful this is a temporary situation," he said last week, adding only that he did not think the Hooters "concept," as they say in the restaurant business, was wrong for New York.
Whether that is the case is arguable, considering the scantily clad -- or not clad at all -- competition nearby.
Of course, New York can be a tough town for anyone who wants to open a restaurant, no matter what the concept. Persnickety customers, temperamental chefs, high rents, lots of regulations, nettlesome neighbors and loads of competition make restaurants among the most frequent visitors to the bankruptcy court at Bowling Green.
As for chain restaurants, which offer middle-of-the-road food at middling prices, New York probably has fewer per capita than any other big city in the United States, industry experts say. Even some of the more expensive theme restaurants, like the Hard Rock Cafe and Planet Hollywood, have been faring poorly here.
In the case of Hooters, court documents and interviews with people involved in the restaurant tell a tale that hits all of those New York hot buttons: sex, food, money and real estate (not necessarily in that order).
Start with sex -- Hooters does. It has fought off government efforts to force it to hire male waiters, arguing that feminine, er, pulchritude is crucial to its business plan. This seems to be working elsewhere: the chain now has 232 restaurants, including 18 that opened in the last year. It is the sixth largest "casual dining" chain in the country, according to Technomic Inc., a leading restaurant consulting company.
Hooters Girls wear scooped-neck tank tops, push-up bras, very short orange shorts, white socks and sneakers (and flesh-toned tights, but don't tell the guys). The company describes the ideal Hooters Girl as a "cheerleader, surfer girl next door," though the ones featured in the company's calendars look more like Miss February.
The waitresses at the Hooters in Manhattan, however, do not. They are pretty and pleasant, but more Jones Beach than "Baywatch." At lunchtime recently, a table of young men clearly enjoyed flirting with their waitress. (Hooters Girls make most of their money from tips, and are encouraged to sit down with customers and chat.) But the smirking men became slack-jawed only when one of the many televisions ran a video of very buxom babes in bikinis.
Of course, men who are mainly interested in seeing female flesh can see a lot more of it at Flash Dancers (Topless Entertainment), say, or Legz Diamond's (All Nude), both of which are mere blocks away down Broadway. But Edward Droste, one of the men who founded Hooters in Florida in the 1980's, said such places are not competitors. "Hooters has never crossed over into that kind of arena," he said, adding that the restaurant is "a little safe haven."
The place looks like a combination fern bar and fraternity house: the blond paneled walls are covered with beer signs, pinup posters and fake traffic signs bearing slogans like "Double Curves."
As befits a restaurant whose slogan is, "Delightfully tacky, yet unrefined," the menu is written in a hokey, jokey style, as if the author were simultaneously channeling Hugh Hefner and Walt Disney. It boasts about the food, especially the "nearly world famous" chicken wings.
But customers do not seem convinced. In a recent survey for the magazine Restaurants and Institutions, consumers ranked Hooters 78th out of 90 chains in quality of food. As for what New Yorkers think, well, here's the 1999 Zagat Survey review: " 'Look but don't touch' applies both to the skimpily costumed staff and to the fried chain grub at the recent cholesterol-and-Lycra import; it's 'everything you've heard and less.' "
Of course, food is not likely to be the primary draw for the men who frequent Hooters -- and they are almost entirely men. Michael McNeil, vice president for marketing at Hooters of America, based in Atlanta, reports that nationally, 70 percent of the customers at Hooters are men, though it depends on the location and time of day. (Some Hooters have a children's menu.)
In Manhattan, almost all of the customers appear to be local men in their 20's rather than tourists. On a recent evening, they streamed into the place, paying a $3 cover charge to watch the waitresses compete in a bikini contest.
At lunch, however, things seem a lot slower. While nearby restaurants like the Brooklyn Diner and the Redeye Grill were jammed on a recent Thursday, only 50 or so people rattled around in Hooters, which seats 250.
That presents a particular problem for such a place, restaurant experts suggest, because its costs are high and its revenues are relatively low. Most of its entrees go for less than $10, and it serves only beer and wine, not hard liquor, which is more profitable. In court papers, Mr. Yudenfriend estimated that the restaurant would take in about $140,000 in December.
Meanwhile, there is a big nut to cover: The rent is almost $30,000 a month. And, because it is a franchise -- locally owned but part of a chain -- the restaurant must also pay about $10,000 a month in royalties to the mother ship in Atlanta. And all of that is before the payroll, food, taxes, insurance and interest payments on its loans. Total costs for December, Mr. Yudenfriend estimated, would be almost $173,000.
"Most franchises are still a volume business," said Jeffrey L. Bradach, a professor at Harvard Business School who has written a book called "Franchise Organizations" (Harvard Business School Press, 1998), which focuses on restaurants. "Because they don't have huge margins, they need people moving through the doors every hour of the day."
But the most important thing for a franchise, Professor Bradach said, is to match the concept of the restaurant to the demographics of the area.
Child-towing tourists do not seem to be flocking to Hooters. As for the locals, well, New York's service economy is unusually mixed, in terms of men and women working together, said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "I don't want to be harsh," he said, "but there are too many successful women in New York for men to be public about this. No professional male can come home and say, 'I went to Hooters.' "
Hooters executives say that the biggest problem for the Manhattan restaurant has been its location. The entrance and awning are in a little courtyard on the north side of 56th Street, and its signs are not very visible to anyone driving down Broadway or Seventh Avenue.
The interior of the restaurant needed a lot of work, said Mr. Droste, the Hooters founder, and "the operator got very much involved." As a result, he said, Mr. Yudenfriend may not have concentrated on "the promotional aspect we are famous for."
Some of Mr. Yudenfriend's backers, however, suggest that he did not get as much support from the home office as he might have expected, given that the Manhattan restaurant was supposed to be Hooters' marquee property. While Mr. Yudenfriend did have experience running a Hooters -- he took over the one on Staten Island in 1996 -- Manhattan is clearly a different market (for starters, the local Corvette club is not likely to hold meetings in the parking lot).
He has suffered some recent setbacks, according to papers his lawyer filed in court early last month. A manager resigned unexpectedly, the document says, and "Mr. Yudenfriend was mugged outside the Manhattan restaurant in the early morning of Dec. 1."
If Hooters of America does pull Mr. Yudenfriend's franchise, as it has threatened to do, that will not be the end of the restaurant chain's efforts here, Mr. McNeil said, adding, "Ultimately, we believe Manhattan needs, wants and deserves a Hooters restaurant."
But desire may not be enough. Expanding a chain from Atlanta to Birmingham is one thing, said Ron Paul, president of Technomic, the restaurant consulting firm. But New York City, he said, is something else.
"Don't be offended, but we tell clients that it's like going into an international location, in terms of culture, real estate, laws," Mr. Paul said. "It's very high risk to go into Manhattan."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROPOSES A BUDGET INCREASE FOR THE MILITARY

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
Heeding warnings from the nation's military chiefs, President Clinton has decided to propose the first real increase in the Pentagon's budget in nearly a decade and the largest since the cold-war buildup of the mid-1980's, Administration and defense officials said.
Mr. Clinton's proposal, only the first step in a drawn-out process with Congress, would reverse years of dwindling resources after the collapse of the Soviet Union. It would address growing strains, the officials said, caused by aging weapons and increasing operations overseas, from Bosnia to Iraq. 
 The proposal represents a significant political shift for Mr. Clinton. A Democrat who has often had an uneasy relationship with the military, he came into office in the wake of the cold war, focused more on his domestic initiatives than on the military.
But in the face of growing complaints about military readiness, both from within the military and from Republicans, Mr. Clinton was persuaded to seek an increase of more than $4 billion in the military budget for the fiscal year 2000 and about $100 billion over the next six years. That is the first increase, discounting inflation, since 1991, when spending spiked slightly for the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Clinton is expected to announce the increase in his weekly radio address on Saturday, and the early word of his plans appeared to be an effort to blunt a growing chorus of mostly Republican critics who say he has let the military erode. It is unclear, however, how he would pay for his proposals, setting the stage for what is sure to be an intense fight with the new Congress over military spending.
In the budget he will submit to Congress a month from today, Mr. Clinton plans to propose increasing spending for the Department of Defense to nearly $269 billion, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
While that is a modest net increase of just under 2 percent after inflation, Mr. Clinton has also agreed to let the department keep another $8 billion freed up as a result of lower-than-expected inflation and fuel prices, money that would normally be returned to the Treasury, they said.
Taken together, the Pentagon would have $12 billion in new money for the fiscal year that begins in October to spend on new equipment, spare parts and raises for the nation's soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines. Over the next six years, Mr. Clinton's budget would propose additional spending of just above $100 billion. That would represent the most significant rise in military spending since the buildup by President Ronald Reagan in the early 1980's, although it is only two-thirds of what the military chiefs had said they wanted in an ideal world.
Next week the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, and the chiefs of the Army, Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps are scheduled to appear before the Senate Committee on Armed Services. When they last appeared before the committee in September, they faced unusually hostile questioning over the military's readiness problems from Republicans, who accused them of having sugar-coated issues like pilot shortages and training cuts in a similar appearance earlier in the year. Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is considering a run for President in 2000, said then that the chiefs were "not candid to this member in the problems and challenges that we faced."
Despite strict spending caps set by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, many Republicans have called for much larger increases in the Pentagon's budget, accusing Mr. Clinton of having let the military become "hollow" and the generals and admirals of not blowing the whistle.
Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, a Republican who leads the Senate's subcommittee on military readiness, reacted strongly when asked about Mr. Clinton's plan to increase spending now, saying Mr. Clinton was belatedly trying to head off Republican criticism that he had skimped on the military.
"He's personally responsible for the defamation of our defense system and our hollow forces," the Senator said. "The President is going to try to make it look like he's a pro-defense President. It's an outrage."
Administration officials dismiss the accusations. In interviews this week, they said Mr. Clinton's proposals reflected the reality of today's military. The armed services are doing more -- from flying over Kosovo to bombing Iraq -- while the jets, ships and other equipment bought during President Reagan's buildup have become old and need replacing or at least spare parts.
The officials refused to say exactly how Mr. Clinton would propose paying for the increase in military spending. He has already vowed not to spend the recent Federal surplus until he and Congress agree on a way to shore up the Social Security system, which is lurching toward insolvency.
And the Balanced Budget Act has placed strict caps on total discretionary spending, requiring that any increases be offset by reductions elsewhere. Mr. Clinton could propose to pay for new military spending by cutting other domestic programs, although he has not done so in the past and seems unlikely to now.
Instead, the Administration is expected to find or create new pots of money that could be used for new increases. One Administration official said Mr. Clinton would call for increases in both military and domestic programs when he outlines his budget priorities, beginning with the State of the Union address later this month.
For much of the last year, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and the service chiefs have been steadily trying to build a case for an increase.
Even though no threat on the scale of the Soviet Union has emerged to challenge the United States' supremacy, they have argued that the declining or flat budgets since the Reagan years have left the country spending less on the military as a portion of the total Federal budget -- now just under 15 percent -- than at any other time since World War II.
When Mr. Cohen asked the chiefs to list their budget priorities, they came back with requests for personnel and equipment that totaled $148 billion over the next six years, which Mr. Cohen cut back to $112 billion. Negotiations with Mr. Clinton's budget aides have since whittled that down to the roughly $100 billion figure.
"It's still short of what we needed," one uniformed officer said.
Nevertheless, most Pentagon officials interviewed this week sounded pleased. One senior officer said the $12 billion in the coming fiscal year and more than $100 billion over six years would go a long way toward shoring up the areas of the budget under the most strain.
"Their most critical needs could be covered with something over 100 billion," the officer said.
Of the $12 billion, about $2.5 billion would pay for raises and improved retirement benefits that Mr. Cohen and General Shelton announced last month. They have called for an across-the-board 4.4 percent raise for each of the nation's nearly 1.4 million troops. They have also proposed giving targeted raises for thousands of mid-career officers and noncommissioned officers, those most likely to be tempted away from service by a robust economy.
Another $2 billion would pay for the peacekeeping force in Bosnia, where 6,900 American troops are now serving. In previous budgets, the Administration has paid for that mission, now three years old, with "emergency" spending.
The rest of next year's increase would be divided among the four services and pay for a variety of things, including increased maintenance on bases, spare parts for aging trucks, ships and airplanes, and more fuel and munitions to use in training. There is also new money for recruiting and still more bonuses for Air Force and Navy pilots being aggressively courted by commercial airlines.
Only a small bit of the proposed increase in 2000 would pay for expensive new weapons, the officials said. But in future years, most of the increases would pay for this "modernization." The Air Force would be able to buy more of its new F-22 fighters, the Navy to build new ships and the Army to pay for new Comanche attack helicopters.
"This is not absolutely everything the services need," a Pentagon official said. "I think it meets more of them than not, though, and certainly the most high-priority needs."
But other officials in the Pentagon and on Capitol Hill raised concerns. One official said it seemed that the Administration was committing itself to increases in the future -- after Mr. Clinton leaves office -- without yet identifying the way to pay for them. That could leave the Pentagon short of money down the road or saddle the Federal budget with new deficits.
"How that happens and we stay within the balanced-budget agreement is the difficulty in the whole process," said another Pentagon official, who was closely involved in shaping the budget. "I'm not sure I even know how they do that."

HEADLINE: Nature Ceded the Missouri to Man; Now Some Would Give It Back

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: NEBRASKA CITY, Neb.

 BODY:
Lewis and Clark would not know the Missouri River now.
The tumultuous water that taunted their canoes as they forged the way to the American West is docile now, domesticated. 
 The "confused jumble of savage-looking snags" that Mark Twain steered his steamboat through is now slick and sanitized. There is little left of the muddy water that Horace Greeley once said was like "thick milk porridge -- you could not discern an egg in a glass of it."
For 50 years now, the hand of man has tamed the Missouri River, damming it and diking it, choking off chutes and oxbows, streamlining and straitjacketing it into a channel for barges and a generally well-behaved feeding tube for the fertile farmland on its banks.
But big changes are coming to the Big Muddy. America's longest river, nearly 2,500 miles stretching from Three Forks, Mont., to St. Louis, is in the throes of an identity crisis.
After the withering drought of the late 1980's and the ferocious floods of 1993, the United States Army corps of Engineers, which essentially controls the river's flow, decided that it needed to re-evaluate its master plan.
The fracas over the river's future is fierce as environmental groups, farmers, barge operators, recreation boosters, hydroelectric utilities, Indian tribes and municipal leaders all try to make sure the river stays -- or becomes -- what they want it to be.
"Everybody would dearly love if we could come up with a recommendation that everyone could agree on," said Richard H. Opper, executive director of the Missouri River Basin Association, a coalition of the eight river-basin states and two dozen Indian tribes, which met to discuss the river in December.
Caught in the middle is the corps, which controls how much water is released from upstream reservoirs after each year's snow melt -- and when. It has the sometimes Sisyphean task of insuring there is enough water when and where needed, but not so much that it mutinies its banks.
The corps has issued a list of alternatives -- ways to adjust the ebb and flow of the Missouri -- aiming to make a decision later this year.
And that has unleashed a torrent of debate.
"I was saying for years there are really two things that the corps could not propose politically," Mr. Opper said. "One was keeping the current situation the same. The other was any sort of change."
Here in Nebraska City, an unpretentious, plain-vanilla Plains town about 400 miles upriver from where the Missouri dumps into the Mississippi just north of St. Louis, most of the conflicts are easy to see.
Farmers like John Crook, growing corn and soybeans on river-bottom land his great-grandfather staked out in 1878, want the Missouri to be even more reined in so their crops will not drown.
People like Ray Pinney, who manages the barge terminal here, want the water to stay swift and deep so towboats and barges can keep hauling fertilizer up from St. Louis and Kansas City and taking grain downriver at harvest time.
Chad Smith, who represents the environmental group American Rivers in this part of the country, and Gerald Mestl, a biologist with the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission, want the river to return, as much as possible, to its natural, free-flowing state. Decades of man-made management have destroyed miles of natural habitat, threatening the survival of many species and landing three -- the pallid sturgeon, the piping plover and the least tern -- on the endangered species list.
And Nancy Hoch, who heads the economic development corporation in this town of about 7,000 people, supports farming and business interests. But like leaders in other cities that once used the river as an industrial dumping ground, she also understands environmental concerns. After all, Nebraska City's claim to fame is as the home of the inventor of Arbor Day, and Ms. Hoch is promoting a Lewis and Clark interpretive center planned for 2004, the 200th anniversary of the explorers' Missouri River bonanza.
"I feel very strongly that the river does not belong to anyone," Ms. Hoch said. "It does not belong to the least tern. It does not belong to barge traffic. We need to balance the river."
But balance is hard to come by on a river that sculptures the country's midsection, draining about a sixth of the United States.
Farther north of Nebraska City, a booming hunting, fishing and boating industry wants to insure that the reservoirs do not lose too much water each year.
And up and down the Missouri are Indian tribes that have begun to assert claims to water rights along significant portions of the river, supported by a turn-of-the-century Supreme Court ruling. When they ultimately negotiate which water they will control, the tribes say they will use it for everything from irrigation to electricity to exporting it for sale.
"There's so many interests in the Missouri River Basin," said Richard Bad Moccasin, executive director of the tribes' organization, Mni Sose Intertribal Water Rights Coalition ("Mni" means "water" in the Lakota language, and "Sose," Mr. Bad Moccasin said, means "the way the Missouri used to be -- murky and muddy and wild and woolly.")
"I don't envy the Army Corps," Mr. Bad Moccasin said, "but, well, they created the monster -- trying to change that mighty Missouri."
Fifty years ago, concerned that the river would overrun some of the nation's richest farmland -- and eager for a public works project to employ the veterans of World War II -- the corps erected six dams on the Missouri, with reservoirs to hold the snow melt from South Dakota to Montana. Farther downstream, it narrowed a wide bramble of sandbars and side-channels into a single manicured canal with fast, deep water to satisfy towboats and barges plying between Sioux City and St. Louis. Dikes and levees were rigged up too, keeping the river in check and holding back the runoff that once muddied its waters.
"Some people," Mr. Opper said, "say it more closely resembles a plumbing system rather than a natural river."
The voices of those who say that have become stronger in recent years. Environmental groups, distressed that the loss of about a half-million acres of the river's habitat has threatened or endangered a fifth of the plant and animal species in and around the river, have been pressing for substantial changes.
Initially, American Rivers proposed ending all commercial navigation, saying it paled in economic significance to the river's environmental and recreational value. When that caused a firestorm of anger, the group suggested the corps change its policy of releasing a constant amount of water from the spring through the fall and instead release more water in the spring and less in the summer. That would create a "spring rise," which would act as a kind of aphrodisiac to fish, and in the summer would encourage the formation of sandbars, where birds like to nest.
To the navigation industry, that is a grave threat. It would ground barges and towboats when the river was low in the summer. While the Missouri's barge traffic has never been heavy and has diminished in the last 20 years -- the corps says 2 million tons of cargo a year travel on the Missouri compared with over 100 million tons on the Mississippi -- industry officials say it is important because it forces railroads to set competitive shipping prices.
Paul J. Werner, a vice president with American Waterways Operators, the barge industry trade association, said keeping the Missouri's water levels consistently high was also crucial for insuring the Mississippi River had enough water for navigation.
"The people that are suggesting that the only answer to the right hand's problem is to cut off the left," Mr. Werner said, "I think they are part of the problem."
Farmers, for their part, worry that a spring rise could cause flooding or make it impossible to drain fields in time for planting.
"If it's too wet to get a crop planted by the first of June, you're not farming this year," said Mr. Crook, who like many farmers here is reeling from the loss of some crops in recent years because wet weather has made the river unusually high.
Of course, weather anomalies like that have made the corps' choice even harder.
"The river changes and you need to change with it," said John Remus, a corps hydraulic engineer, standing on a riverbank near Nebraska City. "We're not going to be able to be as highhanded as we once were. We're going to have to listen to other people."
Mr. Opper, who in the last year has managed, with the help of professional mediators, to get sworn enemies to at least acknowledge one another's claims to the river, hopes the pressure of the corps' coming decision and the responsibilities imposed by the Endangered Species Act will force the groups to reach a consensus, even though "it will be a recommendation that nobody is completely happy with."
But one recent change on the river has so far not angered too many people.
The corps has begun buying up parcels of farmland along the banks, grafting them on to the river and converting them into wetlands that re-create a little bit of the old Missouri. The environmental groups approve, even if they consider it a drop in the bucket. And most navigators and farmers are not complaining, since the wetlands are walled off with rocks so they do not disturb the flow and depth of the main river channel.
The first of these, Hamburg Bend, created in 1996 just south of Nebraska City, is a chute carved from land so damaged by the 1993 flood that it became practically unfarmable.
On a recent tour in a flat-bottomed skiff, as a bald eagle and a blue heron flapped by, Mr. Mestl of the Game and Parks Commission pointed out the sandbars, slower, shallower water and tapered natural banks that attracted wildlife, including the speckled chub, the plains minnow and the catfish.
"Lewis and Clark called the Missouri a catfish river," Mr. Mestl said. And even though the wetlands are small consolation for environmentalists, he said, at least "people are starting to catch fish here."

HEADLINE: In City of Castro's Triumph, Most Still Back Him

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 1

 BODY:
It has been 40 years since Fidel Castro led his rebels into this seaside colonial city and declared the end of the Batista dictatorship from the balcony of city hall. For residents here, it has been 40 years of Communist rule, economic sacrifice and endless maneuvering in a cold war with the United States.
But as the city prepared for Mr. Castro's return tonight to give a speech commemorating the anniversary of the revolution, it was hard to find anyone on the streets here who would openly criticize the 72-year-old Cuban leader or his policies. 
 The town was dressed in propaganda. Cuban flags flew from balconies, and signs celebrating the "triumph of the revolution" could be seen in all the shop windows. "To be Cuban is a privilege and a pact with Fidel," one sign said.
In his speech here, President Castro described the moment of victory on Jan. 1, 1959, saying that "I felt for a moment a strange sense of emptiness" to leave behind the "hard, pure and healthy" life of a guerrilla to take over the leadership of Cuba.
"The people I lead are not the same people of that January first," he said, noting that 7 million of Cuba's 11 million inhabitants were born after the revolution. He said he was "not exactly the same man of that day, either."
But he said he still thought the same way and predicted that the capitalist system would fall. Referring to financial speculators, he said, "They have turned the planet into a giant casino."
In interviews earlier, several working-class people and veterans of the rebel army said they still supported Mr. Castro's long experiment with socialism, despite the economic hardships they have had to endure. Even with the economy in tatters, many said they have more opportunity now than they did before 1959, when a good education was out of reach for most poor people, especially those with black skin. Mr. Castro's supporters also blame the United States trade embargo and not the Castro Government for their economic woes.
"The blockade is a crime against Cuba -- Cubans never deserved this," said Ibrahim Salazar, a 63-year-old retired bus driver, who was waiting with friends near the main plaza where workers were setting the stage for Mr. Castro's speech.
He wore a frayed T-shirt commemorating the revolution's 30th anniversary. Mr. Salazar said he believed the revolution's major goals, like free education and health care, had been met. His son had become an engineer, something unthinkable for poor people 40 years ago.
"We can't lose faith," he said. "We have problems, but we are going to conquer them."
But others, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the country's economic fabric had been slowly unraveling since 1991, when Russia stopped subsidizing the economy with more than $4 billion in aid. Since then, Cuba has become a country where doctors make less than $30 a month and must moonlight as cab drivers for tourists to make ends meet and where some educated women with professional skills choose prostitution at resort hotels. The average monthly salary is 207 pesos, or about $10.
It is also a country that more than 1 million people have fled since Mr. Castro took over. Just last year, more than 450,000 applied for visas to the United States.
"This is a sort of Titanic," said a one resident of Santiago, who spoke on condition of anonymity because he feared arrest. "Everyone is trying to get a boat to leave."
He added: "The system doesn't work. At this moment money is the principle problem for everyone here. You need money to survive."
After four decades of Mr. Castro's socialist experiment, Cuba has become a paradox. With free education and health care, it has the highest literacy rate and the lowest infant mortality rate in Latin America. The average life expectancy is now 75.3 years, far above the 60 years in 1959. The number of university graduates per capita has quadrupled, and Cuban doctors have broken new ground in biotechnology and vaccines.
Yet Mr. Castro has failed to break the dependency on the sugar crop and tourism for hard-currency earnings -- twin factors that were blamed before the revolution for making Cuba an economic vassal of the United States. And the country is no more democratic than it was under Fulgencio Batista, the dictator who fled on Jan. 1, 1959.
Since the fall of the Soviet Union, Mr. Castro has reluctantly undertaken some market-oriented reforms. He has legalized the dollar and allowed some small-scale private business. He has also decentralized some of the state-owned industries.
But professionals like doctors, who continue to work are not doing it for the money.
"The living is not much, but we manage," said Dr. Juan Fernandez, a general practitioner, who says he makes about $30 a month. "I like my profession, and I'm dedicated to my work."
To his supporters, Mr. Castro remains the best hope for working-class people in Cuba. Even if he is an autocrat, several said, he is their autocrat, looking out for their interests.
Part of his appeal is rooted in history and nostalgia. Some of the older residents remember the New Year's Day morning in 1959 when Mr. Castro and his troops marched into town and announced the end of Mr. Batista's rule. There was jubilation in the streets, people singing and cheering for the end of the regime, which had used increasingly repressive measures in an effort to stanch the rebellion.
"We have lived through many assassinations, many tortures, and the life was impossible here," recalled Rafael Guillen, an accountant. "When Fidel came, it was as if we had been in great pain and someone had given us a painkiller."
"The new generation who didn't live through it cannot understand it," he added.
Others continue to support Mr. Castro because he has advanced equality for blacks and women. Fermin Reynoso, a 40-year-old driver, who is black, said that before Mr. Castro's takeover, blacks never had a chance of rising in society. Racism was pervasive then, he said.
But under Mr. Castro, Mr. Reynoso could have a military career. He served for nine years, fighting in Angola and Ethiopia, and retired as a lieutenant. Now he has a relatively good job, and his children have a chance at a college degree.
"The socialist system has given a lot of opportunities to all the blacks here," he said.
Rolando Segui, 83, is typical of many of the older people here who still support Mr. Castro. Like his father before him, Mr. Segui was a butcher in the 1950's.
"I had to become a butcher because there was no other work," he said. "I never had the opportunity to study."
He joined the rebellion, the July 26 Movement, and after Mr. Castro's victory, was rewarded with government jobs, first as a health inspector and later a housing inspector. He retired 10 years ago. Mr. Segui says he is still optimistic about the future. The abject poverty, illiteracy and sickness he witnessed in his youth no longer exists. Most important, he said, his grandchildren have a chance of rising in society.
"This is what we fought for," he said. "If you want to be a doctor, and you have the capacity to be a doctor, you can be a doctor."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2568 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW EUROPE: United and Divided;
Shiny, Prosperous 'Euroland' Has Some Cracks in Facade

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: AACHEN, Germany

 BODY:
Europe has two faces, light and dark, and they are evident on Germany's western and eastern borders as the continent crowns four decades of integration with the adoption of a single currency, the euro.
Here in Aachen, which lay in ruins in 1945, borders have ceased to exist. It has become usual for people who work in this western German city to live in Belgium and play a weekly tennis match in the Netherlands. The sweet whiff of prosperity seeps from Italian shoe stores, Spanish tapas bars, French croissanteries and English pottery shops that line the pedestrian shopping areas on all sides of the borders. 
 "This used to be a border city, but no longer," said Hans Poth, a spokesman for the Aachen town council who lives in Belgium. "And once we have the euro, the last barriers will disappear."
But a few hundred miles to the east, in Gorlitz, crumbling facades testify to decades of Communist rule. The town is split into two halves, as it has been since 1945 when eastern districts fell into Poland as European borders were rearranged after World War II. A single bridge, clogged by long lines of traffic, links the German and Polish parts.
While Aachen's melting borders symbolize the growing unity of Western Europe, Gorlitz underlines the continuing division of the continent.
Rolf Karbaum, mayor of the German part of Gorlitz, gazed out over a disjointed vista of baroque homes built centuries ago by German burghers and apartment blocks left by Polish Communists. "Now we want to be one city again," he said. "But for that, we need Poland in the European Union and the euro as our currency on both sides of the river."
Aided by the United States, postwar Europe has risen from the ruins of 1945 and overcome seemingly perennial rivalries through a bold vision of union that has brought prosperity and peace to regions plagued for centuries by instability and bloodshed. The euro, a single currency for 290 million people that may in time challenge the dollar, symbolizes a colossal achievement.
Yet it falls short of the original vision of a federal Europe with a single currency at its heart. Through its 20-year gestation, the euro appears to have shifted from a political ideal to a more prosaic economic tool.
Europe, for the foreseeable future, seems set to remain a hybrid beast, using English as its lingua franca, running its monetary policy through a federal institution -- the European Central Bank in Frankfurt -- while control of most other instruments of government, including budgets, remains at the national level.
Whether such an arrangement -- a new experiment in historical terms -- is workable remains unclear. Projected slower European growth in 1999, dragged down by slumps in Asia and Latin America, will place added strain on the euro's inception.
Beyond the economics loom larger questions. With the Cold War's glue now gone, will the trans-Atlantic bond that buttressed European growth remain firm as "Euroland" takes form?
The 11 nations joining the euro have abandoned an important part of their sovereignty to the European Central Bank. That probably will dispose them toward finding multilateral solutions to world problems, while a wholly sovereign America may choose -- as recently in Iraq -- to take a unilateral view of its interests.
And does Europe still have the vitality and drive to overcome the many remaining divisions between its capitalist and former Communist halves, to fulfill Mr. Karbaum's wish of making his wounded Gorlitz whole again?
Voicing a sentiment common in France, which acutely feels an end-of-millennium intellectual malaise, Arnaud Jacomet, a French defense official, considers Europe "a tired continent, in late middle age, looking only for a comfortable retirement, with the United States as its eternal protector." In this vision, Europe may be content to rest on its laurels, leaving the formerly Communist, still impoverished states in its east on the outside looking in.
The 11 nations that have adopted the new currency carry formidable economic heft. They represent about 18 percent of the world's total output and account for about 20 percent of its exports. After the United States, Europe will be the world's second-largest trading area with a single currency.
The euro, if it is successful, will provide enhanced European capital markets, easier comparison of prices, improved competitiveness, convenience and the kind of stability that resisted any European contagion from Asian or South American crises in 1998.
Already, the tough fiscal and other criteria set for qualification for the euro have drawn countries like Spain, Italy and Portugal toward a low-inflation prosperity they have never previously known. The euro, and the 15-nation European Union in general, have amounted to a beneficent magnet.
Some day, many economists believe, the euro may even rival the dollar as a reserve currency, obliging the United States to abandon a central assumption: that its deficits will always be financed because the world wants dollars.
Norway, for example, is certain to take payment for oil exported to its European neighbors in euros rather than dollars, because it imports principally from European countries. Eastern European exporters may do the same.
"Taking a three-year view, the euro will present a serious challenge to the dollar," said David Hale, chief economist for the Chicago-based Zurich Group. "America may have to rethink its view of itself."
But challenging America in the ether of world financial markets is far from creating the unified political entity imagined by the founding fathers of European Union and very far from any European emancipation from American military tutelage.
 
The Dream
From War's Ashes, A Single Future
For generations, ever since Churchill spoke in 1946 of uniting Europe in "the sharing of its common inheritance" and Jean Monnet of France laid the first foundation stones of integration, many Europeans have dreamed of unity. Yet just as the euro is being introduced, the idea of Europe may have lost its galvanizing appeal.
A difficult decade in Europe has taken a heavy toll on the European ideal. Slow growth and high unemployment -- more than 10 percent in Germany, more than 11 percent in France -- have been widely equated with the budgetary rigors imposed as preparation for the new currency. In many places, Brussels has become a dirty word.
Although East Europeans still talk constantly of "joining Europe," seeing in this mantra the age-old vision that European unity could banish the continent's demons and bring peace, "Europe" has little or no resonance for the millions of young West Europeans touched by unemployment. No new, forward-looking message has been found to take its place.
Indeed the very words "idea" and "Europe" seem strangely paired because intellectual vitality appears to have migrated elsewhere, and with it the forces now changing the world.
Yves Thibault de Silguy is the European Union's top monetary official and an ardent promoter of the euro. For this energetic Frenchman, a Paris-to-Potsdam, Berlin-to-Barcelona currency may eventually make the nations that have opted to join "Euroland" more stable and robust.
But European patriotism -- hearts thumping, even stirring, before Europe's blue-and-gold flag? Forget it. A quick expansion eastward to embrace formerly communist Mitteleuropa? Not likely.
"We can never be an American melting pot, even with a single currency," Mr. de Silguy said. "People here are firmly attached to national ideas. They like to live in a big, open European market, but within their own language and culture. As for expansion eastward, we need to wait. You have to be a realist."
Such realism, however, is new at European headquarters. A few years ago, the dismissal of a United States of Europe -- especially by a Frenchman -- would have been viewed as Thatcherite Europhobia. For decades, the 15-nation European Union progressed precisely by being unrealistic. It embraced far-fetched dreams, like a single currency, and somehow staggered toward them.
But now, the boldness of a postwar European generation driven by the desire to banish bloodshed from the continent has given way to the pragmatism of a more pampered generation for whom America is at least as resonant as Europe.
This shift of ambition suggests that Europe will long remain what Norbert Walter, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank, calls "an economic giant and a political dwarf." While challenging American supremacy on the currency markets, the dwarf will still desire -- even require -- American military protection and, in times of crisis such as recent Balkan conflicts, strategic leadership.
"Nobody buys the federalist model in Brussels any more," said Andrew Moravcsik of Harvard's Center for European Studies. "As governments have started looking beyond the euro, at harmonizing foreign and defense policy, even at a common tax policy, they have seen that public opinion is just not with them."
In this climate, Mr. de Silguy and other officials said, the euro will not propel Europe toward political unity -- a common foreign and defense policy, a European army, the federal European government long seen by France as the best escape from American domination of Europe and by Germany as a refuge from a troublesome national identity.
"Right now, a shared defense, security and foreign policy looks unrealistic to me," Mr. de Silguy said.
In its absence, America, through NATO, will continue to bear the chief burden of Europe's defense. But already, debates on the future of the Alliance have been marked by differences over how "global" NATO should become and whether, as Europeans now argue, the organization should be bound in its missions by the United Nations Security Council.
Still, for now the alliance of interests binding Europe and the United States since the end of World War II has held. The success of this joint undertaking -- European integration under the umbrella of American security guarantees -- is evident in Aachen.
 
The Reality
A Hybrid Approach To Hard Problems
Once home to Charlemagne, who governed much of Western Europe from here in the 9th century, including modern France and Germany, Aachen was long disadvantaged by the proximity of the Belgian and Dutch borders -- barriers to trade and economic development that were as cumbersome as today's German-Polish border at Gorlitz.
But now, on the German-Dutch border, a unique project has begun. Called "Avantis," it is a 100-acre trans-border industrial zone that literally straddles the frontier. Dutch and German mail boxes, red and yellow, have already been placed side by side in an act of playful symbolism.
The project is complicated because Dutch and German taxes and regulations are different. But it is intended to feed off Aachen's renowned university of technology and engineering to create between 7,000 and 12,000 jobs in the high-tech sector. A brochure describes the project as a "European Science and Business Park" set in a "win-win situation."
That, in many ways, is a good summary of Europe today: A German-Dutch cross-border project with an English name and American jargon. Areas of prosperity in places long prone to instability abound. Alsace-Lorraine, and the French-Spanish border region between Perpignan and Barcelona are other examples.
"Peace and freedom are now taken for granted," said Jurgen Linden, the mayor of Aachen. "So we have to show our citizens that Europe has advantages by creating jobs in projects like these. With the euro, we can work on both sides of a border."
Not everyone is convinced. In the streets of Maastricht, the Dutch town where European leaders decided in 1991 to tear down trade barriers and adopt a single currency, Elisabeth Lubbers, a housewife, said the people of Europe were still different, and its nations too diverse, to accept the euro. "There will be trouble," she said, "and with Germany you never know."
That sentiment is not uncommon in Britain and has contributed to keeping the country out of the euro for now. Among the 18 million unemployed in Europe and the continent's "new poor," resentment against Europe is often virulent.
 
The Doubts
Nagging Suspicions About Path to Take
For most Europeans -- a clear majority, according to polls -- the euro is now seen as a logical extension of a successful experiment. What is not clear is whether the will exists to reach out from the relative comfort of today's western European society to take that experiment decisively further.
Some ideas do exist: the nomination of a "High Representative" to coordinate European foreign and security policy; a passage to majority voting on more European issues, seen as essential if Europe is not to become too unwieldy; a possible integration of the Western European Union, Europe's largely dormant defense arm, into the formal structures of the European Union.
But such steps -- known as "deepening" -- are controversial, because they may imply further compromises on national sovereignty.
They may also prove difficult because Germany and France, long the motors of European integration, have discovered other priorities. Germany has been absorbed with its costly unification and, of late, with an attempt to step out from the shadow of its past.
"Of course, we are all for a strengthening of Europe, but we no longer feel this is a historical obligation," said Bodo Hombach, minister of State at the Germany chancellery. "We want Europe, but not because we have to."
In practice, the new government of Social Democrats and Greens led by Gerhard Schroder has adopted almost Thatcherite tones in demanding a reduction in its huge contribution to the European budget. It has also suggested that candidates for European Union membership -- including Poland -- may have to wait a long time.
Across the Rhine, French politicians have been made acutely aware of the enduring appeal of nationalist slogans by the success of the National Front, and disgruntlement over unemployment has made any ringing appeals for united European governance tantamount to political suicide.
Until Europe works out these internal problems, it will not reach out to address the pressing needs of Gorlitz and all the once-Communist countries on its eastern flank. Already, with unemployment running at 21 percent in the area, many Germans complain about Poles coming to work illegally in Gorlitz.
"It took generations to resolve the French-German problem, and here tensions with Poland have been compounded by almost 50 years of Communism," said Mr. Karbaum, the Gorlitz mayor. "But this is an artificial border, and we have to overcome it, just as on Germany's western side."
Jreneusz Aniszkiewicz, the deputy mayor of Zgorzelec, as the Polish side of the town is known, agreed: "The economy can resolve everything today," he said.
The two men have a project: to rebuild Gorlitz's old bridge, destroyed by Allied bombing in 1945. But six years of negotiation have so far failed to resolve various difficulties and the two banks of the River Neisse -- no more than 30 yards apart -- remain unbridged in the center of town. The one existing bridge is on the outskirts.
"It is not easy," Mr. Karbaum said. "Young Germans say to me, we have no work, no hope, nothing to do, and you want to spend millions of euros on a bridge."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1812 words

HEADLINE: Lost Man of the Lost Generation

BYLINE: By Robert Kiely; Robert Kiely, a professor of English at Harvard University, is the author of books on modern and post-modern fiction.

 BODY:

MAN FROM BABEL
By Eugene Jolas.
Edited by Andreas Kramer
and Rainer Rumold.
326 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $30. 
 "For the most part we were not interested in social problems, in economics or in any particular political complex. . . . We were the Romantics of the 20th century." So wrote Eugene Jolas of the cosmopolitan literary and artistic world he inhabited, observed and contributed to in the Paris of the 1920's.
Given the legacy of World War I and the tensions building in Europe at the time, the comment sounds arrogant and insular. Jolas seems nostalgic, not apologetic, about a period of willful blindness. Yet while it is true that nostalgia informs many moments in this memoir of an extraordinary life in an extraordinary time, Jolas was anything but a blind participant in events of the first half of the 20th century. The statement is a typically honest recollection by a person who did not forget the past or sentimentalize the future, but who by disposition, personal history and profession was an acute recorder of moods and events in rapidly shifting times.
Eugene Jolas was born in Union City, N.J., in 1894 of a German mother and a French father from Alsace-Lorraine. His parents returned to their native town of Forbach when Jolas was still an infant. He was raised in a bilingual family, educated in German at Roman Catholic schools and surrounded by French-speaking neighbors. Nothing in his eventful life seems to have marked him more than this early experience of a cultural and political border tense with instability and burdened by a history of conflicting allegiances and ideals. Even after he immigrated to America (he was a citizen by birth), he continued to associate the word "frontier" with a complex and fateful inheritance from the past rather than with opportunity and hope for the future.
Jolas returned to the United States at 15, lived with relatives and took odd jobs as a messenger in New York City. Despite low pay and hard living, he loved the variety and bustle of the city. Instead of two languages, he heard dozens. He relished the accents and atmosphere of Hell's Kitchen, Chinatown, Flatbush and Prospect Park. When he heard the story of another immigrant boy, Joseph Pulitzer, he decided to be a newspaperman. He wandered from city to city taking any tasks a paper would offer, and between jobs he slept on park benches, sharing hunger and stories with others out of work. There is something Dreiseresque in the cold chaotic whirl of Jolas's American city at the turn of the century, but there is nothing of Dreiser in Jolas's outlook. He sounds more like the Artful Dodger. Where others might fall into despair, he inevitably finds reason for hope and even a kind of irrepressible cheerfulness.
His first serious job was with a German-language newspaper in Pittsburgh. The teen-ager arrived hungry and alone in what at the time must have been one of America's least appealing cities: "I arrived in Pittsburgh on a cold, snowy February evening. The tall chimneys of the steel mills and glass factories pierced the sky. Blast furnaces belched soot and smoke. I felt exhilarated by the lurid cosmos, the cloudy world of industry, grandiose and Dantesque."
Since Jolas began writing his memoirs in the 30's and continued through World War II, it is possible that the older man casts a golden haze over the hardships of his youth. Still, his capacity not only for survival but also for taking genuine pleasure in the unexpected shifts of fate that might have defeated a more fragile psyche seems to have remained with him throughout his life. It is a trait that helped make him one of the outstanding journalists of his day and may have prevented his brooding American-French-German philosophical poetry from possessing the originality and authenticity of his English prose.
The writing, even in this unfinished memoir, will strike any reader. Jolas began dictating chapters to his wife, Maria, in the late 30's or early 40's and continued intermittently until his death in 1952. It was in the 1980's that Maria brought these papers to the attention of the editors of "Man From Babel," Andreas Kramer and Rainer Rumold.
Whatever else he was doing, Jolas also found time to write verse. His memoir is punctuated by samples of it. Strongly influenced by the German Romantics and the French avant-garde, as well as by Whitman and Hart Crane, he longed to universalize his incurable homesickness -- for Europe when he was in America, for America when he was in Europe -- and consequently his restless need to keep moving, which he considered "an immigrant neurosis." He was obsessed by language, and, like many of his generation, he borrowed Freudian terminology to label if not explain his inner conflicts, including the linguistic ones between the literary and the idiomatic, French and German, American slang and standard English. "Language became a neurosis," he writes at the outset as if to alert us to the pathology that will provide consistency to a life divided between continents and interrupted by two world wars.
If language was his neurosis, he turns it -- much as he did the sidewalks of New York, the smokestacks of Pittsburgh, the bordellos of Savannah -- to his advantage as a reporter. In the 20's he found himself writing for the Paris edition of The Chicago Tribune. He seemed to be everywhere in Paris at once -- in the right hotel lobby for the entrance of Gloria Swanson, in the right bar to overhear drunken conversations of Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald, in the right park to see Ernest Hemingway take his son for a walk: "He usually wore workman's clothes and was always most careful to avoid being taken for a literary man. . . . He seemed to have a preference for intermingling his vocabulary with strong four-letter words. Frequently, however, these gave the impression of being carefully calculated."
But Jolas was more than a literary gossip columnist. He was deeply interested in the esthetic avant-garde of the 20's; he was a defender of Dadaism and Surrealism and of any effort to break language and the arts away from the cliches of conventional light entertainment. Not long after his arrival in Paris, he was asked to take over from Ford Madox Ford the writing of The Tribune's literary column, "Rambles Through Literary Paris." During interviews and by attending readings, he met everyone -- James Joyce, Francois Mauriac, Andre Breton, Gertrude Stein, Sinclair Lewis, Andre Gide -- and quickly became not only an observer but an actor in the Paris scene.
His most important and influential contribution to the literary life of the times was his founding and editing of Transition, a journal dedicated to the publication of avant-garde works and, of equal importance to the trilingual Jolas, the exposure between the same covers of Continental, American and British experiments in language. In a manifesto published in the third issue in 1927, Jolas expressed himself with characteristic expansiveness: "We need new words, new abstractions, new hieroglyphics, new symbols, new myths."
One of the closest and most important of his many literary friends was Joyce, with whom Jolas shared a nostalgia for an impossible homeland and a fascination with the meeting and mingling of alien languages. Jolas became a defender of Joyce's radical linguistic experiments and published excerpts of "Work in Progress" (early fragments of "Finnegans Wake") in Transition. But he also came to know a side of Joyce few outside his closest circle of friends would ever see. He saw the lover of Italian opera; the introverted celebrity who refused to be interviewed but who could talk and sing into the night with those he trusted; the aloof literary giant who wished readers would be more appreciative of his humor (and said, "in riso veritas"); the grieving father tormented by his daughter's mental illness. Like all good reporters, Jolas could capture a personality in a moment and a phrase. Recalling an evening with Joyce in a Parisian restaurant, he noticed at a nearby table Picasso, Breton and Jacques Prevert. "Informed of their presence, Joyce did not look up."
Though Jolas's English was supple and fluent, some of his most pointed vignettes depend on what he considered untranslatable expressions. Whenever the French printer of "Work in Progress" heard that Joyce was about to send in yet another addition or correction, he threw up his hands and shouted, "Joyce, alors!" -- so often that it became for him all one name. When the Paris police booked several writers for an unruly clash between the Romantics and the Surrealists, Jolas loved the fact that the official charge was bagarre entre intellectuels. At the end of World War II, when Jolas was in Germany working for the Office of War Information, he encountered two Jewish brothers who had lost their father in Dachau; he quotes but deliberately does not translate their words to him: "Wir mochten nach Israel auswandern."
A gain and again, Jolas reveals not only his sharp eye and ready ear for a good story but also his sensitivity to human suffering and injustice. Having cheerfully rejected politics in the avant-garde carnival of literary Paris in the 20's, he, unlike many others of the time, did not lurch toward Fascism or Communism in the 30's. His experience of America had imprinted on him democratic longings and a tolerance for difference that he eventually saw to be in conflict with the idealized nationalism and racism of the German Romantic poets he had once so admired. When he returned to the frontier land of his parents to help establish a free press in postwar Germany, he faced not only the devastation of people, landscape and language but also a past poetic self that had been deaf to what the mature journalist took to be chillingly clear. "I found a definite predilection among the Romantics for the totalitarian state, for anti-Semitism and for . . . Pan-Germanic dementia."
It would be too simple to say that in Jolas's conflicted life the American journalist triumphed over the German poet, the modernist over the Romantic, the practical good-humored survivor over the melancholy dreamer. Outwardly this all seems to be true. Yet the poetry of abstract angst continued to be written. And there was a private, inner life -- marriage, children, his complex relationship to Roman Catholicism -- that is barely touched on in this action-packed memoir. Like so many modern expatriates, Jolas took on many attributes of a new world without ever letting go of the old. Finding Forbach, his ancestral home, in ruins in 1945, he wrote: "I realized that throughout my wandering life I had been in constant flight from this land of restless frontier-shifting. . . . And yet in the American world something had continued to live in me that was part of this medieval night."
