LENGTH: 1433 words

HEADLINE: The Kremlin Connection

BYLINE: By Joseph E. Persico; Joseph E. Persico, a historian, a biographer and the collaborator on Gen. Colin L. Powell's memoir, is currently writing a book on World War II espionage.

 BODY:

THE HAUNTED WOOD
Soviet Espionage in America --
the Stalin Era.
By Allen Weinstein and
Alexander Vassiliev.
Illustrated. 402 pp. New York:
Random House. $30. 
 In December 1948, the legendary broadcast journalist Edward R. Murrow went on the air to deplore the death of Laurence Duggan, a former State Department official seemingly hounded to suicide by the Communist-hunting House Un-American Activities Committee, whose members included Representative Richard M. Nixon. Murrow's outrage might have been tempered if he had possessed the information about Duggan that is revealed in "The Haunted Wood," by Allen Weinstein, the founder of the Center for Democracy in Washington and Moscow, and Aleksandr Vassiliev, a journalist and a K.G.B. alumnus.
While once-unimaginable collaborations among writers from opposing trenches in the cold war are not all that uncommon today, this work has a special power. During a two-year window of opportunity (or of lowered guard), Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service, the successor to the Soviet Union's K.G.B., allowed the authors access to thousands of secret documents from the Stalin era. Much of what they found is not new -- and yet it is.
The experience of reading "The Haunted Wood" is rather like looking into the new edition of a book from which half the pages had previously been torn out. What emerges most sharply is proof of the guilt of certain Americans whose spying for the Soviet Union has been the subject of debate for over half a century. Laurence Duggan, for example, may have been driven to suicide by the HUAC Red hunters; but one document the authors unearthed in Moscow reveals how a Soviet defector was murdered to protect the identity of Duggan, whose espionage "take" in the 1930's occasionally went directly to Stalin.
Similarly with Alger Hiss. For decades, the truth about the Hiss-Whittaker Chambers case had been obscured by its symbolism. To both liberals and conservatives, as Weinstein and Vassiliev put it, "the protagonists assumed the status of icons in the demonologies and hagiographies of their opposing camps." In an earlier work, "Perjury: The Hiss-Chambers Case" (1978), Weinstein, possessing far less evidence than is now available, traced his odyssey from believing in Hiss's innocence to accepting his guilt as a Soviet agent. Now the most die-hard Hiss apologist will find it daunting to explain away a document the authors discovered in the K.G.B. files revealing that Hiss and his ring were awarded Soviet decorations for providing military information going back to 1935.
Indeed, the book consists in great part of swatches of actual quotation from the files of the K.G.B. and its predecessors during what the authors call the "golden age" of Soviet espionage (1933-45). The files document Soviet spying by Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York, so greedy that his handlers gave him the code name "Crook." The material from the file on Martha Dodd, the daughter of the American Ambassador to Germany in the 1930's, reads better than most spy thrillers: the beautiful and reckless Dodd, known socially to President and Mrs. Roosevelt, gave her all, sleeping with Nazis or whoever could provide useful intelligence to her Soviet spymasters.
Michael Straight, a wealthy American blue blood recruited for Soviet espionage at Cambridge University along with Donald Maclean, Guy Burgess, Harold (Kim) Philby and Anthony Blunt, went directly to an unwitting Roosevelt for help in wrangling a job that would position him conveniently for Soviet spying. Serving in America's own World War II intelligence agency, the Office of Strategic Services, and close to its chief, William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan, was Duncan Lee, a descendant of Gen. Robert E. Lee, and another Soviet recruit. Lee always denied the charge, yet a K.G.B. file reveals a Soviet agent boasting of Lee's value as a source, noting that all O.S.S. intelligence "from Europe and the rest of the world . . . comes through his hands." Still another file documents the Soviets' strategy to tap Lauchlin Currie, a top Roosevelt White House aide who became a source of intelligence to Moscow.
None of the foregoing names are new to accusations of espionage. But in the past many escaped opprobrium, shielded by the notion that they were victims of anti-Communist hysteria. The Weinstein-Vassiliev discoveries in the archives of the opposition camp tear away that shield.
All the above penetrations, however, pale before the all-time Soviet espionage triumph, the piercing of America's most zealously guarded secret of the war, the development of the atomic bomb -- fittingly code-named "Enormoz" by the Soviets. The activities of Klaus Fuchs, Harry Gold, David Greenglass, the Rosenbergs and many others have long been chronicled. What is new here is the view of their manipulation from the Soviet side and evidence of even deeper penetration of the Manhattan Project than previously suspected.
The authors found in the archives of the K.G.B. a virtual hemorrhage of Allied atomic secrets. An anonymous donor left a bundle of top secrets practically on the doorstep of the Soviet Consulate in New York. A still-unidentified "Tina," a Communist working for a British firm, revealed to the Soviets the metals used to make the bomb. "Fogel," the code name for an American who was never caught or identified, delivered to his controller plans for plants and equipment employed to construct the bomb. Another document reveals Soviet paranoia, with Moscow prodding its agents in the United States to work harder because the Americans intended "to maintain a complete monopoly on 'Enormoz' and to use the atomic bomb for aggressive purposes against us."
The K.G.B. archives further detail Moscow's nearly total control and orchestration of the failed worldwide public relations campaign to save Julius and Ethel Rosenberg from the electric chair for passing atomic secrets to the Soviet Union. And the authors' probing in Moscow finally lays to rest long-bruited suspicions about the loyalty of the scientific chief of the Manhattan Project, J. Robert Oppenheimer. Files they found suggest that he was a "secret member" of the American Communist Party, and make clear that he was indeed a target of Soviet operatives -- Oppenheimer "represents a very large interest for us." Yet Weinstein and Vassiliev uncovered no shred of evidence that he ever spied for the Soviet Union.
The hardest part of these revelations to accept, at least for those of us who deplored the overzealous Red-hunting of the late 40's and early 50's, is that the hunt rested on more substance than we cared to admit, the phony posturing of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy aside. Still, one question lingers. What prompted so many privileged American intellectuals -- a Hiss, a Duggan, a Straight -- to become seemingly mesmerized servants of an authoritarian spy service? "Soviet intelligence files," the authors conclude, "document the mixture of accidental encounters, underlying ideological beliefs, romantic antifascist views and Soviet persistence." One finishes "The Haunted Wood" with a sense that the romantic antifascism, coupled with a romanticized Communism, produced a potent political narcotic. To be an economist for the Farm Security Administration might lack glamour, but to toil for the F.S.A. and also to be a spy! Now there was excitement, heightened by membership in "an elite . . . secretive club fighting for a noble ideal."
Of course, critics may charge that it is all a fraud. Could not the Russians have fabricated incriminating documents and then fed them to eager researchers? But to what end? Why would Russian intelligence operatives have concocted and buried these files until only the impossible-to-predict collapse of the Soviet Union brought them to light? Further supporting the validity of the documents is the fact that many of the messages in the K.G.B. archive were matched by the authors against outgoing messages that the Soviets radioed from the United States to Moscow during the war, transmissions intercepted and broken through an American code-cracking triumph called Venona.
It has been said that all World War II histories written before the revelation of Ultra, the British success in breaking German codes, are incomplete. The work of Weinstein, Vassiliev and their colleagues mining the Soviet lode begins to approach the significance of an Ultra. Histories of Soviet-American relations written without benefit of Soviet secret files now available are, to some degree, books with missing pages.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 18; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1151 words

HEADLINE: Science Fiction

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas 

 BODY:
Religion has always been a problem for science fiction writers. While they are occupationally biased toward rationality, their stock in trade is imagining plausible futures -- and no speculation about future societies can be complete without considering the evolution of current belief systems or the advent of entirely new religions. Yet few writers have taken this challenge seriously. When religion has not served merely as a symbol of irrational reaction, it has usually figured as window dressing -- a few hints of altered rituals or creeds to remind the reader that this is indeed "the future." Among the memorable exceptions: Walter M. Miller Jr.'s "Canticle for Leibowitz," James Blish's "Case of Conscience," Frank Herbert's "Dune" series, Gene Wolfe's multivolume "Book of the New Sun." Add to these Octavia E. Butler's PARABLE OF THE TALENTS (Seven Stories, $24.95), which continues and deepens the story she began five years ago in "Parable of the Sower."
Once again, the protagonist is Lauren Oya Olamina, a 21st-century prophet, born, she believes, to bring a new kind of truth to troubled times. Reeling from environmental, political, financial and military blows, American society is just barely surviving in the opening years of the next millennium. The revelation that Olamina feels called upon to share can be summed up in two sentences: "God is Change" and "The Destiny of Earthseed is to take root among the stars." "Earthseed" refers both to her new faith and to the small circle of believers she assembles through the force of her personality and her writings, which consist of aphoristic verses that couch revolutionary thoughts in deceptively simple words. 
 Butler's narrative skills are impressive. We follow the rise and fall of Earthseed's first communal home through a chorus of voices that jump around in time, giving us contrasting perspectives on the heartbreaking events that test the faith and will of the founding mother, her family and her adherents. Most remarkably, the ideas they espouse -- at the risk of their freedom and even their lives -- are presented with the respect they deserve. The tenets of Earthseed arise from a thought-provoking collaboration between the scientific and religious imaginations. As the founder's husband notes, "Olamina believes in a god that does not in the least love her." Conceding that Earthseed "isn't a very comforting belief system," Olamina achieves prophetic stature by insisting that in the long run the true test of a religion is whether the solace it offers conforms with the nature of the universe we live in.
Despite its provocative title, PLAYING GOD (Aspect/Warner, $22), by Sarah Zettel, disappoints, because the author fails to take her stated theme seriously enough. In two previous novels, "Reclamation" and "Fool's War," Zettel ranged across time and space with the bracing confidence of a latter-day Asimov or Heinlein. In "Playing God," she focuses on the fate of a single planet and, paradoxically, loses her way.
In a not-so-distant future, human beings have averted the destruction of the earth by splintering into competitive but mutually respectful political and economic entities called enclaves. A species of warlike aliens on a distant world has not been so lucky: after nearly destroying their ecosystem with biological and nuclear weapons, they find that their only hope for survival is a worldwide makeover proposed by Bioverse Incorporated Enclave. The project involves temporarily evacuating 1.3 billion aliens to giant orbiting spaceships, followed by "full-scale bioremediation efforts to clean the planet up after two centuries of extremely dirty warfare." As if that were not difficult enough, the aliens suffer "massive anaphylactic reactions" from close contact with humans, so attempts to keep the mutually murderous clans from killing each other on the spaceships must be supervised from afar.
The humans who devote themselves to this project must respect the alien culture while containing the aggressive tendencies inherent in it. I wish I could report that Zettel successfully dramatizes this problem. Unfortunately, she allows the situation to deteriorate into open conflict, which she then describes in prose that lacks the snap and conviction of her earlier books. Despite page after page of dutifully detailed description, I never got a clear picture of the aliens or their society. Even worse, I did not much care what happened to the humans whose efforts to "play god" give way, in the end, to all-too-predictable melodrama.
If you are unfamiliar with the work of Paul J. McAuley, his new collection of stories, THE INVISIBLE COUNTRY (Eos/Avon, paper, $13.50), provides a useful introduction to this engaging writer. The title story, set in a grim near-future London, is told in a noirish style that might be characterized as "bio-punk." A former professional biologist, McAuley conjures a world ravaged by global warming and a breakdown in social order exacerbated by the easy availability of intrusive biotechnology. In a convincing demonstration of his stylistic sleight of hand, he transmutes this nightmarish vision into a dream of utopia right under the reader's nose, so to speak.
Four of the nine stories in this collection evoke a future (also encountered in McAuley's novel "Fairyland") in which "dolls," gene-engineered humanoid creatures, serve as all-purpose slaves. By coming at this painful subject from the point of view of society's human outcasts, McAuley avoids the twin traps of facile moralizing and maudlin sentiment. Another story, "Recording Angel," shares setting and theme with McAuley's recent novel "Child of the River" and casts some light on the confusing background of that work, the first in a promised trilogy.
When I was 10 years old, I read a book entitled "Tom Swift and His Electric Elephant Gun." I can still remember the thrill generated by the technological wonder of a superweapon that allowed Tom to subdue a ponderous pachyderm without actually killing it. A similar sense of wonder animates the recent crop of computer-driven techno-thrillers, of which THE TERMINATION NODE (Del Rey/Ballantine, $24), by Lois H. Gresh and Robert Weinberg, is a suitably breathless example.
An evil mastermind is killing off computer hackers faster than you can say "delete." Only the skills of a superhacker, Judy Carmody, known to her on-line friends as "TerMight," can save the day -- not to mention the billions of dollars of electronic bank deposits about to vanish forever at the click of a mouse.
I would not venture a guess about whether this Internet-savvy collaboration will stir feelings of wonder in today's young readers. I can only report that the book's series of brutal murders raised not so much as a hair on the back of my neck, since the authors failed to breathe life into these victims before they were dispatched.

HEADLINE: Shaw in New York

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Garrison Keillor's review of "Writing New York" (Dec. 13), my colleague Phillip Lopate's omnium-gatherum of the reaction of writers -- both American and others, like the Englishman Stephen Graham -- to the city of New York, omits one extraordinary assessment by a British visitor of Irish extraction through the eyes of an equally eminent American on the literary scene. The stage is set by Edmund Wilson, who writes of the historic visit of George Bernard Shaw to New York in the depths of the Depression. Wilson's essay in The New Republic of April 26, 1933, recounts Shaw's address to a crowd of 3,500 at the old Metropolitan Opera House on April 11. Wilson describes in detail how "the straight black figure diminishes: It stands at the bottom of a gulf -- the immense well of the Metropolitan with its ugly and stale magnificence: the heavy tarnished gold of the proscenium arch, the gilt boxes lined with red plush and embellished with electric bulbs. . . . Tier upon tier of boxes drop down; balcony upon balcony. The tall slim figure behind the pulpit is all but drowned at the bottom." 
 But Shaw had another take on the splendor of the Met and the opulence of the crowd. Speaking, as he usually did, from his Socialist point of view, he finally came out with this conviction: "The splendor of this building had blinded me to the fact that the majority of my audience apparently belong to the unemployed." His remarks were greeted with a burst of applause from the highest balcony. He could not have known, Wilson concludes, that it was not the majority of the audience but a handful of radicals in the gallery, where the seats were only a dollar, who broke into spontaneous applause at his utterance.
 
Rhoda Nathan
New York

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Miami

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO; MIREYA NAVARRO is Miami bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
Miami, which is registering ever-increasing numbers of visitors, is undergoing a building boom that sometimes makes the area look like a giant construction site. Visitors will find new and renovated terminals at Miami International Airport and the Port of Miami, numerous restored hotels and other expansions.
In downtown Miami, a new arena for the Miami Heat pro basketball team is going up and expected to be completed by early 2000, by which time the National Basketball Association labor impasse may be over. After a renaissance of restored Art Deco hotels, Miami Beach last month welcomed the 800-room Loews Miami Beach Hotel. Not far away, the first convention hotel with African-American majority ownership, the 422-room Royal Palm Crowne Plaza Resort, is expected to be complete by January 2000. 
 These hotels could help Miami-Dade County capture some of the convention business that now goes to cities like Orlando. Others, including the Fontainebleau Hilton Resort and Towers, are undergoing multimillion-dollar face lifts.
A free shuttle service, the Electrowave, now operates along Washington Avenue in Miami Beach's South Beach section late into the night to transport revelers among hotels, restaurants and bars.
Visitors will also find a new annoyance throughout Miami: having to dial the 305 area code for local calls. To add to the confusion, the caller will not reach the intended party if a 1 is dialed first.
The big event this month, of course, is the return of the Super Bowl to Pro Player Stadium. The last Super Bowl held here, in 1995, brought 142,000 visitors (even though the stadium seats only 75,000 for the game) and more than $176 million, an economic bonanza that officials expect to be repeated or exceeded this year.
 
Events
Super Bowl XXXIII will kick off at Pro Player Stadium, 2269 Northwest 199th Street, on Jan. 31 at about 6:20 P.M. Tickets are sold out. (Some are allocated to National Football League teams, which distribute them, by lottery for example, to season ticket holders.) But plenty of activities surround the event. From Jan. 22 to 24, the west side parking area at Pro Player Stadium turns into an interactive theme park, with games, card shows and displays and National Football League stars. Tickets, $15 for adults and $10 for children under 12, are available through Ticketmaster, (305) 358-5885.
From Jan. 29 to 31, there will be free concerts, football memorabilia displays and interactive games that test football skills at Bayfront Park in downtown Miami from 11 A.M. until midnight. Information: Bayfront Park, (305) 358-7550. And also between Jan. 29 to 31 in Miami Beach, N.F.L. stars will mingle with fans at an N.F.L. Players Party on Ocean Drive between 20th and 22d Streets. Tickets are $12; a three-day pass is $25. For tickets: Ticketmaster, (305) 358-5885.
Visitors can step back to 15th-century Italy at an Italian Renaissance Festival from March 18 to 21, which will bring entertainment, an international food court and more than 200 costumed characters to the Vizcaya Museum and Gardens, 3251 South Miami Avenue in Miami; (305) 250-9133, extension 3. Hours are 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $12, $6 ages 6 to 12. There is an extra charge of $3, $1 for children, to visit the sprawling mansion at the edge of Biscayne Bay, fashioned after the villas of the Veneto, and it is worth it.
Cowboys from around the country will converge at the 50th annual Homestead Championship Rodeo Feb. 5 to 7 at the Doc Demilly Rodeo Arena at Harris Field at the intersection of Highway 1 and Southwest 312th Street in Homestead. Seven championship events, including bull riding and steer wrestling, will be featured, and a parade is scheduled for Feb. 6 at 11 A.M. along Krome Avenue in Homestead. Tickets are $10 to $12, and $4 and $5 for children. Information: (305) 247-3515; on the Internet: www.homesteadrodeo .com.
Art Deco Weekend, Jan. 15 to 18 along Ocean Drive between 5th and 15th Streets in Miami Beach, (305) 672-2014, is an annual celebration of artifacts and antiques along the oceanfront strip of restaurants and bars in the Art Deco district. The event, for which the theme this year is Art Deco and Sports, features big band music and a children's play area between 10th and 12th Streets in Lummus Park. It runs from noon to 11 P.M. Jan. 15; 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. Jan. 16 and 17, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Jan. 18. The lecture schedule includes "Worldwide Origins of Art Deco" on Jan. 16 at noon and Art Deco architecture in Miami Beach on Jan. 17 at 1 P.M., both in the Ocean Front Auditorium. Admission is free. There will also be an Art Deco film festival Jan. 11 to 18.
The Nationsbank Coconut Grove Arts Festival Feb. 13 to 15 at South Bayshore Drive and McFarlane Road in Miami, (305) 447-0401, annually attracts more than 300 fine arts and crafts vendors, and you can browse amid a wide selection of food and music. Free admission.
From March 5 to 14, Miami celebrates its Hispanic heritage with a carnival that culminates with a 23-blocklong party known as the Calle Ocho Festival on March 14. Salsa bands spread out along Southwest 8th Street between 4th and 27th Avenues in Miami's Little Havana. Other events will include an eight-kilo meter run on March 5; a street festival in Coral Gables on March 7; a cooking contest on March 9, and a golf tournament on March 11 at the Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables. Information: (305) 644-8888.
 
Sightseeing
The Miami Seaquarium at 4400 Rickenbacker Causeway, the bridge that leads to Key Biscayne, last year added an exploration program that allows visitors (children must be at least 52 inches tall) to touch, kiss and swim with dolphins for $125. The price includes a towel and snacks as well as admission to the aquatic park's marine-life exhibits and shows, which otherwise costs $22.32, $16.99 for children 3 to 9. (Under 3 is free.) Reservations, at (305) 365-2501, are required for the dolphin exploration program, which is offered twice a day Wednesday through Sunday. The park is open daily 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: (305) 361-5705.
After swimming with the animals, you can talk with them at Parrot Jungle and Gardens at 11000 Southwest 57th Avenue in Miami, (305) 666-7834. The collection of exotic birds, monkeys and other animals is spread out in a setting of tropical trees and flowers, and there are shows with trained birds. Admission is $14.86, $9.53 ages 3 to 10. Open daily from 9:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.
A 15-mile tour through Everglades National Park's Shark Valley, about 40 miles west of downtown Miami on Highway 41, offers a glimpse of the expanse of marshlands and wildlife, including alligators and wading birds, in the Everglades. (The area sits in a slough whose waters feed the Shark River farther south.) Admission is $8 a car. Two-hour tram tours, from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. every hour on the hour, cost $9.30. Reservations, (305) 221-8455, are recommended for the tram tours through April. Bike rentals, from 8:30 A.M. to 3 P.M., are $3.85 an hour. Shark Valley itself is open 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.
 
Where to Stay
The Leslie Hotel, 1244 Ocean Drive in Miami Beach, (800) 688-7678, fax (305) 672-5611, has 43 rooms decorated in yellow, purple and orange. The festive atmosphere matches the oceanfront strip of restaurants, bars and hotels where it is situated. It is one of Chris Blackwell's group of Island Outpost hotels in the Art Deco district. Doubles, $125 to $195.
A block away, the 28-room La Flora Hotel at 1238 Collins Avenue, (877) 523-5672, fax (305) 538-0850, is a new addition to the intimate boutique hotels in the Art Deco district. Rooms are decorated with soft tones and Art Deco style furniture. The lobby has the original terrazzo floor. Doubles start at $179 with Continental breakfast. The hotel also has a business center in a 12-seat conference room.
Budget: The 247-room Hotel Riande Continental, 146 Biscayne Boulevard, (800) 742-6331, fax (305) 532-7689, is in the heart of downtown Miami's shopping district and across from Bayside Marketplace, the shopping and entertainment mall by Biscayne Bay. Most rooms have two double beds; all have small refrigerators. Doubles are $105.
Luxury: Ian Schrager's Delano, 1685 Collins Avenue, (800) 555-5001, fax (305) 674-6499, this year added a beach "village" with tents that offer massages and spa treatments, fitness classes and food and drink to sunbathers. The oceanfront hotel has all-white decor and geometric furniture. Doubles, $300 to $400.
The Hotel, 801 Collins Avenue in Miami Beach, (305) 531-2222, fax (305) 531-3222, an Art Deco building with three stories and 52 rooms in the heart of South Beach, has had an exquisite restoration by the fashion designer Todd Oldham. Green, blue and gold predominate in guest rooms, which have custom-designed furniture. Doubles from $185.
 
Where to Eat
In many restaurants, particularly in Miami Beach, a tip (generally 15 percent) is included in the bill.
On Lincoln Road, a pedestrian boulevard of cafes, shops, street musicians and galleries, Balans, 1022 Lincoln Road, (305) 534-9191, is a neighborhood hangout with reliable food at reasonable prices. Main courses include an excellent herb-crusted Chilean sea bass ($14.95) and tuna teriyaki ($14.95). The menu also has salads and sandwiches. A three-course dinner for two with wine costs about $65. Open 8 A.M. to midnight Sunday through Thursday, until 1 A.M. on Friday and Saturday.
Not far away is Norma's on the Beach, at 646 Lincoln Road, (305) 532-2809, which serves Caribbean-inspired dishes such as jerk chicken penne pasta ($14.95) and grilled Bahamian black grouper marinated in teriyaki and garlic ($22.95). Dinner for two with wine, about $70. Dinner Tuesday through Sunday, lunch Friday through Sunday.
For Cuban fare and the latest in exile-politics gossip, there is Versailles Restaurant, 3555 Southwest Eighth Street in Little Havana; (305) 444-0240. Combination plates include El Clasico, a heap of roasted pork, ground beef stew, sweet plantains, white rice and black beans, ham croquettes, yucca and tamal pie for $10.95. A meal for two with wine costs less than $45. Open 8 A.M. to 2 A.M. Monday through Thursday, until 3:30 on Friday and 4:30 on Saturday, 9 A.M. to 2 A.M. on Sunday.
Red Fish Grill in Matheson Hammock Park at 9610 Old Cutler Road in Coral Gables, (305) 668-8788, is out of the way but worth the trip for its setting at the edge of Biscayne Bay. You can sit outside, under palm trees and stars. Entrees include sauteed snapper with red wine grape sauce, shallot mashed potatoes and vegetables ($18.50). Reservations are suggested. Dinner for two with a modest wine runs about $80. Dinner only; closed Mondays.
A tropical courtyard is the setting for Wish at The Hotel at 801 Collins Avenue in Miami Beach, (305) 674-9474. The menu emphasizes the vegetarian, with entrees such as grilled portobellos with whipped sweet potatoes ($15.50) and artichoke risotto with aged asiago and summer truffles ($16.50), but the restaurant is adding meat and fish entrees as well. The executive chef is Gary Robins, formerly of Match Uptown and Aja in New York. A meal for two with wine comes to about $80.

PUB-DATE: January 3, 1999

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2296 words

HEADLINE: Don't Drive Without 'Roo Bars'

BYLINE: By TODD WOODY; TODD WOODY reports on the economics of the Internet for The Industry Standard.

 BODY:
WE first heard about Ningaloo on a balmy November evening after a day of swimming with bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, off Western Australia's outback coast, north of Perth.
Chatting with a local marine biologist as the sun disappeared into the Indian Ocean, my wife, Sarah, and I mentioned that we would be heading back to Perth the next morning. No, the biologist urged, don't leave without visiting Ningaloo Marine Park, a vast coral reef off the Northwest Cape, also known as the Cape Range Peninsula, some 300 miles to the north. The snorkeling, diving and marine life, he said, rivals that of the Great Barrier Reef, and the onshore Cape Range National Park is a wildlife wonderland, where kangaroos forage on white-sand beaches and the rare black-footed rock wallaby lives in granite outcrops. 
 Intrigued, we studied our well-worn map. After driving 1,000 miles from Albany, on the south coast, what was a few hundred more? We were on the second leg of a trek around Sarah's native land and we had grown to love the red, red earth and blue skies of Western Australia's northwest coast, where our distance from civilization could be measured in the rising price of gasoline and water.
The state of Western Australia is more than a quarter the size of the United States but has just 1.4 million residents, 90 percent of them in or near Perth, the capital. "This, mate, is the real Australia." my father-in-law is fond of telling me.
It didn't take long for us to reach a decision: we extended our rental car agreement and hit the road for Exmouth, the cape's main outpost and the gateway to Ningaloo. Exmouth sprang into existence in 1967 to serve an Australian-American naval communications base, the Harold E. Holt Naval Communication Station. Thanks to the cold war and the peninsula's isolated locale, the cape remained more or less undiscovered for decades. Most guidebooks devote only a line or two to Ningaloo and many Australians -- even in Western Australia -- confess that they have never heard of the place. When the base's operations were cut way back in the early 1990's, local residents turned to eco-tourism to keep Exmouth from becoming a ghost town.
The ghosts seemed to be winning as we rolled into the town of 2,400 on a blazing and breezy morning and turned into the Potshot Hotel Resort's nearly empty parking lot. (In Australia, just about every vacation accommodation, from backpacker camps to five-star hotels, calls itself a resort.)
Exmouth, on the windswept northeastern edge of the cape, was built for utility, not charm, and lodgings there tend to run toward the prosaic -- a place to rest one's head and refuel between adventures at the Ningaloo and Cape Range parks. After the rather surreal experience a few weeks earlier of taking in the ancient spirituality of Uluru (Ayers Rock) in the company of hundreds of foreign tourists bussed in from a nearby upscale resort, the simplicity of Exmouth was a relief.
Our comfortable two-bedroom apartment at the Potshot included a kitchen and patio with a barbecue. There were two big leather chairs and a dining room table in the living room. The bathroom had a shower and a utility sink for washing clothes and rinsing off snorkeling gear. The complex also has a pool, a hot tub and a restaurant.
We usually ate our meals at the apartment since most restaurants in Exmouth offer basic Aussie fish-and-chips fare. But food wasn't the point; there aren't many places in the world where you can go out to lunch and watch an emu -- a large, ostrichlike bird -- amble down the street.
We dropped off our belongings at the Potshot and drove to the tourist bureau a few blocks away. We had three things we wanted to do during our three-day stay: snorkel, see the endangered black-footed rock wallaby and watch the giant sea turtles lay their eggs. The tourist bureau representative, a young woman named Michelle, quickly arranged these activities while giving us the inside scoop on eco-tours.
Directing us toward a diving store, she bade us farewell with a piece of advice: don't drive at night. We would soon find out why.
We picked up snorkeling gear and a map of the best snorkeling areas at the Coral Coast Dive shop on the Harold E. Holt naval base. The facility, on the outskirts of town, is named for the Australian Prime Minister who mysteriously disappeared in 1967 while swimming in the ocean off Melbourne. With the cold war's end, parts of the base have been leased to businesses and some of the barracks now house backpackers.
Mornings are best for snorkeling -- the late afternoon winds make the ocean choppy -- and the next day we set off to explore Ningaloo Marine Park. We drove around the tip of the peninsula -- passing the huge transmitter towers built for the military that rise incongruously as much as 1,200 feet over the shore -- and into the 125,000-acre Cape Range National Park, about 15 miles to the south.
It is a stark and stunning landscape. The red earth and gray-green bush of the cape sweep into pearl-white sand dunes overlooking the aquamarine waters of the Indian Ocean. Emus grazed among the grasses, and red and gray kangaroos bounded across the range. As we walked on to Lakeside beach, a light gray kangaroo called a euro watched us from atop a sand dune, its ears swiveling like radar dishes.
The abundance of wildlife was the reason for Michelle's warning against night driving. Kangaroos are mainly nocturnal and a collision with one can be fatal. Hence, even a family station wagon looks like something out of a Mad Max movie, equipped with thick steel "roo bars" and high-intensity spotlights. We, on the other hand, were driving a tinny Ford Festiva, no match for a six-foot-tall great red kangaroo. Getting home by sunset seemed a good idea.
But those thoughts were far from our minds as we donned our snorkeling gear on an empty beach. We could see the main part of the reef, which runs 161 miles along the west coast of the cape, about 500 feet offshore. (In contrast, reaching the Great Barrier Reef can involve a 20-to-50-mile boat ride.)
After wading into the warm water, we only had to swim a few yards before we found ourselves hovering over magnificent coral gardens and "bombies" -- collections of coral encrusted rocks sheltering an incandescent array of blue, green and orange fish. Sea turtles glided by and manta rays skimmed the ocean floor.
Poking our heads out of the water, we noted that we were utterly alone. We found the same seclusion at other snorkeling spots along the peninsula.
Divers and snorkelers who venture out to Ningaloo's main reef may be rewarded with sightings of dolphins as well as dugongs -- marine mammals that are cousins of the South Florida manatee. Between March and May the star attraction is the giant whale shark, a gentle, plankton-eating fish that can grow to more than 50 feet.
At midday we returned to the Potshot to rest up for our turtle-watching expedition that evening. Between September and April the giant sea turtles come ashore to dig their nests and lay hundreds of eggs. At twilight, Les Player, the owner of Exmouth Eco Tours, and his 8-year-old son, Matthew, pulled up in a Toyota Land Cruiser, luxury transportation after our jolting journeys in the Ford Festiva. We picked up a British tourist at the naval base hostel, then drove toward Cape Range National Park. Les turned onto an unmarked dirt track and headed toward the beach. Turtle watching is a competitive business and guides fiercely guard the locations of their best viewing spots. Les told us to make ourselves comfortable behind a dune. Nesting turtles emerge from the ocean after dark and sometimes don't make an appearance until the wee hours of the morning.
WE waited in the inky blackness as shooting stars crossed the sky and the surf crashed. While Matthew pointed out the constellations, his father scouted for turtles. We were in luck. A green sea turtle had lumbered ashore and was making her way to the dunes.
Sea turtles are a protected species and it's illegal in Australia, as in many other countries, to interfere with their nesting. So, Les escorted us one at a time, crawling on hands and knees, closer to the turtle. He used an infrared flashlight that wouldn't disturb her as she dug.
Les explained that the 200-pound turtle was at least 40 to 50 years old -- the age when females begin reproducing. The turtle methodically dug a hole in the sand with her flippers. We returned to our hiding spot and waited. It can take a turtle two hours to dig a nest and begin laying eggs.
But after an hour and a half of labor, the turtle realized that the sand was too dry to keep the nest intact and abandoned the effort, trying again in a new spot. That nest collapsed, too. We crept closer and watched the apparently exhausted turtle shuffle down the beach and slip into the ocean.
We weren't the only ones watching turtles that night. As we walked back to the Land Cruiser, Les pointed out the glowing green eyes of a red fox that had been waiting to dig up the nest and snatch the eggs. Foxes, introduced by British colonists in the 19th century, have devastated much of Australia's native wildlife.
After a break for coffee, tea and homemade cookies -- "bickies," in local parlance -- we drove to another beach to watch turtles. On the road back to Exmouth after midnight, we ran a gantlet of grazing kangaroos -- dozens of them -- as they jumped in front of the car, confused by the headlights, forcing Les to take evasive action.
The next day we set out for Yardie Creek, 50 miles from Exmouth on the southern end of the cape. We were in search of the black-footed rock wallaby. As the paved road gave out and we began a bone-jarring ride along a rutted track, we longed for Les's Land Cruiser (guidebooks wisely urge using four-wheel-drive vehicles on the road). But our snail's pace gave us a close-up view of goannas -- large, fierce-looking lizards -- and scores of normally skittish kangaroos escaping the midday heat under roadside bushes.
At Yardie Creek we boarded a a 30-passenger motorboat. As we and half a dozen other sightseers cruised through a gorge enclosed on three sides by rugged walls of red rock, the captain, Neil (Macca) McGregor, pointed to a ledge high above the creek. Peering down at us was a rock wallaby and a joey, the baby peeking out of its mom's pouch.
A mini-kangaroo, the delicate charcoal-gray wallaby spends its days in the crevices and outcrops of Yardie Creek, emerging occasionally to feed in the bush above. But the proliferation of foxes has devastated it, and only a few scattered groups survive.
As we rounded a bend, Macca, who assists biologists by keeping count of the rock wallabies at Yardie Creek, spotted the body of one keeled over in the shallows. We went ashore and checked to see if there were any signs of predation. But it appeared that the wallaby had fallen into the creek and drowned.
Driving back to Exmouth, we saw Macca's four-wheel-drive parked on the side of the road. He was a few yards in the bush, peering intently into a small pool of water that seeped out of a rock basin. A finger-sized white fish, a blind gudgeon, wriggled around in the water. The fish had no eyes, Macca explained, and is found only at Cape Range.
The conversation took a philosophical turn. He talked about the growing pressure in Exmouth to build big resorts. He confided his fears that small eco-tourism operations like his would be overrun and the fragile environment of Ningaloo and Cape Range ruined.
We shared his concerns. And as dusk began to fall and the kangaroos emerged for their suppers, we decided to postpone the next part of our journey and spend some more time in this rugged paradise.
 
Along the Outback Coast
 
Getting There
United, (800) 241-6522, Qantas, (800) 227-4500, and Air New Zealand, (310) 615-1111, fly to Perth via Sydney and Melbourne. From Perth, Ansett Australia Airlines, makes the 750-mile trip to Learmonth Airport, just south of Exmouth, daily. Round-trip fares begin at $282. For reservations, call (61-8) 131-300.
 
Where to Stay
Potshot Hotel Resort Murat Road, Exmouth, Western Australia 6707, has 24 two-bedroom apartments with kitchens (about $84), 7 three-bedroom apartments ($102) 39 studios ($61) and 22 backpacker rooms ($47). It has a pool, hot tub and two restaurants; (61-8) 9949-1200, fax (61-8) 9949-1486.
Ningaloo Lighthouse Resot, also called the Lighthouse Caravan Park, Yardie Creek Road, north of Exmouth, is next to a lighthouse overlooking Ningaloo Marine Park. It has a pool, a tennis court, a dive shop and air-conditioning throughout. There are 14 two-bedroom chalets 11 with kitchens, ($37 to $74), and 9 one-bedroom units ($31); (61-8) 9949-1478.
Exmouth Base Lodge, at the Holt Naval Communications Station, offers 39 air-conditioned backpacker rooms for about $9 a person, a pool and two tennis courts; toll free in Western Australia (800) 241-474, or (61-8) 9949-1474, fax (61-8) 9949-1440.
 
Where to Eat
Three Palms Lunch Bar, Thew Street, Exmouth, (61-8) 9949-1391, offers no-frills dining in town. A shrimp sandwich costs $5. Quiche and sausage rolls are also available.
 
Seeing the Animals
Exmouth Eco Tours, (61-8) 9949-2809, offers one-day four-wheel-drive safari tours of Cape Range National Park for $60, and night turtle-watching expeditions for $19.
Yardie Creek Tours Post Office Box 687, Exmouth 6707, offers a guided boat ride through Yardie Creek to see the black-footed rock wallaby and other wildlife, for $20; phone and fax (61-8) 9949-2659.
The Exmouth Tourist Bureau, Maidstone Crescent, Exmouth 6707, books tours and provides area information; (61-8) 9949-1176, fax (61-8) 9949-1441.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO

 BODY:

APRIL ON A BARGE -- French Country Waterways has cut prices by $500 a couple on April barge cruises in Champagne, the upper Loire and Burgundy. Rates, incorporating the discount, are $2,645 to $3,745 a person, double occupancy, on departures from April 4 to 25. The five barges on those routes take 8 to 18 passengers. Rates cover accommodations, meals, wines at lunch and dinner, open bar, tours and excursions and transfers between Paris and the barges. Reservations: (800) 222-1236, (781) 934-2454 in Massachusetts. 

TWO FOR BRUSSELS -- Sabena Belgian World Airlines has expanded its Valentine's Package offer to eight weekends from Jan. 21 through March 11. The price of $750 a couple includes round-trip economy air transportation for two from any of six Sabena gateways in the United States (including New York and Newark), two nights at the Brussels Hilton with buffet breakfast, airport departure taxes and fees. Departures are on Thursday with returns on the following Sunday. Though the packages have sold quickly in the past, a substantial number were available in late December. The package is nonrefundable, and limited to four seats per call. Reservations: (800) 955-2000 from 8 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. on weekdays and 9 to 5:30 on Saturday and Sunday.
 
BERMUDA IN WINTER -- Three-night getaways to Bermuda from now into March are available starting at $389 a person, double occupancy. That price is for a Gogo Worldwide Vacations package from Hartford, including round-trip midweek air fare, accommodations at Grotto Bay Beach Hotel and round-trip airport transfers. A similar package from New York starts at $469; departures are through March 15. US Airways Vacations has a two-night package starting at $394 a person, double occupancy, for departures Sunday through Wednesday from La Guardia Airport through March 28. TNT Vacations' three-night package starts at $399 a person from Hartford, $444 from either La Guardia or Newark. Some taxes are additional. For Gogo Worldwide Vacations, contact a Liberty Travel agency or call (800) 764-1000. US Airways Vacations can be booked through a travel agent or by calling (800) 455-0123. For TNT Vacations, contact a travel agent.
 
MYSTERY PACKAGE -- In connection with the exhibition "Empires of Mystery: The Incas, the Andes and Lost Civilizations," through April 25 at the Florida International Museum in St. Petersburg, the Don Cesar Beach Resort and Spa has a Masterpieces of Mystery package for $214 a night on Sunday through Thursday that includes a condominium-style suite, breakfast or lunch for two, and admission for two to the exhibit, as well as tax and tip. The package costs $234 a night in the main resort. Weekend prices are $269 and $289 respectively. Reservations: (800) 282-1116. JANET PIORKO

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Packing Relief For Health Woes

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
MEDICAL preparations for trips to exotic places must include a visit to a doctor or travel clinic for inoculations and advice. But even trips to more conventional places like a spa in California or your cousin's cabin in Colorado should involve gathering items for first aid or other health problems that might arise.
For many, this counsel is redundant. Some of my best friends are hypochondriacs, and I do travel with them. I scoff when they climb aboard with Merck Manuals bulging in their pockets, carrying a first-aid kit that's the size of a carpenter's toolbox. 
 But while they may be hypochondriacs, I am absolutely a hypocrite. If anything goes wrong, that kit is the first thing we rip open: for sealed sterile pads to wipe wounds, small bandages for blisters, something for diarrhea, elastic bandages, instant cold packs and a variety of other items not always easily found, particularly in the back country.
If you are the one forced to carry it, the medical kit should contain the essentials and little more. Liquids weigh a lot, so one-shot containers of antiseptics are just fine. Be sure you have enough rinse for contact lenses. Factory-sealed containers raise fewer questions at customs frontiers than repacked pills or ointments. If a group is going to be together the whole time, a collective kit is a luggage economy. But be sure you have your own extra pair of eyeglasses.
 
Extra Prescription Copies
The most important parts of the medical kit for anyone with a chronic condition, and that means many people over 60, are hospital records and extra copies of all prescriptions, written not for trademark names but for generic names, and thus useful in pharmacies everywhere.
Dr. Martin S. Wolfe counsels the State Department on its employees' travel needs as well as directing a travel clinic in Washington. He says the first priority is gathering information to guide a doctor who may have to treat you for the first time: X-rays or electrocardiograms, for example. Part of this information-gathering is an examination of health insurance policies and medical evacuation coverage, he says. A record should be made of all essential numbers, with telephone and fax for your primary-care doctor or organization. All this should be in carry-on bags.
The new edition of "Health Hints for the Tropics," edited by Dr. Wolfe and published by the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, contains a practical list for a medical kit. Although intended for tropical travel, the list can be amended for all sorts of trips. (Ordering information for the book is given below.)
The list is particularly helpful in providing generic names for products as well as trade names, which may be virtually all anyone remembers: for example, dimenhydrinate (Dramamine). These over-the-counter items may be hard to find under United States trade names.
Among the nonprescription items listed in the booklet are first-aid materials, Ace bandages, tincture of benzoin, dental floss and traveler's dental kit, extra glasses or contact lenses, hearing-aid batteries, thermometer, pocketknife, itch or sunburn medicine, Burow's solution (for skin inflammation), sunscreen, insect repellant, a mosquito net with the repellant permethrin, a water purification device, oral rehydration salts for use in diarrhea, foot powder, analgesics, antiseptics, laxatives, antidiarrheals, motion-sickness medicine, throat lozenges, antihistamines, antacids, infant feeding materials, birth-control devices, multi-vitamins and a Sawyer extractor pump for snake and insect bites.
The tropical-medicine group's list does not include two items I consider useful. One is an instant cold pack. These light 5-by-4 1/2-inch plastic packs of ammonium nitrate and water become ice-cold when pounded or massaged. Activated, they are so cold they are not supposed to be applied longer than 20 minutes because of the danger of frostbite. Once activated, the packs cannot be used again safely. They can be bought in pharmacies or from sports specialty shops.
As Disposable Cold Packs, they are available from Chinook Medical Gear, Post Office Box 1736, Edwards, Colo. 81632, (800) 766-1365, which sells three for $3.95 or 10 for $11.95, plus postage. This company has a catalogue of kits and individual items. On the Web, the address is www.chinookmed.com.
My other choice qualifies as first aid the same way that parents of young children define "emergency" when they pull up the car in areas marked "emergency parking only." This item is called Brief Relief. It is a zip-shut plastic pouch, with interior funnel, that contains a material that congeals urine to an odorless gel. For obvious reasons, they are favored by winter tent-campers. These are sold in the latest Magellan's catalogue in a four pack for $9.85, plus shipping. Magellan's, 110 West Sola Street, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93101; (800) 962-4943.
In addition to the $5 "Health Hints" booklet, which has 54 pages packed with information, the Society of Tropical Medicine has just issued the 1998 edition of its directory of specialists in tropical medicine, parasites and travelers' health. People preparing for travel who want a reference to a specialist pre- or post-travel can find one here; the names of practitioners and clinics are cross-referenced by state and town.
This book is free to those who send a 9-by-12 envelope with $1.70 postage (for United States addresses). For the booklet and the directory, send a check for $6.70 and the unstamped envelope to: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, 60 Revere Drive, Suite 500, Northbrook, Ill. 60062; www.astmh.org on the Web.
 
Hard-to-Find Books
Right now two reliable, inexpensive publications for travelers are scarce or out of print, so the tropical-medicine booklets may be the best game in town. The Federal Centers for Disease Control's "Health Information for International Travel," in its most recent edition, 1996-97, is in modest supply at the Government Printing Office. The new edition is due sometime in May, in a new format. The old one costs $20 from the Superintendent of Documents, Washington, D.C. 20402, where it is publication 017-023-00197-3. It can also be found at www.cdc.gov. The nonprofit International Society of Travel Medicine's Clinic Directory is now out of print, and the organization is seeking sponsorship for a new edition.
The Shell Oil Company, as part of an auto-safety campaign, has urged that all cars contain a first-aid kit with the following: bandages, adhesive tape, scissors, blankets, latex gloves, a mouth guard (for artificial respiration), flashlights, flares and reflectors, plus change for a pay telephone.
Shell has also published a series of booklets: "Crash Course, Simple Tips That Could Help Save Lives," "Driving Dangers" and "Kids in the Car." The simple tips are worth keeping in the car. Among other things, they give a quick explanation of artificial respiration steps for those who have not taken an E.M.S. course. These booklets are available free at Shell stations, by calling (800) 376-0200 or, on the Web, through www.countonshell.com.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By PAUL FREIREICH 

 BODY:

Literary Paris
 Q. I will be going to Paris and would appreciate information on the location of the salon that Natalie Clifford Barney had there earlier in this century. Is the salon or studio a place that can be visited? -- Maria E. Hopewell, Dallas
 A. It was at 20 Rue Jacob, in the sixth arrondissement, that Barney, an American expatriate and writer, conducted a salon every Friday, attracting a galaxy of literary and intellectual lights. Among them were Djuna Barnes, Sylvia Beach, Colette, Hilda Doolittle, Janet Flanner, Andre Gide, Gertrude Stein and William Carlos Williams. 
 The salon met for more than 50 years (except during the two world wars) until about the early 1960's, according to Karla Jay, director of Women's and Gender Studies at Pace University in New York. The Rue Jacob building, near the Place Furstenburg, is landmarked but not open to the public. In the garden there's a small temple, with Doric columns, that bears the inscription "A l'Amitie" ("To Friendship").
Born to an Ohio family of great wealth, Barney moved to Paris as a student and pursued her interest in French culture, writing primarily in French. She died in 1972 and is buried in the ninth division of the Passy cemetery. Also buried at Passy is Renee Vivien, an expatriate poet from Britain who was among Barney's loves. Another was Romaine Brooks, whose paintings include some of Barney.
The sixth arrondissement is rich in literary connections. If you set out on your own, you will find the maps and descriptions in Noel Riley Fitch's "Walks in Hemingway's Paris" valuable. (It was reissued by St. Martin's Press in 1997 and is $10.95.) If you prefer a guided tour, one possibility is Bohemian Paris, run by Siren's Song Tours, 5 Rue du Parc, 93389 Pierrefitte-sur-Seine, France; (33-1) 48.26.62.15, fax (33-1) 48.21.41.69. Web site: www.onecity .com/paris.
The tours, conducted by Gentry Lane, are available daily by appointment. They take about two and a half hours, cover a mile and a half on the Left Bank and are limited to six people. On the itinerary are cafes frequented by Hemingway and Modigliani, the residences of Modigliani, the composer George Antheil and James Joyce and the studios of Man Ray, Picasso and Brassai. Cost: $36 each, at 5.5 francs to the dollar.
By way of background, you may want to read Shari Benstock's "Women of the Left Bank: Paris, 1900-1940" (University of Texas Press) and Ms. Jay's book "The Amazon and the Page: Natalie Clifford Barney and Renee Vivien" (Indiana University Press). A site on the Internet devoted to Barney and her era -- run by Paula L. DiTallo, who describes herself as an Atlanta software engineer with a love for literature -- is home.sprynet.com/ sprynet/ditallop/natalieb.htm.
 
Rugby World Cup
 Q. We would like to attend the Rugby World Cup this year. How can we get tickets, especially to the championship matches, and do you have suggestions for lodging? Is there hooliganism as there is at soccer matches? -- Andrew J. Schiavoni, Bronx, N.Y.
 A. Competing in the Rugby World Cup, scheduled to be played in Britain and France from Oct. 1 to Nov. 6, are 20 teams divided into five groups. The official source for tour packages is Gullivers Sports Travel, which takes the minimalist approach: Fans handle their own air travel.
The closer the date of the final games, the more nights of accommodation one must buy. So fans who want to follow the initial progress of a single team, or what is called "follow the flag," get two nights' lodging in the Dublin area. The cost, $695 to $895, is based on double occupancy and includes two breakfasts; a seat at the opening game and ceremonies on Oct. 1 at the new 72,500-seat Millennium Stadium in Cardiff, and seats at three games played by a single team.
A package that offers a ticket to the quarterfinal in Paris or Edinburgh is $699 to $799. It includes three nights at a three-star hotel and three breakfasts.
Fans who want tickets to the last four games -- the two semifinals, the playoff and the final -- getnine nights in London at $3,245 to $4,895. The package covers breakfast daily and, except for those choosing the economy level lodgings, bus transportation to and from the games.
Whichever package you choose, there is no guarantee as to the category of ticket you get. Information: Gullivers Sports Travel, 973 Vale Terrace, Vista, Calif. 92084; (760) 941-7323, fax (760) 941-2997.
A Rugby World Cup spectator's guide is available from the British Tourist Authority by mail; call (800) 462-2748. It includes tour suggestions plus a listing of places to stay and agencies handling accommodations.
Asked about rowdiness, Ed Hagerty, editor and publisher of Rugby magazine, cited this adage: Rugby is a ruffians' game played by gentlemen; soccer is a gentlemen's game played by ruffians. He noted that after a game, competing teams socialized in what is known as "the third half."
 
Indonesia's Haze
 Q. We are considering a tour that will include Indonesia but are concerned that it could be spoiled by haze from the forest fires. Can you hazard a guess as to the chances of clear conditions in February and March? And what about the outlook for Myanmar and Thailand? -- John B. Hebard, Sutton, Vt.
 A. The drought of El Nino and the haze created by forest fires are history -- for now, anyway. "Definitely pack your umbrella," says Bill Patzert, a research oceangrapher at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. He reports that there are no fires and no smog over Indonesia or Southeast Asia; in fact, in December, there were heavy rains. On average, Jakarta, for example, has 11.8 inches of rain in February and 8.6 in March.
The Topex-Poseidon satellite, a French-American project, measures the height of the sea surface. As the surface heats up, the sea level rises, which in turn promotes conditions that produce rainfall. That is exactly what is happening now: At year's end, the sea level was 7.8 inches above normal in the western Pacific, Mr. Patzert said.
As for Myanmar and Thailand, a National Centers for Environmental Prediction model suggests that temperatures may be a bit higher than usual -- it's normally in the low 70's to low 90's in Bangkok -- and that the precipitation will not differ from the norm, which is eight-tenths of an inch in February and 1.4 inches in March. PAUL FREIREICH

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Asian Economic Woes Hurt Canadian Tourism

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
THE cartoon colors that Japanese tourists seem to favor in ski suits -- orange, pink and shiny silver -- may not be missed on Canadian ski slopes this winter, but the extravagant spending habits that Japanese tourists used to bring with them certainly will be.
Since the spread of Asian economic flu through Japan and other Pacific countries over the past year, Canadian tourism has been hit hard. By October the number of Asian tourists had dropped by 19.7 percent across Canada. And except for unusual attractions like the Aurora Borealis and the house on Prince Edward Island that was the inspiration for "Anne of Green Gables," Canadian tourism destinations have lost some of their biggest spenders. 
 "They have traditionally been very generous visitors," Rod Harris, the president of Tourism British Columbia, said of Japanese tourists. "It's a source of great concern."
British Columbia has done slightly better than the rest of Canada in luring Asian tourists despite the economic slowdown that has crippled the once mighty economies of Japan, Taiwan and South Korea. So far this year, Asian visits to British Columbia are down 17 percent.
Asian tourists often stop in Vancouver or Victoria, two major West Coast cities with large Asian populations. Mr. Harris said that while fewer Asian visitors are taking extravagant cross-country tours, many continue to make the trip to the nearest destination in Canada, which is British Columbia.
Since Asian visitors make up 33 percent of overseas visitors to Canada who stay for at least a night, the decline represents a loss of about $78 million in the first six months of this year alone, according to the Canadian Tourism Commission.
The sharpest drops are in the number of visitors from South Korea, down almost 60 percent, and mainland China, off almost 25 percent. The decline in Japanese tourists is less steep, 16 percent, but it hurts more because Japanese are the largest single group of Asian visitors to Canada and the ones who spend the most money.
"It's definitely having an impact," said John C. Olsthoorn, a spokesman for the Canadian Tourism Commission. "Fortunately, the increase in American tourists has helped buffer the drop."
A significant weakening of the Canadian dollar this year has made traveling north a bargain for Americans, who can expect an exchange rate of from $1.45 to $1.50 Canadian for every American dollar. American overnight visits to Canada in the first 10 months of 1998 totaled 13.3 million, a 10.6 percent increase over the same period in 1997.
"That has more than compensated for the erosion in visitors from the Asia-Pacific region," said Mr. Harris of British Columbia, referring to the influx of Americans. He said that Americans from border states who hop in their cars and drive to Vancouver or the ski slopes at Whistler do not spend as much as the rich Japanese tourists, but there are many more of them.
"The absolute size of the U.S. market is far larger than any other of our other international markets," he said, "so when the number of U.S. tourists grows, even though some of it is short-haul visits, the overall effect is very positive."
Asian visitors to some specialized Canadian sights are driven by dreams rather than costs and will come despite economic conditions. Kathie Adam, general manager of the Northern Frontier Visitors' Association, a Government tourism office in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories, said she hasn't noticed any decline in the number of Asian tourists planning to come to see the Aurora Borealis.
Perhaps the most specialized Canadian destination for Asian tourists is Prince Edward Island, the home of Lucy Maud Montgomery, the author of "Anne of Green Gables." For more than a decade, Japanese girls have been fascinated by the freckle-faced Anne, and a visit to the house in Cavendish that inspired the book has become a once-in-a-lifetime pilgrimage.
"What we have here is a niche market for people who really have an interest in Anne," said Bob Brammer, owner of Prince Edward Tours, an agency that specializes in Japanese tourists.
Mr. Brammer said his agency has handled about 5,000 tourists in the last 12 months, a decline of only 3 to 5 percent, despite current economic conditions. "I had one lady who said she had been saving for close to 10 years," he said. "For many, it's a lifelong dream."
Mr. Brammer said Japanese tourists used to want to see all of Canada, starting with British Columbia and working east to Banff National Park, Toronto, Niagara Falls and the city of Quebec before arriving at Prince Edward Island. "Now they land in Atlantic Canada or the United States before heading here," he said. "It's cheaper."

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Not So Fast!

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
It's relatively easy to find a label for a policy that involves the promise of action. Both "Fifty-Four Forty or Fight!" and the more temperate "Speak Softly and Carry a Big Stick" carried messages of stern forewarning. Policy slogans beginning with Remember, with their pledges of vengeance, had a good run in wartime, with the outrages to be recalled ranging from the Alamo to the Maine to Pearl Harbor.
 More recently, containment was George Kennan's somewhat more sobersided contribution to cold-war foreign-policy nomenclature, followed by the Clinton Administration's engagement. These offered a sense of quiet but resolute policy action. 
 What do you label a policy that does not appeal to jingoism, adventurism, interventionism -- or, indeed, commit you to any reaction whatever? Many statesmen find much in a philosophy that eschews escalation, arguing instead, "Don't just do something -- stand there."
 That was the challenge that faced Strobe Talbott, Deputy Secretary of State, as he sought a catch phrase to define the Clinton Administration's foreign policy in a multipolar but uni-superpower world. As a former correspondent and columnist for Time magazine, Talbott knew that a diplomatic word or phrase had to be conceived in quietude, preferably before an academic audience, and then be allowed to develop slowly over the months. Any more pretentious unveiling, or capitalization, would alert the legion of carping critics to strangle the label in its crib.
 On Sept. 19, 1997, he offered his conception to Stanford University: "We need to make sure we have a policy toward Russia that contains an indispensable feature: strategic patience. That means a policy not just for coping with the issue or the crisis of the moment or the week or even of the season, or for getting through the next summit meeting; rather it means a policy for the next century."
 Few combinations of words are now wholly original. Strategic patience had been used two weeks earlier by a corporate executive, Jim Maxmin, in an article for Industry Week; a year before that, in "The Good Guys," a book by Jules Bonavolonta and Brian Duffy, the phrase was used to describe the F.B.I. plan to infiltrate major Mafia families to conduct long-term investigations. Earlier hits can be made in databases covering fields from music to the military.
 But after Talbott slipped his diplomatic usage into the bulrushes, the Senate's authority on foreign affairs, Richard Lugar, picked it up in a January 1998 Harvard speech. "American policy toward Russia must contain a healthy dose of strategic patience," he said, accepting the Talbott definition, but adding that it was today "particularly susceptible to Russian nonperformance."
 By November, the conceiver was ready to incubate the phrase in a speech subtitle. In "Gogol's Troika: The Case for Strategic Patience in a Time of Troubles," Talbott -- whose enthusiastic support of Boris Yeltsin has been tempered by disappointment -- returned to Stanford to say, "The policy that flows from realism is one of strategic patience and persistence." Lest he be accused of departing from previous policy, he added, "That means continuing engagement." After he reworked his thoughtful speech for The Economist, his phrase was picked up by his former colleagues at Time.
 Because White House speech writers have chosen no Clinton Doctrine or catch phrase of their own and are not really married to engagement, Talbott's personal, long-suffering, tactical patience has paid off: his phrase is in play.
 On what linguistic structure is this coinage bottomed? (As Henry Kissinger once shouted at a football referee who had just made an egregious interference call against a Redskins cornerback, "On vot theory?")
 The use of an active modifier to qualify a noun that justifies not rushing into action has a grand history in diplomatic rhetoric. President Grover Cleveland, criticizing the seizure of Hawaii by the United States in 1893, wrote, "There seemed to arise. . .the precise opportunity for which he was watchfully waiting." Twenty years later, President Woodrow Wilson picked up that alliterative phrase and, refusing to be drawn into a war with Mexico, elevated it to policy status: "We shall not, I believe, be obliged to alter our policy of watchful waiting." The stern watchful gave a monitoring, almost monitory, cast to the feeble waiting.
 This built on the tradition begun in 1791 by Sir James Mackintosh, an historian and Member of Parliament, in "Vindiciae Gallicae," a response to Edmund Burke's criticism of the French Revolution. "The Commons, faithful to their system," wrote Mackintosh, "remained in a wise and masterly inactivity.. . ." That phrase resounded among all who wanted to do little or nothing, and was soon followed by his equally stirring "disciplined inaction."
 No ringing refutations or derisive slogans have yet met Secretary Talbott's sophisticated essay into the field of semi-oxymoronic phrase making. We will just have to let the dust settle. But those sensitive to the technique soon noted another, similar construction that offered a corollary to strategic patience. A White House spokesman seeking to substitute censure for impeachment used a highly active adverb to give backbone to a passive participle: "Officials publicly indicated more interest than before," reported The Washington Post, "saying they were aggressively listening.. . . "
 
COMPULSIVE COMPELLING
 "We've made a compulsive, a compelling case," opined Henry Hyde, House Judiciary chairman. Which did he mean?
 Both words are rooted in the Latin pellere, "to drive." Compel is "to drive forcefully," impel is "to drive with moral pressure" and propel is "to drive forward." Although compelling and compulsive are usually taken to be synonyms, the meanings of the two adjectives are differentiating usefully.
 Compulsive, which still means "having the power to compel," is being overtaken by its secondary meaning, "under the psychological coercion of obsession." One of these days, psychiatrists will adopt the verb compulse.
 Meanwhile, compelling (though its root of compel still means "to force" or "to urge irresistibly") is more often being used to mean "driving toward a conclusion or action by cogent argument."
 Chairman Hyde meant compelling, I hope.

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Marvin E. Wolfgang;
Charting the Devious Mind

BYLINE: By James Q. Wilson; James Q. Wilson is the author of "Moral Judgment" and "The Moral Sense."

 BODY:
Studying crime is much harder than studying the economy. Criminals conceal their behavior; only a fraction of all crimes lead to an arrest; some, but not all, convicted offenders are imprisoned.
 The hardest way to study crime is also the best way -- go out and look at what individuals do. That is what Marvin Wolfgang did. He did it so well that much of what everybody really knows about crime comes from his research. 
 Everybody knows that in many murders the victim started the quarrel that led to his death. Before 1958, when Wolfgang published "Patterns of Criminal Homicide," a detailed examination of nearly 600 Philadelphia murders, people didn't know that.
 Everybody knows that a few chronic offenders commit most serious crimes. Before 1972, when Wolfgang and his associates published "Delinquency in a Birth Cohort," a careful scrutiny of the arrest histories of 10,000 Philadelphia boys, people didn't know that.
 This individual focus gave a new direction to criminology and saved the field, I think, from becoming a small branch of economics or sociology. Wolfgang's study was the first to look at all boys born in a certain year and thus was the first to tell us the crime pattern for every 18-year-old in Philadelphia. If data about real individuals had not been gathered, we would still be trying to understand crime by correlating inaccurate unemployment rates with even more inaccurate crime rates for states or nations.
 By making us think about individuals, Wolfgang set the stage for the next major development in criminology -- finding out why individuals behave as they do. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, criminology was a branch of medicine, and so scholars were quite ready to consider biological as well as social explanations for crime. But then Hitler arrived and the issue of racism clouded the discussion, helping to put an end to any explanation for crime other than a purely environmental one. People must not differ in any important way, some people said, otherwise some people will be thought inferior to others. Therefore, all crime must have a social cause.
 As a result, many scholars became preoccupied with describing how high unemployment rates or social oppression explained crime. These things do matter, but they are not the whole story.
 When Wolfgang looked at individual arrest rates, he did so with the firm conviction that criminology had to be an interdisciplinary activity in which all sources of human behavior should be explored. In his Philadelphia study, he showed that most serious offenders had lower I.Q. scores than the nonoffenders. Because I.Q. is largely inherited, something in addition to social factors was obviously at work.
 Since the Wolfgang study, there have been many studies of I.Q. and crime, all finding more or less the same connection. No one is quite certain how to explain this, but the search for other constitutional factors continues. These days, we also know that high-rate offenders are more likely than nonoffenders to be impulsive, to have slower heart rates, to have lower levels of certain neurotransmitters (like serotonin) and to have difficulty metabolizing manganese and perhaps other minerals.
 Wolfgang rarely drew sharp policy conclusions, but I'm certain he would say that crime involves a complex interaction between neurobiological and social factors. He was a careful scholar and a modest man. When he died, he was hard at work, on a longitudinal study of crime in China.

HEADLINE: ART;
How 20 Artists Treat the Human Body 20 Different Ways

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
AN exhibition called "Extensions" focuses exclusively on representations of the human body in recent art. The show, a bristling and entertaining spectacle, is at the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford in West Hartford through Jan. 17.
What's winning about what the gallery director, Zina Davis, has assembled is that it isn't about anything but how 20 artists treat the human body. Ms. Davis made sure she chose 20 different ways to keep viewers on their toes. The pleasure of the show is one's own body circumnavigating the large gallery space encountering several alluring limned and sculptured kindred spirits, even though there is a distinct lack of spirituality in the show. 
 While several currently hot artists are included, the show gets a kind of ballast from the presence of well-known artists from an earlier generation. These include Alice Neel (1900-1984), known for unconventionally posed full-figure portraits.
Philip Pearlstein's large investigations of the nude, with the head cut off by the frame to emphasize the body, used to impress because of their starkness. But lately, paradoxically, Mr. Pearlstein has included exotic items from his extensive collection of folk art as props, objects that seem more live than the models.
Holograms were very much in vogue during the 1980's, but are used rarely now. Harriet Kasdin-Silver, who was born in 1925, puts the mysterious science of holography to its best use. Her human updating of the neolithic "Venus of Willendorf," one of the earliest images of the body ever found, is at once grotesque and beautiful.
Leon Golub, born in 1922, had his acme in the 1980's with large, graphic images of torture during wartime. His more recent work, such as "Like Yeah" is more ambiguous; it gains interest through the juxtaposition of live figures, skeletons and animals against a backdrop of graffiti.
Ida Applebroog, born in 1929, made herself into an influential artist in the 1980's with her composite works featuring very sympathetic characters from everyday life often encountering the horrors of life. The two works here feature surgeons.
Bruce Nauman, though born in 1941, still has a youthful and flamboyant approach to his art. Ms. Davis, however, has gone back 30 years and picked a 1968 videotape, "Walking With Contrapposto." This is an attitude often seen in antique painting of the figure twisted on its axis so that the arms and shoulders are unaligned with the rest of the body. To promenade that way is a feat but Mr. Nauman performs it amusingly, as if he were another Chaplin.
Among younger artists there is a prevalent urge to explore parts of the body usually regarded as taboo. Sue Williams does this with abandon. From a distance her paintings seem stylized versions of Abstract Expressionism, but they are really concatenations of body parts the likes of which were imagined in an earlier era by Hieronymous Bosch.
Kiki Smith often provides a shock, but an opposite sensation, deflation, is the result of her paper sculpture of a dismembered man, painted a screaming red, hanging on the wall in parts and with the head on the floor. The piece has an aura of absolute emptiness.
Christopher Cairns's corpse-like bronze figure that seems to melt into the floor is reminiscent of one of those neolithic mummies found in a glacier, so the feeling is more one of awe than of the shudder of death.
And even though Magdalena Abakanowicz's 12 standing figures of burlap and resin have no heads, she manages to make them seem very vital as they disturb.
The surprises in the exhibition are from artists who come from outside the United States, all with outsized works; two are gigantic.
Marlene Dumas is a South African living in Amsterdam, a situation reflected in a grid of rather fragile portraits of people in her homeland made with ink on paper; occasionally she uses multiple sheets of paper for a collage effect. The aggregate is called "Rejects." The faces she draws are rudimentary yet she records particular gestures and nuances of expression with great sympathy.
Jenny Saville from England has painted an immense portrait of a back, the kind of luxurious back the French painter Ingres would have seized upon. The portrait is 11 feet high and the female subject's buttocks rest on the bottom edge. Her nose is squashed by the frame on the right side. She might be trapped but she is a cascade of paint, interrupted only by a mole, which makes her something to revere.
"Three Large Men," by Stephan Balkenhol from Germany, is what it purports to be. The figures, each 13 feet tall, seem to be hewed from poplar trees and the uniform texture of rough chisel marks distinguishes them. They're painted minimally in white shirts and black pants, and differ only slightly in their stances. They seem distant relatives of Michelangelo's "David," but are marvelous as paeans to ordinariness.
"Extensions" is at the Joseloff Gallery of the University of Hartford through Jan. 17.
