HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Dentist on the Airwaves, Sound Bites and All

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER 

 BODY:
HARVEY PASSES was on grin patrol. Not that checking out smiles is unusual for a dentist, particularly a cosmetic specialist. But Dr. Passes was holding neither a drill nor a toothbrush.
Standing in front of Barney's at the Americana at Manhasset, a microphone in his hand, a stack of business cards in his pocket, Dr. Passes was cajoling shoppers to play candid camera. And the more embarrassed they were, the more they smiled. 
 "Excuse me," he said to Carolyn Keith, a homemaker from Garden City. "Would you like to be on television? You should be. All you have to do is smile."
"Welcome to Tooth or Consequences," he said, as she beamed into the video camera held by a Cablevision cameraman, Mitch Brown. "Look at that smile. Big smile. Oh, come on, beautiful smile."
Dr. Passes, of North Hills, host of the only oral health talk show in the New York metropolitan area, was searching for Long Island's best smiles.
On the air for the past year, his half-hour dental program, broadcast five times weekly on local origination Channels 44, 25, 80 and 27, features local and national experts in air-abrasive technology, endodontics, oral pathology, implants and dentistry for the developmentally disabled.
"When you meet someone for the first time," he said, rolling through his opening segment, "what is the first thing that you look at? Their ears? Their chin? Their hair? No, it's their eyes." And the second thing you look at? "Their smile," he said. "Some say that the eyes are the door to the mind. The smile is the gateway to the heart. Through the eyes when you meet someone you get a sense of what they are thinking. But when they smile, you get a sense of what they are feeling."
What Dr. Passes doesn't want patients to feel is pain. Or fear of going to the dentist. When he's doing plastodontics and sculpturing teeth with a laser, he sings. While scraping plaque, he cracks jokes. Anything, said Dr. Passes, who formerly ran a dental phobia clinic and taught biofeedback and hypnosis, to distract patients from their anxiety.
Before attending dental school, Dr. Passes, 49, was a stand-up comedian and professional folk-rock singer. Had a contract with Columbia Records, performed all over the nation. Never got over it. Loves being in front of the camera. But he also encourages patients to ignore the high-speed suction tubes he's sticking in their mouths and sing along.
In 1991, Dr. Passes helped developed a dental laser. He was co-founder of the international Academy of Laser Dentistry, does hi-tech research and has lectured across North America.
"We're increasing the dental I.Q. of the public," said Dr. Passes, one of 2,557 dentists in the Nassau and Suffolk County dental societies.
"They don't have to go into Manhattan to get top people," he said. "Dentistry is not what you believe it has been. Dentistry is going into the third millennium. We have incredible technology."
Among the latest developments are pain-free injections that deliver Novocaine through a computer. Drill-free, noise-free fillings fix children's teeth with a thin stream of aluminum oxide powder shot into cavities at five times the speed of sound. With digital visiography, X-rays are taken via computer, transmitting barely a trace of radiation. And the cost of implant dentistry has been halved, making it affordable for the elderly to have a third set of teeth.
"Should I spit my gum out?" asked Allyson Mayo of Roslyn, facing the camera. Ruth Steinberg, a homemaker from Great Neck, worried about lipstick on her teeth. Two-year-old Devin Hakimian just screamed when her mother, Debbie, tried to remove a pacifier from her mouth.
A smile that shows teeth, Dr. Passes continued, as he pointed out a passer-by's grin, subliminally and subconsciously shows openness, warmth of spirit and generosity.
"These are the messages that come across without saying one word," he said. "Six percent of our communication is with our words. Ninety-four percent is with our bodies. You can say so much without saying one word, with a smile." Not everyone has a beautiful grin, admitted Dr. Passes, who has sported white porcelain veneers ever since a patient told him he couldn't touch her teeth until he fixed his own chipped, widely spaced, very yellowed set.
"Clearly, some people have dynamite smiles and some don't," he said. "When there is too much gum in a smile, it becomes a bit of a turnoff. People do want to see your teeth, but they don't want to see your insides."
Too much teeth doesn't work either. "You wind up being Mr. Ed," he said, referring to the talking television horse.
What is Long Island's greatest resource?
"Some say it's our wonderful beaches, maybe it's this fantastic economy," said the dentist.
"When you look into our eyes, you see the eyes of a savvy New Yorker. But when you see our smile, you see the warmth, the generosity of small-town individuals. And that's the smile that comes from the heart."
 
On Hold
Being put on hold on a telephone call is one of life's little annoyances. Waiting in silent desperation or being linked to musical static while you're waiting for your party to return can be aggravating. Except to Dave Goldberg, whose baritone voice is at the other end of the line for more than 2,000 Long Island companies.
Mr. Goldberg, 31, creates "on hold' messages. He knows that his recordings are on target when, instead of hanging up, callers ask to be put back into the waiting pattern.
"The average on hold time in the United States is two minutes per call," Mr. Goldberg said, adding that most phone calls result in being put on hold twice.
Working out of his five-year-old Digital Waterworx company office in Plainview, Mr. Goldberg invents customized scenarios, sometimes running more than half an hour depending on how long his customers keep their clients waiting, and records them in 30- to 60-second segments.
"It's fun," said Mr. Goldberg, who charges $450 per Infohold recording. "Ultimately it makes the person's time on hold feel shorter. My goal is to pacify the clients. If they call and they are irate and they have to be put on hold, maybe they'll get distracted and listen to what's on there."
This is not your typical groan-eliciting, "All our customer service agents are busy now." Instead, using the broadcast voice he honed playing disk jockey at bar mitzvahs and sweet 16 parties, Mr. Goldberg simulates a radio station broadcasting from outer space for a themed restaurant. Trucks backing down a loading dock make a garment distributor sound busy.
Trivia questions with giveaway prizes for the right answers keep callers hanging.
Call Stephen DiNapoli at DiNapoli Plumbing Supplies in Garden City Park and win a portable compact disk player for figuring out how many gallons of water an average slow dripping faucet leaks a year. So far, Mr. DiNapoli said, nobody has figured it out.
Some of the more progressive messages, Mr. Goldberg said, are for dentists, who keep patients from hanging up with buzz about the latest intra-oral cameras and reasons not to go through life with a chipped tooth.
"If you are on hold for 30 seconds listening to silence, the perception is that it's much longer," Mr. Goldberg said. "Having music from the radio on the phone is illegal. You're re-broadcasting copyrighted material." Besides, he said, callers may end up listening to competitors' ads.
"It's hard enough to get people to call your company," he said. "Once you have them you want to retain them. Companies typically spend 85 percent of their advertising budget to get people to call their company yet they spend about 4 percent of their budget to keep the customer."
When not on the phone, Mr. Goldberg, who started playing classical piano at age 5 and publishing songs at 8, composes radio jingles for local companies. That's his voice announcing the specials at Dairy Barn, Bagel Boss and Five Town Toyota. He studied communications and music merchandising at Hofstra University, but attributes his creative streak to his grandfather, a sign painter.
Recently, Mr. Goldberg recorded an audio business card that fits into a cassette player, but not a wallet, for a professional networker, Steven Krauser of Port Washington, who schmoozes with 13 different business groups for a living. For Hal Gold, owner of Black Gold Systems Corporation, a telephone sales and installation company in Farmingdale, Mr. Goldberg fabricated a trivia quiz:
"Who invented the telegraph -- not the telephone -- and was it in the year 1844, 1899 or 1911?" Mr. Goldberg began. "Answer it correctly and you'll win the grand prize: an all expenses paid luxurious romantic getaway to beautiful Yaphank! We'll be right back with the answer. You keep thinking!"
 
An Update
Larry Wallach, the lion rescuer and wild animal specialist mentioned in this space three weeks ago, has lost his bid to create a special society for the protection of wildlife and exotic animals in Nassau County.
The decision, on Dec. 21 by Judge Jerald S. Carter, determined that although Mr. Wallach was not entitled to the status of Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, with its associated law-enforcement powers, he could still promote and advance the humane treatment of lions, tigers, bears and other exotic creatures.
"There is no reason advanced why Mr. Wallach and his organization cannot work in coordination with the local, state and Federal law-enforcement agencies, when required," Judge Carter wrote, "to pursue the stated organizational purpose of protecting wildlife and exotic animals from cruel and inhuman treatment and to encourage kindness and humanity in the treatment of wildlife and exotic animals."
Although it dismissed his petition, the court applauded Mr. Wallach for expending much time, energy and personal funds toward the protection of wildlife and urged him to continue his good work.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property / Westchester;
Big Corporate Shifts Raise Office Vacancies to 18%

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
WHILE surrounding office markets thrived last year, Westchester County's -- tied to large corporations -- ended with a higher vacancy rate than in 1997, leading some brokers to wonder what it would take to turn the market around.
The county had a vacancy rate of 18 percent, up from 16.5 percent in 1997, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial brokerage. And in the White Plains market, which is the county's business hub, the rate hovered at 30 percent, up from 28.3 percent a year earlier, making the city one of the worst-performing office markets in the country. 
 "Even if we start doing deals in Westchester, which we aren't, it can take about a year from the signing of the deal to the actual occupancy of buildings," said John Goodkind, executive managing director of Newmark's Connecticut/Westchester office. "That's very concerning to me."
Mr. Goodkind said that, although Westchester traditionally lagged Bergen County in New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut, where vacancy rates stand at 8 and 11 percent, respectively, "the situation is getting worse instead of better."
Pointing to a lack of available space in Manhattan, Mr. Goodkind said that Westchester's inability to attract tenants was "disturbing at this point." He added: "New York City is outpacing itself. It should be the beginning of a trend of companies relocating from Manhattan. Why hasn't it happened in Westchester?"
The answer is multifaceted, reflecting, in part, some of the county's inherent problems as well as bad luck, several brokers and other interested observers say.
"The vacancy numbers reflect a continuation of corporate reductions and move-outs where companies have left a significant amount of space," said Martin S. Berger, a founder of the Robert Martin Company, a large developer of office space in the county. "It just so happened that Westchester's companies, particularly I.B.M., were more adversely affected by economic downturns than were those in other communities."
Westchester's heavy reliance on large companies, relative to other communities, exacerbated the problem, said Frank Tomasulo, an executive vice president with CB Richard Ellis's Westchester office. "On a proportional basis, Westchester was dominated by these large users, like I.B.M. and AT&T," he said. "So when the market changed, it was harder to change with it."
Much of the vacancy in the county is attributable to a handful of properties, primarily in White Plains. And if as While Plains goes, so goes Westchester, the news is not hopeful.
The county's hub has been severely jolted in recent years by several major corporate consolidations, primarily by I.B.M. and Nynex. And this trend is continuing with more recent arrivals, such as Nine West, the women's shoe manufacturer, and Oxford Health Plans, both of which are returning large blocks of space to the market.
THE rise in White Plains's vacancy rate to 30 percent is due primarily to the return to the market of the former Kraft Foods headquarters building, with more than 600,000 square feet. "The higher vacancy we're seeing now has a great deal to do with the Kraft facility alone," said Maureen O'Boyle, a director with Cushman & Wakefield, which is marketing the space.
"The Westchester market is small enough -- with about 23 million square feet of space -- that a return of that size can really make an impact," Mr. Tomasulo added. "It can affect vacancy by about 2 1/2 to 3 percentage points."
On a positive note, several of the vacant buildings, including the Kraft complex, are being renovated and repositioned to take advantage of the current market. The Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, a Manhattan-based developer, bought the Kraft building in 1997 and hired the architect Philip Johnson to design new facades and help break the building up for smaller users.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company plans to spend $20 million renovating 445 Hamilton Avenue, a 360,000-square-foot building in White Plains that has been vacant since Prodigy moved out at the end of 1997.
And one of the most problematic buildings in White Plains, 360 Hamilton Avenue, which has been vacant since I.B.M. abandoned it in 1989, is undergoing a $30 million renovation.
Its new owner, the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a Long Island real estate investment trust, had tried to market the building as is, planning to renovate once it secured a major tenant. But Reckson abandoned that strategy and is gutting the 360,000-square-foot building, revamping its systems and repositioning it from a single-tenant to a multitenant building.
Westchester's buildings are generally older than those in Fairfield and Bergen Counties, a disadvantage, according to Ms. O'Boyle. But the upside is that Westchester is the only market outside of Manhattan in the area that can accommodate the large corporate user. "Those large blocks of space just aren't available in the other markets," Ms. O'Boyle said.
The large user, however, is no longer a major factor in the marketplace. Insignia/ ESG's year-end report shows that 73 percent of all deals in Westchester last year were for 5,000 square feet or less and only 3 percent were for more than 50,000 square feet.
"People look at an 18 percent vacancy and say, 'What happened to Westchester?,' " said Michael Klein, an executive director with Insignia. "Well, it's not getting the large user out of Manhattan anymore. The size of the average tenant now is around 6,500 square feet. However, if you took out the large blocks of space, Westchester would, I think, look like a healthy market."
An example of that is Eastridge Properties, whose 16 buildings along Westchester Avenue contain two million square feet. It caters to small and mid-size tenants and is now 95 percent occupied, said Michael Ziatyk, Eastridge's managing director. "While we're doing well, the high vacancy in the county casts a negative pall which tenants try to use against you," he said.
Westchester is not the only market not getting the large user, according to Mr. Klein. "Fairfield and others aren't getting them either, but they're not as adversely affected by it," he said. "The problem is that companies are increasingly staying in Manhattan. It's got a better quality of life. And for some companies, it's important to have a presence in Manhattan."
The uncertainty of the economy has also played a part in Westchester's misfortunes, according to John McCarthy, a principal of McCarthy-O'Callaghan, a commercial brokerage in White Plains. "It's kind of a delayed reaction. Ever since August really, there's been this wait-and-see attitude on the part of tenants," he said. "I think we'll start to see some movement by the beginning of the year."

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
From the 15th Century, A Tale of Two Cultures

BYLINE: By KAY LARSON; Kay Larson is an art critic who practices Zen.

 BODY:
IT'S magical. I left 15th-century Tibet, took an elevator up one floor at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and stepped into the Netherlands: same century, different universe. In the exquisite "From Van Eyck to Breughel: Early Netherlandish Painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art," Christian Europe opens its eyes to the Renaissance. In "Sacred Visions: Early Paintings from Central Tibet," spiritual splendor and flowing Buddhist cosmology inhabit the main-floor galleries off the sculpture hall. Two cultures at opposite poles of the 15th century -- neither knowing of the other -- are housed, 500 years later, under the same roof. The metaphor seems inescapable. East and West are no longer twain. So why not ask what these two handsome exhibitions, on view through Jan. 17, can tell us about the worlds that gave them birth?
Despite the ubiquitous presence of the Dalai Lama and his monks, and the release of films like Martin Scorsese's "Kundun," Tibetan Buddhism remains impenetrably exotic for most of us (unless, like Richard Gere and Philip Glass, you are one of the growing numbers of serious Western practitioners). In "Sacred Visions," the closed door of Tibetan culture cracks open another notch. The cataclysm that has killed a million Tibetans and all but wiped out Tibet's monasteries has sent its spiritual images -- in pristine condition because they were preserved for up to a millennium in closed temple rooms -- on clandestine pilgrimages to the West. The shock of seeing them at the Met is immense. It's as if chunks of the Sistine Ceiling had begun to appear in Asian museums. The Met's catalogue steers clear of awkward questions about how these magnificent pictures got to Western collections. But we can be sure that only a cultural apocalypse of unimaginable dimensions would have pried them out of their stewards' hands. 
 So how do 15th-century Asia and Europe speak to one another? In many respects, effortlessly. "From van Eyck to Breughel" -- which airs some of the staggering wealth of the Metropolitan's collections -- opens with an "Annunciation" attributed to Petrus Christus. One of the most beautiful themes in Western art, an Annunciation depicts the ordinary world permeated by mysteries, the body made luminous by Spirit. Here, cloaked in the blue gown of heaven, Mary stands in the doorway of a freshly built church, a bit of symbolic architecture that signfies the birth of Christianity. Alighting before her in a verdant garden is a gorgeously gowned angel, the agent of transformation, who shuttles between material and immaterial realms.
Buddhism also includes a mystical conception, in which the Buddha's mother, Queen Maya, is impregnated through her right side by a holy elephant -- the human body acknowledging kinship with all beings. But the scene is a minor element in Tibetan painting, which is fundamentally concerned with the spiritual architecture of the universe. Tibetan painting is a map of the mind, a guide for meditations. Its basic form is the mandala: a symbolic palace for a deity, akin to the medieval western artist's City of God.
SOMETIMES the mandala is viewed from above, like the floor plan of a mansion. The Met's show includes several of these: spectacular, intricately detailed squares within circles, shimmering in a mosaic of red, yellow, blue, green, white. When Tibetan monks build their ornate sand mandalas, grain by colored grain, they use these floor plans, which have courtyards, gates, doorways, and an inner sanctum or altar.
Most of the paintings in the Met, however, show the mandala in elevation, as though we were arriving to visit the deity, who sits in an arch or portico on a sacred lotus throne. In one exquisite version owned by the Cleveland Museum of Art, "Green Tara" -- an olive-skinned goddess with a gentle smile -- sways gracefully in a filigreed grotto capped with delicate floral greenery.
In West and East, the religious artist's job is to bring the immaterial down to earth so that ordinary people can identify with spiritually extraordinary beings. Tibetan deities are known by their attributes, just as saints and angels are in the West. Elegant Manjushri, epitomizing wisdom, wields his great sword to cut the karmic bonds that tie us to suffering. Radiant Avalokiteshvara, embodying compassion, opens her 1,000 arms and hands to give mystical help wherever she is needed. (Tara is one of her manifestations.) The fierce Achala summons the psychological forces that help the meditator penetrate obscuring clouds of ego. More than 1,000 years before Freud, Buddhism proposed a model of the psyche that viewed nightmares as expressions of deluded minds, to be swept away by wisdom and compassion.
In other equally profound respects, 15th-century Tibet and the Netherlands are worlds apart. The West, still witch-obsessed, was just beginning to emerge from its medieval nightmares, epitomized by the hellish visions of Hieronymous Bosch and the horned mutant beasts that cluster around St. Anthony the Hermit in the Met's splendid altarpiece "The Penitence of St. Jerome." Damnation and salvation -- envisioned in a diptych by van Eyck, across the room from the Petrus Christus "Annunciation" -- were two inseparable realities.
"From van Eyck to Breughel" documents the changing cultural climate that we call the Renaissance. Artists began inserting breathing space -- the human body's perspective -- into the claustrophobic medieval schematic. The dawning of the Age of Reason gave new importance to individual faces. Although artists made Mary, Christ and the angels generic, they often painted ordinary men and women as recognizable characters borrowed from Netherlandish parlors and back streets. The most vivid realism is reserved for high clergy and layman donors -- the people paying the bills.
The Renaissance, argues the historian Lisa Jardine in her recent book "Worldly Goods," was driven mainly by market economics. In Ms. Jardine's radically materialist reading, trade and the emerging spirit of capitalism created a new reality of robber barons, venture capitalists, commodity dealers and bankers. Free trade was a guarantor of and spur to the free flow of ideas. A new "esthetic of expenditure" -- a "blurring of boundaries between piety and vanity," in her view -- filled Renaissance painting with luxury goods. Art works as shelter magazines: the 15th century turns out to look just like us.
Ms. Jardine may be reading the past through the filter of the present. Renaissance art took its faith for granted. In a stunning room at the Met filled with portraits, not all the sitters are rich, and even the obviously wealthy are radiant with reverence. Is van Eyck's painting of the wedding of the Arnolfinis a "celebration of ownership," as Ms. Jardine speculates? Or are we reducing all human qualities to market factors?
The West went on to create the greatest mercantile society the world has ever known. Tibet, locked in its high mountain land and populated by nomads and farmers, had no such option. The new ideas that swept through its courts from the seventh through the 12th centuries -- brought by famed traveling teachers -- came from spiritual centers in eastern India, site of the Buddha's enlightenment. By the time Mongol invasions wiped out Indian Buddhism in the 13th century, Tibet's flourishing monastic culture had established itself as the height of intellectual life throughout the region.
Tibetan painting doesn't evolve in the Western way. Its artists were monks; a display of individual ego would have been anathema. Nor does Tibetan monastic life and culture change much. After its renaissance, Tibet sheltered and perfected its spiritual mission, rejecting the outside world, secure in its time capsule, until the Chinese invasion in 1949.
Walking between these two exhibitions -- and using a hefty dose of hindsight -- I was struck that the seeds of Tibet's annihilation are visible in "From van Eyck to Breughel." Western materialism, in its dialectical Maoist version, fueled the Chinese invasion. In the mind of Karl Marx, that son of the Enlightenment, the material world is the only reality, so economics is fundamental. Class struggle, he said, is the only true human relationship; all else is false consciousness. As a pale-faced Mao hisses to the Dalai Lama in "Kundun": "Religion is poison . . . the opiate of the people."
The Dalai Lama has often said that one's enemies are one's best teachers. Certainly one's enemies give a brutally frank portrait of one's strengths and weaknesses. But maybe the Chinese should think twice about consequences. Dialectical materialism is erasing Tibetan Buddhism in its homeland but also dispersing it throughout the West. Two extremes -- Tibetan indifference to worldly things and Western obsession with them -- are meeting on common ground. And China is seeding the world with its own nemesis.
Amazing what an elevator ride can reveal.

HEADLINE: The View From/Ten Thousand Villages;
Hand-Made Craft Items From Around the World

BYLINE: By MIMI G. SOMMER 

 BODY:
IT is a special event when handcrafts from around the world not only appear on the Internet but also land on the doorstep of a nearby boutique.
And that is the service provided by Ten Thousand Villages, a shop at 1054 Chapel Street in New Haven, part of a national network of stores run by Mennonites, who use the proceeds to help people in developing countries. 
 In the New Haven shop -- the second to open in Connecticut (the first was in West Hartford) -- are sequined ornaments from Calcutta, banana raffia and muhugu wood sculptures from Kenya and exotic papers from Bangladesh.
More than 200 Ten Thousand Villages stores can be found in the United States and Canada, all with handmade inventories from more than 100 artisan cooperatives in largely rural and poor areas of 30 countries: Vietnam, Pakistan, Peru, Mexico, Chile, Kenya, Bangladesh and India among them.
The retail network is an arm of the Mennonite Central Committee, which has its headquarters in Akron, Pa. The Mennonites, Christians who believe in pacifism and in the separation of church and state, also believe in actively working to improve the quality of life in developing countries.
Prices paid for handcrafts are based on the locale's economic customs. Store prices reflect a markup that covers overhead. For each boutique, there are two paid staff members, a manager and assistant manager as well as volunteers.
The relationship between the retail world and the cooperatives means a living wage for the artisans and their families, the opportunity for people of different faiths to work together and the chance to keep artistic traditions alive. The handmade gifts and the stories behind their making offer customers lessons in cultural geography.
Why the name, Ten Thousand Villages? Mennonites cite Mahatma Gandhi as the inspiration: "I have believed and repeated times without number that India is not to be found in its few cities, but in the villages. We have hardly ever paused to inquire if these folks get sufficient to eat and clothe themselves with."
The network of retail stores was set up 53 years ago by Edna Ruth Byler, an embroiderer and member of the religious group's central committee. On a visit to Puerto Rico in 1946, she purchased needlework to sell to friends and neighbors at home. The idea mushroomed.
Liz Rider, manager of the Ten Thousand Villages store in New Haven describes her domain as a bazaar with the sights, sounds, and scents of a bustling marketplace. Indeed, on a recent visit, an intricately woven Nicaraguan ivory cotton hammock-turned-canopy floated above handcrafted merchandise of many colors. In one corner, rolls of textured gift-wrapping papers, embedded with leaves, ferns and flowers are displayed, all from Bangladesh. The paper is made from scraps of jute and water hyacinth weed. In an explanatory video, colorfully garbed women laboriously stir pulp ingredients in vats that seem to dwarf them.
Miss Rider explained that in many countries, women's handiwork is significant because women are often the sole supporters of their families. The Ashirwad cooperative in Calcutta (an exception to the village sites in that it is in a big city), produces sequined felt ornaments, kites and wall hangings -- all to win women independence and sufficient income to sustain and educate their families.
Jewelry makers from Taxco in Mexico produce pins, earrings, and necklaces from shell and silver. Videos, telling artisans' stories are available for viewing in the store.
In the shop, a sound like the rush of rain and sand can be heard. Someone is twirling a rain stick, a cactus that has been hollowed out, filled with seeds and spines, and sealed. The item comes from a cooperative in Chile.
The majority of items are made with an eye to environmental preservation. Kenyan woodcarvers, for example, are now using faster maturing woods, like jacaranda and muhugu, for creating animal figures. (Teak and ebony not only cost a great deal but the trees that provide the wood also require new protections if they are to renew themselves.
Prices at Ten Thousand Villages start at 50 cents (for a jute ring) and rise to $3,500 (for a wood giraffe from Kenya). Miss Rider said that all the products in the store are inspected and tested for safety. Toys are lead-free, as are ceramic wares.
In the shop on a recent visit was Marilyn Valenti, of New Haven, who bought an Indian silk scarf for $16.95. "It's beautiful," she said, as well as admitting to a longtime interest in handmade things from around the world.
And Tom Carberry, a Yale student from Tennessee, was buying a gift for a friend. "I'm a big fan of Epcot Center," he said. "But the things I like to get there are all here."

HEADLINE: Old Mill Town Has New Bustle, Thanks to Antiques

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
AT the start of the 1990's, Putnam, in the northeast corner of the state, was a prime example of an old mill town slowly dying. Its population was less than it had been at mid-century and since then had suffered through two catastrophic events, one natural, one manmade. The first was the great flood of the mid-1950's when the Quinebaug River leaped its banks and destroyed some 200 homes. The second was the post-World War II economic disaster, when textile companies that had fueled the economy of eastern Connecticut for generations started moving South because it was cheaper and warmer there.
The business district -- centered around the intersection of Main Street and Route 44 -- was a place of mercantile ghosts. National companies including Grant's and Montgomery Ward and local ones like Bugbee, a department store since 1880, were gone, leaving their names on buildings like tombstone markers. "Fifty percent of downtown was vacant," says Mayor Daniel S. Rovero, recalling the worst of times for his town. "And three of the six mills were totally empty." There was no question that if something didn't happen for the better, Putnam would continue to spiral downward. It would be, in the words of the Mayor, "unfortunately like lot of other towns today, lots of littering, lots of empty buildings." 
 But something did happen in Putnam. Over the brief time of Mr. Rovero's tenure as Mayor -- he is currently in the middle of his fourth two-year term -- Putnam has gone from one more old mill town rooted in an age that has long since passed to a new life predicated on, of all things, antiques.
"Now we call it the antiques center of New England," says Mayor Rovero.
Whatever it is called -- another popular description is "Putnam Is Antiques" -- there is no question that the town, population now about 9,000, is a heartening example of one that went from down to up dramatically and with one good idea.
Today, downtown Putnam, which basically is one big block, is occupied by antique stores or complementary businesses like crafts, framing and book stores, as well as six restaurants ranging in offerings from pizza and hamburgers to the upscale Vine Bistro where roasted rack of New Zealand spring lamb, "finished with the sauce of the moment," is available.
The antiques establishments vary from the Antiques Marketplace, which rents out space to 250 dealers, to the Putnam Antiques Exchange, which deals in "architectural elements" -- including an outdoor fountain of Italian marble or even an entire old barber shop -- to smaller establishments like Mrs. Bridge's Pantry, which specializes in items from the British Isles, with a nice cup of tea thrown in.
Not one shop in the cluster of some two dozen at the key intersection is vacant, Mayor Rovero says. "If someone moves out, someone else moves right in."
Particularly on weekends, the center of town is a bustling place, people scurrying around, into one building, then out, and into another. A big -- and free -- parking lot next to the old Victorian railroad station, is usually filled up, or close to it.
On weekdays, many of the cars have out-of-state plates. Greg Renshaw, who owns Putnam Antiques Exchange, says these cars are mostly owned by dealers trading with the Putnam dealers.
A major spinoff from the success of the antiques center, Mayor Rovero says, is that all six old mills in the town are now occupied -- for offices, storage, even for more antique stores, a situation quite unlike mills in some other Eastern Connecticut towns that have no present uses and are unheated and untended and slowly rotting away.
And yes, Putnam does have a Walmart, the traditional main foe of old town centers. It also has a KMart and a Super Shop & Shop, all in a mall away from the center. "The mall and the center complement each other here," says the Mayor.
The happy circumstance of an occupied, and taxpaying, town center and tax money from the mall have led to a new town-sponsored two-mile walk along the Quinebaug River. The walk helps to encourage visitors to make a full day out in Putnam when they go antiquing, says Putnam's civic economic development director, Elizabeth Murphy.
Another civic benefit is that the Bradley Playhouse, in the antiques district, has been resurrected. The Bradley was born as a vaudeville house in 1905, Ms. Murphy says. It eventually became a movie house, but was shut down in 1980. Now it is the Theater of Northeastern Connecticut and presents six productions each year. The first this year was "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof." The final was "A Christmas Carol" last month.
Perhaps the most interesting aspect of the renaissance of Putnam is that in an era of town planners, economic surveys, viability studies and Federal and state aid, the town had none of the above.
Mayor Rovero, as the chief elected officer of Putnam, might be forgiven for taking a bit of credit for the revival. But, in a most unpolitical manner, he does not. The business people in the antiques district are responsible for rehabilitation of the area, he says. "None of them asked for special breaks," he said. "They did most of the work on their own and they did a great job."
The move to antiques, which he supported once it got started, was inspired by Jerry Cohen.
"Jerry Cohen is the king of Putnam," says David Hellman, proprietor of the Corner Cafe. "He had a certain vision."
So who is Jerry Cohen?
He is a native New Yorker who went to Oakland, Calif., and established a good business dealing in arts and crafts and furniture of the last century. Ten years ago, as he explains it, he and his wife, after the birth of their first son, decided to move back East to be near their families.
They settled in Woodstock and one day he came across the old Bugbee building in nearby Putnam, smack in the middle of what had once been a thriving commercial center.
"It was a grand old department store built in 1880 and I fell in love with it," he says. He had some money from the sale of his store in California and decided to buy it.
"I was thrilled but on the day of the closing a banker looked me in the eye and said, 'We appreciate you buying the building but why buy in a ghost town like Putnam?' "
The closing was in October 1990. For a year, Mr. Cohen says, he kept the building closed while he had it brought back to the grandeur of the past, with some modern refinements like good lighting and heating. "We took away 100 years of bad renovations, windows boarded up, dropped ceilings."
Occasionally someone would drop in with an opinion of the work in progress and its future. "Are you out of your mind? This isn't Boston. You must be losing your marbles."
In November 1991 the building was reopened as the Antiques Marketplace. Mr. Cohen's idea had been to lease out most of the 26,000 square feet of space to small dealers. Almost immediately, he knew he had guessed right.
"Within 90 days we rented every space," he said, "and every dealer said, 'This is a phenomenal place.' And then other dealers started coming in with tape measures and cameras. We broke the mold of the antique mall as a musty old warehouse with showcases made out of two-by-four pine boards."
The Marketplace is not a great revenue producer for him, Mr. Cohen adds, and he does not regard it as his living because he also kept the business he brought from California.
"It's really a labor of love." he says of the Putnam business. In the section of the building he retained for himself, "We do $1.6 million in business a year, and we net $15,000."
But the old building remains very important to him. "I have 250 dealers here and I have a paternal feeling toward them," he said.
And he is proud that his effort, in less than a decade, has attracted so many businesses around it, to a little downtown that was a short time ago considered near to dead.
"I think people feel better about their town," he said. "In the past, when you asked them about it, they would just look at you. Now they say what a great little place this is."

HEADLINE: The Millennium Bug, A Bite or a Nibble?

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
A YEAR from today, the so-called millennium bug computer time bomb will have exploded, and if the experts are correct, our microprocessor-dependent society will be experiencing the greatest collective headache in history.
Computer chips, billions of them, are responsible for the operation of everything from strategic nuclear weapons to supermarket doors, and when the calendar flips over from 1999 to 2000, an unknown number of them will no longer be able to recognize the date, resulting in various degrees of failure. In fact, some glitches are already occurring. Some are amusing, as in the case of the nonagenarian gentleman who received a notice to report for kindergarten orientation. Others are far more ominous. If you thought El Nino was bad, just wait. 
 Annoyance ahead, or Gotterdammerung? "The simple answer is nobody knows," said George Scott, a professor of management information systems at the University of Connecticut. "The other answer is it is a real problem."
Hundreds of millions of dollars are being spent by the state, local governments and businesses in Connecticut to prepare for Y2K, the ubiquitous abbreviation for Year 2000. While the state government, many local governments and many businesses are well prepared to deal with it -- as well prepared as is possible, that is -- a good number are not.
Individuals have been warned to be prepared, as well, by taking a few common-sense preventive measures. Edward J. Deak, a professor of economics at Fairfield University who testified before a United States Senate subcommittee hearing on the problem last February, said the ordinary person would definitely notice the effects, but he laughed at concerns that it would be the end of the world. "For the average person, it will be annoying but not a financial disaster," Dr. Deak said.
Others on the Y2K battle's front lines were similarly reassuring. "Most people will experience inconveniences here and there, depending on who they're connected to electronically," said Peter Sullivan, the project leader for the state government's Year 2000 preparations.
"Most automobiles will not be affected," he added. "That's good news." Because most cars nowadays have computer chips in them that regulate the engines, there were fears of massive car die-outs after the calendar turned.
Experts said the average citizen should spend 1999 compiling an inventory of any property for which ownership is recorded electronically, such as investment portfolios and bank accounts, and have reliable records fully updated as of Dec. 31, 1999. Similarly, having copies of bill payments and tax returns is a wise precaution. Anyone receiving pension or government benefit checks should keep records of them, too.
That way, Dr. Deak said, if a computer makes a mistake, a person has a starting point for reconstructing his or her holdings and liabilities, and proof for claims and payments.
"I would have a little extra cash on hand, just in case," said Mr. Sullivan. "Not a lot. Just in case there's a problem with cash machines and credit cards."
The state's Department of Information Technology has a Web site that offers advice for businesses and local governments on how to prepare for the bite of the millennium bug, and Mr. Sullivan said he plans to add information for individuals.
But home computers are presumably less vulnerable than large mainframe machines that keep government and business records, because most are already "Year 2000 compliant," meaning that their microprocessors and software have been designed to recognize the date change. All Macintosh computers are presumed safe, but not all of those with Microsoft's Windows operating systems, especially older machines.
"If you have an old 386 system from 10 years ago you probably have a problem," Dr. Deak said.
Software for Windows that can be used to test one's computer can be downloaded off the Internet or bought in stores. Dr. Deak warned against setting a computer's clock ahead, to the end of the year to test it, because if there is a problem it could corrupt programs and files stored on it.
Besides the processing glitches that may occur, there is also the enormous cost of fixing millions of computers -- not to mention the torrent of lawsuits that may result. Dr. Deak said the most reliable estimate he has heard is that the technical work will cost the world's economy a $1 trillion, and $600 billion beyond that for liability claims.
"I don't look at somebody suing me," he said, but he might have to sue a bank if it lost track of his money.
That doesn't mean that a widespread bank failure is imminent, however. "What we're hearing is that banks are about as well prepared as anyone," said Roberta Burntower, a spokeswoman for People's Bank. She said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has required banks to make their computers Year 2000-compliant, and has inspected them to assure they have done so.
Aside from the huge known costs of compliance, Dr. Scott noted, a hidden cost is that of deferred improvements and repairs. For local government that might mean increasing class sizes in schools and putting off neighborhood improvements. For the state it might mean the depletion of the budget surplus without any improvement in services and make tax cuts impossible. For businesses it will surely mean that improvements or new ventures that could have increased profits won't be done.
The state legislature has appropriated $95 million for fixing the state's computer systems, with millions more coming out of different departmental budgets, and Mr. Sullivan said the Department of Information Technology would ask for more money in the next year's budget. He said the latest estimate is that it will cost state taxpayers $147 million, barring unexpected glitches, which he said are virtually inevitable.
All the state's 40,000 desktop computers have had to be tested, and those that fail either replaced or repaired.
The state's computer systems have been triaged into those considered mission critical systems -- the 50 systems with the highest performance priority, including child-support enforcement and pension benefits; those for which remediation can be delayed because no one's life or welfare depends on them, and those that either cannot be tested at all or can't be made compliant and tested in time.
Eleven states, including Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont, were unable to meet a Federal Labor Department deadline for having their unemployment benefit system compliant by the end of 1998. This is a problem because the period for receiving benefits will now extend into 2000, and their computers may refuse to pay legitimate claims. Connecticut was expected to meet the deadline, but had not done so by late in December.
Mr. Sullivan said contingency plans have been developed for all the bureaucratic functions that depend on computers. The state has set March 31 as the deadline for the completion of testing of its 50 highest-priority computer systems.
The state and the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities are concerned that some local governments may have waited too long or lack the resources to meet the challenges of Y2K. There are fears of malfunctioning traffic lights, disorganized town offices, and even raw sewage spills.
According to the conference's spokesman, Kevin Maloney, as of last August, 40 percent of the towns had made no effort at all, and only 9 percent had done any contingency planning.
Mr. Maloney says he believes many towns are still behind. He said his organization would ask the state legislature to authorize the use of money from its municipal capital improvement program to help towns pay for Y2K repairs.
A few communities are well along, however. Hartford began working on the problem four years ago and expects to have all its systems fixed and tested by the summer. "Having the ability of hindsight, I guess we made the right decision," said Albert Ouellette, Hartford's director of information services.
One of the most ominous parts of the problem involves what are known as embedded computer chips. These are microprocessors that are date-dependent, but often do not provide any evidence of their existence. A substantial number of microwave ovens, or example, may stop working when the calendar turns, as may security alarm systems, heating systems, traffic lights and pollution control equipment.
While the failure to reheat leftovers may be annoying, however, it is hardly of the same significance as millions of tons of raw sewage fouling rivers and Long Island Sound.
Mr. Maloney said there aren't any reliable estimates of how much it will cost Connecticut's 169 municipalities to fix their computers. Stonington, relatively small, has estimated its cost at $250,000, and many other communities expect to spend more than $1 million each.
On top of that there are the legal liability costs in case, for example, someone's house burns down because fire engines aren't dispatched. Probably most maddening about the millennium computer bug is the amount of uncertainty.
"Nobody can tell you with 100 percent certainty what's going to happen with computer systems," said Dr. Deak.
The prudent are expecting the unexpected. Mr. Ouellette said Hartford has contingency plans on how to deal with the effects of its neighboring communities' problems.
"Worst case, the power goes out," he said. "We've been there and done that, haven't we?"
But what does he expect to happen? "Something less than that," Mr. Ouellette said.
 
Hunting on the Internet
 THE Internet, naturally, is an excellent source of information on the millennium bug problem. Following are some Web sites of interest (all addresses begin with http://www.).
The Department of Information Technology's Web site has information about the state's preparation program and links to other informative Internet sites:
doit.state.ct.us/y2k/
The Web site for the organization Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility has a detailed explanation of the Y2K problem, tips for individuals and links to other informative Internet sites:
cpsr.org/program/y2k/faq.html
The University of Connecticut Computer Center's Year 2000 page:
ucc.uconn.edu/year2000/uccyr2k.html
The Y2K News Magazine Web site has the latest on the problem from publications in the United States and other countries:
y2knews.com/
The General Services Administration's Gateway for Year 2000 Information Directories Web site leads to the Federal Government's Year 2000 Web sites:
itpolicy.gsa.gov/mks/yr2000/y2khome.htm
One of the many Web sites poking fun at the problem, this one a collection of stupid things people have actually said about the Y2K problem:
duh-2000.com/

HEADLINE: To Burnish the Loop, Chicago Turns to Live Theater

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
IN an effort to revive the downtown Loop commercial district as an entertainment area and add a substantial new tourist attraction, Chicago is betting heavily on live theater.
The centerpiece of the plan is a theater district along Randolph Street that includes the newly renovated Oriental Theater as well as two projects that are currently under way -- restoring the historic Palace Theater and building a two-theater complex for the Goodman Theater, the city's oldest and largest nonprofit ensemble. 
 In addition, the city recently finished an elaborate streetscape improvement project along eight blocks of Randolph Street. It includes new sidewalks and streetlights as well as colorful banners and signs ballyhooing the district.
Over all, the city has put about $60 million into the project, much in the form of tax-increment financing.
"The idea is to make the Loop a 24-hour neighborhood, and we think theaters will do that," said Christopher Hill, the city's Planning Commissioner.
"When everything is in place, people will be buying upwards of 15,000 tickets a day on Randolph Street," said Daniel P. Coffey, president of Daniel P. Coffey & Associates, the architecture firm that is renovating the Palace Theater. Mr. Coffey's firm also did the Oriental Theater, which reopened this fall.
The theater district is the crest of a sudden wave of new live-theater development downtown.
Two other theaters -- the Chicago Theater on State Street and the Arie Crown Theater at the McCormick Place convention center -- were recently renovated. A third project, construction of a home for the nonprofit Shakespeare Repertory Theater, is under way at the nearby Navy Pier.
Many of the downtown projects are partnerships that involve both private developers and the theater companies or managers and producers that will eventually be the tenants. An example is the renovation of the Palace, which is part of a hotel and office building that dates from 1926.
The entire complex was acquired early last year by Pal/Met Venture, a real estate partnership of the developer Michael Moyer and the VanKampen family. The hotel -- formerly the Bismarck and now called the Allegro -- reopened earlier this year. The Palace, a 2,350-seat former vaudeville house that has been closed many years, will follow this summer, and the office building sometime in 2000. The total cost of the project is $75 million, including $21.5 million for the theater. Fox Theatricals, the Palace's tenant, is putting up $4 million, and the whole project received $17.6 million in tax increment financing from the city.
Fox is a locally based production firm that began in the early 1980's and has been a major player in the Off-Loop theater scene, the Chicago parallel to Off Broadway. The company has also done several productions on Broadway, including the current musical "Jekyll & Hyde."
Fox has the theater for 98 years. "We structured it as two 49-year leases," said Michael Leavitt, executive producer of Fox. "Effectively, it's like owning the building."
Mr. Leavitt said the Palace would be used for Fox productions as well as for touring Broadway shows. "We've designed the house so that it can hold just about any production," he said. "We've expanded the stage depth to 45 feet and added three loading docks. It's very presenter friendly."
The other two projects under way are the Goodman and the Shakespeare Repertory.
The Goodman, which occupies a half block at Randolph and Dearborn streets, has been in the works many years. Its cost is $44 million, of which $18.8 million is coming from the city. The rest is being raised in a fund-raising campaign. Half the site is vacant; the other half is occupied by two small historic theaters, the Harris and the Selwyn.
The Selwyn is being renovated into a 400-seat studio theater, while all but the Beaux-Arts facade of the Harris has been torn down. The rest of the project consists of a new 800-seat main auditorium as well as a lobby and administrative space. The complex will also include about 50,000 square feet of rentable retail space on three levels.
Part of the site was once occupied by the Garrick Theater, which was designed by Louis Sullivan in 1892. The theater was razed in the 1960's over the protests of preservationists and eventually replaced with a parking lot.
According to Roche Schulfer, managing director of the Goodman, the theater will own the building and have a 99-year lease on the land. The architects for the project, which is expected to be finished in the fall of 2000, are Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg Architects of Toronto and Decker Legge Kemp Architecture of Chicago.
THE Shakespeare Repertory project is the final piece of the redevelopment of Navy Pier, which began several years ago. The pier, which extends into Lake Michigan, is just northeast of the Loop and has been turned into an urban amusement park with numerous shops and restaurants.
The pier is controlled by the Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority, which has proposed several plans over the years to bring live theater to the Pier before signing a deal with the Shakespeare company in 1997.
Shakespeare Repertory, which was founded 12 years ago but has never had a permanent home, is Chicago's third-largest nonprofit theater.
The new complex, which will open next fall, will have a 550-seat main auditorium and a 350-seat studio theater. The cost is $26 million. In exchange for a 90-year lease, Shakespeare Repertory is putting up $12 million.
"It's a perfect model of the public and private sectors working together," said Criss Henderson, executive director of Shakespeare Repertory. "Metropolitan Pier is building the shell, and we're doing the interior."
When the dust finally settles at the turn of the century, Chicago will have added 10,000 live theater seats downtown on an existing base of about 15,000 seats.
According to the League of Chicago Theaters, a trade group that runs several half-price ticket booths downtown, the Chicago area currently has about 54,000 live theater seats.
Can the city support the new activity? It depends on whom you talk to. There is little consensus, even among theater professionals.
N EW theaters coming on line do not scare me," said Dulcie Gilmore, general manager of the Oriental Theater, which is also known as the Ford Center for the Performing Arts and is owned and managed by Livent. "What scares me is the availability of product. It's almost totally tied to what gets produced in New York. If New York dries up, it's a problem."
"If you talk to performing-arts centers anywhere in the country that rely on blockbuster Broadway shows, you can hear the panic in their voices," said Douglas Kridler, president of the Columbus Association of Performing Arts, based in Columbus, Ohio, which recently took over the Chicago Theater. "I don't think Broadway is going to go into free fall, but there is a drought in mega-musicals."
Mr. Kridler added that the Chicago plans to sidestep this problem with a booking philosophy that stresses "a wide variety of arts and entertainment events," including theater, dance, music and, possibly, film.
Others, however, see it differently. "If you pick up the weekend entertainment section in New York, how many good or great plays are being presented at any one time? It's a lot more than three or four," said Robert Wislow, chairman of U.S. Equities Realty, a real estate firm that worked with the city to devise the plan for the theater district. "Up until now, Chicago has never had the houses to support this level of activity. Now we do. I don't really understand what we're worried about."

HEADLINE: Clearing the Tracks for Penn Station III

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
AFTER six years of pushing and pulling, negotiators believe they have arrived at a workable division of the General Post Office in Manhattan, allowing it to remain a hub of mail service even as it is transformed into a new version of the lost Pennsylvania Station.
The Postal Service and the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation are now talking about how to share the building rather than how to partition it. The distinction is more than semantic. 
 Instead of searching for a sharp line demarcating post office from train station, the designers have found ways in which passenger movement and mail handling can overlap in the massive neo-Classical structure, known formally as the James A. Farley Building.
"We've mixed and marbleized the cake," said Robert A. Peck, the Federal Commissioner of Public Buildings, after a meeting Dec. 21 at which agreement was reached on the general layout of the building.
With the agreement in hand, the architects and engineers can now begin a detailed redesign of the space within the 1.4 million-square-foot Farley Building. In broad outline, it will have these features:
The main entrances for Amtrak passengers will be on 31st and 33d Streets, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Driveways on both streets will lead to a 300-foot ticketing hall -- as long as the main waiting room of the original Pennsylvania Station.
Passengers arriving on foot will be able to use entrances under the niches on either side of the grand Eighth Avenue staircase. The window-service postal lobby at the top of those stairs will remain. (See you there April 15, 2003.)
Passengers arriving on the Eighth Avenue subway will be able to enter the Farley Building on an extension of the Long Island Rail Road's West End Concourse. Those arriving on the Seventh Avenue line would come through the existing Penn Station, which will remain in use by New Jersey Transit and the L.I.R.R.
From the ticketing hall, passengers will proceed into a 160-by-205-foot atrium on the Eighth Avenue side of the building, at the base of which will be a terraced series of three concourses cascading down to the train platforms, some of which will be visible through skylights. The platforms, which already extend westward from the existing station, will be reached by stairway, escalator or elevator.
"You'll actually be able to see the trains as you're waiting," said David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, part of the team redesigning the space in the building.
No one involved in the project presumes to say that this concourse will make New Yorkers forget the glory of McKim, Mead & White's original, which was torn down in the early 1960's. But they are quick to note that it will share the quality of bringing daylight and visibility down to track level.
More than esthetics are served by this gesture. It will make it easy for travelers -- particularly those arriving at the station for the first time -- to orient themselves, unlike the current maze, which is closer to a hamster run than a great train shed.
Taking its cue from airports, Amtrak will build pre-boarding lounges on the intermediate concourse level for intercity trains. Commuters will use the lower concourse.
Pennsylvania Station would also become an important destination for air travelers early in the next century, on completion of rail lines planned to link Newark International Airport to Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains and Kennedy International Airport to the Long Island Rail Road.
Just how much the Farley Building project will cost has yet to be determined, since the detailed design work is only now beginning. Earlier estimates put the price tag at $315 million. Officials hope to open the new station in December 2002.
To accommodate the ticketing hall, the Postal Service will move many of its truck docks into a new space below grade on the Ninth Avenue end of the building, reached by ramps paralleling 31st and 33d Streets. To free up the interior courtyard for use as a concourse, the Postal Service will move the letter-carrier sorting stations into workrooms on the Ninth Avenue side.
"What's key is a phasing plan that will allow postal operations to continue," said Rudy Umscheid, vice president of facilities at the Postal Service. "We don't want to compromise mail service during construction. And we don't want to compromise the potential for mail service in the future."
Having said that, he added, "Everyone wants this project to be successful."
FOR their part, state officials have temporarily set aside the idea of building 200,000 square feet of retail space as part of the station, which was proposed to help finance the project. "The short-term compromise will help us achieve a greater development in the future," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the redevelopment agency and its corporate parent, the Empire State Development Corporation. Among other things, that compromise helped pave the way for the Dec. 21 accord.
"It means we are definitely going to move forward," Mr. Gargano said.
Six years have already passed since a plan was first announced to improve Amtrak's passenger areas by building a new concourse in the General Post Office.
"It occurred to me that there was a monumental building that kind of looked like a station right above the platforms," recalled Fred Bartoli, the manager of high-speed rail and facility programs in Amtrak's Metropolitan Division.
What made the idea so appealing was that it offered a kind of redemption for the demolition of the original station. "You don't get a second chance like this often," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
Designed by McKim, Mead & White, the Farley Building opened in 1914 as a companion piece to the station. A Ninth Avenue annex was added in 1935. Above a portico of tree-sized Corinthian columns is inscribed the famous "Neither snow nor rain" motto. The Farley Building was one of the earliest designated landmarks, protected by a law that had been prompted in part by the demolition of the station across the street.
In retrospect, the inscription was a bit of a warning sign. Postal officials are quite attached to the Farley Building; not only because it has vast work floors and dozens of truck bays but because it is a national cynosure, the grandest of the grand old post offices. Some families have worked in the building for two or three generations.
Because it was moving some operations out of Farley to the Morgan General Mail Facility annex at Ninth Avenue and 29th Street, the Postal Service had subscribed nominally to the station expansion plan from the outset. But the path from generalities to specifics turned out to be tortuous.
POSTAL officials were offended by what they regarded as cavalier incursions into their space by people who had no idea how a post office operated. And they resented implications that the General Post Office was inefficient or unnecessary.
"It probably wasn't being utilized to its fullest efficiency," Mr. Umscheid said, "but the fact is that there has been a growth in mail volume and services over time."
Meanwhile, economic development officials and civic leaders were growing impatient with what they saw as bureaucratic intransigence impeding the conversion of an antiquated structure into an urban dynamo.
"Postal Service bureaucrats go, well, they go postal when the plan is mentioned," said a 1997 editorial in The Daily News, whose offices are near the Farley Building.
By late 1997, horns were locked. The Postal Service insisted it could not give up more than one quarter of the Farley Building (350,000 square feet) and the redevelopment agency insisted it would need half.
The Municipal Art Society went so far as to propose emptying Farley of all postal operations except the service windows on Eighth Avenue and turning it into a station, civic center, postal museum and mall.
The White House dispatched Mr. Peck, of the Federal Public Buildings Service, to broker a compromise. "Shuttle diplomacy wasn't working," he said. "It was more like long-range shelling."
In August, the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation designated an architectural and engineering team headed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Parsons Brinckerhoff, with Castro-Blanco Piscioneri & Associates, Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates and Ove Arup & Partners.
A joint management committee was also formed that month, bringing postal officials and state officials to the same table. "There is a different tone now," Mr. Peck said. "They're fully committed."
Both sides credit the architects with helping them find the common ground necessary to apportion the building. "S.O.M. has been key in putting on their wisdom-of-Solomon hats," Mr. Umscheid said.
Marilyn Jordan Taylor, a partner in the Skidmore firm, likened the process to solving a three-dimensional jigsaw puzzle, made easier to solve because "a lot of people in the post office rolled up their sleeves and were ready to take a fresh look."
One big piece of the puzzle was the truck docks on the ground floor, which an earlier redevelopment plan had proposed to eliminate in favor of a pedestrian arcade. "Without the docks, the building has no functional value," said David Eales, the manager of realty assets for the Postal Service.
John D. T. Gerber, senior vice president of the redevelopment corporation, said there was a "great deal of competition" for the ground-floor space.
The solution involves the construction of new loading docks below grade, while keeping some supplemental docks on the ground floor level for extra-long tractor-trailer trucks that could not make a sharp turn on the ramps. Reducing the area of the ground-floor docks will permit construction of a grand ticketing hall.
For the time being, at least, the Postal Service will not be ceding more than 350,000 square feet, although it acknowledges that it may be possible to move other operations out of the Farley Building over time.
"Our plans describe a project of independent utility that we can begin very shortly," said Alexandros E. Washburn, president of the redevelopment corporation. "That doesn't preclude us from weighing options for the eventual reuse of the entire Farley Building.
"Postal operations seem to me more and more a form of transportation," he said. "And what we are basically trying to do is improve transportation for New York City."
An advocacy group called the Committee for Better Transit fears that the Farley concourses may create as many problems as they solve. Among their concerns is that moving Amtrak across Eighth Avenue will make it harder to reach from the Sixth and Seventh Avenue subways, leading in turn to more taxi and auto trips, thereby worsening traffic and air pollution.
Amtrak also has concerns about the mid-block ticketing hall. "It has to look like a main entrance," Mr. Bartoli said. At the same time, it cannot compete too strongly with the renowned Eighth Avenue facade.
The railroad expects some back-and-forth over the arrangement of ticket counters and the location of stairways, elevators and escalators. But it is generally satisfied with the plans drawn up by the redevelopment corporation, Mr. Bartoli said.
Walter R. Ernst, the general manager of Amtrak's Metropolitan Division, recalled that the project could be traced to a need, recognized a decade ago, for better access to the platforms below and more waiting room in the station above. "When the Farley project is completed," he said, "you'll have greatly improved vertical circulation."
"Everybody needs to deal with the problem of making Penn Station better able to handle significant peaking levels of passengers," Mr. Ernst said. Designed for a steady flow of intercity trains through the day, the station was not equipped to handle waves of commuter trains discharging or boarding more than 1,000 passengers at once.
OTHER projects have been undertaken to improve conditions.
* The Long Island Rail Road, which operates 542 of the 882 trains that run through the station every weekday, completed a $190 million renovation in 1994. Designed by TAMS, it includes a new central corridor, a new vaulted ceiling for the connecting corridor and more platform access. A 90-foot-high entrance structure on 34th Street, by R. M. Kliment & Frances Halsband Architects, restored some small sense of the station as an important gateway. The L.I.R.R. also built the West End Concourse to Tracks 13 through 21.
* New Jersey Transit, which operates 219 trains daily, has begun a $105 million waiting room and East End Concourse, to open in 2001. A steel canopy over the concourse, leading to Tracks 1 through 12, is meant to evoke somewhat the look of the old station. The architects are Sverdrup & Parcel.
* Amtrak, which operates 121 trains daily, has begun a $37.5 million renovation of the existing concourse, including three new escalators and a waiting area for passengers boarding the high-speed trains that are to begin running along the Northeast Corridor later this year. The architects are Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum.
All but invisible to passengers is another critical improvement, the $100 million upgrade to a switching and signaling system that was essentially unchanged since the station opened in 1910.
The work done by five control towers in Manhattan and Long Island City, Queens, has been consolidated in a computerized operating "theater" at the Claytor-Scannell Control Center at Ninth Avenue and 31st Street, a joint venture between Amtrak and the L.I.R.R. It opened in 1994.
Dispatchers work at consoles in front of a 70-foot-long illuminated board that shows the position of every train coming into or out of Pennsylvania Station, from Morrisville, Pa., to New Rochelle, N.Y.
Impressive as this center is, it would not be enough in itself. "Whatever is done to improve the signal system goes for nought," Mr. Ernst said, "if you can't deliver people and get them off the platforms quickly."
