SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2413 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
Sewing a Label on a Decade

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Some decades in the life of the business world are easy to label. The 1960's saw a rebellion against the established order. Inflation dominated the 1970's. Deals branded the 1980's. But the 1990's, so far, seem to be the fill-in-the-blank decade.
As the decade opened, Japan was an economic powerhouse, Eastern Europe had its post-World War II borders, Democrats controlled Congress and Republicans ran the White House. By its midpoint, Japan had stumbled, parts of Eastern Europe were a killing field, Republicans controlled Congress and Democrats ran the White House. As the decade ends, Japan is an economic quagmire, Eastern European capitalism is a question mark and it is not clear that anyone controls anything in Washington. 
 Nine people, who view the business world from different vantage points, were invited to name this decade. Their suggestions follow.
One caveat, as Richard H. Jenrette, one of the founders of the investment banking firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: "It ain't over yet."
"At the end of 1928, you would have said the 1920's were the most prosperous decade ever," Mr. Jenrette said. "There is something wonderful about the eighth year; 1988 was the peak of the 1980's, and 1968 was certainly the peak of that decade. But that ninth year -- it can suddenly rise up and bite you."
Even so, Mr. Jenrette calls the 1990's "probably the most prosperous, felicitous overall decade we've had this century." Whatever the decade's ninth year brings, he suspects the future will see the decade as a time when the world began to question the "rugged 'let-the-markets-rule' philosophy" of the 1980's.
"This decade may be the beginning of a kinder, gentler capitalism," he suggested.
"Some funny things happen on the way to the millennium," Mr. Jenrette said, citing the political shifts to the left that have occurred during the decade in Britain, France, Germany and Italy. "And we just had a big swing back toward the Democrats in this country," he added.
What's going on? "I think the world tried the rugged brand of capitalism, and not everybody found it to their liking," he said.
In 1972, Jules B. Kroll, a former prosecutor, founded Kroll Associates, a large corporate detective agency in Manhattan. He is now chief executive of the Kroll-O'Gara Company, a corporate-security concern formed in 1997 by a merger with an armored-car maker.
As Mr. Kroll sees it, the decade has been a flashback to "Network," the 1976 film by Paddy Chayefsky. "You remember that great line, 'I'm as mad as hell, and I'm not going to take this anymore,' " Mr. Kroll said. "Well, I think the 1990's have been like that."
People around the world spent the decade removing their leaders over issues of corruption, he said -- in Brazil, Mexico, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Pakistan and South Korea.
"You can list an extraordinary number of individuals outside the United States who have been removed or forced out by accusations of corruption, proven and unproven," he said. "It seems to be based on people simply saying, 'We've had enough.' "
In the private sector, Mr. Kroll said, the decade has become the era of the megafraud. "Partly that's because there are just more zeros out there -- the economy is so much bigger than it was in the 1980's and everyone is playing with bigger chips."
But the growth in the use of esoteric financial derivatives has also played a role, he argued. "Most boards of directors, most regulators, really don't understand the importance of this derivatives activity," Mr. Kroll said. "It is scary that so few people understand it. It is the advent of these derivatives that has opened the doors to the institution-threatening, and nation-threatening, financial debacle."
For Maria Livanos Cattaui, who helped organize the prestigious World Economic Conference in Davos, Switzerland, and who is now secretary general of the International Chamber of Commerce in Paris, the label for the 1990's "is absolutely obvious: This has been the decade of globalization."
Certainly, the economies of the world have been inching closer since the first caravans set forth centuries ago. "But never has the world been so intensively pulled together," she said. Technology has dramatically altered "the speed with which ideas -- and capital -- can whiz around the world."
In her view, globalization was encouraged by the demise of the Soviet Union in 1991. "That unleashed all the capital and energy that had previously been locked in this global power struggle," she said.
Ms. Cattaui warns against any nostalgia for a less-connected, slower-paced world. "When cars first came in, we didn't have any uniform rules of the road," she said. "Road systems all developed nation by nation, with some driving on the left and some on the right." And after more than a century, there still are no global rules to govern electricity. "You cannot take your computer from home and plug it in anywhere else in the world," she said with a laugh. "The voltage is different, the outlets are different, even the silly plug is different."
By contrast, she argued, today's business leaders and government officials are doing a much better job of developing standards for trade documents, global financial transactions, compatible computer software and international telecommunications.
"Globalization need not mean homogenization, after all," she said. But, she added, it must mean better cooperation among regulators and better communication among corporations about their exposure to risk.
Charles R. Schwab, chairman of the financial-services company that bears his name, said, "I think the dominant theme of this decade is confidence."
With the collapse of the Soviet Union, Americans were freed at last from what he called "that awful, final what-if" -- the nuclear nightmare. "That gave us personal confidence with respect to our own and our families' security."
But the decade has also been marked by growing confidence in "the sustainability of the United States growth story," he said.
That may be based on the broad access to the Internet and the speed with which this technology is spreading, Mr. Schwab said. Already, more than 70 percent of his company's relationships and contacts with customers have been over the Internet -- "up from zip a few years ago."
But the can-do spirit he sees as dominating the decade cannot obscure the battle lines that stretch into the future, running between "the high-tech and the high-touch" approaches to business growth, he said.
Seen from the 1990's, he said, the future belongs to "the firms that get that balance right -- providing high-tech service but also helping people, face-to-face."
To Nicholas Negroponte, the 1990's may turn out to be the decade when both nations and corporations began to go the way of the buggy whip.
Co-founder and director of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Professor Negroponte is a pioneer in the application of computer technology to everyday life and the author of the 1995 best seller "Being Digital" (Knopf).
In an interview by E-mail, he called the 1990's "the digital decade." From the emergence of the Internet to the Year 2000 computer bug, "it is a decade where the biggest asset is having none."
He explained, "The energy, people, spaces and vehicles needed to move physical things from country to country are suddenly a liability in an age of weightless, sizeless, colorless bits which move at the speed of light."
As he sees it, the bits of electronic information "make the world very small, borders truly meaningless and territory almost irrelevant."
Professor Negroponte also sees the face of the future in the "shockingly high" valuation the stock market is putting on new technology companies with little revenue. It is, he said, "a future that tells us today that we are clueless about who will be our competition."
But while investors may be in for a roller coaster ride, the professor is optimistic: "We're in a decade which is the first hint of people belonging to a single planet. Kids born today will grow up feeling like global citizens way much more than adults do today."
"Children will be the agents of change," he added. "A kid's grasp of the digital world will look and feel genetic."
But it may be the old, not the young, who give the 1990's their defining label, in the view of Richard C. Leone, president of the Century Foundation, formerly the Twentieth Century Fund, a public policy research foundation in Manhattan.
For Mr. Leone, what is "new under the sun" in this decade is the aging of the world's population, thanks to improvements in public health and a dramatic drop in birth rates.
Mr. Leone, the former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and former president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, thinks this graying of the population will challenge both government and business.
For government, "the key issue is the same issue we had when the baby boomers were young," he said. "The things that the young and the old need are things that we once tended to supply with public money. But that will be harder in the future," especially for nations that do not yet have a secure social safety net.
For business, the global graying will present big opportunities for those that guess correctly about the aging population's preferences. "With everyone living longer, attitudes about the importance of saving and investment are going to proliferate," he predicted. "Anything to do with aging and the extension of vitality and vigor into one's later years will see dynamic growth."
Bruce Wasserstein, chief executive of Wasserstein Perella Group, thinks the dominant theme of the 1990's has been its volatility.
While Mr. Wasserstein, one of the leading dealmeisters of the last decade, agreed that globalization and technology have left their imprint, he said they came mixed in with "immense frustration and false gods."
"A lot of the foundations here are not as strong as one would think," he added. "There are a lot of false leads."
He pointed to the exuberant bidding for Internet stocks when, "in fact, the Internet may be technologically obsolete." In the course of the same decade, Japan was hailed as a triumph and then collapsed.
More recently, he said people optimistically "assumed a legal system in Russia that doesn't exist." He added, "It is quite a remarkable period."
While Mr. Wasserstein is hopeful that the world has changed for the better, he noted that "if you are in Brazil right now, it may not look that way."
"In many of the emerging markets, the glory of an entire decade has been wiped out in the last few months," he said.
As for Wall Street, the 1990's were the beginning of "the new era of consolidation," he said. With stock and bond offerings sold globally and with mergers valued in the billions, he added, Wall Street is likely to become a place where only about five giant firms will survive. "The problem is, there are about 30 people who think that they are 1 of the 5."
Esther Dyson is a computer industry consultant and venture capitalist and the publisher of Release 1.0, an industry newsletter. For her, the 1990's will go down in history as the decade when the Internet started to be taken for granted.
"A major issue of the decade was that we got wired," she said. "We got connected."
As Ms. Dyson sees it, the advent of the Internet trumps all the other changes the decade has seen. "Globalization, the backlash to globalization, the inevitability of globalization; the diminishing importance of the nation state, the rise of the tribe, on the one hand, and the corporation on the other -- the Internet makes a difference to all of those," she said. "Those changes are, in one sense, being pushed by the Internet."
While people always learn and adopt new technologies more slowly than cyberspace pioneers expect, Ms. Dyson thinks the Internet has unleashed wholly unappreciated changes in society. "The Internet permits people to communicate in a more decentralized way" by using a tool that is far more accessible than, say, a television station or newspaper, she said.
"The personal computer and the Internet put the means of production in the hands of individuals," Ms. Dyson explained. "Businesses are motivated primarily to make a profit, but individuals are motivated by other things, too. I think more people want to do good, and just get ground down. So if you're given a tool to resist that pressure, the world might be very slightly better."
The historian David Hackett Fischer of Brandeis University thinks the 1990's may be the decade when a century-long surge in inflation finally faltered and stopped.
In his book "The Great Wave: Price Revolutions and the Rhythm of History" (Oxford University Press, 1996), Professor Fischer suggested that European history has been shaped by four great waves of inflation, the first climaxing in the mid-14th century and the most recent beginning in 1896 and continuing into this decade, with the 1930's a mere pothole in the upward path. It is this last long inflationary wave that may have begun to break in the 1990's.
"We've seen a very deep change in the dynamics of price movements," he said. "This is not the usual flutters, but something more profound."
Professor Fischer attributes this apparent shift to a worldwide decline in the rate of population growth coupled with a decline in military spending after the end of the cold war.
According to him, the transition from inflation to price equilibrium in the past has been a time of severe crisis -- and, indeed, he said, just such a crisis has been unfolding in recent years, with the shattering changes in the former Soviet Union and economic and social strains elsewhere.
Who wins and loses when prices finally stabilize? In the past, Professor Fischer said, the losers have included the world's farmers, as commodity prices fell, and the lending classes, which earned very low interest on their capital. On the other hand, businesses could borrow cheaply, pensioners were more secure and workers' wages stretched further, helping to close the gap between rich and poor.
"We have thought the world's recent troubles were caused by a monetary crisis in Thailand that spread to other nations," he concluded. "But most people have missed the demographic factors entirely. We have to look beyond economics to history and demographics to understand what's happening."

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 798 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- TOBACCO;
Companies Refocus Efforts As the Litigation Cloud Lifts

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Cigarette makers are starting this year relieved of their biggest financial and legal threat but still not free of the uncertainty that has recently hovered over the industry.
In November, producers and 46 states, including many that had filed lawsuits against the industry to recover health care costs related to smoking, settled those actions in a package worth $206 billion over 25 years. 
 Producers had previously reached similar settlements with the four other states totaling $40 billion over 25 years.
The plans, under which producers also agreed to certain marketing restrictions, such as a ban on tobacco billboards, brought to a close a cycle of litigation that once threatened to bankrupt the industry. But the deals did not satisfy the anti-smoking groups, which wanted stronger measures like Federal regulation of nicotine, and other lawsuits may continue to plague the industry.
"The single biggest litigation threat has receded," said Martin Feldman, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "But tobacco will remain a difficult social issue, and the residual litigation risk will be of concern to investors."
Mary Aronson, the president of Aronson Washington Research, which advises institutional investors on tobacco litigation risks, said that state lawsuits were just part of a "snowstorm" of legal problems that have fallen on the industry in recent years.
Still continuing are a Justice Department investigation into possible criminal wrongdoing by producers, individual cases brought by smokers and a class-action case, now under way in Miami, that was brought on behalf of all Florida smokers.
There are also assaults from abroad. Nicaragua filed suit in Puerto Rico last month, seeking to recoup the cost of treating sick smokers, and Brazil has threatened to sue as well. Guatemala brought a similar action in Washington last spring.
But such matters, both Ms. Aronson and Mr. Feldman agreed, pose a lesser threat than the state lawsuits did, and industry officials are turning their attention away from the courthouse and back to their businesses.
"The settlement allows the companies to operate in an atmosphere of greater stability," Mr. Feldman said.
The cigarette producers that participated in the plan are the Philip Morris Companies; R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, a subsidiary of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation; Lorillard Tobacco, a unit of the Loews Corporation, and Brown & Williamson Tobacco, which is owned by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C.
The nation's fifth-largest cigarette maker, Liggett & Myers, a subsidiary of the Brooke Group, also joined in, at the 11th hour, and U.S. Tobacco, which is owned by UST Inc., the nation's largest producer of smokeless tobacco, settled with all states except Massachusetts.
Financially, the biggest test for the industry will be the effect of recent price increases on smoking rates. Soon after the signing of the settlement, both Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds increased prices 45 cents a pack at the wholesale level, passing along the settlement's cost to smokers.
Some analysts are speculating that the price increase could reduce cigarette consumption by 6 percent to 8 percent.
Others, like Mr. Feldman, say that while the price increase is not likely to make many smokers quit the habit, it may cause them to reduce the number of cigarettes they smoke each day.
Michael E. Szymanczyk, the chief executive of Philip Morris U.S.A., said in a recent interview that he had little idea how the price increase would affect consumption.
While analysts believe that Philip Morris will continue to consolidate its position as market leader, the biggest winner from the tobacco settlement may be Liggett & Myers.
Unlike its larger competitors, Liggett, as part of a last-minute deal with attorneys general, was essentially given a free ride to participate in the $206 billion settlement plan. The company will not have to contribute to the settlement unless its future sales exceed 1997 levels by 125 percent. And that outcome is all but impossible because the company, just before signing the plan, sold three of its cigarette brands, representing some 14 percent of its sales, to Philip Morris.
As a result, Liggett can raise its prices, too, without feeling any of the pain of having to give up any revenues to the states.
Paul Klemperer, an economist at Oxford University, recently estimated that even if Liggett & Myers loses some sales when it raises its prices, it will still collect an additional $100 million a year, a sum equal to its recent market value.
Investors apparently also see a boom for the company. In late November, when states approved the $206 billion pact, the stock of the Brooke Group, long an industry laggard, shot up nearly 60 percent in a single day's trading.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- AUTOMOBILES;
Car Makers Predict Strong Sales This Year

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Global slowdowns in the auto industry have consistently started in the United States, which accounts for nearly a third of worldwide demand. But that pattern, which dates back to the end of World War II, seems to have been broken in the last year as plunging sales in Asia and South America have hurt auto makers around the globe.
The question now is whether sales will stay strong in North America, and whether the European auto market will remain vigorous despite recent hints of weakness, particularly in Germany. 
 Most auto executives are still expressing optimism for 1999. But difficulties in North America or Europe, the world's two biggest markets in terms of sales, would create serious problems for multinational auto makers.
The industry's health is important because highly variable auto sales tend to be a leading indicator of recessions. Auto manufacturing accounts for about 4 percent of economic output in the United States, for instance. The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are the world's two largest companies in terms of sales and share of global economic output, although the planned acquisition of the Mobil Corporation by Exxon would produce an even bigger company if antitrust regulators do not require the combined enterprise to sell significant parts of their businesses.
For now, auto executives are watching low unemployment rates and low interest rates in Western industrialized countries and concluding that 1999 will be a fairly good year. "If you look at the world today, there are only two areas that look strong, but they happen to be the two biggest," said John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of General Motors.
G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler A.G. are predicting a sixth consecutive year of high sales of around 15 million cars, sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans in the United States -- a remarkable streak of level sales in an industry that until the current boom had never managed more than two successive years of roughly identical sales.
Auto executives in Europe are slightly less bullish about 1999 than their American counterparts, though they are not gloomy. "We will see a possible slowdown but we definitely don't see a recession in 1999, as far as the United States and Europe are concerned," said Jurgen E. Schrempp, the German co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler.
But outside the United States and Europe, there is a definite pall. The domestic Japanese auto market has been moribund since 1990. Auto sales in smaller markets in Southeast Asia and Latin America have fallen as much as 70 percent, compelling auto makers to furlough workers and postpone investment plans made as recently as two years ago.
Some analysts worry that the optimism in Detroit may be misplaced, given the troubles overseas. Prosperity at home "gives us the mind-set things haven't changed," said Paul D. Ballew, chief economist at J. D. Power & Associates, the automotive consulting company.
Yet in truth, he added, "we are in the midst of a global slump."
The precise level of worldwide auto sales is hard to calculate because some developing countries provide statistics late, if at all. But auto makers release detailed figures for worldwide auto production, which match up closely with sales. The final worldwide tally is likely to show a 12.8 percent drop in 1998, and a further 1.5 percent decline in 1999, according to estimates by J. D. Power.
The biggest financial damage has been to Japanese and South Korean auto makers, which face weak markets at home and were making the most aggressive efforts to expand in Asia before that region became the epicenter of global currency and economic problems. The Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea has already bought control of the insolvent Kia Motors Corporation, another Korean producer. Now auto makers around the world are following the struggle of the Nissan Motor Company, which was forced in November to negotiate a 100 billion yen ($817 million) loan from the Government-run Japan Development Bank.
Asian auto makers are also suffering because they are strongest in small cars, the segment of the global auto market hurt by an enormous excess of assembly plants. Auto makers around the world have the capacity to build 70 million vehicles a year of all sizes for an international market of 50 million vehicles, and most of the overcapacity is in small cars.
But while small-car factories are being closed or are running shorter hours, factories that produce sport utility vehicles and other light trucks are typically running around the clock and are still unable to keep up with demand. American auto makers own most of the world's sport utility vehicle production capacity, particularly for larger, high-profit models. These models have become very popular in the United States and, to a lesser extent, in foreign markets as gasoline prices have fallen in inflation-adjusted terms.
G.M. and Ford survived in the early 1980's partly because of profits from their international operations, while foreign auto makers used their profits overseas to build up American subsidiaries. But as Asian and South American markets crumble and the European market looks a little shaky, the North American market has turned into a bastion of profits for the auto industry.
"Now the shoe is on the other foot -- North America is carrying virtually everybody else," said William Clay Ford Jr., Ford's chairman. "We are very dependent on North American profits, and particularly our North American truck profits."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1447 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY --;
World Economies On a Tightrope

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Last fall, with global financial markets imploding and recession fears rampant, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told a group of business forecasters that he had been "looking at the American economy on a day-by-day basis for almost half a century" but had "never seen anything like this."
Not even Mr. Greenspan could have foreseen the chain reaction that began with a currency crisis in tiny Thailand. Who would have thought that stock markets as distant as Moscow, Rio de Janeiro and New York would tumble like dominoes? Or that an avalanche of bankruptcies and the near collapse of the high-flying hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management would follow and credit markets around the world would virtually freeze up? Or that a series of three modest interest-rate reductions by the Fed -- and similar actions by its counterparts abroad -- would restore calm and confidence in a matter of weeks? 
 Predicting the economy's ups and downs has always been tricky.
History is full of famously wrong forecasts, from the economist Irving Fisher's assertions throughout the Depression that recovery was imminent, to Mr. Greenspan's statements two months after the 1990 recession began that chances of a downturn were minimal.
A 25-year study by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private group in Cambridge, Mass., concludes that growth estimates for the year ahead typically err by 100 percent or more and that, computer age or no, they have become no more accurate over time.
Last year, when economists were sure a slowdown was in the works, proved a case in point: growth was much faster and inflation and unemployment stayed much lower than predicted.
What now? The economic expansion that began in 1991 is about to become the second-longest since America entered the industrial age in the late 19th century. This alone suggests that the likelihood of recession is rising, but almost no one is predicting one in the foreseeable future. And even economists at J. P. Morgan, one of the few bears, say such a downturn will be "the shortest and mildest recession we've ever had."
In fact, most economists say that this year is going to look the way they thought 1998 would look. Growth is supposed to slow sharply, profits to shrink, inflation to creep up, unemployment to edge up a bit. The Blue Chip consensus of 50 forecasters expects growth to slow to 2.2 percent, compared with 3.7 percent last year, and inflation to accelerate to 2.2 percent from 1.6 percent last year.
Sure, they may be wrong. But that is exactly the kind of soft landing that Mr. Greenspan and other central bankers have been hoping for.
Three forces, economists say, may bring it about: a sluggish world economy, a growing profit squeeze and a less than ebullient stock market. The unsettled global economy should continue to drag down growth in the United States. Merrill Lynch expects growth in the 45 biggest economies to slow to just over 1.25 percent, from 3.5 percent in 1997 and 1.75 percent in 1998.
Asia's economies, which absorb a third of American exports, are likely to keep shrinking, though not as fast as last year -- assuming that Japan will hit bottom. South America, which accounts for one-tenth of American exports, will merely stagnate as long as Brazil doesn't collapse; growth for the continent should be around 1 percent. Mexico, as big a trading partner as South America and struggling with the effects of plunging oil prices, is already slowing. As monetary union begins, Europe will be growing about 2 percent, down from nearly 3 percent last year. Some of the biggest risks from abroad continue to be financial.
Unexpectedly aggressive easing by the Federal Reserve and foreign central banks has reduced but not eliminated the global liquidity squeeze. Even now, AAA-rated corporate bonds are still more than 2 percentage points over Treasury bonds, only slightly below the recent peak spread of 2.25 points.
"While equity markets are roaring ahead, credit markets are still depressed," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "That will slow growth because the marginal borrower is not able to get credit."
A growing pinch on corporate profits, already under way in the last six months, is also likely to retard growth. Per-share operating profits for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index are down 3 percent from a year ago. Total corporate profits reported by the Commerce Department are also lower than a year ago.
Profit margins are beginning to erode, and there is no relief in sight. The problem is that incredibly tight labor markets -- unemployment is now 4.4 percent and job growth remains solid -- have been pushing wages up faster than robust productivity gains. Thus, labor costs per unit of output have been rising inexorably. With lots of excess capacity at home and abroad, a result of the 1990's investment boom, most companies are finding it impossible to pass along higher costs to customers.
"There's no pricing power out there in corporate America right now," Mr. Steinberg said.
Finally, the stock market is not likely to give the economy much extra kick, the way it has in recent years. Although stock prices no longer look as outrageously high as they did a year ago, somewhat lowering the risk of a plunge, few forecasters expect American households to keep reaping the huge capital gains that have propelled spending faster than income.
Economists expect these forces to affect individual parts of the economy in various ways. The trade deficit will continue to widen, but, barring another international crisis like last summer's, the deterioration is not likely to be as sharp as it was in the last year, when it shaved 1.5 percentage points from growth. This is in part because slower growth in business and consumer spending means less of a surge in imports.
Capital spending, booming in the first half of last year, has already flattened. Most economists are predicting sluggish growth, but not outright cuts in spending, in the 12 months ahead.
One factor that may cause spending to keep rising is that capital is a bargain right now. "I can buy more," said Ken Matheny, an economist at Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis.
Government has not contributed much to spending in the last few years, and 1999 will be no exception, despite a small lift from the $500-per-child tax credit and the emergency spending measure passed in October to skirt the spending caps.
Consumers, who have been spending all their income and more, are due to behave in a more restrained manner. They have been on a tear, with car sales stronger last year than at any other time in the last decade. Most economists expect consumer spending to grow about 2.5 percent this year, about half of last year's pace and roughly in line with income growth. One reason is that job growth is apt to slow as the profit picture continues to darken.
But Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board, one of the most bullish forecasting groups last year, says consumers will surprise forecasters once more. He says last fall's rash of layoff announcements by Fortune 500 companies has led to an exaggerated sense of how fast the labor market is weakening.
"The hullabaloo about layoffs is ridiculous," Mr. Goldstein said. Most job cuts since 1991 have been by attrition, he added. And first-time claims for unemployment insurance were no higher in December than they were a year earlier.
The red-hot housing market is also set to cool. It is still in great shape, with new construction of single-family homes running at their most rapid pace in 20 years. But few people expect mortgage rates, already the lowest in a generation, to keep falling, so fewer families will be refinancing. And fewer families will be cashing in stock market gains to renovate or trade up. Besides, housing starts have been outpacing family formation for several years.
With all the uncertainties, the only sure thing is that things will not turn out precisely as predicted.
Kenneth J. Arrow, a Nobel laureate in economic science, likes to tell his students the story of a group of statisticians (of which he was one) in the Pentagon during World War II who were responsible for forecasting the number of rainy days in Europe a month ahead of time. At some point, the statisticians concluded that the forecasts were worthless and asked Gen. Henry H. (Hap) Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, for permission to stop making them. After a few weeks the following reply came from General Arnold: "The commanding general is well aware that the forecasts are no good. However, he has to have them for planning purposes."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY -- ADVERTISING;
Madison Avenue Waltzes to the Beat of the Market Share Drum

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
A year ago, Madison Avenue was asking: Will 1998 be as busy a year for agency and account acquisitions and consolidations as 1996 and 1997 were?
Now, after enduring another frenetic 12 months, Madison Avenue is asking another question: How could anyone have even asked that question? As a result, few are asking the question about 1999; the tumult of the last three years is widely expected to keep on keeping on. 
 "The pace of acquisitions will continue," said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst who follows advertising for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "Some of that stems from the large agencies' need for market share growth that clients alone can't satisfy.
"And if you get market share growth," she added, "that can stave off any uncertainties about what clients will do" about their ad budgets for the new year.
Edward H. Vick, president and chief operating officer at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, echoed Ms. Fine. "The consolidation of agencies is not over by any means," he said. "There's no doubt the multinational communications companies will continue to get bigger and stronger."
As mergermania rages, said Edward H. Meyer, chairman, president and chief executive at Grey Advertising in New York, "we're all focusing much more of our attention on marketing services" outside the realm of traditional advertising like direct marketing, sales promotion and media buying.
"We've made three acquisitions in the media business in the last year," Mr. Meyer added, "and we're in there trying to buy whatever is still around."
James Dougherty, advertising industry analyst at Prudential Securities in New York, said he agreed that deals in marketing services "and other specialty communications will clearly continue."
That will come, he added, as spending for advertising and marketing campaigns remains relatively strong.
Despite dislocations in local economies, "I think the advertising industry's rolling," Mr. Dougherty said. "While there are some soft pockets, there are no really serious signs that conditions in 1999 will be materially different from 1998."
The primary reason he gave was that "you now have a real engine of growth in the United States," where ad spending is rising at a higher rate than overseas.
"One percent growth in the United States," Mr. Dougherty said, "is worth a lot of Taiwans." America is the world's largest single advertising market.
"Marketers, the guys who make stuff, have already gone through growing profits by lowering costs and saving money," said Alan J. Gottesman, managing director at West End Communications/Consulting in New York.
"Now the way to grow profits has shifted from saving more to earning more," he added, "and the way to earn more is to sell more stuff."
Enter advertising.
"That will drive marketing service companies' revenues over the next couple of years," Mr. Gottesman predicted.
"It's almost like saying, 'The answer is up; what was the question?' " he said, chuckling.
Michael Russell, an advertising industry analyst for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York, listed three reasons he was optimistic about ad spending in the United States.
One is "the continuing thrust from the pharmaceutical industry," he said, to advertise prescription drugs directly to consumers. The second is the growing number of campaigns to discourage smoking that are sponsored by state and Federal governments. The third reason is the rising demand for Internet advertising.
"The Internet is not interesting as a percentage of total ad spending," Mr. Russell said, "because it seems to be 1 percent for every business. But its very growth makes it interesting."
Mr. Vick at Y.& R. said he believed that "the rate at which electronic commerce transactions take place on the Web will triple by the end of next year."
"That's not only because of the technological explosion," he added, "but because people will finally realize their Visa is no less secure on line than at the Gap."
Some anticipate that conditions for the advertising industry will improve further in the final months of 1999 as the year 2000 approaches.
"You'll have an Olympics and a Presidential election in 2000," Mr. Dougherty of Prudential said, both of which stimulate demand for commercial time and ad space, "and the millennium on top of that."
Mr. Meyer at Grey is also bullish on the millennium, predicting that it will generate significant spending in the form of contests, sweepstakes and other promotional pitches.
As for what advertisers will tell consumers about 2000, "the messages will run the gamut," Mr. Meyer said, "from boring seriousness to outrageous mockery."
Hmm. In other words, not unlike advertising before the millennium.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- PHARMACEUTICALS;
Investors Study Drug Pipelines for the Next Blockbuster Medicine

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
The successful introduction last year of Pfizer Inc.'s Viagra, the impotency pill, delivered huge returns to investors who bought shares in the company. The windfall -- Pfizer's stock zoomed 68 percent in the year -- has encouraged investors to study the current pipelines of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, hoping to spot the next boom drug.
They and analysts alike are betting that at least one of the medications scheduled for introduction this year will also produce impressive gains. 
 Predicting the next blockbuster drug is never easy because pharmaceutical executives are loath to forecast the sales of their wares. But some compounds clearly have a better chance than others of achieving $1 billion in annual sales, the benchmark for a blockbuster drug.
Analysts agree that top-selling drugs share two common traits: they have to be prescribed by more than one type of doctor, ideally a general practitioner and a specialist, and treat an illness that is sorely lacking in new remedies.
Not only was Viagra prescribed by several types of doctors, including urologists and psychiatrists; it was offered in pill form, making it a popular alternative to the invasive shots of other impotency medications.
That formula for a winning drug should work this year as well, but with one major twist. Many of last year's hot new remedies -- Viagra and Detrol, Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc.'s pill for incontinence -- were so-called life style drugs, designed to relieve afflictions that damage self-esteem. This year's top-selling new medications are expected to treat several chronic or life-threatening conditions, including diabetes and organ transplant rejection.
The two most anticipated introductions this year are the Monsanto Company's Celebrex, which Pfizer is helping to market, and Vioxx by Merck & Company. Both drugs will treat the pain and inflammation of arthritis and are expected to be free of the gastrointestinal side effects of other medications.
This market is projected to be enormous, rivaling the $7.4 billion in antidepressant sales. About 13,000 Americans take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs each year, according to Merck. Yet, these drugs are not always safe; according to arthritis experts at Stanford University, they cause 20,000 hospitalizations and 2,600 deaths each year.
While the first product to market usually gets the largest market share -- in this case, that will most likely be Celebrex -- both drugs are expected to record strong sales. Analysts predict that Celebrex will have $3 billion in annual sales and Vioxx $2 billion by 2002.
"The peak sales of these drugs may not happen quickly," said Neil Sweig, a pharmaceuticals analyst with Southeast Research Partners. "It could take four to five years after the drugs are introduced in the United States."
As a supplement to the search for blockbusters, and in an effort to maintain annual earnings gains of 16 percent or more, many pharmaceutical companies are introducing drugs for markets that have been profitable.
Traditionally, the industry's cash machines are ulcer drugs, which can easily bring in annual sales of $1.5 billion or more.
The American Home Products Corporation and Johnson & Johnson are expected to roll out their respective ulcer drugs, Protonix and Aciphex. Even though the ulcer market already has several players, including Astra A.B.'s Prilosec, with $2.3 billion in annual sales, both new entrants are expected to be very successful. Analysts expect Protonix to bring in an annual $400 million in 2002, when Aciphex is expected to have sales of $800 million.
The market for diabetes drugs, which has long been competitive, should be vicious by the end of the year. SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. is expected to release Avandia, a drug that may siphon sales from the three leading medications, Glucophage by the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Glucotrol XL by Pfizer and the Warner-Lambert Company's Rezulin.
Analysts expect that Avandia will have annual sales of $755 million and that the sum could be higher if patients decided to switch from the leading medications.
Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. will introduce Ziagen to treat H.I.V. infection. Analysts expect the drug to have $450 million in annual sales.
American Home Products is set to introduce Rapamune for organ transplant rejection, a use that should generate some $750 million in sales.
The Schering-Plough Corporation and Zonagen, a tiny Texas biotechnology company, are expected to begin marketing Vasomax, a competitor to Pfizer's Viagra.
Unlike Viagra, which analysts predict will have $1 billion in sales during its first year on the market, Vasomax is not expected to surpass $500 million in annual sales during its first four years on the market. But it may usher in this year's crop of drugs to address everything from age spots to facial hair on women.
"We're really just beginning this phase of life style drugs," said Viren Mehta, a partner at Mehta Partners, a biopharmaceutical investment research company in New York.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING -- COMMODITIES;
Good News for Consumers Is Bad for Many Exporters

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Oil is about $12 a barrel, near its lowest level in 12 years. Copper is 66 cents a pound, its lowest price in 11 years. Aluminum is $1,241 a metric ton, the least expensive it has been in almost five years, and, like other commodities, still falling in price. The major commodity indexes are at or near their lowest levels in more than two decades. And analysts are not predicting a turnaround soon.
That's great for consumers. Gasoline prices, adjusted for inflation, are the lowest they have been since the 1950's. Those low prices are even better than a tax cut at stimulating spending, economists say, and they have been a major contributor to the continuing decline in inflation here and in other developed economies. 
 "No doubt, the collapse of commodity prices provided an important spur to U.S. disinflation," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. He is forecasting an inflation rate of just 1 percent this year.
But low commodity prices are bad for much of the developing world -- for Russia, Chile, Mexico, Indonesia, Malaysia and Zambia. And they are not so good for some major developed nations, including Australia, New Zealand and Canada.
These countries depend on commodity sales to spur economic growth, and many of them also count on the revenue to pay for a major portion of their government spending. The price declines mean they have less of both.
Russia and Latin America will be especially hard hit. About 60 percent of Russia's export earnings are from oil, natural gas and precious and base metals. And a major portion of the revenue for the Russian budget comes from these sales and taxes on them. In Latin America, 50 percent of Venezuela's government revenue, 30 percent of Mexico's and 25 percent of Ecuador's come from oil.
The collapse in commodity prices since October 1997 has been dramatic and has been one of the major ways the Asian financial crisis, which began in Thailand in July 1997, has spread around the world. The collapse of the economies in Asia, whose people had been major consumers of oil, copper, timber, cotton, textiles and other commodities, sent prices tumbling.
Since the autumn of 1997, prices have plunged 45 percent for oil, 44 percent for natural gas and 30 percent for copper.
"I have no optimism about the demand for industrial commodities in the first half of 1999," said William O'Neill, director of futures research at Merrill Lynch. And, he added, the recovery will be "a long, slow process."
Neal Shear, head of commodities trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, is even more pessimistic. He said that commodity prices will be "in a flat to lower trend" this year. His reason: He does not expect demand to recover.
He thinks the economies in Europe will be flat and growth in the United States will slow, and he adds, "Asia will not recover in 1999."
He also worries that there is a chance commodities may fall further if market psychology leads to the kind of overselling that often occurs when prices are on a long decline.
What also could help delay a recovery in commodity prices is a rebound in the strength of the dollar, which fell 7.1 percent against the German mark and 12.8 percent against the Japanese yen last year. Most of those declines came in the last five months of the year.
Major commodities, like oil, are priced in dollars. This means, for one thing, that when the dollar weakens against the yen, oil prices in yen are lower for the Japanese. If the dollar rebounds, commodity prices are likely to rise for those spending yen and other Asian currencies, slowing the revival of demand in Asia that is ultimately crucial to any commodity rebound.
The cutting of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, in an effort to stabilize financial markets and prevent the American economy from falling into a recession, helped weaken the dollar at the end of last year. The unwinding of special hedge fund trades involving the yen, as investors panicked in the wake of the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, also sent the dollar sharply lower against the Japanese currency.
But the dollar has not lost value against all foreign currencies, which means commodity prices will get less of a boost than might be apparent from looking only at the mark and the yen.
The dollar has remained strong against the currencies of two of America's biggest trading partners, Canada and Mexico. Over all, the trade-weighted dollar -- computed by measuring the strength of the American currency in relation to currencies of the country's chief trading partners -- still rose last year. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, the trade-weighted dollar was up almost 1 percent through October.
And although most analysts expect further rate cuts by the Fed, some economists expect the dollar to stay at current levels or rally this year. One reason is that the United States will still be attractive to investors because it will be performing well in comparison to the rest of the world.
"The world is full of dollar bears right now," said Karen E. Parker, the currency strategist at Chase Securities. "But the U.S. economy is in a relatively good position. Asia is not recovering, Japan is in a recession and the recovery in Europe is more fragile than some think."
And if that is the case, then a rebound in commodity prices will not get an assist from the dollar.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING;
Foreign Stocks Are Down But Aren't Necessarily Out

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
What good is diversification, anyway?
After years of injury, watching the nation's stocks handily outperform foreign stocks, owners of globally diversified equity portfolios last year suffered the insult of seeing the value of nearly all their investments decline during the summer downturn. When the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 12 percent in the third quarter, stocks in places like Japan, Switzerland and Mexico also fell, offering investors little, if any, downside protection. 
 Last year was not the only year in which diversification seemed to provide little value. Over the last three years, investors whose portfolios contained only United States stocks would have had better returns with less volatility, according to the Frank Russell Company, a Tacoma, Wash., money-management and investment-advisory concern. Those investors would have seen average annual returns of 27 percent through November, compared with gains of 21 percent for people who put a third of their money in a mix of foreign stocks.
Small wonder, then, that a lot of people are questioning the notion of diversification. Many individual investors are already shunning overseas stocks, putting the bulk of their retirement funds in domestic stocks. Even some professional investors are throwing in the towel.
"Financial advisers seem to be abandoning this idea as fast as clients," said Paul O. Solli, managing director of Financial Design Associates, an investment advisory firm in Larkspur, Calif. And some institutional investors, like pension funds, have been slow to rebalance their portfolios by taking money away from the booming domestic market and moving it overseas.
The events of the last year have clearly underscored the limits of diversification. With the domestic markets soaring, despite a few drops along the way, any foreign exposure has tended to reduce the overall returns. "It's the ugly side of diversification," said George U. Sauter, a managing director for the Vanguard Group, the giant mutual fund company. And when a global shock like Russia's bond default occurred, the tremors were felt everywhere.
But proponents of diversification say that the last few years have been atypical. "It's been an exceptionally unusual run in U.S. equities," said Ernest M. Ankrim, the director of portfolio research for the investment management business at Frank Russell.
Even the most troubling aspect of the last few years -- world markets that moved together, defeating the whole purpose of diversification -- may be a short-lived phenomenon, according to David Harding, director of global investments for Nicholas-Applegate, an investment firm based in San Diego. "You have had these periods where there is higher correlation, and they have not lasted," he said. For example, correlations between domestic stocks and their foreign counterparts rose for a while, and then dropped in 1987 and 1993.
Outside the United States, few need convincing that diversification still makes sense. Asian investors who put some of their money in the United States market or some of the European markets clearly benefited.
"If you ask an investor in Singapore, he would reply that it worked," Mr. Harding said.
Diversification also makes sense because no one anywhere knows what the future will bring. While the United States market has lately been the best performer, it is unlikely to keep beating other markets, analysts say. During other periods, foreign stocks have performed better than domestic stocks: Over the 10 years ended Dec. 31, 1992, for instance, the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe, Australasia, Far East index, or EAFE, gained an average of 17.1 percent a year, versus 15.4 percent annual returns for the Wilshire 5000 index, a broad index of the domestic market.
"If you look back in history, there is no one asset that dominates consistently," said Arthur A. Micheletti, the chief economic and investment strategist for Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a money-management firm in San Mateo, Calif.
When will diversification become popular again among American investors? The probable answer is only after they have watched their solidly domestic portfolios trail foreign stocks -- which strategists say could be sooner rather than later.
"To abandon diversification in this environment," said Mr. Ankrim of Frank Russell, "would be the poorest decision."

SECTION: Section C; Page 10; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- THE BUDGET;
How to Spend a Long-Sought Surplus

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In 1997, Congress and the Clinton Administration agreed on a five-year plan to balance the Federal budget.
In 1998, they watched in surprise as the deficit disappeared ahead of schedule and the nation entered what should be a long era of surpluses.
In 1999, Congress and the Administration will debate in earnest for the first time what to do with the fiscal windfall, which the Congressional Budget Office estimates should total $1.55 trillion over the next decade. 
 They can use the money to help shore up the Social Security system. They can use it for tax cuts. They can use it to increase spending on education, health care, the military and other politically popular programs. Or they can use it to pay down the $5.5 trillion national debt accumulated over decades of deficit spending.
But if the options are clear cut, budget politics this year are likely to be more muddled than usual, even if the focus has shifted from the belt-tightening of the deficit years to dividing up the spoils generated by a strong economy and excess tax revenue.
"For the last 18 years the goal of fiscal policy was clear: to reduce the deficit," said Thomas D. Gallagher, a political economist at Lehman Brothers in Washington. "Now there's no clear goal for fiscal policy. This will be the hardest year to anticipate the outcome of the policy debate, and a hard year for the markets to interpret what's going on."
In addition to the usual ideological and interest group politics that shape the debate over tax and spending priorities, both parties will be keeping a close eye on the economy. If growth slows substantially and unemployment rises, Republicans are likely to step up calls for a tax cut to give the economy some fiscal stimulus and Democrats are likely to call for additional spending on unemployment insurance, job retraining and other social programs to help ease the impact of any downturn.
Barring a sharp economic downturn, though, the budget debate will center on Social Security. With the retirement system heading toward insolvency in 2032, according to the latest Government projections, the Administration and Congressional leaders are looking for solutions among a host of ideologically charged and politically sensitive proposals.
At stake is not just Social Security's long-term health, but the budget agenda for 1999. In a move that even Republicans concede was brilliant politics, Mr. Clinton demanded early last year that Congress set aside any surpluses until the nation had dealt with Social Security -- a formulation that stymied Republican efforts to use the surpluses to finance tax cuts.
Democrats, too, have been itching to get at the surplus. After years of being told that social programs had to be curtailed in the interests of bringing down the deficit, they have a long list of priorities that they say deserve more money, especially education, child care and help for people moving off welfare.
Working out agreements that can pass a Republican Congress and win the President's signature would be difficult enough, given the ideological difference between the parties. Reaching bipartisan deals in the aftermath of impeachment proceedings will be even trickier.
"In the end, you have to find a way to accommodate both sets of goals, or neither gets done," said Philip D. Moseley, a former Republican chief of staff for the House Ways and Means Committee who is now a partner at Ernst & Young. "It's going to take some accommodation. What I don't know is whether the political situation will allow for that."
If Republicans succeed in freeing up some of the surplus for a big tax reduction, they will face a fight among themselves about what kind of cut to pursue. Social conservatives want to concentrate on tax cuts for families, and have put at the top of their list a reduction in the so-called marriage penalty. Economic conservatives are pressing for an across-the-board cut in income tax rates. In recent years the social conservatives have prevailed.
Mr. Clinton has left open the possibility that he could support a tax cut once Social Security's problems are solved. But when asked about uses for the surplus, Mr. Clinton's advisers have, in the last several months, emphasized the need to also shore up Medicare, the health insurance system for the elderly.
Given all the crosscurrents at play, Mr. Gallagher of Lehman Brothers said he could see four possible developments. First is what he calls "the big deal," in which the two parties agree on Social Security and tax cuts.
Second would be an outcome similar to 1998, in which the two parties stalemate, spending a bit of the surplus, but basically allowing it by default to go to reducing the national debt.
The third of his outcomes is no Social Security deal, but a modest budget package, including some additional spending plus some reduction in the marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leads many two-income couples to pay more in taxes than single people with the same incomes.
And fourth is a sizable tax cut independent of a Social Security overhaul -- an outcome that would be likely only if the economy turned down sharply.
There are some signs that the two parties may be able to reach a compromise on Social Security. But any bipartisanship on that front could be more than offset by lingering effects from the impeachment proceedings. And if the two parties are unable to reach some accommodation on fiscal issues this year, they will have to wait until after the Presidential race of 2000, which both sides think could hinge on what priorities the nation wants to set for the new era of fiscal plenty.

SECTION: Section C; Page 10; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1480 words

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- ECONOMIC SCENE;
5 Problems Tarnishing a Robust Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
It might seem churlish to find fault with a best-in-a-generation economy. Unemployment and inflation rates are at record lows, and low-paid workers are, for the first time in decades, receiving wage increases that outpace price increases. But despite the benefits of a temporarily buoyant economy, deep-seated problems remain.
Frank Levy, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, notes that the best time to tackle problems is when the economy is flush. He points to increasing inequality at a time of stagnating wages in his new book, "The New Dollars and Dreams" (Russell Sage Foundation, 1998). Borrowing a phrase from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Mr. Levy warns against "defining deviancy down -- accepting economic outcomes as normal today that would have been seen as pathological 10 or 20 years ago." 
 The new year is traditionally the time for making lists. So here are five profound problems facing the American economy:
INCOME INEQUALITY -- A study by Sheldon Danziger of the University of Michigan shows that from 1969 to 1997, when the earnings of college graduates rose briskly, the inflation-adjusted median earnings of white male high school graduates 25 to 34 fell nearly 30 percent. An economy that was supposed to lift everyone to new highs of income and consumption instead pushed the least skilled workers down.
Professor Danziger points to a stunning statistic: the earnings of these less skilled white workers fell so far that they earned less in 1997 than their black counterparts, a notoriously underpaid group, had earned almost 30 years earlier. And those black male high school graduates fared almost as badly. From 1969 to 1997, their inflation-adjusted earnings fell 25 percent.
Mr. Levy's data show that the richest one-half of 1 percent of American taxpayers account for about 11 percent of aggregate income, and about 5 percent of households take home 20 percent of total income. The share of income captured by the bottom 60 percent of households is falling. Only college graduates, about a quarter of the work force, are racking up significant wage gains.
There is substantial evidence that the nature of technology in an information-intensive era is stacked in favor of workers with college-level verbal and math skills. That leaves at least half the work force behind.
The United States, the richest country in history, has a fifth of its children in poverty. That this has taken place when the national unemployment rate hovers around 4.4 percent raises the question: What will happen when the next recession strikes?
WEALTH INEQUALITY -- The only sure way for a country to grow and prosper is for its citizens to save and invest, in education, highways, research, machinery and other wealth-creating activities. But data from Edward N. Wolff of New York University show a country where few people save. That leaves them with skimpy bank accounts and meager holdings of stocks, bonds, real estate or other forms of wealth.
Nearly 20 percent of American households, Professor Wolff contends, possess no net wealth (the value of their liabilities, like mortgage debt, offsets the value of assets) or negative net wealth (their liabilities exceed their assets). The bottom 40 percent of households control a meager two-tenths of a percent of total wealth. By contrast, the wealthiest 1 percent of households control nearly 40 percent of the total wealth.
The picture looks even grimmer if the value of housing -- a form of wealth that cannot be bought and sold quickly and is, therefore, largely unavailable for solving many financial emergencies -- is subtracted from the calculations. By this measure, the bottom 40 percent of families have more debt than assets. And from 1983 to 1995, the poorest 40 percent of households lost 80 percent of their wealth, while the wealthiest 1 percent of households gained 17 percent.
Members of minority groups did much worse. In 1995, Mr. Wolff reports, for example, the typical black household held only 12 percent as much wealth as the typical white household. Subtract housing, and that figure falls to 1 percent. More than 30 percent of black households, but only about 15 percent of white households, have no net worth.
SLUGGISH PRODUCTIVITY -- Over the long sweep of history, wages rise only about as fast as productivity -- the value of output per hour of work by all workers. If productivity rises by, say, 3 percent a year, employers can raise wages by 3 percent without sacrificing any profit. But if wages rise faster, workers' extra income can only come out of payments that would otherwise go to investors and creditors, a process that cannot continue indefinitely.
During the halcyon days of the 1950's and 1960's, productivity rose by an average of 3 percent a year. At that rate, wages could double in 20 years or so. But since the 1970's, productivity has been crawling along at a 1 percent annual clip, taking about three times as long to double. The productivity numbers have improved recently, but there is scant evidence that the new numbers will be permanent.
It is one thing for an economy, as is currently the case, to operate close to capacity, thereby reducing unemployment and driving up employment and wages. But to keep wages rising thereafter requires harnessing technology to expand the economy's productive capacity.
On this score, the lessons of history are sobering. For much of the last 100 or so years, productivity has been rising at the seemingly slow pace of about 2 percent. The fast pace of the 1950's and 1960's was anomalous. At the very least, it would take stiff increases in savings and corporate investment to return the economy to fast growth, but, according to Mr. Wolff's data, Americans appear unconvinced that they need to make such sacrifices.
EDUCATION GAP -- Investing in training and education is a possible cure for sluggish productivity and rising inequality. Indeed, the hiring practices of employers increasingly reward employees with college-level verbal and math skills, a trend caused by skill-biased technology. In 1978, male college graduates 25 to 34 earned about 15 percent more than recent high school graduates. Now the gap is about 50 percent.
Yet college and, therefore, access to high-income jobs remain beyond the reach of many families. In 1992, about 40 percent of high school seniors from the 25 percent poorest families did not enroll in post-secondary education. By contrast, only 10 percent of students from the 25 percent richest families failed to enroll in college or other post-secondary education.
Employers are turning increasingly to college-educated workers. Over the last 20 years, the number of full-time workers who are college graduates has risen from about 20 percent to almost 30 percent. Many unskilled male workers have become so discouraged that they have dropped out of the labor force, increasing the fraction of nonworking male high school dropouts from about 25 percent in 1975 to 35 percent in 1995. The current employment rate of high school dropouts, 40 percent, is only about half that of college graduates.
Given the huge earnings increase associated with college attendance, it is no surprise that college enrollments are rising. About 65 percent of whites in this country now acquire some college education. But black attendance rates are about 10 percentage points lower. Hispanic students are about four times as likely to drop out of high school as are whites.
The obvious explanation for these wide gaps in college attendance -- the ability of the family to cover tuition and living expenses -- may not be accurate. James Heckman of the University of Chicago argues that the income of parents at the time their children leave high school has less impact on the decision to attend college than do long-term factors, such as the economic and social circumstances of the family when the child was young. The time to intervene, Professor Heckman argues, is early in a child's life.
TATTERED SAFETY BLANKET -- Millions of adults have dropped out of the labor force because they cannot afford to replace their Government-paid health insurance with a private policy. Nor can they afford day care for their young children. The percentage of the population without health insurance has risen to about 16 percent and is nudging higher. An ominous trend is that workers are increasingly turning down offers by employers for insurance.
The economy has turned quickly and viciously against unskilled workers, leaving many of their families adrift. Fifty years ago, low-paid workers could seek their fortunes by migrating out of Southern agricultural areas and into Northern manufacturing cities. Today, escape routes are far more difficult to find. As Mr. Levy of M.I.T. notes, "getting an education is harder than getting on a bus."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- BAILOUTS;
U.S Role as World Savior: A Delicate Balancing Act

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Markets and governments around the world operated under an unshakable assumption throughout the economic turmoil last year: if things really got bad, the United States would be there to engineer a bailout.
After all, as everyone from President Clinton to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin kept declaring, the future of the United States was inextricably linked to the fate of the troubled emerging economies. 
 That was how Washington justified its $5 billion commitment to the bailout of South Korea led by the International Monetary Fund. It was why the Treasury persuaded America's allies to pony up $17 billion in additional aid for Russia in July -- money that failed to stabilize the country but that made it a lot easier for some rich oligarchs to convert their fast-falling rubles into dollars, which were immediately parked in Europe. And it was the justification for the American commitment to aid Brazil, an effort whose success is still an open question.
But the unstated assumption that the United States will always be ready to step in is a risky one. The failure of the Russian bailout was a searing experience, opening the Clinton Administration to the criticism that it had wasted billions on a government that was never as committed to change and capitalism as Mr. Clinton contended. And if the instability around the world continues, a likely bet in the minds of many in the Administration, the question of whether America should serve as the savior of last resort seems likely to come under increasing scrutiny from all sides.
"Russia was the turning point," conceded one senior Administration official who has been an advocate of aggressive economic intervention by Washington. "When it went bad, and it became clear that the U.S. and its allies were not about to pour more money into the place, it led to the two scariest months we have seen in markets around the world."
And yet, the official noted, "the political tolerance for continued American contributions, particularly in countries that are resisting major reform programs, clearly has some limits."
The problem is one of the most complex in modern American foreign policy. On the one hand, the United States feels a mounting obligation to help stabilize the world economy, to act as what Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright calls "the indispensable nation." That urge reached its zenith this fall, when the United States engineered a series of steps to calm world markets, starting with three interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
But many economists still warn of the so-called moral hazard problem: If investors know that Washington and the I.M.F. will ultimately step in to prevent the worst, they will not consider the potential risks of lending their money abroad. And that can distort investment decisions, leading to a flood of money into markets when times seem good -- exactly what happened in Russia -- and a devastating rush to get that money out after investors decide that no amount of outside help will keep the country afloat.
So Washington is caught in the middle, fearful of doing too much or two little. The problem is that American participation in huge bailouts is considered a key to restoring what is gingerly termed "market confidence," building an aura of stability around a country in chaos. The creation of that aura starts with confident-sounding predictions from the Treasury or the I.M.F. that a country is on the right track and that the world's major powers are there to provide support. Such declarations worked quite well for months in Brazil, as the I.M.F. and the Clinton Administration slowly put together a $41.5 billion package of aid -- a package that was meant to signal investors that they should not bet on a falling Brazilian currency because Brazil's allies were ready with a huge war chest to prop it up.
The problem is that the war chest works only if the markets are convinced that the fundamental economic problems are being addressed. In Brazil's case, that means bringing down a huge budget deficit and putting limits on very generous pensions and other social programs that Brazilians had come to expect from their Government. Naturally, politicians balk at such moves. And as the Brazilian Congress has delayed compliance with some of the toughest commitments it made in return for the huge loan, investors are again nervous and money is continuing to flow out of the country.
"It's a balancing act you can only keep up for so long," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist for Primark Decision Economics, a consulting firm in Boston. "Sooner or later, you have to show that you are willing to make the changes, or even the biggest bailout will not work."
Treasury Secretary Rubin puts it more diplomatically. "These programs work in countries that are willing to internalize the need for change," he said, pointing to places like Thailand and South Korea, where the reforms have come slowly but still seem on track. "Without that commitment, success is limited."
So far, Mr. Rubin has been lucky. Of the big bailouts, only Russia's has blown up in his hands. He tends to view these things with a trader's equanimity, arguing that Russia was a risky but reasonable bet in July, a bet worth taking if a loan from the West gave Russian politicians the time to stabilize their economy, collect taxes and come up with a reasonable budget.
But Russia's Parliament rebelled, and the effort collapsed. Remarkably, there was relatively muted criticism on Capitol Hill, largely because Russia's economic collapse in mid-August led to a market panic around the world. With the stock market plunging in the fall, a reaction to Russia's troubles and fear of a global recession, even the politicians who attacked the 1995 American-led bailout of Mexico kept silent. After all, who wanted to be blamed for fueling the international market chaos at a moment when Boeing was laying off 24,000 workers and farmers throughout the Midwest were suffering because their export markets had collapsed?
But this year could easily be different. The market is back, at least for now, and once again there is a sense, perhaps a false one, that the United States is more insulated from the worst effects of the global chaos than many feared a few months ago. If that remains unchanged, one or two more Russia-like failures may call the American role into question.
