HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY -- NEWSPAPERS;
Publications Are Trying New Techniques to Win Over Loyal Readers

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
For most newspapers, the numbers game played out in the twice-yearly audited circulation figures has been a losing proposition for the last 14 years. The figures, which are often considered a basic measurement of the industry's economic health, have dwindled more than 10 percent, to slightly more than 56.7 million copies from a peak in 1984 of 63.4 million newspapers.
In the past, the reactions have ranged from a heavy dose of price-cutting to a willingness to exercise unused marketing muscles. But this year a new set of remedies is being readied as some newspapers prepare to sell themselves in different ways and different places on different days. Meanwhile others are enlisting the people in their circulation area as partners in their marketing drives. 
 To find the latter strategy one need only head to New England, to the Blackstone Valley area of Rhode Island. There, The Providence Journal is betting that the devotion of communities to their high school athletes can translate into permanent circulation gains.
The Journal, bought (along with nine television stations) in 1997 by the A. H. Belo Corporation of Dallas for $1.5 billion, is not fiddling around with its pricing. Its cover price has been 50 cents since August 1990. Instead, it is looking for targeted sports coverage to produce targeted circulation gains.
A pilot program last spring to marry sports coverage, marketing and circulation is becoming routine this winter. It gives high school athletic directors a chance to propose which of their athletes should be profiled in articles designed for the editions delivered to the neighborhoods around the school.
Last spring, the newspaper interviewed and profiled the teen-age volleyball or baseball or soccer players every Tuesday and Thursday. Before publication, high school assembly announcements mentioned the upcoming articles. Stores and newspaper boxes in the neighborhood heavily promoted the player profiles. The work was recognized as a largely promotional vehicle; the athletes sign legal releases before participating in the interviews and photo sessions, according to Peter Phipps, the newspaper's deputy managing editor.
Such blending of journalism and marketing has been taboo at many newspapers, but the economic payoff was quick: the pilot program pushed single-copy sales up 7 percent, about 250 copies, according to Michael Dooley, the Journal's circulation director.
And the new readers appear hooked; the paper has held on to those circulation gains, helping stem a long-term decline that has left the Journal with a daily circulation of 167,381 -- down about 24 percent from its daily peak of 219,000 in 1982. This year, the program is being moved to the areas around Pawtucket and Woonsocket in the Blackstone Valley.
The Journal, like many other newspapers, is also working to keep subscriber revenues steady by asking home-delivery subscribers to pay and renew by leaving credit card information on file with the company. The number of subscribers who pay by credit card is still small -- 7,000 out of more than 125,000 subscribers -- but it is more than double the 3,000 of a year ago.
In Phoenix, there is the same kind of credit card push, and the circulation strategies are becoming more complex and computer-dependent. Leon Levitt, the circulation director for The Arizona Republic, said he was trying to make it more attractive for subscribers to renew by using the growing data base of demographic and economic information on its customers.
The Republic wants to use data it gathers on subscribers to decide, for instance, which readers would stay with the paper if their discounted $2.25-a-week offer were continued, and which readers would continue to take the paper even when the introductory offer ends and the $3.80-a-week rate starts. After it kicks in, it may also mean giving away papers to lower-income subscribers for two months to win their loyalty, Mr. Levitt said.
While The Republic is in a market most of Mr. Levitt's peers would envy -- booming with new residents -- its circulation growth has not kept pace with the region's population growth, he said. As of Sept. 30, it was selling an average of 435,330 copies daily and 553,495 on Sundays, down about two-tenths of a percent from the year earlier.
Another option being tried by several newspapers -- including The Republic, which is owned by Central Newspapers Inc., and The Charlotte Observer, owned by Knight Ridder -- is finding new middlemen. Apartment managers take out subscriptions at a discount, and they in turn offer it to tenants as part of the rent. In other programs, customers pay for cable and newspaper service in one bill.
It's a far cry from the bygone days of the newsboy collecting quarters door to door. But John Murray, vice president of circulation marketing for the Newspaper Association of America, points out that the Internet, like television, is creating a generation of news consumers with no habit of paying for the product. This, he said, makes direct payment increasingly problematic. More of the cost, he believes, will be borne by advertisers -- who already provide about three-quarters of the industry's revenue.
The Republic is also refining another strategy, though it is not quite ready to put it into action. Instead of the old trio of subscription options -- Monday through Saturday, Monday through Sunday and Sunday only -- he wants to experiment with have-it-your-day offerings. For someone who does not want to read the paper on Monday or Tuesday but wants the grocery coupons on Wednesday or Thursday or the entertainment news on Friday, why not a Wednesday-Thursday-Friday-Sunday subscription?
"Up till now, we've been in the habit of doing things for our convenience," not the customer's, he said, adding that the key is developing an electronic route list that can change daily and that carriers can download in the predawn hours before they begin their routes. There is even talk, he said, that porch delivery -- as opposed to leaving a paper at curbside -- could be offered for a premium.
Like the days of delivery, the bundle of paper delivered may also be streamlined to suit the customer, he said. "The biggest stopper any salesman gets," Mr. Levitt said, "is people saying they have no time to read. We've been almost our own worst enemy. The product gets bigger and bigger with more bulk, and that's not what people want." Electronic route lists, based on refined subscriber data bases, could shrink the pile of daily inserts. "Advertisers could give inserts for just people with pools or just people who wear glasses," he said.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: INTERNATIONAL -- RUSSIA;
Mustering a Whistle in a Graveyard Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin left his sickbed to deliver a surprisingly bullish year-end verdict on Russia's economy. "Russia is on the up," he declared.
Mr. Yeltsin, in fact, is probably the only optimist. From international economists to the Kremlin's own specialists, the prognosis is decidedly grim.
The chief question is not whether Russia will turn the corner this year. It is whether Russia will find some way to muddle through despite a weakening economy or whether the situation will tumble precipitously out of control. 
 This is not just an economic matter. Given its vast store of nuclear material and often poisonous politics, Russia's struggle to establish a stable, pro-market system has powerful implications for the West.
The muddle-through school believes that Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and his unlikely coalition of Communists and social democrats are far more realistic than their polemics would suggest.
True, they have lauded the idea of state intervention in the economy and mocked the specialists at the International Monetary Fund.
But optimists say the Government team will try to limit the printing of new rubles, contain public spending and do just enough market reform to pry a few billion dollars from the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
The movement toward a market economy will continue, they maintain, but at a slow pace. And Russia will be spared yet another debilitating Government shake-up, like the ones last year that resulted in the ouster of Sergei V. Kiriyenko as prime minister and Anatoly B. Chubais, one of the nation's most prominent economic reformers.
The muddle-through theorists even have a name for this policy: They call it the "Russification of reform."
The darker view foresees hyperinflation, a deepening recession and mounting confusion in the top Government ranks, as financial problems overwhelm Mr. Primakov's untested and ideologically incongruous team.
No one can say for sure how Russia's economy will fare. That will depend mightily on the Government's ability to make unpopular but necessary decisions about the economy and to make them stick.
The failure of the I.M.F., the United States Treasury, most specialists and the news media to foresee Russia's current economic crisis should chasten anyone bold enough to hazard a prediction.
It is sobering, however, to see what a "good year" signifies for Russia's policy makers. The nation's gross domestic product fell almost 6 percent in 1998 and Russia will be fortunate if the decline is no more than 4 percent or 5 percent this year. (The International Monetary Fund projects that economic output will shrink 8.3 percent, and some critics fear the contraction could be as much as 15 percent.)
Inflation, the Russian Government hopes, will hover at 30 percent in 1999. (The I.M.F. is predicting 56 percent and other critics say it could be more.)
The Government says the exchange rate this year will be about 21.5 rubles to the dollar, more or less the rate in late December. Before the currency collapsed in August, the rate was about 6, and few believe that the ruble will not be devalued further.
With a little luck, and some food and other humanitarian aid from the West, the nation will suffer only isolated pockets of hunger. (That, experts say, is a fairly credible expectation, assuming that the assistance reaches those that need it and is not stolen.)
The economic crisis gathered force when foreign and domestic investors began to lose confidence in emerging markets because of the economic turmoil in Asia. That was a huge problem for Russia, because it had financed much of its debt through the sale of Government Treasury securities to foreign investors. Its troubles were compounded by the plunging prices of oil and other natural resources that Russia exports.
The crisis hit average Russians hard. Many people lost their savings when the banking system collapsed. After the Government stopped propping up the ruble in August, the price of imports soared, no small concern considering that the goods most desired by Russian consumers are made abroad.
Since many Russians are owed months of back wages, the devaluation of the nation's currency means that the wages they will eventually receive will be worth only a fraction of what they expected.
Real incomes dropped 15.6 percent last year, according to Government statistics. The Kremlin's sanguine view is that real income will continue to drop by 7.5 percent this year and then rise in 2000, a presidential election year.
There has not been any sustained period of economic growth since the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. And as the Government tells it, growth is always just around the corner.
There is no easy explanation for the Russians' ability to grin and bear it. But the question is a vital one -- especially for those who are worried where the economy is headed.
Russians appear to have become accustomed to many of the material benefits of a freer economy even as they have become disillusioned with Russia's corrupt version of market reform. Russia may not be moving boldly to carry out economic changes, but at least it has not been moving backward.
Nor have the nation's financial elite been dislodged by the economic crisis. The so-called oligarchs who dominate the nation's energy, banking, natural resources and media industries are mostly still in place, though they are not quite as swaggering as they used to be.
The key factors to watch will be President Yeltsin's faltering health, which could open the door to early elections, and a change of economic policy.
Much will also depend on whether the Primakov team has the will to tackle fiscal problems. Mr. Primakov has successfully pressed Parliament to pass important legislation, encouraging foreign investment in Russia's oil industry.
The list of unaccomplished changes, however, is long and includes a new tax code, laws that would allow farmers to buy and sell land and the overhaul of the battered banking system.
Putting the nation's fiscal house in order is also essential. After defaulting on its domestic debt, the Kremlin can no longer finance its deficit by selling Treasury bills.
Printing money is not the answer. The money supply was increased 20 percent after the August crisis, but the Primakov Government understands that it is flirting with hyperinflation if it covers the deficit by running the printing presses at full steam.
Assistance from the I.M.F. and the World Bank would help. But the fund has made it clear that it will not provide more aid until the Government demonstrates its ability to cut spending and collect taxes.
The fund put it accurately, if somewhat inelegantly, in its latest report on the world economy.
Russia, it said, urgently needs a fiscal policy under which most expenditures "would be financed by tax revenue, without resort to arrears, and whose financing would allow inflation to be reasonably well contained, without price controls."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING -- ACCOUNTING;
Turning Financial Dialects Into a Common Language

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Life would be simpler if all companies, whether in Thailand, Tanzania or Tennessee, spoke the same financial language.
But each country now sets its own accounting rules, and what may look like profits at a bank in Kuala Lumpur may turn into losses at a bank in Kansas City with the same numbers but using American accounting rules. 
 The International Accounting Standards Committee, a group of accountants and executives from around the world, has set out to change that. And, after more than two decades of work, the committee is ready to present a core set of 15 universal accounting standards.
This year, world securities regulators, including the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States, will review the proposed rules and decide whether they are strong enough to recommend to all countries. These would not be the first international rules to be devised, but the goal is to have one set that applies worldwide.
"This is the year," said James L. Cochrane, the chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange. "Investors and analysts are crying out for a common language, a common set of accounting principles."
But a growing number of critics, many of them in this country, say that the global rules written by the London-based committee are weak and full of loopholes. The critics, including members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting rules in the United States, have also raised questions about the inner workings of the committee, which has been holding its meetings in private and has some members with close ties to companies that would follow the rules.
In defense of the proposed international rules, Patricia A. McConnell, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company and the International Accounting Standards Committee's vice chairwoman, said that they "look and smell" like the American rules. "They are far superior to most things you would get outside of the U.S.," she said.
And Trevor S. Harris, a professor of accounting at Columbia University and a consultant for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said that while the United States accounting rules are more detailed, the broad differences between the American and the proposed global rules are small. "In my mind there are few differences that are significant from an investor's point of view," he said. "Sometimes the extra detail does not lead to more informative information."
Many financial experts and executives are clamoring for a worldwide set of accounting rules. They contend that universal rules are necessary in a world where investors regularly struggle to compare companies that operate across several time zones and under very different governments.
Some countries, like South Korea, Poland and Russia, now have few accounting rules or do not enforce the rules they have, leaving executives to decide on their own what investors should and should not know.
While such countries may seem distant enough not to worry most of this nation's investors, even now anyone can go on the Internet and invest in foreign companies in countries that lack well-enforced accounting rules.
Dozens of countries have already adopted existing international rules as an alternative to writing their own, and the World Bank recommends the existing standards as a condition of its loan agreements. But the aim of the new effort is full global standardization.
Global rules have widespread appeal in Europe, where 11 countries are now using a common currency, the euro, but have not yet knitted together their accounting rules.
Many European countries now allow foreign companies wanting to sell stock on their exchanges to use the existing international rules rather than to conform to their own. One of these is Britain, and many companies that would like to sell their stock on the American exchanges have gone to the London Stock Exchange instead.
Mr. Cochrane at the New York Stock Exchange said that many foreign companies now turn away from American markets because they do not want to reconcile their financial statements to United States accounting rules, as required by the S.E.C.
American regulators say they understand the need for having one set of accounting rules, and they have agreed to review the international committee's rules and decide whether to allow their use in this country.
And in a recent speech to the World Congress of Accountants, the president of the World Bank, James D. Wolfensohn, said: "In a world that is growing more and more like a single economic household, it makes no sense to be speaking in different voices. We urgently need a unified global language of business."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING;
90's Mantra: Bull Market To Carry On

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The economy will probably cool and corporate profits will probably slow, but stocks will stay in the stratosphere. That is the dichotomy that market strategists believe is in store for investors in the United States stock market this year.
This sort of disconnect -- falling profit growth but rising stock prices -- is familiar. After all, it was in the midst of last year's disastrous third quarter, when corporate profits at America's largest companies wound up falling an average of 3.2 percent, that stocks shook off the bear-market blues and started soaring again. The big-capitalization shares that make up both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index took off on Oct. 8 and by the end of the year had risen 18.7 percent and 28.1 percent, respectively, from their lows. 
 For the year, the Dow Jones rose 16.1 percent and the S.& P. returned nearly 26.7 percent. The biggest mover of them all was the Nasdaq composite index, which gained a monumental 39.6 percent, largely on the fortunes of technology stocks like Dell Computer, Intel and Cisco Systems.
Although the market has recovered nicely from its brush with the bear last fall, corporate earnings have not rebounded nearly as much. The final calculations for the fourth quarter will not be tallied until February, but expectations are that full-year earnings for S.& P. 500 companies averaged 5 percent, according to Charles Hill, research director for the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings estimates. Many analysts and economists are guessing that the rate of growth will be lower this year, an average of 4.2 percent for stocks in the S.& P.
Earnings this tepid are obviously not enough on their own to keep stock prices at or near current levels. But many strategists think stock prices will remain high this year. After all, it is that kind of market: Internet stocks such as Amazon.com and Ebay Inc. have scant earnings, but they are the hottest issues around.
The fact is, something other than earnings has been propelling equity prices for years. Consider this: Earnings for stocks in the S.& P. 500 have been flat since early 1997, but during that time the index has risen nearly 67 percent, to 1,229.23 from 737.01. Since 1995, the S.& P. has almost doubled, while average earnings are expected to have advanced only 28 percent for the period.
The factors other than earnings that have driven stocks to historically high valuations will keep them aloft this year, strategists say. The most significant factors are barrels of cash on the sidelines earmarked for stocks, a continued explosion in the growth of the nation's money supply and more corporate megamergers.
"Astonishingly, after yet another good year in stocks, the outlook going into next year is still pretty favorable," Byron R. Wien, chief domestic investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York, said late last year. "My view is we'll have another up year -- not a 20 percent year, but maybe a 10 percent year" for the S.& P. stocks, he said.
To be sure, most market predictions are barely worth the paper they're printed on. But Mr. Wien has proved fairly prescient on stock movements recently. A year ago he predicted, among other things, that technology stocks would re-emerge as market leaders and that the Dow would roar to 9,000 in the spring, only to fall to 7,000 later in the year. Although he was wrong about the reason for the decline in the Dow -- he thought inflation and rising interest rates would be the culprits -- his numbers were pretty close. The Dow was at 9,211.84 on May 13 and fell to 7,539.07 on Aug. 31.
Mr. Wien thinks stocks will rise again this year for two reasons. One is that central banks around the world are expanding their money supply, and that is usually good for equities. Even more important, "It doesn't look like we're going to have a recession," he said. "The economy didn't do as badly in the third and fourth quarter as everybody thought it would." As a result, he predicts that average earnings of companies in the S.& P. could rise 7 percent this year.
Still, all is not rosy on the economic front. The nation's trade deficit will almost certainly worsen as Asian economies begin to recover and flood American shores with cheap products. Furthermore, the ability of corporations to raise prices in the new deflationary world is nonexistent, a factor that pushes down profit margins.
This is unlikely to change. James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Norwest Investment Management in Minneapolis says that both the supply of goods and the capacity to make them have been growing faster than demand for the last four years. This imbalance cannot go on forever without some unhappy consequences, like plant closings and ensuing layoffs.
In addition, sluggish profit growth is likely to decrease capital spending, which has been the jet propellant behind many stocks recently. And as layoffs rise, consumer confidence may fall, putting pressure on stocks.
But as the bulls correctly point out, stocks have climbed this wall of worry before, and admirably. So another good, if not great, year for stocks may be in the cards.
A big push for stocks will very likely come from the billions of dollars currently sitting on the sidelines waiting to be invested, according to Christine A. Callies, equity strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. She said that the year-over-year growth of assets held in retail money market mutual funds hit 24.8 percent in October, the most recent data available and the highest rate since 1990. "There was one growth rate of 23 percent in 1996, but it's quite rare," Ms. Callies said. "This year, the growth rate really started to sprint over the course of the summer."
Ms. Callies thinks that this money is headed for equities. "Because employment is reasonably good and wages are rising, we doubt that this money is being piled up to support consumer life styles," she said. "This appears to be recycled from other sources and stored there with intent of putting it to use."
Another force that will continue to be positive for stocks is merger mania. Edward M. Kerschner, chief strategist at Paine Webber, expects that record levels of merger and acquisition activity seen in 1998 will extend into 1999. Mr. Kerschner pointed to some factors that would drive deals this year: Mergers will appeal to companies trying to gain economies of scale and scope -- for example, by offering consumers one-stop shopping -- and to those looking to acquire new technology or assets that would be impossible to build quickly. Corporate combinations are also the answer for companies that want to expand internationally, move into higher-margin businesses or respond to deregulation, according to Mr. Kerschner. All in all, a pretty compelling case for lots more mergers and acquisitions.
But while some aspects of the market may look familiar in 1999, there will also be significant differences. For example, index-fund investing may no longer produce results superior to those obtained by seasoned stock pickers.
It may be just a straw in the wind, but according to Lipper Inc., the mutual-fund research firm in Summit, N.J., funds in two of the most popular stock fund categories were beating the return of the S.& P. 500 index during the last months of 1998. From the end of October to mid-December, the average capital appreciation fund gained 8.86 percent and the average growth fund returned 7.69 percent. The S.& P. returned 7.63 percent during the period.
In 1999, the market may shift to reward stock picking over basket picking, a reverse of the trend throughout the decade.
And even though high-priced growth stocks, particularly those in the technology sector, have been the place to be in recent months, more defensive issues might be the favorites this year. Strategists who question the market's ability to make 1999 the fifth consecutive year of double-digit returns suggest that investors focus on high-yielding stocks of good-quality companies, such as utilities, consumer goods manufacturers or integrated oil concerns. With inflation nowhere to be seen and the possibility of future credit loosening by the Federal Reserve Board, shares in these kinds of companies would seem to be a safe but profitable place for investors to stash some cash.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MEDIA & TECHNOLOGY -- TEL ECOMMUNICATIONS;
2 Industries Unite to Pave the Way for High-Speed Internet Access

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Anyone who has used the Internet at both work and home knows that those are vastly different experiences. Whatever the metaphor they choose -- jack rabbit and tortoise, water and molasses, heaven and hell -- most people who access the Net from home via dial-up modems miss a big part of what cyberspace ought to be all about: high-speed, low-hassle access to text, graphics, audio and video.
The problem, of course, is that typical modems are simply not able to do the Internet full justice. And most consumers have no other economically realistic options for connecting. 
 But if the telecommunications and cable television industries have their way, that will start to change in a big way this year, beginning a process that could bring quick Internet connections from the office to the living room just as Henry Ford brought the automobile from the mansion to the middle class.
Coupled with the advent of truly low-cost personal computers, the mass deployment of cheap, reliable, high-speed Internet links for residential consumers could have an impact as deep as Ford's. After all, it was not until cars became less of a novelty for the rich than a necessity for the rest that it made sense to actually pave roads.
Likewise, the broad availability of high-speed cyberspace connections could foster the development of new sorts of applications that make today's Internet look like a rutted cart path.
That, at least, is the bet that many of the nation's largest telephone and cable television companies have made or are getting ready to make. And 1999 will probably be the year that those two industries, with their vastly different financial, regulatory and cultural dimensions, join their battle to control the future of how the nation's consumers enter cyberspace.
"This is the biggest single opportunity that exists in all of communications," said Howard Anderson, the managing director of the Yankee Group, a high-technology consulting firm in Boston. "It will get very serious and this, 1999, is the year that we will see competition."
The cable television and telephone industries are trying to use radically different technologies to deliver huge amounts of data to homes, but the financial opportunity for each of them is impressive.
Even the most aggressive projections peg the number of homes that had high-speed Internet access at the end of last year at something less than 750,000 (a vast majority of those using cable modems rather than the telephone technology known as asymmetric digital subscriber line, or A.D.S.L.)
Over all, somewhere around 45 percent of the nation's 100 million homes have computers, and only about half of those, or around 22.5 million, are on line at all.
U S West Inc. has been the most aggressive of the Bell local phone companies in deploying A.D.S.L. technology, planning to sign up as many as 25,000 customers by the end of last year. Michael Rouleau, a U S West vice president for marketing, estimated that about 10 percent of cyberspace-using homes would pay extra for high-speed access.
Thomas A. Jermoluk, the chairman of the At Home Corporation, the cable-modem venture backed by many of the nation's large cable system operators, said his company's business plan was to win 20 percent of any given market's on-line homes as customers after four years.
Split the difference at 15 percent and the potential market today -- at $40 a month a home, which is roughly what both the telephone and cable companies are charging -- comes to about $1.6 billion. In the communications world, that is not a large number.
Mr. Anderson of the Yankee Group, however, believes that fully half of the on-line homes would pay $40 a month for high-speed Internet access. If that were true, and if, in a few years, the proportion of United States homes that had computers rose to 60 percent and if the proportion of on-line homes also rose to 60 percent, then the market opportunity would be a much more significant $8.7 billion.
But even that is just the entrance to the potential gold mine. That $40 a month just covers basic access to cyberspace. What the telephone and cable companies may try to do is to leverage that relationship with users to sell them additional services, ranging from E-mail to clothing shopping to video games.
Of course, standing in the way of such incremental revenue are some very daunting fixed costs. It generally takes around $700 to upgrade each phone or cable line to provide high-speed data access. (Additional options, like offering Internet-based phone service over a cable line, cost even more.)
So, for instance, because At Home's affiliates serve about 60 million customers, Mr. Jermoluk said, it would cost a staggering $42 billion to get all of them on line using cable modems. And so the deployment goes slowly.
Other than competition between each other, however, the biggest force pushing the cable and telephone companies to deploy high-speed data systems may not be consumers, but the computer industry.
In this day of 450-megahertz processors and video cards with as many transistors as Pentium chips, the biggest bottleneck in the computer system is the link to other computers. If the connections do not increase in speed, the prospect of buying a new computer every year or two becomes less compelling.
That is why companies like Compaq Computer and Microsoft are perhaps more eager for widespread high-speed data connections than even the most intense Internet surfer. For the local phone and cable companies, the Internet is the future. For the computer companies, it is now.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: INTERNATIONAL -- TRAVEL;
Price Rises Ahead for Road Warriors

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
By the time business travelers fly to their destinations, hop into rental cars, check into hotels and sit down for meals, their trip will most likely cost their employers 5 percent to 7 percent more than it did last year. That is, if they are among the lucky ones who get to travel at all.
While even 5 percent would be almost double the 2.8 percent inflation rate forecast for this year by PricewaterhouseCoopers, corporate travel managers do not seem overly concerned, probably because anywhere within that range would be an improvement over last year's 8 percent rise over 1997 travel costs. And if costs do exceed expectations, corporations are not entirely helpless to rein them in. 
 For example, until the stock market started declining last summer, corporate America had been content to impose travel policies on employees at a measured pace. But by the fall that gradual approach had become a gallop.
A survey of 450 major companies in October by the National Business Travel Association found that 56 percent had cut back on the number of employees who travel and 53 percent had replaced some travel with videoconferencing and teleconferencing. And in the wake of big cutbacks recently announced by manufacturing companies and financial institutions alike, there is every reason to assume that travel costs will not escape corporate belt-tightening.
Meanwhile, a preliminary projection of 1999 business travel costs by American Express expects them to rise an average of 5 percent to 6 percent -- not much higher than the 4.8 percent rise forecast by Runzheimer International, the management consulting firm in Rochester, Wisc., and not much lower than the 7 percent increase forecast by Travel One, the management company based in Mount Laurel, N.J.
But the forecasters agree that all bets are off if, as American Express put it, "current economic turmoil overseas and stock market instability in the United States translates into lower demand for business travel."
A good many road warriors expect to see that lower demand. In a recent survey of 1,348 frequent corporate travelers, compiled for Business Travel News magazine by Plog Research Inc. of Reseda, Calif., 49 percent said that they expected a decrease in company travel this year and 56 percent expected a decrease in the number of travelers.
That survey did not pinpoint where the travelers expect the decreases to come from, although the source of any substantial savings is fairly obvious. Air travel accounts for 42 percent of companies' travel and entertainment budgets, according to American Express, while meals and entertainment account for 22 percent, lodging 21 percent and car rentals 8 percent. Communication and miscellaneous items make up the rest.
Since corporate travel managers know that, in the words of the old adage, the place to go duck hunting is where the ducks are, the most likely target for cutting costs -- on paper, at least -- is air fares. Yet corporate travel managers do not expect air fares to fall this year, although they disagree about how much they are likely to increase.
Runzheimer, for example, expects overall fares to rise an average of 5.1 percent, but about 10 percent on the hundreds of routes without nonstop competition. American Express has forecast an average fare increase of 4 percent to 5 percent, while Travel One expects domestic fares to jump a whopping 9 percent. It reasons that airlines are in no big hurry to expand capacity even though the number of passengers remains at record high levels, and that except for Southwest Airlines and Pro Air in Detroit, low-cost competitors have had little impact on business fares.
If the forecasters are right, business fares to Europe will increase about 6 percent, while fares to Asia and the Pacific region may rise as much as 5 percent. While 5 percent is not out of line with historic trans-Pacific fare increases, travel management companies say any such rise this year will seem much higher in view of the fact that just a few months ago some struggling Asian airlines were practically giving away trans-Pacific tickets (many of which were bought by American companies with business in Asia).
"Most of the major airlines in the Asia-Pacific region survived the 1998 economic crisis by restructuring routes and re-examining capital expenditures to decrease operating expenses," said Clint Cable, general manager of that region for Rosenbluth International, the Philadelphia travel management company.
The forecasters expect car rental prices to rise between 5 percent and 8 percent, the result of a combination of higher rates, insurance, airport fees and surtaxes imposed by cities; for example, Houston's average surcharge for midsized car rentals has risen 24 percent since 1997, according to American Express. And according to Michael Boult, director of supplier relations for Rosenbluth, "Car rental is also a convenient target for higher Federal, state and local taxes."
The only break business travelers can count on are in restaurant prices, which none of the forecasters expect to rise more than about 2.5 percent. But given the large percentage of travel budgets spent on meals and entertainment, corporations are still paying close attention. Most of this scrutiny is in the form of spending limits, but some companies are going beyond that. One major Midwestern company, for example, not only scrutinizes the entertainment portion of expense accounts, but occasionally contacts guests whose names appear on expense accounts -- ostensibly to inquire if they found the food and service satisfactory.
Hotel rates have been climbing for several years and show no signs of stopping or even slowing down. PricewaterhouseCoopers projects a 3.9 percent increase, to $81.77 a night, an average that includes budget and economy motels. For business travelers, though, American Express forecasts a jump of 7 percent to 10 percent in the top 25 business cities, while Runzheimer expects rates in downtown hotels will rise about 12 percent.
Moreover, New York's room rate has averaged $245 for several months, 15 percent higher than in 1997, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, while a standard room at a luxury New York hotel has ranged between $350 and $700 a night.
Sky-high room rates and sky-high occupancies are also pretty much the outlook for 1999 in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Washington and other major cities.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- MERGERS;
After $2.5 Trillion in Combinations in 1998, the Sky's the Limit in 1999

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
You would think that after last year's more than $2.5 trillion in announced mergers worldwide -- the largest on record -- corporate executives might take 1999 off. Think again.
With the stock market for the most part continuing its upward march, investors can expect even more mergers in the next 12 months. But unlike last year, when mergers were concentrated primarily in the telecommunications, banking and insurance industries, the frenzy this year will spread to other industries as well, merger professionals say. Even more international combinations are expected in the months ahead, along with a shift in activity to include industrial companies as well as increased activity in the burgeoning high-technology industry. 
 "If you assume a reasonably stable market environment for a good part of the year, it will be good for the merger market," said Stephen R. Volk, a senior partner at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling. "Chief executive confidence is quite high now, and it is a major predictor of deals getting done."
Most of what has driven the megamerger boom in the United States is the effort by corporations to fend off competition from larger rivals by combining. As a result, regional companies will continue to turn their attention away from their home market in the hopes of quickly establishing a national, if not international, presence.
"Timing becomes important," said Steven B. Wolitzer, head of global mergers and acquisitions at Lehman Brothers. "The ability to build your business first becomes important to really create the winners. It's a mad scramble to get there quickly."
Witness the flurry of activity after Nationsbank bought and assumed the name of BankAmerica in a $60 billion stock deal or after SBC Communications announced its intent to acquire Ameritech for $62 billion in stock, a deal the Federal Communications Commission is reviewing. Investors can expect even more activity, particularly in pharmaceuticals, health care, utilities and energy -- the latter recently evidenced by the planned merger of Exxon and Mobil.
"One of our themes has been the everyday nature of this activity," said Mac Heller, co-chief operating officer of the investment banking division and head of global mergers and acquisitions at Goldman, Sachs. "Yes, the numbers are spectacular, but it is no more spectacular to have a $70 billion deal in 1998 than it was to have a $10 billion deal in 1984."
More United States executives are expected to turn their attention to foreign concerns. That's in part because more European companies have set their sights on America, as well as on their next-door neighbors, in an effort to extend beyond national borders -- a trend that will only grow as Europe moves closer to a common market. A unified Europe "requires companies to look at themselves and become larger and more competitive," said John Studzinski, head of European investment banking at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "There will be more profound consolidation in the midsize sector."
The courtship has already begun, for companies of all sizes.
There has been a spate of recently announced pharmaceutical combinations in Europe, including the $35 billion planned acquisition of Astra of Sweden by the London-based Zeneca Group, and the agreement to combine the drug and agricultural units of Hoechst of Germany and Rhone-Poulenc of France.
And while European companies have always been attracted to United States targets, they are finally going after them in a big way. In December for instance, Scottish Power announced its intent to acquire Pacificorp, which operates in the Pacific Northwest and is one of the country's biggest power companies, for $7.9 billion. If approved, it would be the first purchase of a United States utility by a foreign company. And Deutsche Bank said it would buy Bankers Trust for $10.1 billion.
Such cross-border combinations will be anything but easy to pull off as companies grapple with inconsistent accounting, legal and regulatory rules in the home countries. And there are sure to be social and political ramifications as foreign workers and their bosses alike become accustomed to the American-style corporate reorganizations of the 1980's, which turned many companies into leaner operations -- but only after major cost-cutting and huge layoffs.
Technology will continue to be an active area for mergers, too, but these combinations present their own complications, industry experts say. For one thing, technology stocks are quite volatile, and anyone seeking a merger partner is subject to unpredictable downside risk because of the often short life span of technology products. That is why activity in the industry has mostly consisted of weaker companies being acquired by stronger concerns. This is likely to change as the industry matures.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING;
After 4 Years of Optimism, Not Giving Up Now

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Abby Joseph Cohen did not flinch in August when the stock market sank. Instead, Ms. Cohen, the chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, telephoned her clients and told them the same thing she told them a year earlier when the market seemed to be in free fall: "Stay the course."
It has become a familiar refrain for Ms. Cohen, who has remained steadfast in her bullishness even when others have turned bearish. And what should investors expect this year? 
 "When we do a retrospective of 1999 we'll be saying, 'It wasn't so bad after all,' " she said in a telephone interview late last year. "We see profits continuing to grow in 1999."
After combing through an array of charts and graphs, her statistical crystal ball, Ms. Cohen predicted an unprecedented fifth consecutive year of solid gains for blue-chip stocks, even though profit growth will continue to moderate. By the end of the year, she said, the Dow Jones industrial average could reach 9,850 and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index could climb to 1,275.
Last year, Ms. Cohen said that the Dow, one of the most widely followed market barometers, would end the year at 9,300. (It ended at 9,181.43.) She also predicted that the S.& P. 500, which most index funds track, would finish the year at 1,200. (It ended at 1,229.23.)
She has not been alone in forecasting a prolonged bull market. Edward M. Kerschner, the chief investment strategist at Paine Webber, has also had relatively accurate predictions, bucking the trend toward pessimism when the Asian economic crisis appeared. He, too, was projecting modest gains for stocks this year, noting that the big shift of cash into equities (spurred by baby boomers) could continue for the next 15 years.
Another prescient Wall Street forecaster is Laszlo Birinyi, a former Salomon Brothers technician, who now heads his own research and money management firm in Greenwich, Conn. By following the amount of cash rushing into certain stocks, Mr. Birinyi has been able to discern trends in buying sentiment -- trends that have made him an unrepentant bull, even during sharp downturns.
"We're still very positive," Mr. Birinyi said. "When the market goes down, people continue to buy stocks, you see investors manifesting their views about the future."
Mr. Birinyi, who said the blue chips would continue to lead the rallies, predicted that the Dow would reach 12,000 this year.
For those who see nothing impressive in the actions of these bulls, consider this: almost every other Wall Street strategist has forecast that the sharp increase in stock prices that began in October 1990, with the Dow at 2,365.10, would surely collapse into a bear market. Valuations, they said, were too high. They said it in 1995. 1996. 1997. And 1998.
In late 1997, for example, Barton M. Biggs, the chief global strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said: "If this has been a year of moonlight and roses, next year, I expect, is going to be sackcloth and ashes. In other words, the huge brutal hug of a bear market will squeeze some."
The same year Ralph J. Acampora, the widely followed technician at Prudential Securities, predicted a Dow 10,000 by 1998, and then had a change of heart in August, after the Dow passed 9,300, declaring himself a bear and warning that the Dow could fall 20 percent. "It was the toughest call I've ever made, but I didn't flip-flop," Mr. Acampora said. "I market-time -- that's my job. I saved my clients a lot of agony."
In fact, concerns about a global economic crisis caused the Dow to fall 19 percent from its all-time high in August and September, before it roared back in the final quarter.
During the downturn, Ms. Cohen was resolute. She moved swiftly to calm investors' fears, calling the decline a short-term "market event" and not a real threat to the economy or the thriving bull market in equities.
That most strategists would expect a sharp and prolonged downturn is only natural. Few other bull markets have roared so fast for so long. And if one listens to Ms. Cohen, that run is not over yet. "Where our forecast ends, there is no recession in sight," she said. "The U.S. economy is strong. I believe in business cycles; I just don't think this cycle is ending in the next 12 months."
Ms. Cohen said she expected more of the same this year: steady earnings growth, with profits up about 5 percent from a year earlier; a steady economy, and stable interest rates -- a recipe for the strong rise of share prices.
A year ago, Ms. Cohen said that investors should be comforted by the nation's economy, which she likened to a "supertanker": it wasn't the fastest or most colorful ship at sea, but it was the strongest and the steadiest. This year's metaphor? "Supertanker revisited," she said with a chuckle.
Investors will be much more comfortable this year, she contended, having worked off a great deal of anxiety during the downturn in 1998.
How exactly does Ms. Cohen forecast what will happen 3, 6 or 12 months out? Ms. Cohen said she had developed statistical and intellectual models, models that weigh economic trends, cash flows into mutual funds, corporate earnings and other variables that could propel or eventually upset the apple cart.
"The most important thing we do is deciding which of the things we look at are the most important, the critical variable," she said.
Of course, every Wall Street strategist has a model, but Ms. Cohen said she sweated all the details. She creates her own measurement of corporate earnings growth and tries to identify the variables that may eventually undermine her projections.
"What we do is a combination of science and art," she said. "Many investors believe if they only have the numbers they can get all the answers, but there are also critical variables."
Such variables, she says, could include earnings, the global economy, wage growth -- almost any statistic or trend in business and the economy. The real trick, she says, is in learning how to use those details to construct a forecast.
An important and early lesson came when Ms. Cohen was working at the Federal Reserve Board in the 1970's. Some of the best econometricians had devised an enormously successful forecasting model that suddenly did not work. Ms. Cohen helped try to find out why. The reason, she and other staff members later determined, was that the forecast was based on a particular inflationary environment, and when that environment changed, the model failed.
"One of the great lessons I learned is that you can have sophisticated models and they might not work," she said. "I view our work as: Let's try this disciplined scientific approach, and then let's try intellectual approaches as to why it won't work."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: INTERNATIONAL;
AsiaRegains Confidence As Its Stability Returns

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Like a cyclone victim emerging from a storm cellar to survey the damage, Asia ended 1998 with equal measures of shock and relief. Shock at the enormity of the devastation wrought by the economic crisis; relief that its storm-tossed markets and currencies had finally regained their footing.
"Until now, everyone was stuck with a very gloomy picture," said Neil Saker, the head of economic research at SG Securities in Singapore. 
 But thanks to cuts in interest rates in the United States and the strengthening of the Japanese yen, Mr. Saker said a modicum of confidence had returned to Asia. Stock markets and currencies in Thailand, Korea and Malaysia have risen steadily since October. Even fragile Indonesia has gained ground.
"We've turned the corner and we're in a period of stability, which is the prelude to real recovery," Mr. Saker said.
Of course, Asia could easily falter again. Experts said the blow could come from a number of places: the United States, if its growth slows; Japan, if it cannot revive its moribund economy, or the rest of Asia, if social unrest in Indonesia or Malaysia spreads and scares off returning investors.
Even without fresh shock waves, the region's recovery will be a protracted and painful affair. After predicting that Asia would follow a pattern similar to that of the Mexican currency crisis -- in which that country tumbled abruptly into recession but climbed out just as fast -- most economists and international agencies are now scaling back their expectations.
In recent reports, the World Bank and the International Labor Organization both predicted that most of Asia's economies would barely eke out positive growth this year. The World Bank forecasted that Indonesia's economy would shrink 2.5 percent, on top of an estimated 15.3 percent decline in 1998.
And the supercharged growth that led people to marvel at the "Asian Miracle" may be gone for good. The World Bank projects that after growing at an average annual rate of 6.8 percent between 1991 and 1997, East Asia's four major economies -- Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines -- will grow at an annual rate of just 2.8 percent between 1998 and 2007.
"The consensus is that it will take two to five years for Asia to recover," said Mac Overton, a portfolio manager at MBF Unit Trust here. "If you have a serious injury, it's not like you can go out and play ball the next day."
The challenge for Asian governments will be to pursue disciplined policies during this convalescence. Banks will have to be shut down, corporate assets will have to be sold and millions of workers laid off, all at a time when unemployment has tripled in Korea, Thailand and Indonesia.
The economic stress is already fraying nerves. Indonesia has been riven by clashes between students and soldiers, as well as between Christians and Moslims. In Malaysia, crowds rallied to denounce Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad for ousting and imprisoning his change-minded deputy, Anwar Ibrahim.
"If there is no recovery in a year, these social problems will multiply," said Marc Faber, the head of his own investment firm in Hong Kong.
Indonesia may have less time than that. President B. J. Habibie has begun to close unprofitable banks and take over debt-ridden conglomerates. But his hold on power is tenuous at best. Although Mr. Habibie has pledged new elections in the middle of this year, student protesters say he has been irredeemably tainted by his ties to his predecessor, President Suharto, and should step down immediately.
"As an economist, how can you run a restructuring when it is being influenced by the political process?" asked Mari Pangetsu, the executive director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research group in Jakarta.
Although Indonesia's neighbors are in less precarious shape, they, too, face internal pressures that could derail changes. In Korea, the chaebol, the corporate leviathans that dominate the economy, are obdurately resisting efforts to slim down their empires.
The President of South Korea, Kim Dae Jung, recently summoned the leaders of the five top chaebols to his residence, the Blue House, for a curt lecture on the need to reduce their debt and spin off unprofitable operations.
In Thailand, Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai is pushing for a bankruptcy law that would allow the Government to begin weeding out insolvent companies. But Mr. Chuan's campaign is being threatened by opposition from "vested interests" in the corporate sector, according to James Stent, the senior executive vice president of the Bank of Asia, Thailand's 11th-largest bank.
Looming above all these stop-and-go efforts is Malaysia, which has chosen a radically different remedy for its ills. Rather than accept the prescriptions of outside agencies like the International Monetary Fund, it has imposed sweeping capital controls on its currency and financial markets.
Economists warn that the controls could sabotage Malaysia's overhaul efforts. For now, though, they are shielding Malaysia from the vagaries of the global economy. Some experts in Kuala Lumpur argue that the economy is even perking up a bit. Outside analysts fear that if Malaysia thrives while the rest of Asia languishes, other countries will follow its example.
"The problem comes if growth doesn't pick up in 1999," said Simon L. Ogus, the managing director of Asian economics at Warburg Dillon Read in Hong Kong. "Then Malaysia may serve as a siren call for other countries."
And there is an even more fundamental debate under way: about where countries should put their emphasis in economic policy. The conventional wisdom here has been that Asian countries must export their way out of recession. Only by selling rubber, palm oil, cars and computer chips to their neighbors -- as well as to the United States and Europe -- could they hope to recover.
But now some economists argue that Asian countries cannot depend on each other or on the West to fuel a recovery. C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, a research organization in Washington, said these countries must first revive demand in their domestic markets. To do that, he said, the governments should increase public spending and relax their monetary policies.
"It looks to me that they're continuing to go downhill," Mr. Bergsten said. "They really have to put a concerted strategy in place."

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: INTERNATIONAL;
WithEuro, Europe Reinvents Itself

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
Europe is making history today, but there will not be much time for self-congratulation.
After years of political squabbling, arduous negotiations and painful economic preparation, 11 European nations are opening for business today with a new common currency: the euro. 
 It is a political and economic achievement that seemed impossible and even quixotic as recently as three years ago. Yet suddenly, the euro is here. And in a testimony to the euro's remarkably smooth start, the economic debates within Europe have already moved on to other topics.
Almost no one worries whether the euro can establish its credibility as a strong currency in world markets. Now the big issue is whether the euro will be a bit too strong, so highly valued that it hinders European growth by making exports more expensive.
Similarly, almost nobody fears an imminent resurgence of inflation -- not even the famously austere German central bank, the Bundesbank. Now the debate is whether Europe faces a danger from deflation and declining prices.
Meanwhile, European business is reinventing itself both at home and in the global marketplace. Much of that is a simple response to global competition, but the euro is accelerating the change by bringing Europe closer to the ideal of a single market as big as that of North America.
Led by the stock exchanges in Frankfurt and London, European bourses are moving rapidly toward becoming cross-border equities markets. Corporations, which traditionally financed themselves through their own reserves or through bank loans, are now raising billions in global stock and bond offerings. Junk bonds and American-style leveraged buyouts are on the increase. Banks and insurance companies are searching for mergers and partnerships throughout the world. And Europe's bewildering patchwork of consumer pricing -- where the price of a Volkswagen Golf or a bottle of Chanel perfume can be 25 percent higher in Paris than in Madrid -- is under new challenge as the euro strips away the camouflage of currency differences.
The euro will still seem like a phantom currency to many consumers for some time. The new bills and coins will not enter circulation until Jan. 1, 2002, and companies are allowed to keep doing business in their national currencies until then.
But as an economic entity, the euro is now more real than the German marks or French francs that people keep in their wallets. European monetary policy and interest rates are under the control of the new European Central Bank. And when European finance ministers locked in the exchange rates between their national currencies and the euro on New Year's Eve, the old currencies became nothing more than different ways to print euros.
Beginning today, the securities exchanges in all member countries will conduct their business in euros. All interbank transfers, even those within the same country, will be in euros. Consumers now have the choice of keeping their bank accounts in euros or their national currencies. During the next year, many stores and companies plan to convert credit-card and other electronic transactions into euros.
As Europeans enter this new era, the ground beneath them is shifting. Economists and government officials are much more worried about an economic slowdown this year than they were just six months ago. Having argued somewhat smugly that Europe would be only mildly affected by the financial crises sweeping through Asia, Russia and Latin America, government officials now admit they are troubled.
Most economists have cut their aggregate growth estimates for the 11 countries in Euroland from more than 3 percent to about 2.5 percent or less. In Germany, which accounts for nearly a quarter of the region's economic activity, some economists predict that growth will drop from about 3 percent in 1998 to just 1.7 percent this year.
Manufacturing companies are considerably more pessimistic. German engineering and machine-tool companies have slashed their predictions for export growth from 7 percent to 4 percent. Chemical companies such as BASF and Hoechst are all reeling from lower prices and lower demand, mostly as a result of the problems in Asia.
Much like the United States, Europe is flooded with low-cost imports as a result of currency devaluations from Asia and Latin America. While Europe still has a big trade surplus with the rest of the world, a rising tide of imports is cutting into local growth.
"Together with the U.S., Euroland is turning into the global importer of last resort," wrote Holger Schmieding, European economist for Merrill Lynch in London, in a recent report. He predicts that the shift in trade will reduce Europe's growth by about one-half of a percentage point, and bring it down to about 2 percent this year.
That would not be catastrophic. Most economists expect that the United States, which has grown faster than Europe since the early 1990's, will not do much better.
But even a modest slowdown will put more pressure on the fledgling European Central Bank, with Wim Duisenberg as its president. Formerly the president of the central bank of the Netherlands, Mr. Duisenberg has cast himself as an unflinching hawk on monetary policy whose only interest is preventing inflation.
Long after the Federal Reserve Board began cutting American interest rates last fall, hoping to head off a possible recession, Mr. Duisenberg argued against similar measures in Europe.
But as the signs of a European slowdown continued to multiply, Mr. Duisenberg and his mentors at the Bundesbank changed course and surprised almost everybody last month by cutting nearly all benchmark rates to 3 percent.
It remains to be seen whether that will be enough to shield Europe against the chill winds from Asia or Latin America. But the rate cut is bigger than it looks, because it came on top of even more radical reductions in European countries like Italy, Spain and Ireland, which have traditionally had higher inflation and interest rates.
Because countries adopting the same currency have to have the same general level of inflation and interest rates, central banks in these poorer periphery countries had already slashed their rates to 4 percent from more than 6 percent in the last year.
As a result, baseline interest rates are now mostly at 3 percent from Madrid to Frankfurt for the first time in European history. As recently as a year ago, most economists assumed that this process of convergence would head in the opposite direction, with countries like Germany nudging their rates up to about 4 percent.
The lower interest rates could lead to economic tensions within Europe. For Ireland, Spain and Portugal, which were already growing much more rapidly than their bigger and wealthier neighbors, the latest cuts simply add more rocket fuel to the mixture and could ignite inflationary pressures.
But that hardly settles the matter. With last fall's election victory in Germany by Gerhard Schroder and the Social Democratic Party, most countries in Europe are now controlled by left-of-center governments that are more interested in reducing unemployment than in adhering to orthodox inflation-fighting policy.
Many of those political leaders are hinting at a readiness to run higher budget deficits, especially if European unemployment rises beyond its current level of about 10 percent. If budget deficits do begin to swell, Mr. Duisenberg will be under pressure to counterattack with tighter monetary policy -- an unpopular job.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- HEALTH CARE;
With a Difficult Road Ahead, H.M.O.'s Are Set for Many More Mergers

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
This is bound to be a better year for the health care industry than 1998, which, to borrow Queen Elizabeth's mournful phrase, was an annus horribilis for some of the nation's biggest insurance, hospital and physician practice companies.
After several years of mediocre earnings, and only small increases in profits last year, many big health maintenance organizations have raised premiums 8 percent to 20 percent this year. 
 The managed-care companies are racing to push their revenue ahead of the growing cost of care, especially for heavily advertised prescription drugs, as well as new surgical equipment and more consultations, tests and referrals to specialists by physicians. Incomes of many types of doctors continued to rise last year, and hospitals, with notable exceptions, thrived.
H.M.O.'s generally set their monthly premium charges based on estimates extrapolated from past experience. Seriously misjudging costs, as several big companies did last year, invites financial trouble; premiums typically cannot be raised again until the following year.
"If the managed-care industry's losses in 1998 are worse than expected, 1999 is unlikely to be a stellar year -- the early 1999 pricing is already locked in," said Arun Kumar, a director of Standard & Poor's. "It will probably be a break-even year, with small profits, if any at all."
And Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office and now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said employers might resist H.M.O. price increases now that growth in corporate profits is slowing.
The difficult conditions are likely to be reflected in another round of health care mergers and acquisitions. Aetna Inc. agreed last month to buy the Prudential Health Care unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, making Aetna the nation's biggest managed-care company.
"Some recognizable players won't be here in a year -- they will be absorbed by other companies," said Dr. Peter Kongstvedt, a partner in the Washington office of Ernst & Young.
Several of last year's big losers are still not out of the woods. "There are alarming signs of fragility in the corporate health care sector in an otherwise strong economy," said Jeff Goldsmith, an independent consultant based in Charlottesville, Va.
Kaiser Permanente, the nation's biggest H.M.O. company, with nine million members, reported big financial losses for the second consecutive year. (It is, however, projecting a tiny profit in 1999.) Oxford Health Plans, one of the largest H.M.O.'s in the New York region, was also struggling with red ink. And state regulators in New Jersey recently took control of the 194,000-member H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey, the troubled unit of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.
Hospitals, too, have had some rough times. the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's biggest for-profit hospital chain, was still struggling to shed unprofitable units, regain the confidence of customers and investors, and settle Government charges that fraudulently inflated expenses were charged to Medicare and other Government programs. The Government also joined a lawsuit last year based on similar charges against the Quorum Health Group Inc., another hospital company.
In Pennsylvania, the 13-hospital nonprofit Allegheny Health, Education and Research Foundation system filed for bankruptcy protection in July. The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, a for-profit hospital chain, agreed to buy eight Allegheny hospitals in Philadelphia.
There was also trouble for companies that bought the practices of physicians. Medpartners Inc., once a high-flying player in physician practice management, left that business, casting doubt on the ability of physician groups to meet Wall Street demands for quarterly earnings growth.
Insurance premiums are again rising more rapidly. And that means employers will be paying more for care, adding to pressure on profits and, potentially, prices.
Consumers who pay for their own care faced especially steep increases in monthly premiums. The alternative was to pray for good health and go without insurance. The pool of uninsured people continued to rise by more than 1 million annually, to 43.1 million in 1997, the latest information available from the Census Bureau. The increase also reflected overall population growth and welfare policies that forced millions of low-income people off state Medicaid rosters.
Economists, while admitting that they often misjudged the strength of the economy, said a general slowdown would swell the ranks of the uninsured and add to pressures on Medicaid, which is a major, if not the largest, item in most state budgets.
Growth in Federal payments for Medicare has also slowed, cutting into a formerly lucrative business for many managed-care companies.
Last year, H.M.O.'s in 30 states announced they were leaving unprofitable Medicare markets, forcing more than 440,000 elderly Americans to scramble to replace their coverage. Mr. Kumar of Standard & Poor's said a "legislative backlash" might try to restrain managed-care companies from exiting certain markets by threatening to blackball them statewide.
On another cost-sensitive front, recent Federal laws are straining the computerized information systems of health plans just as computer problems related to the year 2000 are casting a broad shadow, Dr. Kongstvedt of Ernst & Young said. The H.M.O.'s must computerize their Medicare systems and must also track measures intended to show the quality of care they provide.
"We will know in 1999 whether the health plans and Blue Cross plans will be able to make it past the Year 2000 problems," Dr. Kongstvedt said. If their computer systems cannot distinguish between the new year and 00, meaning 1900, they may have to go to outside contractors for information services.
The H.M.O.'s would also be vulnerable to computer glitches at the Federal Medicare financing agency, state Medicaid programs and managed-care drug companies, and in the records and billing systems of hospitals and doctors.
Adding yet another big uncertainty for managed-care companies, lobbyists for doctors and consumers have pushed through patient protection laws and regulations in most states that the health maintenance organizations contend will raise their costs. Similar proposals are likely to be revived in Congress, where they were blocked last year by lobbyists for the insurance industry.
Health maintenance organizations were manipulated "into doing the job that most other companies have to do for themselves" -- squeezing down expensive services, said Ian Morrison, a health care consultant and senior fellow at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif.
"Now we are going to regulate them and prevent them from doing the things they were supposed to be doing in the first place," Mr. Morrison said.
