LENGTH: 2190 words

HEADLINE: Hospitals in New York Escalate Competition for Cancer Patients

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The vast prestige, power and -- critics would argue -- arrogance of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center can be measured by its physical space.
It is on York Avenue in the 60's -- inconvenient, like many prestigious New York hospitals, to public transportation. Many of its hospital floors feel grim and dated, with harsh lighting and nurses' stations enclosed in Plexiglass. Its parking lot is dismal, and some waiting areas are about as welcoming as the average public hospital's. 
 Yet historically, Sloan-Kettering has been the place to go for cancer treatment in New York, because of its prestigious doctors and esteemed reputation for clinical research, and the promising drugs trials it conducts. Ambience has never been the point.
But lately, curious things have been happening at Sloan-Kettering. It is building a new ambulatory care center at 53d Street and Third Avenue, smack next to several subway lines. The main hospital is undergoing a face lift: peach-toned walls, with still-life paintings, are replacing blinding white ones, sand-colored carpeting is being added to match, and nurses' stations are now open and accessible. In recent years, it has also opened a modern, attractive center for breast cancer patients on East 64th Street, complete with comfortable furniture and a shop that sells hats, scarves and other accessories.
And last week, Sloan-Kettering's 72-year-old president, Paul A. Marks, said he would retire this year, perhaps paving the way for further changes in the center's way of doing business, which at this point has included all but ignoring the managed-care movement.
This is hardly enlightenment in a vacuum. Cancer is becoming an essential part of any hospital's business, and the major medical centers in the city are aggressively trying to nibble away at Sloan-Kettering's market share. While this concentration on cancer patients is a nationwide phenomenon, experts say the new competition is particularly fevered in New York, where there are already more centers that have the official designation of the National Cancer Institute -- and its financing -- than in most other regions.
"Right now, New York is the hotbed of competition," said Christopher Demby, who runs the Oncology Round Table program for the Advisory Board, a health care research firm. "There is action being taken by every player in the market now."
Hospitals are building new centers devoted to the disease, and poaching some of the country's biggest names in cancer care -- some from Sloan-Kettering itself -- to run and staff them. They are investing in expensive technology, adding all manner of consumer-friendly fringe benefits, like support groups and libraries, to their cancer wards, and pouring money into advertising campaigns that hawk cancer treatments in a way once reserved for gentle innovations like birthing centers.
"We are here to show that Memorial is no longer the only game in town," said Marilyn Halper, executive director of Beth Israel Medical Center's gleaming new cancer center, in the Zeckendorf Tower on Union Square.
Carving off one disease and homing in on it is an important trend in medicine, especially chronic diseases that require long-term care. Diabetes, for instance, is also getting lots of attention. But few illnesses have attracted quite the same focus and investment as cancer.
The reason is largely financial: Cancer is big business. Experts believe that cancer will soon overtake cardiovascular disease as the No. 1 killer in America as the population ages and cardio-care becomes more advanced.
Cancer offers other financial incentives beyond the sheer flow of cases: the disease is still fairly immune from managed-care penny pinching, while at the same time, treatment advances have helped to streamline care. And there is constant excitement in the field: there are more than 300 cancer drugs in the pipeline.
 
Offering Convenience And New Technology
Much of the activity involves the opening of outpatient clinics, which are starting to flourish across the country as new technologies and changing medical economics allow patients to have chemotherapy and radiation treatments without staying overnight in a hospital.
Continuum Health Partners, which runs Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, has built the new outpatient center at Union Square, and beefed up its breast cancer program at St. Luke's. It has poached several doctors from other, far more prestigious cancer centers to run many of its programs, and has spent over $400,000 last year on cancer advertising campaigns.
Over at New York University, the medical center has carved off neuro-oncology as its brightest attraction, investing $10 million alone in a rare Gamma knife that administers beams of gamma radiation without surgical incision to the brain, and $2.5 million more on special M.R.I. machines, which enable doctors to rule out malignancies without a biopsy. It also lured Dr. Michael Gruber, a prestigious neuro-oncologist from the University of California in Los Angeles, to run the unit.
St. Vincent's Hospital, which has had almost no profile with cancer, has hired an outside company to build its cancer clinic. Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan and Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx have made similar deals with Dr. Bernard Salick, the California physician-entrepreneur whose 24-hour for-profit cancer clinics have raised the customer-service bar.
Significantly, all of these hospitals and their doctors are well versed in the ways of managed care, and are in a position to take the increasing load of patients who are enrolled in H.M.O.'s and can only afford to go to centers that honor them. Sloan-Kettering has all but shunned the managed care movement, a position that could cost a hospital important drug trial money. "In order to have enough patients to do these trials, you need a cross section of patients," said Joann Schellenbach, a spokeswoman for the American Cancer Society. "Not just those who can afford to go to elite physicians."
It is almost impossible to track cancer business market share figures -- most of the hospitals guard their numbers more closely than any privately held company, and many experts think that community hospitals are simply getting slices of a growing market rather than stealing business from Sloan-Kettering.
But since 1996, when Beth Israel opened its Union Square center, the number of patients seen there has risen to 21,174 from 15,027. Further, the hospital's inpatient cancer business has grown 12 percent since 1992.
At N.Y.U., new-case growth is similar. In 1993, its department of neuro-oncology saw five patients. In 1997, that number grew to 275. And if Dr. Salick's history in California is any indication, numbers of new cases at hospitals he has been affiliated with should certainly swell this year.
 
A Push in the Direction Of Patient-Friendly Care
Dr. Salick, whose mere name tends to raise hackles in more traditional circles, can be credited with helping to push New York's medical centers toward a greater emphasis on patient-friendly cancer care.
Dr. Salick began opening for-profit centers in 1986 in California, then expanded to Florida. He says that his niche is the 24-hour comprehensive service that patients can get in his centers, and that his deep knowledge of managed care, prevalent in California for a decade but still fairly new to this area, gives him an edge. He also provides the financing, badly needed by hospitals with dwindling resources, to get clinics off the ground.
"I have a highly credible reputation of running very cost effective facilities," Dr. Salick said in an interview. "You have wonderful hospitals and wonderful doctors in New York, but there is a breakdown in the delivery system. You go to these places at nine at night and no one is there. Cancer is a disease that happens to go on 24 hours a day. All these other hospitals are doing is opening a center and sticking some doctors in there."
Some cancer experts have expressed concerns about Dr. Salick's for-profit model, contending that health care surpluses should go back into the hospitals that generate them, not into shareholders' pockets. Others deride his approach as either impractical or nonthreatening. "Not too many people want radiation at 4 A.M.," said Dr. Warren Enker, the associate director of Beth Israel's cancer center. "So it's not that great a gimmick."
But Dr. Enker's colleague, Ms. Halper, admits that Dr. Salick has underscored the importance of focusing on customer service. "The for-profits have taught us the importance of being patient friendly," she said. "This is a service." A wig shop, wooden furniture designed in Vermont and a light-soaked atrium of a lobby are all part of Beth Israel's efforts in this regard.
And patient friendliness has traditionally been the Achilles' heel of Sloan-Kettering's reputation. Doctors who have worked at the hospital, and some patients who have received care there, describe an imperious and sometimes cold atmosphere, where waits can be long and doctors hard to reach.
Sometimes, warmth wins over clinical reputation. Michael Berkowitz learned he had lung cancer in 1996. His wife was pregnant, his life as a successful Wall Street lawyer was thrown into turmoil, and he had to make some decisions about treatment, fast. First, he went to Beth Israel, then to Sloan-Kettering for a second opinion. He decided to go with Beth Israel.
"Everyone says to be cured, you have to go to Sloan because they have the reputation," he said. While he was impressed with the doctors, he found the hospital to be "a scary and institutional place," he said. "It feels big, and you feel small. I felt that I did not have the same personal connection as I did to the Beth Israel doctors."
Some former Sloan-Kettering physicians say a lack of warmth toward patients was an unfortunate byproduct of working in a highly elite institution. "Sloan-Kettering is one of the institutions that has an exceedingly cumbersome administration," said Dr. Enker, who left the hospital in 1995 for Beth Israel.
"The surgeons there are very dedicated to their patients," Dr. Enker added. "But it is a very busy environment. You can't see hundreds of patients each year and not have patients feel rushed. And I hear repeated complaints that the medical oncologists are lacking in compassion, and part of the arrogance becomes, 'Look, I am the expert, you came to me for my opinion, so listen to me or you're dismissed.' "
Sloan-Kettering doctors and administrators are not unaware of their reputation. But they maintain that it is more myth than reality. "There is a misperception that we are an ivory tower," said Dr. James B. Dougherty, deputy physician in chief of clinical affairs at Sloan-Kettering. "This is a very patient-centered environment."
Nonetheless, Dr. Dougherty and his colleagues have made customer-friendly cancer care a focus of their energy in recent years, even studying the hospitality industry for clues, and have adopted elements like a more room-service-style approach to patient meals as a result. Focusing on getting patients out of the hospital and into its new 200,000-square-foot outpatient center on East 53d Street, where care will be more streamlined, is a goal.
 
Aggressively Recruiting The Cream of the Crop
Just as universities and corporations go after big names to attract new business, so do medical centers. Cancer is no exception. In the last few years, Sloan-Kettering has lost several doctors to various centers, four to Beth Israel alone. St. Luke's poached Dr. Alison Estabrook of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and she now heads St. Luke's breast center. In addition to Dr. Gruber, N.Y.U. recently recruited Dr. Patrick Kelly from the Mayo Clinic and several prominent doctors from other states. In turn, Beth Israel took three doctors from N.Y.U.
"The best way to go after patients is through building your talent base," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University. What is more, prestigious doctors attract drug companies and other institutions needed for drug trials, which are another major attraction for critically ill patients.
Interestingly, Sloan-Kettering is not just content to spiff up its hospital here. It is also encroaching on some of the cancer business of community hospitals in the region by opening satellite centers in smaller towns, which enable patients to undergo chemotherapy and radiation without having to trek into Manhattan. There is one such center on Long Island, two in New Jersey and one in Westchester, and there are plans for more, Dr. Dougherty said.
Of course, hospitals on Long Island are not cheering. "There is considerable concern in Suffolk County over Sloan-Kettering's plans," said Mr. Demby of the oncology round table, "and what that will mean to local facilities."
Indeed, the cancer war promises to escalate, experts say. "Cancer is to the 1990's what heart disease was to the 1970's," said Dr. Gruber of N.Y.U. "It puts a center on the map, and that begets business."

HEADLINE: St. Croix Hopes Gambling Will Bring Back Tourists

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: CHRISTIANSTED, V.I.

 BODY:
When Lisa Newkirk-Svarczkopf heard that casinos would soon open on St. Croix, the biggest of the three United States Virgin Islands, she moved her clothing store to a location three times the size of the old one in anticipation of a tourism boom.
"I thought I was getting a jump start on things by moving to a bigger spot," she said. 
 As it turned out, the move was four years off and Ms. Newkirk-Svarczkopf had to move back to a smaller store. But her excitement and that of other St. Croix residents has not abated as the first casino is scheduled to open here this fall. In a region battered by four major hurricanes in the last decade, casinos are seen as a catalyst to help bring back the economic prosperity that all but vanished in September 1989, when Hurricane Hugo left 90 percent of the buildings damaged and more than 20,000 people homeless.
"It's the beginning of our turnaround," Ms. Newkirk-Svarczkopf said. "We know it's just a matter of time because we know what a beautiful island this is."
The Caribbean is full of islands with casinos, but the United States Virgin Islands, where tourism accounts for two-thirds of the economy, has resisted starting their own. In a 1992 referendum, both St. Croix and St. Thomas voted the idea down, concerned by the unsavory aspects of gambling.
But the economic need for more tourism in St. Croix, a less popular tourist destination than either St. Thomas or St. John, increasingly made residents here see casinos as a necessary evil. In another referendum four years ago, St. Thomas still said no but St. Croix's 60,000 residents relented.
Moving cautiously, however, the Legislature of the Islands has limited the number of casinos to six and allowed them only as a means of increasing the number of hotel rooms in St. Croix, which stands at about 1,000 -- half what it was before Hurricane Hugo. To get a license, a casino operator would have to either build a hotel or renovate an existing one to add new rooms.
"We never talk about casinos; we talk about casino-hotels," said Eileen R. Petersen, a former territorial court judge who chairs the islands' new Casino Control Commission. "Our goal is to surpass what it was before the hurricane."
Hotels are vital to what Government officials describe as an economic chain reaction: more hotels mean more tax dollars to promote tourism, which would in turn lead to more visitors, more airline flights from the mainland, where most visitors to the islands come from, and, it is hoped, lower fares.
Airlines usually carry that most desirable breed of tourist, the overnight guest. Government figures show that in 1997, 1.6 million cruise ship passengers spent $288.3 million in the American Virgin Islands. Land-based travelers were far fewer that year, 410,000, but spent almost as much, $281.6 million.
"Cruise ships are really not doing it," said Noel Loftus, president of the St. Croix Chamber of Commerce. "Cruise ships are getting larger and have their own stores. Passengers are spending less and less money."
St. Croix lags behind its two sister islands in all tourism. In the first three quarters of 1998, Government figures show, St. Thomas and St. John together had more than 315,000 airline visitors and 1.2 million cruise passengers. St. Croix received 111,000 airline passengers and fewer than 126,000 cruise ship visitors during the same period.
St. Thomas has made a name for its duty-free shopping district, and St. John, mostly an unspoiled national park, for its natural beauty. St. Croix combines elements of the two and has found it more difficult to create a separate identity. But, its residents note, the island is bigger and friendlier and offers less predictable attractions, like West Indian and Danish colonial historic sites.
Cruzans, as the locals are known, say the Government favors St. Thomas and St. John in advertising, an accusation officials explain by saying that promotional dollars come from hotel taxes and St. Thomas has four times as many.
"They're rather paranoid about feeling they always get the short end of the stick," the islands' tourism commissioner, Wylie H. Whisonant, said about Cruzans. "It's like a sibling rivalry." And, he added, even if more tourists were directed St. Croix's way, "Where are people going to stay?"
Enter casinos.
St. Croix's first casino is scheduled to open in September in the island's scenic eastern end, on the grounds of a hotel resort that was destroyed by Hurricane Hugo and is being rebuilt as the 200-room Divi Carina Bay Resort and Casino. The hotel, owned by Grapetree Shores Inc., is expected to open a few months earlier, in April or May.
The casino license went to Grapetree Shores' partner, Treasure Bay Corporation, a Mississippi casino operator that is investing $6.8 million here, moderate by industry standards, on a 10,000-square-foot casino with 275 slot machines, 12 table games and 132 employees. By law, the Government will take 8 percent of the casinos' annual gross revenue for the first two years, and up to 12 percent by the fifth year. The casino has also agreed to give at least 80 percent of the casino jobs to Virgin Islands residents.
Bernie Burkholder, president and chief executive of Treasure Bay, said he expected his property to capture about half of what he estimated was already a $20 million casino market in St. Croix.
"Obviously there's a lot of competition in the Caribbean," Mr. Burkholder said in a telephone interview from Biloxi, Miss. "A big percentage of tourists are going to come from the United States and they'll fly over the Bahamas and Puerto Rico and other places with casinos to get to St. Croix."
"We feel a well-executed, quality property will be able to compete. We will compete well against the older, more dated properties."
In the shopping district of Christiansted, store owners said they expected nothing but economic good from the first casino venture. "This will help bring in the Marriotts and the Hiltons," said Rob Low, owner of the Gold Shop jewelry store. "This is going to give the bigger-name hotels a reason to come. Then the airlines would start adding flights."
At the Casino Control Commission, the hope was to earn respect as a world-class gaming jurisdiction.
"We want people to feel that when they gamble in the Virgin Islands the games are fair and honest," Ms. Petersen said. "The best that can happen is that we have six fabulous, widely recognized casino-hotels and that the community is happy that it invested time, money and energy in this venture."
With so much at stake, Treasure Bay officials are feeling some pressure. "I'm concerned sometimes that maybe the expectations are too high and people would be disappointed," Mr. Burkholder said. "I know a lot of people are watching, the people in St. Croix, the investment community."
But although casinos are not a cure-all for the island's troubles, Mr. Burkholder said, they could make a difference if their success helps stimulate other investment. "We're the catalyst, but we won't by ourselves double the tourism," he said. "But in two or three years that can happen."

HEADLINE: Partisan Tone Seen in Return Of Legislature

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
With the capital's political landscape left virtually untouched by the November elections, lawmakers return here this week for a 1999 legislative session that experts say is likely to yield the same sort of partisanship and acrimony that have become synonymous with Albany.
Both Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, and his Democratic rivals in the State Legislature enter the new year with their hands strengthened by voters. Mr. Pataki won a second term by handily defeating all three of his major opponents, while Democrats increased their already large majority in the Assembly by one seat. 
 The election results seem to have emboldened these bitter adversaries as they prepare to confront a host of important policy issues, from proposed utility rate cuts to criminal justice initiatives.
The Governor and legislative leaders must also grapple with the main business of Albany, adopting a state budget. The Legislature has failed for the last six years to enact a budget by the April 1 deadline, becoming mired instead in long and bitter legislative sessions that have regularly plunged the state into fiscal uncertainty.
The budget is expected to be among the most contentious issues again this year, largely because the state has a ballooning budget surplus that Democrats and Republicans are already deeply divided over how to spend. Experts contend that the surplus could total as much as $2 billion by March 31, when the state's 1998-99 fiscal year ends.
Lawmakers note that at least they will not face the same kinds of highly partisan issues that divided them in previous years, like revamping the state's welfare and rent-regulation laws. Zenia Mucha, the Governor's spokeswoman, said that left open the possibility for a relatively smooth session. "If partisan politics do not become the focal point," she said, "I think we can have a relatively productive session."
But the work awaiting the Legislature in 1999 would be difficult to resolve even in the most collegial environment. Democrats in the Assembly say they intend to push a plan to cut electricity rates by reducing the Pataki administration's role in reorganizing New York's electric power industry. Mr. Pataki has resisted that proposal in the past, though he also strongly advocates cutting electric rates.
Some Democrats are also seeking to ease what they and others assert are the state's Draconian drug penalties, though Republicans have made no effort to change them even as they acknowledge that the penalties should be more flexible.
Mr. Pataki and his Republican allies who control the State Senate say they will renew their call for a sweeping overhaul of the state's juvenile justice system, seeking harsher sanctions and flexibility to prosecute youths as adults for certain violent crimes. Democrats have expressed willingness to compromise on this issue in the past but have failed to pass a bill that Republicans would support. Mr. Pataki and Senate Republicans also want to pass a package of bills that would stiffen penalties for sex offenses and crimes committed in schools.
A looming complication for 1999 could be Mr. Pataki's apparent ambition for national office. After proposing an election-year budget last year that was criticized by fiscal conservatives nationwide, the Governor plans to offer the kind of austere budget that he championed in his first two years in office. His aides say he mainly wants to hedge against a downturn in the economy.
Such a move could also help enhance his standing among conservatives who dominate the national Republican Party, even as it potentially angers Assembly Democrats who battled against deep spending cuts that he proposed in 1995, his first year in office.
Anger between Mr. Pataki and the Legislature would be nothing new. They clashed fiercely over a surplus last year after Mr. Pataki vetoed hundreds of millions of dollars in programs approved by both houses of the Legislature. The items vetoed were largely Democratic initiatives, like a plan that would have spent $500 million to refurbish existing schools and build new ones. But Senate Republicans also saw some programs dear to them cut from the budget.
The hostility stirred by that action has yet to subside as Mr. Pataki's main nemesis in the budget debate, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, indicated in a recent interview. "I don't think the public will let the Governor get away with his partisan vetoes," Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said. The Speaker, ignoring the Governor's overwhelming re-election victory in November, added that Mr. Pataki's "right wing" agenda was "out of step with New Yorkers."
Not even the Governor's recent decision to grant lawmakers a much coveted pay raise has helped ease the tensions. After years of blocking a raise, the Governor agreed to approve one last month during a brief special session. In return, Democrats, by far the most vocal supporters of a pay increase, passed legislation that allows for the creation of publicly financed schools that operate largely independently.
But Democrats and some Republicans in the Legislature are still seething over Mr. Pataki's contention that lawmakers did not deserve a salary increase.
"I think lawmakers on both sides of the aisle feel he was being demeaning," Mr. Silver said.
What may be hardest to predict for the 1999 session is the role of the Republicans who make up the majority in the Senate. They have been the Governor's loyal allies in his campaign to reduce taxes and toughen criminal penalties. He will need them again in this second term.
But the Senate Republicans have also been willing to align themselves with Assembly Democrats when it suited them. In 1996, for example, they helped Democrats block the Governor's proposals for sharp spending cuts in education, welfare and health care, among other programs. The Republicans feared the impact that such cuts would have on their constituents.
Mr. Pataki also stunned and angered Senate Republicans last year when he vetoed not only Democratic initiatives from the budget but Republican ones as well. The vetoes were largely viewed as an attempt by the Governor to burnish his credentials as a tough fiscal conservative and thus improve his prospects for national office. But he risks alienating Senate Republicans if he continues along that path.
The Republicans have already started staking out their own agenda for 1999, even before the Governor has laid out his own. They are seeking a package of multiyear tax cuts that would cost the state $770 million by 2002-03.
The Senate plan would, among other things, use much of the budget surplus to provide tax credits to individuals who pay into medical savings accounts, cut taxes for businesses that make capital investments, reduce utility taxes for banks and insurers and offer tax credits to businesses that provide child care for employees.
While Mr. Pataki has generally supported tax cuts, people close to him say he wants to set part of the budget surplus aside in case the economy slows and tax revenues dwindle. Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader in the Senate, said in a recent interview that he shared the Governor's concerns. But Mr. Bruno and his Republican colleagues in the Senate also believe that further tax cuts would bolster the economy.
The main opposition to the Senate plan is expected to come from Democrats in the Assembly, who would like to use the surplus for initiatives like refurbishing schools and reducing class sizes in the fourth through fifth grades. The Assembly persuaded the Senate and the Governor to approve a similar plan two years ago that was intended to reduce class sizes in kindergarten through the third grade.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY;
How the U.S. Consumer Feels . . . and How the Economy Is Doing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The American economy is in good shape, according to 85 percent of the 895 adults polled in the middle of December by The New York Times and CBS News.
This positive outlook from respondents to the nationwide telephone survey was even higher than the 83 percent who found the economy either very good or fairly good at the start of last year. 
 In fact, optimism about the national economy has been gaining almost steadily, according to poll results, since February 1992.
Analysts believe that consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economy, will continue to feel good about the economy and continue to spend freely.
"Consumer spending is by and large determined by income and wealth," said Michael Cloherty, a bond strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. And many households seem to have more of both.
With the unemployment rate at 4.4 percent, the lowest in a generation, most people not only have jobs but the likelihood -- despite some layoffs -- that they will continue to be employed. Raises may not seem particularly generous, but neither are they being eaten up by inflation. And a lot of households are building assets as the stock market ends its fourth consecutive year of double-digit gains.
Another reason many Americans have more spending money is that they took advantage of tumbling interest rates last year to refinance their home mortgages. That freed up cash for monthly spending and for paying off debts.
"Consumers," said Keith J. Leggett, a senior economist at the American Bankers Association, "feel fairly good about their financial circumstances." ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

HEADLINE: Biracial Politics

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"In the Rural White South, Seeds of a Biracial Politics" (front page, Dec. 30) highlights two important points about race and redistricting: polarized voting is not an all-or-nothing proposition, and black candidates can win office even in majority-white districts with widespread racism.
Biracial politics can have a transformative effect on a community: the more that white voters see a black politician representing their interests, the less easy it is to maintain historic prejudices. And having a black representative in a rural district goes a long way toward shattering stereotypes about the policy positions minority candidates take. 
 This does not mean that districting should be race-blind, but it does indicate that highly gerrymandered majority-black districts work against minority interests by making it more likely that surrounding districts will go Republican and by eliminating the possibility of a biracial politics that was the goal of the civil rights movement.
 
DAVID EPSTEIN
Stanford, Calif., Dec. 30, 1998
 
The writer is a professor of political economy at Stanford University.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- 1998 HIGHLIGHTS;
The Fed Seeks an Even Keel

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve reduced interest rates three times in seven weeks late last year because the global financial crisis was making it hard for companies to raise money, threatening the long expansion in the United States.
 The three quarter-point reductions in the Federal funds rate, to 4.75 percent, helped fuel a rebound in the stock market while providing considerable reassurance to other countries. 
 Although analysts still expect the American economy to slow this year, perhaps enough to require further rate cuts, the continuation of the nation's long expansion no longer appears to be in any immediate danger.

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: ECONOMY & INDUSTRY -- 1998 HIGHLIGHTS;
A Decidedly Drab Year for Many Fashion Companies

 BODY:
It's been a tough year for the fashion industry. Among the year's casualties: Isaac Mizrahi, below, lost his financial backing and closed his design business. Anne Klein & Company was put on the block, Kenar Enterprises filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Andrea Jovine shut its doors and Todd Oldham closed his wholesale collection business.
 Faced with sagging sales and profits, Liz Claiborne also fell victim to the industry's malaise. In December, the New York-based clothing maker announced a reorganization that would result in the closing of about 30 stores, eliminate 400 jobs and cost about $17 million. 
 The thinning ranks of design concerns stemmed to some degree from a gradual erosion in consumer confidence as well as a ripple effect from an earlier consolidation among department stores, which weakened fashion's grip on retailing. Consumers reined in their free-spending ways and balked at look-alike offerings available at most chains.
 Publicly held fashion companies sagged. Shares of Donna Karan International, for example, lost about 40 percent of their value. And St. John Knits, seeking to avoid the pressures of Wall Street while navigating the vagaries of the industry and customer fashion dictates, announced plans to go private after five years as a public company.
 Profits at department stores also slipped as sales of apparel flagged and Internet shopping gained followers.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
The Debut of the Euro Underwhelms the British
Officially, Britain has been reticent over the euro, but the public debate about Europe's new single currency remains fierce. As major banks prepared over the weekend to trade in the new currency, no one in financial circles seemed to think that Britain would escape the tidal pull of the vast euro market lapping at its shores. A1 

The Clinton Administration policy on the euro has assumed that anything that helps build a more prosperous trading partner on the other side of the Atlantic is good for the United States. But that policy masks some complex issues for the United States. The euro may threaten the dominance of the dollar as the world's primary reserve currency. A6
 
Israel Arrests Cult Members
Israeli police officials arrested eight American members of a Denver-based apocalyptic cult who the officials said were planning to mark the millennium by committing suicide or provoking their own killings in the streets of Jerusalem. The police said the eight belonged to the Concerned Christians cult and planned to destroy themselves shortly before the millennium in order to hasten the Second Coming of Christ. A4
 
Angola Peace Efforts in Doubt
The top United Nations official in Angola called into question future peacekeeping efforts after a United Nations-chartered plane with eight people aboard was shot down on Saturday, the second such incident in a week. The head of the United Nations Observer Mission in Angola said the increasing conflict in Angola and disintegration of the country's 1994 peace accord placed the United Nations peace mission in doubt. A4
 
Pakistani Leader Was Target
A powerful bomb apparently intended for Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif exploded under a bridge he was to cross on a road near his home in Lahore, killing three people. Mr. Sharif was not in the vicinity of the blast and was unharmed, but "obviously it was targeting the person of the Prime Minister," said Mushahid Hussain, the Information Minister, speaking from Islamabad. A9

The Chinese police have sentenced two members of a would-be opposition political party to nine months of detention on what a rights group called fabricated charges. Han Lifa and Cai Guihua are the latest members of the nascent China Democracy Party to be imprisoned in the ruling Communist Party's broadest crackdown on dissent in years. (AP)
 
15 Killed in Pakistan Mosque
Gunmen opened fire as Shiite Muslim worshipers prayed at a mosque in eastern Punjab province today, killing 15 people and wounding at least 25, the police said. No one claimed responsibility. The police fear that the attack in Shah Jamal, 180 miles south of Lahore, is part of the relentless violence between rival Shiite and Sunni Muslim sects that has killed hundreds in Pakistan. (AP)

HEADLINE: OUTLOOK 1999: MARKETS & INVESTING -- 1998 HIGHLIGHTS;
A Flurry of Home Improvements

 BODY:
Call it the nesting instinct. Last year, kitchens, bathrooms and dens made the best-dressed lists of many as consumers favored chenille throws over sweaters, scented candles over trendy perfumes and designer labels on their linens and tableware over ones on their jackets. Also, a strong economy and interest rates hovering at 30-year lows pushed sales of new and existing homes to record levels for the third consecutive year; Fannie Mae estimated that 5.6 million units were sold. Consumers -- especially aging baby boomers, confident about the prospects for jobs and income -- went shopping, lifting home ownership to an all-time high. All told, Americans spent about $1.5 trillion on new loans and refinancings, channeling some of that cash to renovations as well.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: A Tough Match: 'Jesse the Gov.' vs. Daily Grind

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Dec. 29

 BODY:
The new Governor of Minnesota doesn't know exactly what he'll do in office yet, but he has made a decision about his daily schedule.
No appointments before 9 o'clock in the morning, he has told his staff.
Why? 
 "Arnold was very worried about me," the Governor-elect said the other day. "Arnold told me I really have to get back to working out, so that's what I'm going to do every morning."
Arnold would be Arnold Schwarzenegger, of course. And he was offering advice to his friend and fellow muscle man, Jesse (the Body) Ventura, the former professional wrestler who happened to get elected in November to Minnesota's highest office.
As Mr. Ventura officially becomes Governor on Monday, there is still a lot up in the air.
How will Mr. Ventura, who won 37 percent of the vote under the banner of the Reform Party, work with a House of Representatives controlled by Republicans and a Senate controlled by Democrats? What will his policies be? How will a self-styled outsider who ran under the slogan "Retaliate in '98" adjust to being part of the political establishment?
One thing seems clear: Mr. Ventura will be unlike any governor Minnesota -- or any state, for that matter -- has ever seen.
He has already been a subject of the comic strip "Doonesbury" and a guest on Jay Leno's and David Letterman's talk shows. He has signed a six-figure book deal. And he is arranging for the sale of Jesse Ventura action figures and T-shirts with slogans like "In Jesse We Trust."
Even his elaborate series of inauguration events seems unprecedented, including a gigantic party later this month for 13,800 people in Minnesota's basketball arena, for which tickets at $10, $15 and $20 sold out long ago. (Mr. Ventura did, however, forgo his initial promise to arrive at the official inaugural ceremony in a helicopter and rappel down through the Capitol dome -- his staff concluded that was a little too dangerous.)
"This is strange stuff," said Steven Schier, chairman of the political science department at Carleton College. "Usually a governor comes in and you know where he stands, who his enemies are and what he's going to do for the next four years. He's working hard at it and he's smart, but the problem is he's got zero background."
Mr. Ventura, the strapping, chrome-domed, former bad boy wrestler, action-film actor and talk radio host, stunned prognosticators by trouncing two respected and well-known opponents, the Democratic Attorney General, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, and the Republican Mayor of St. Paul, Norm Coleman.
Many of Mr. Ventura's supporters were young people, especially men, and nearly half had only a high school education. They saw something refreshing in Mr. Ventura, whose previous political experience was as a part-time suburban mayor and who himself voted in only 4 of the last 14 elections.
Now, Mr. Ventura has put away his leather jacket and jeans -- and his occasional camouflage outfit and Australian bush hat.
"Suits used to take me 40 minutes," said Mr. Ventura, who has a gift for quickly shifting between his entertainer and politician personas. "Now I can do it in 12."
He is getting used to a chauffeured sedan instead of his beloved Porsche. And he has submitted to a phalanx of bodyguards, because, he says, "It wouldn't be too good if the Governor knocks somebody down."
Aware he has a lot to learn, he is trying to get off to a strong start. He has assembled an advisory committee and immediate staff, drawing some of the more independent-minded people from all parties, people generally considered skilled and knowledgeable. He has spent time touring the state and visiting every state department. But he has just begun to assemble a Cabinet and says that will take more time.
"We're like the discoverers of the New World," Mr. Ventura said in his transition office in the basement of the Capitol, where he has hung a neon sign with the words "Jesse the Gov" and an image of Rodin's "Thinker," a pose he struck in one of his campaign commercials. "There was no one who could sit there and say, 'Been there, done that.' "
Since the election, Mr. Ventura, who is generally considered fiscally conservative and socially progressive on issues like abortion, has given few concrete hints about his policies, saying he wants to be prudent and consider a range of ideas.
When asked after the election about the details of his tax cut proposals, he responded, "Oh, sheesh."
In a recent speech to farmers, he said he wanted to "deregulate some stuff," which he later said referred to lifting restrictions, like those prohibiting farmers from growing industrial hemp.
And during the campaign, he criticized state-subsidized child care and the state's health insurance program for children. He said that families should not have children until they could afford them without government assistance. And he told college students, many of whom benefit from state tuition aid: "You don't need the government. There are plenty of ways to get through college. You're smart enough."
Mr. Ventura now suggests his actual approach will be less extreme. His chief of staff, Steven Bosacker, said that Mr. Ventura had a habit of saying things that were intended to provoke debate, rather than establish a policy stance.
"I think unfortunately people tend to believe that as soon as you make a comment, that's your firm position," Mr. Bosacker said.
Mr. Ventura is finding that even firm campaign pledges require careful implementation. After promising to give back the state surplus in increments of $1,000 for every man, woman and child, Mr. Ventura is evaluating different options for returning a surplus and wants to wait until the end of the budget period in June to make sure the state has the money in hand.
It is also not clear how he plans to accomplish one of his major goals: reducing school class size to 17 without spending more money.
Still, while he is treading carefully, Mr. Ventura has already managed to push the envelope, especially in an ethically strait-laced state like Good Government Minnesota.
After refusing contributions from political action committees in the campaign, he has accepted corporate donations to finance his transition costs, although he says he does not look at the contributor list.
He has proposed that his wife be paid a salary. And he wants to put the money from selling T-shirts and action figures into his campaign fund, but will give it to charity if the state's campaign ethics board nixes the idea. (He has also asked stores not to sell the popular, but unlicensed, items that came out shortly after the election: T-shirts and baseball caps that say "My Governor Can Beat Up Your Governor.")
"A whole host of things have come out that are extremely unconventional," said Steve Sviggum, the new Republican Speaker of the State House. "I guess I would just as soon that he focus on the job that he ran for."
So far, though, hardly anyone seems to be complaining. A poll in December by The Minneapolis Star Tribune found that more people would vote for Mr. Ventura today than did in November. Only 3 percent answered yes to a somewhat unconventional poll question -- whether they considered Mr. Ventura an "embarrassment."
And Mr. Ventura has another tremendous thing going for him: a state being left in remarkably good shape by the departing Governor, Arne Carlson, with low unemployment, a projected budget surplus of $3.3 billion over the next two and a half years and money from a tobacco lawsuit settlement to boot.
"I don't expect it's going to be a session that's going to produce a lot of new initiatives, and as far as budget, it's a pat hand," said Roger Moe, the Democratic State Senate majority leader. "It's very difficult to screw it up, to be perfectly honest."
Perhaps a more difficult challenge for Mr. Ventura will be balancing his stated desire to "bring honor to this office" with his rebel instinct.
So far, he has satisfied his need to tweak conformity by smoking stogies on the Capitol steps and eating an occasional lunch in "the regular people's cafeteria."
But some experts worry that he might get bored or frustrated.
"I still have a sense that Jesse may become tired of playing governor," said Chris Gilbert, chairman of the political science department at Gustavus Adolphus College in St. Peter. "Not that he doesn't take it seriously, but I think it is another role for him. I wonder how he's going to hold up in April when the legislation is being introduced. I wonder if he's going to really have the stomach and patience to sit through it."

LENGTH: 1906 words

HEADLINE: No Funeral For OPEC Just Yet

BYLINE: By Ron Chernow; Ron Chernow is the author of "Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr."

 BODY:
Even as cruise missiles rained down on Iraq in mid-December, oil prices scarcely budged from their severely depressed levels of about $11 a barrel. In the past, Middle East tension inevitably spooked the oil markets, provoking panic buying. This time, the December price slump presented us with a stunning paradox: we had waged war against Saddam Hussein precisely to safeguard the Persian Gulf oil fields, yet the market's blase reaction to the fighting seemed to underscore the marginal status of Mideast oil in the global economy.
Is our apprehension about Iraq's threat to Arabian oil now sadly anachronistic? In a world brimming with oil -- and with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries providing only 40 percent of it -- should we finally stop fretting about the Middle East? 
 In fact, it would be both foolish and premature to gloat over OPEC's demise. A retrospective glance at the oil industry last year suggests that, far from being liberated from Mideast oil, we may be sliding into a dangerous new era of dependence on the Arab sheikdoms.
In the 1970's, OPEC was the fearsome bogyman of Western politics, able to quadruple prices and impose a punitive embargo on the United States. The resulting shortage riled many economies, provoking rampant inflation, sluggish growth and plummeting stock markets. Sober analysts predicted that oil might fetch $100 a barrel by century's end.
In the 1990's, we have seen the movie running in reverse as squabbling OPEC members have failed to curb a glut that has slashed oil prices to their lowest inflation-adjusted levels in a quarter century. The breathtaking price tumble has helped to tame inflation, spur economic growth and buoy stocks. Commentators now deride the once haughty OPEC as a sorry relic, rent by blatant cheating and factional feuds. In a world flooded with oil, it has seemed to surrender its formidable powers to the marketplace.
Some factors that have humbled OPEC -- including the sharp contraction in Asian oil demand and balmy weather in North America -- are passing phenomena. The great and most lasting threat to the cartel is the technological revolution that has transformed the oil business. Back in 1972, the Club of Rome, sounding the apocalyptic note so voguish at the time, warned that world reserves might be exhausted in a little more than a generation. What its analysts failed to foresee was the amazing ability of technology to take a finite resource and convert it into something seemingly infinite.
Long a low-tech backwater, the oil industry during the past decade has become an exotic showplace of futuristic technologies. Producers can now find and produce oil with exceptional precision and at lower costs than was ever dreamed possible. Special sensors create three-dimensional maps of deep geological formations. Producers can drill horizontally for long distances, extracting oil trapped beneath towns. With computers guiding drill bits for miles underground, producers have resurrected numberless old fields long thought depleted.
The upshot of such innovation is that analysts have radically revised their sense of the earth's oil-bearing potential. Supplies today are dictated not by the amount discovered but by what can be profitably produced at a given price. In Texas, Oklahoma and elsewhere, a new breed of independent oil producer has extended the lives of small, aging fields. Their so-called stripper wells produce 10 barrels or less per day. This might sound insignificant, but they have been furnishing America with about as much oil as imports from Saudi Arabia have.
Unfortunately, the strippers are now reeling from a crisis that may prove fatal. They typically break even when oil is in the $12-to-$15-a-barrel range, but as prices have fallen below that barrier they have suffered a disaster. Small companies are going bankrupt almost daily, and thousands of wells are being capped in the continental United States. The oil service industry is another casualty, with only about half of its available rigs searching for oil off American shores. Even our giant energy companies are curtailing exploration budgets, and this will simply deepen American dependence on foreign oil.
Bolstered by their networks of refineries and gas stations and their strength in petrochemicals, the big oil companies haven't been as vulnerable as their smaller brethren. Yet the spate of recent megamergers shows that their plight, too, has grown precarious. In early December, the Exxon-Mobil merger reunited the two largest pieces of the Standard Oil trust dismantled by the Supreme Court in 1911. Antitrust concerns about the combination have been misplaced: the new colossus will refine less than 14 percent of American oil, compared with nearly 90 percent for Standard Oil.
The merger testifies as much to the partners' weakness as to their strength. When John D. Rockefeller formed Standard Oil in 1870, he aimed to consolidate refiners into a giant cartel that could contain falling prices. In contrast, the Exxon-Mobil and BP-Amoco deals demonstrate that even the biggest companies now accept lower prices as a fait accompli and can sustain their profitability only through stringent cost-cutting and consolidation.
The real predicament shadowing the Exxon-Mobil merger resides with the State Department, not with the Justice Department. Exxon has enjoyed the luxury of inexpensive oil from Alaska and other domestic fields but must now replace these bountiful fields with more expensive oil from abroad. In the past 20 years, no giant new American fields have been discovered to rival the Texas strikes of the early 1900's or 1930's or Alaska in the late 1960's. Because Mobil has lacked a strong base in domestic oil and has been more aggressive in tapping frontiers abroad, it was an attractive partner for Exxon. The major oil companies are too large to bother with tiny stripper wells at home, which means that their future exploration will be largely in the third world. And Big Oil will turn inescapably to the Middle East as the last place left with huge, cheap reserves.
While OPEC today accounts for only 40 percent of world production, it possesses 75 percent of known reserves. And its Persian Gulf members can drain these vast reservoirs for less than $2 a barrel. By contrast, it costs the super-efficient Exxon an estimated $7 to produce a barrel of domestic oil and more than $10 a barrel for foreign oil. Given the dramatic cost advantage enjoyed by Saudi Arabia and its neighbors over foreign oil companies and non-OPEC producers, OPEC may be on the threshold of a new hegemony.
Now that crude prices have sagged to such low levels, each further dollar decline will bankrupt more high-cost competitors and widen the Arabs' market share. Might OPEC deliberately boost production and drive down prices to single digits to recapture control of the oil market?
It seems unlikely that it would do so by design. In the short run, this risky strategy would rob it of too much revenue before it won the compensating gain in market share.
But if the United States slipped into recession, intensifying the glut and pushing oil down to, say, $5 a barrel, the Persian Gulf states would be back in full control. Production and exploration budgets would be sharply reduced outside the Middle East as prices fell below the cost of extracting oil elsewhere.
During the anti-American frenzy of the 1970's, the Arab states nationalized their oil companies, chasing out the large Western companies that had operated their fields in the early postwar years. In response, big oil companies have turned to places that are geographically remote and politically volatile. The countries rich in new oil and gas deposits -- including Nigeria, Angola, Indonesia, Russia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan and Colombia -- are also places steeped in corruption, poverty and violence. The acrimonious dispute over the pipeline route that will carry oil from Baku in Azerbaijan to Western markets illustrates the extreme geopolitical hazards that await American policy makers in the next century. Guaranteeing oil supplies will create security problems that may make the Middle East seem a peaceful oasis in comparison.
As chance would have it, the Arab oil states are about to forge an alliance with the Western companies 20 years after most of them lost their concessions in the region. On Sept. 25, a Saudi crown prince presided over a one-hour "tea party" to explore possible cooperation with chief executives from seven American companies. Prominent among the chieftains was Lucio Noto, the chairman of Mobil. Analysts have speculated that one motive for the Exxon-Mobil merger was to combine Mobil's Saudi connections with Exxon's capital to strengthen its bargaining position with the desert kingdom.
Why would Saudi Arabia court American investment at a moment of patent weakness for Big Oil? The Saudis have watched jealously as Mexico and Venezuela have angled to supplant them as the foremost supplier to the United States, the largest oil consumer. Not only is Saudi Arabia loath to cede the American market with Asia in recession, but it wishes to retain the Defense Department security umbrella that accompanied its former status as America's largest oil exporter.
The Mideast oil states would also like to profit from the new technologies patented by American companies and to enlist their worldwide refining and marketing apparatus to sell oil. It was partly in the hope of providing expensive services, including exploration and pipeline building, to producers in the Middle East that BP merged with Amoco and Exxon with Mobil to form a critical mass of capital and expertise. Faced with the extreme risks and production costs in new areas like the Caspian Sea, the American oil companies will be powerfully attracted by any new partnership offered by the Arab states. Iran, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates have already formed joint ventures with foreign companies.
All of the foregoing suggests that if oil prices stay low -- and that isn't certain, especially if Asia revives -- the oil industry of the early 21st century may well resemble that of the 1960's more than that of the 1990's. Far from being extricated from the morass of Mideast politics, we may only grow more entangled.
The low prices of recent years have produced an extraordinary complacency about energy policy. Profligate Americans have turned to sports utility vehicles, light trucks and other old-fashioned gas guzzlers. At the time of the Arab embargo in 1973, the United States produced 9.2 million barrels of oil a day; last year we managed only 6.4 million barrels. Yet nobody talks anymore about our perilous reliance on foreign oil. In fact, energy policy is so seldom discussed in Washington these days that the term has acquired a quaint ring. By focusing solely on deterring Iraqi aggression over the past eight years, we have been diverted from the concern over secure energy supplies that prompted both the gulf war and the recent air strikes in the first place.
It may be naive to assume that anybody in our sex-obsessed capital will care about things as banal as energy conservation, fuel efficiency and the like. But the alternative is to be forever menaced by the future Saddam Husseins who will undoubtedly emerge to challenge the American presence in the Middle East's oil fields.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;
A Cuban Sound Dancing North

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
There has been a flood of traditional records from Cuba recently, and the reasons for it are simple. The first is the descent into irrelevance, perhaps temporary, of the Havana-based Timba dance music world, which started receiving plenty of attention five years ago and is now self-destructing. The second is the international success of the Ry Cooder-produced album, "Buena Vista Social Club," released last year. Given the easy availability of hundreds of fine little local Cuban son bands and older singers playing the same music made by Buena Vista Social Club, it's not surprising that the market is overflowing. Here are a handful of the best; all are available from Descarga, (800) 377-2647 or at www.descarga.com.
 
Ibrahim Ferrer: 'Tierra Caliente'
Mr. Ferrer was the star vocalist with the Afro-Cuban All-Stars (another Ry Cooder production), who released an album in 1997 and toured the United States last year. His own record, with Los Bocucos, is a marvel of syncopation and oddness. "Tierra Caliente" (Egrem) is sort of son and sort of salsa, and it shows a side of Cuban music that Americans used to the authenticity of "Buena Vista Social Club" haven't seen. 
 There are electric keyboards and electric guitars, and the rhythms draw from all over the world. Sometimes the music sounds Haitian, sometimes Cuban, and it is always joyous, with a sense of humor that's palpable whether one understands the words or not. And it has an intensity that only the best dance music achieves.
 
Los Naranjos: 'Mi Son Tiene Piel Morena"
What a rocking little record. With a tres guitar motoring away at rhythmic figures, the music, hardcore son, never stops. Most of the songs are older without being overfamiliar, and the chorus sings away, surrounding the rough tones of the lead singer.
There's a force under the prettiness of the music; suddenly the music is charging down the highway, swinging with power. "Mi Son Tiene Piel Morena" (Eurotropical) is perfectly made; the band is obviously a working group, and its precision helps drive the dance-floor sensibility.
 
El Son Entero: 'Cuba'
Yet another little rock-house of a record. This time it features the tres playing of Luis Acosta Pino, a virtuoso, and when the singers call on him to solo, they call him the killer of the tres. His solos charge the record, zipping around the fretboard, using more of a jazz sensibility -- he even bends some notes -- than the traditional Cuban point of view. The music is built around his solos, and when he starts the band seems to stand back, wondering what's about to pop out of Mr. Acosta's imagination. The group is from the province of Camaguey, and it uses a few unusual rhythms. If anybody needed an argument to prove that the son doesn't stand completely still, this is it. There are occasional imperfections in the singing in "Cuba," (Playasound) but the feeling and the solos make up for the problems.
 
Laito Sureda: 'Ahora Comienzo a Vivir'
Mr. Sureda is 84 and the title of the record, "Now I Start to Live," has some truth to it and some wishful thinking, given Cuba's economy. Mr. Sureda sang with Celia Cruz in the Sonora Matancera and spent much of his life traveling. "Ahora Comienzo a Vivir" (Eurotropical) catches him in bolero, son and guaguanco territory, backed by Su Sonora, a swinging small band with a few trumpets. It is sophisticated dance music in an older style influenced by jazz, and Mr. Sureda's large, intense voice floats over the classic sound of the band. The music is nicely balanced and gentle, but with a rhythmic tug.
 
La Banda Municipale de Santiago de Cuba: 'Fanfare Cubaine'
This is an oddity, a record of the community brass band from Santiago, home of the son, produced by the French ethnomusicologist Emmanuelle Honorin. The band, started in 1900, is big and full, and it takes on famous sones, danzones and congas and turns them into lilting, beautiful orchestral pieces. "Fanfare Cubaine" (Buda) includes the Buena Vista Social Club's "Chan Chan," with tubas announcing the bass line. The recording is a footnote, but a gorgeous one that suggests the breadth of imagination and the conservative essence of Cuban music.

HEADLINE: Burberry Modernizes and Reinvents Itself

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO 

 BODY:
It was a neat trick, and between Rose Marie Bravo and Roberto Menichetti, they seem to have pulled it off. They took a moldering old British clothing company called Burberrys, known mainly for its plaid umbrellas and raincoat linings, altered the name to Burberry and gave it a spiffy new look without destroying its essential character.
Ms. Bravo, the chief executive, and Mr. Menichetti, the design director, accomplished the feat by looking at the 150-year history of Burberry and updating the best of its attributes into a thoroughly modern line of women's clothing and accessories. 
 The trench coats, the plaid, the innovative fabrics -- they're all there, but reinvented for a new age. The trench coat has been streamlined, stripped of extraneous epaulets and tabs. The plaid (which the British call a check, reserving "plaid" for tartans) has come out from under wraps to appear on skirts and dresses. New ways with materials include coating canvas with voile and distressing leather with perfume. But there has also been a return to gabardine, the fabric that Thomas Burberry, who founded the company in 1847, had specially woven for the durable coats worn by sportsmen and the military.
The first collection of the new Burberry, for spring of this year, was quietly introduced last September in the company's London showroom. Although it wasn't shown on the runway with all the hoopla that entails, the line took the fashion world by storm. Many fashion magazines borrowed pieces to photograph, and retailers all over the world bought the collection.
In stores where once just a smattering of raincoats could be found, there are now motorcycle jackets and trench coats in buttery soft leather, jersey T-shirts and hip-slung skirts that bare the midriff, motocross pants of stretch canvas with insets of leather, ankle-length kilts without pleats, and plaid dresses of Irish linen loomed on antique machines. Colors are mainly cool neutrals, with touches of sky blue, mauve and a yellow inspired by a pair of the Duke of Windsor's trousers.
The first styles are now arriving in Burberry's own stores, in Bergdorf Goodman in New York, Jeffrey in Atlanta, Louis of Boston, Joseph and Harrods in London, Colette in Paris, Joyce in Hong Kong and Taiwan, Trois Pommes in Geneva and Zurich, and Club 21 in Singapore. Barneys New York started selling the clothes last week in its Madison Avenue and Beverly Hills stores.
"We made a big commitment," said Judy Collinson, an executive vice president of Barneys. "Only 15 percent of the delivery is in now, and the leather coats are already selling. The line has two things we always love: beautiful, modern, amazing fabrics and the old English sports tradition. The marriage of the two things has been done beautifully. There's a lightheartedness to it, but the quality is definitely there. We were so excited when we saw it in London. It was something new and exceptional."
Joseph Boitano, the executive vice president of Bergdorf Goodman, called the line "very sophisticated, in its color palette and styling."
"It's very clean sportswear, with a bit of a twist, but still keeping the Burberry concept," he said. "It's very item-driven, and that's very much how our customer shops these days."
The words of praise are music to Ms. Bravo's ears. Since she left the presidency of Saks Fifth Avenue in October 1997 to reinvent Burberry, she has hired designers, found new factories in Italy, eliminated inappropriate licenses and set up a new band of distributors, dropping those that were channeling goods into discount stores in Asia.
"This is just the beginning, just the DNA of the new Burberry," she said last week in the women's department of the Burberry store at 9 East 57th Street. The first shipment of spring clothes was hanging on racks, and nearby the new handbags and shoes were on display.
Besides Mr. Menichetti, the new Burberry team includes Eugenia Ulasewicz, as president of retail and wholesale operations in the United States; Michele Smith, as senior vice president for women's wear; Robin Marino, as senior vice president for accessories, and J. Stanley Tucker, as senior vice president for men's wear.
Mr. Tucker is currently working on the men's-wear licenses, changing factories to upgrade the current line of suits and coats and adding more luxurious fabrics. Meanwhile, Mr. Menichetti is designing the signature men's collection, which will be made in Italy; it will be introduced next July for the spring 2000 season.
Ms. Bravo decided to concentrate on the women's wear first, she said, because it had no fashion image.
"Burberry had a masculine image," she said. "The women's was anonymous. We felt we could make a big statement in the women's world."
"We were very fortunate in that Burberry has such a reputation globally," she added. "When you think of all the designers and brands working so hard to build world recognition, and the Burberry check is as recognizable as the Coca-Cola bottle."
But that hasn't stopped the design staff from tinkering with the classic plaid, making it bigger on certain fabrics and changing the background color slightly. There are even two tone-on-tone plaids, in beige and in dark blue, used so far only for handbags. There are also sleek new leather shoulder bags that are molded to follow the curve of the hips.
The trench coat has been reinterpreted as a double-layered dress, and the pleatless kilt is fashioned from two pieces that wrap around the hips. There are knee-length and ankle-length skirts, and blazers with a feminine cut.
Mr. Menichetti, who worked on Jil Sander's men's wear line for four years, comes from a family of Italian fabric and clothing manufacturers. When he went to Burberry last year, he immediately began to build on its tradition of marrying fashion and function. He worked closely with Italian mills to develop special fabrics, because like Thomas Burberry, he believes that everything begins with the fabric.
Despite the fact that he is Italian and Ms. Bravo is American, they are committed to the Britishness of Burberry. "When Roberto and I first talked," Ms. Bravo said, "he instantly understood that the man of a certain taste, whether in Italy or Japan or wherever, always had something by Burberry. We felt we could latch on to that and go into the next century."
The path to the new Burberry hasn't been totally smooth. The company's profits nose-dived 90 percent for the six months ending last Sept. 30, mostly because of the economic problems in Asia, which had been Burberry's biggest market.
"The debacle in Asia is complicated, of course," Ms. Bravo said. "We totally stopped parallel trading, where distributors sent our products to discount stores. That was a big business, but over a period of time it was deleterious to the brand. You'd have products selling at regular price in a store on one side and at a discounted price on the other side of the street. That detracts from what we're trying to do.
"So much business was tied up in Asia. That will come back in time. A lot of London business was from Asian travelers, and the idea now is not to be so driven by the tourist trade. We want to gear ourselves to the local audience, wherever our stores are. Burberry has over 50 stores worldwide. We want to build Burberry into an international luxury company with a British style and sensibility."
Burberry's parent, Great Universal Stores, is a multifaceted British company that is also in the mail-order business. Lord Wolfson of Sunningdale is the chairman of Great Universal, and Victor Barnett is the chairman of Burberry Ltd. They have both given their blessings to the changes Ms. Bravo has made.
"Victor and Roberto and I are working together to clean up and develop the business," she said. "One of our strategies is to re-establish ourselves in the United States and London and have a more balanced portfolio around the world."
What Ms. Bravo is doing is similar to what other old-line fashion houses have been doing, starting with Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel and continuing through Tom Ford at Gucci and, more recently, John Galliano at Dior, Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton and Michael Kors at Celine.
The next step for Burberry is to put the women's collection on the London catwalks during the fall shows next month. Ms. Bravo said she wasn't sure Burberry was ready to face the critics last season. Now she is.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Weighs Swifter Action to Bar Economic Crises

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund, sharply criticized for how it handled crises from Southeast Asia to Russia, is discussing an overhaul of its operations that could let it intervene directly in national economies long before they get into deep trouble.
The ideas being discussed in the fund -- and by outsiders like George Soros, the billionaire -- build upon and go substantially beyond proposals made by President Clinton and leaders of other industrial powers in October. 
 At that time, trying to calm investors who were pulling out of developing countries, the Administration backed some cautious proposals that would allow the fund to act before currencies collapsed and economic "contagion" spread around the globe.
The first real experiment with that approach began in November, when the I.M.F. put together a $41 billion "precautionary" loan package for Brazil, hoping that early intervention would prevent the kind of crises that struck Thailand, South Korea, Indonesia and Russia.
The central idea now being discussed in the I.M.F. -- and outlined in a speech on Sunday by Stanley Fischer, its No. 2 official -- is to turn the fund into a "lender of last resort," making available pools of money for countries that, like Brazil, appear threatened by global forces beyond their control.
Mr. Soros outlined his ideas for an enlarged role for the I.M.F. by suggesting in the Financial Times that the fund become a global "central bank."
But the Clinton Administration made clear today that it had reservations about such a grand expansion of the fund's role.
Such a system, while intended to head off trouble, could create new risk. The I.M.F., for instance, has shown little ability to predict which nations are most at risk.
Moreover, there remains the problem of what to do about nations like Russia, which have resisted the kind of economic reforms that would qualify them for I.M.F. aid. But when countries like Russia get into trouble, the West feels compelled to provide aid anyway, as it did last summer, when it determined that Russia was too big -- or too nuclear -- to fail.
"There are a lot of interesting proposals out there, but there are a number of concerns associated with all of them," a senior Treasury official said today, on condition that his name not be used. "We're still working through how to address those concerns, and whether we can adequately address them at all."
In an interview today, Mr. Fischer, a former chairman of the economics department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said he was not trying to "turn the I.M.F. into some kind of superpower."
"If everything we are trying to do works, there shouldn't be five crises in a year, as we've just had, and the I.M.F. should be able to do less lending, rather than more," he said. "The whole idea is prevention."
Mr. Fischer said he was speaking for himself, but acknowledged that many of the ideas had been widely discussed in the fund. So has the question of how the institution can polish its battered image. In December, it hired Edelman Public Relations Worldwide and Wirthlin Worldwide, a polling company, to recommend how the fund can explain itself around the world. That may be especially difficult in Asia and Russia, where the higher interest rates prescribed by the fund are blamed by many for deepening rather than alleviating their recessions.
In essence, Mr. Fischer's proposal would reward nations for good behavior, as defined by the I.M.F. and its board, which is dominated by the United States, Japan and Europe.
Nations that strictly supervise their banking systems, that disclose far more information about their financial state and that balance their budgets would "pre qualify" for I.M.F. help. Presumably investors would be reassured, and speculators would not take the risk of betting against that nation's currency.
"For such a scheme to work, lender-of-last-resort loans would have to be denied to countries that do not qualify," Mr. Fischer said in his speech to the American Economic Association. Those countries might be forced to pay higher interest rates once they do come for help, he said.
There were echoes of Mr. Fischer's proposal in the recommendation from Mr. Soros. Mr. Soros argued that the I.M.F. should act more like an international central bank, imposing "conditions not only on the country concerned but also on the creditors" who lent the country money, thus regulating capital flows.
Undoubtedly, that idea would encounter resistance, both in Congress and among developing nations. Many countries recoil at the idea that the fund, in return for its aid, could dictate economic and monetary policy.
"For the moment at least," Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said in a speech today, "it is difficult to imagine nations ceding control over their money or their banks to an international institution."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Stocks Hit 3-Month Low

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Japanese stocks suffered their biggest declines in three months today on concern a stronger yen would prevent exporters from meeting their profit forecasts.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average sank 426.28, or 3.1 percent, to 13,415.89, its biggest drop since Oct. 8 and its lowest close since Oct. 16. The Toyota Motor Corporation and Canon Inc., which depend on United States sales for a half and a third of operating profit, respectively, paced declines. 
 The dollar fell to as low as 112.75 yen, well below the assumptions of 115 to 130 yen used by many exporters for their earnings forecasts.
Toyota, whose earnings forecast assumes 120 yen to the dollar for the six months ending in March, fell 3.8 percent, to 2,955 yen. Canon shed 3.9 percent, to 2,320 yen. Every one-yen fall in the United States currency's value takes 2.6 billion yen ($23 million) from Canon's operating profit, which was 162 billion yen in 1997. The Sony Corporation, whose forecast assumes 115 yen to the dollar, fell 2.2 percent to 8,050 yen. Bucking the declines, Nissan Motor gained 1.2 percent, to 350 yen.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Slid Again in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
United States manufacturing had its weakest month in December since the end of the last recession in 1991 as production slumped, factories cut jobs and weak demand hurt prices.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index of manufacturing activity dropped to 45.1 last month from 46.8 in November. The index has fallen for three consecutive months; since June, it has held at less than 50, a measure indicating that the number of manufacturers who said business deteriorated was greater than the number of those who said it improved. 
 Manufacturing, which represents about a fourth of the economy, has been in a slump for most of the last year even as the overall economy grew by about 3.7 percent. While slower economic growth is likely this year, there is no sign of a recession as high-technology industries, the service sector and housing offset the weakness in manufacturing.
December's index was the lowest since a reading of 44.5 in May 1991, just as the economy began to recover from a recession. The decline was mirrored in components of the broader gauge.
The production index, a gauge of current output, fell to 46.5 in December from 48.6 in November. And the employment index, a measure of hiring plans and labor-market conditions, fell to 40.8 in December from 44.9 in November -- the lowest since January 1992, when it was 40.6 at a time of more than 7 percent unemployment. In November, the jobless rate was 4.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Motorola Revises Job-Cut Numbers

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO Jan. 4

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. said today that it cut 1,000 more jobs than expected from its chip business, reflecting steps by the big semiconductor and cellular phone maker to cut costs and reduce its chip-product line to increase profits.
Motorola said it cut 6,000 semiconductor jobs by the end of last year, 20 percent more than its earlier target of 5,000, from a total of 51,000 semiconductor workers worldwide. Of the total cut, only 450 were laid off, said Ken Phillips, a company spokesman. He said the remaining cuts were done through buyouts or attrition. 
 Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., has suffered a decline in its chip business as prices declined and economic crises in Asia reduced demand in the semiconductor industry. Last June, Motorola said it planned to cut about 10 percent of its work force, or 15,000 jobs, by June 1999.
Motorola shares, which rose $3.9375, to $65 today, have surged about 69 percent since the company reported third-quarter earnings on Oct. 5. It is scheduled to report fourth-quarter earnings Jan. 13.
The company is expected to earn 23 cents a share for the quarter, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation.
