HEADLINE: Harold Edelman, 75, Architect Who Helped to Save Small Treasures for New York

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Harold Edelman, an architect and teacher who helped to preserve some of New York's small treasures -- a park, an ornate library and a quiet church -- died on Dec. 21 at the Beth Israel Medical Center hospice. He was 75.
He died of cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Edelman, the founding partner of the Greenwich Village architecture firm that bears his name, designed buildings that were not the lofty castles that shape the city's spiked skyline, but the smaller buildings that fill the lower spaces, places where people live, worship or rest when sick. His firm was the architect for the Two Bridges urban renewal area on the Lower East Side, and designed 1,364 apartments between the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges. He also designed housing for the elderly on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and health clinics in the Bronx.
But Mr. Edelman will probably be remembered for twice planning the reconstruction of St. Mark's in the Bowery, one of the city's oldest churches. In 1978, a nearly completed restoration project was ravaged by fire. Colleagues said Mr. Edelman did all the design work personally, finishing with plans for the series of stained glass windows that frame the building's interior.
Mr. Edelman was born in Brooklyn and received his architecture degree from Cornell University in 1943. After serving in the Army Signal Corps in World War II, Mr. Edelman spent a year studying in Paris at Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux-Arts.
He taught at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn from 1952 to 1962, and in 1960, founded an architecture firm with his wife, Judith Hochberg Edelman, and Stanley Salzman.
While teaching at Pratt, Mr. Edelman learned of the impending demolition of the Jefferson Market Courthouse, the turreted red-brick hall in the center of Greenwich Village. He assigned his architecture students to draft possible uses for the doomed building. Two students suggested using it as a branch library, the form in which it survives today.
Mr. Edelman was one of nine architects assembled to redesign Washington Square Park. The committee's design, drafted in response to a city-proposed plan, maintained the crossing paths at the heart of the park and rejected an attempt to turn half of the area into a great lawn.
In addition to his wife of 51 years, Mr. Edelman is survived by a sister, Edna Friedman of Bethesda, Md; a brother, Paul, of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.; two sons, Marc, of Manhattan, and Joshua, of Madrid, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
New Rival Arrives, but Dollar Is Still the World's Champion

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The euro -- the new European currency -- had a positive debut yesterday in foreign exchange dealings. But it is still unclear how the euro will fare against the dollar this year and what kind of challenge it will make over time against the United States currency.
"The dollar will stay the world's predominant currency but the euro will be second," said Robert C. Standing, managing director in London of the global trading division in Europe for Chase Manhattan Bank. But, he added, "the euro will be the first credible challenger." 
Others think the euro may be more than a challenger. C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said that the question was not whether the euro would rival the dollar but simply how quickly it would happen.
"Some people say 3 years, some say 10 years," he said, "but there is no doubt that it will happen."
While the talk is of the euro challenging the dollar, what the new currency really represents is another big step toward a global economy, in which the United States will face more competition. In this case, the euro is a mechanism helping to make a united Europe far more competitive with the United States.
"It's a culmination of the globalization trend," said Mr. Bergsten, adding that "what the Europeans have done is show how you can take maximum advantage of globalization."
In afternoon trading yesterday, the euro cost $1.18060, up from the $1.17400 value of the old European currency unit on Dec. 31. The ecu, a basket of European currencies that was the precursor to the euro, converted to the euro on Friday.
The euro rallied from its New York lows as the stock market reversed course, with the Dow Jones industrial average giving up most of its gains for the day. The dollar fell much more sharply against the Japanese yen, ending at 112.07 yen, from 113.57 Thursday, in light trading, which some traders said might have exaggerated the decline.
The euro, some traders said, was buoyed on buying by European banks and strong rallies in European stock markets from Germany to Spain, France to Italy. Traders also said that trading was orderly, though volume was moderate. Traders "were working their way in slowly," Mr. Standing of Chase said.
For Americans used to following the German mark, the Italian lira and the other currencies from the 11 nations now represented by the euro, the new currency may be a little confusing. Until now, quotes of the value of the dollar against marks or lire have described how many of them one dollar can buy. For example, the dollar was worth 1,639.34 lire yesterday. (Americans will still have to look at the values of individual European currencies because availability of the euro in coins and bills is to be phased in over three years.)
But the euro's value will be quoted in how many dollars it can buy. When the euro moves, for example, from $1.17 to $1.18, it is strengthening and the dollar is weakening. The British pound is quoted in the same fashion.
Since the euro is not yet available in coins or bills, Americans traveling on the Continent this year will still spend marks, lire and French francs when using cash. But goods can be bought in the euro on credit cards, and visitors can get euro-denominated travelers checks. Britain and three other nations in the European Union -- Greece, Denmark and Sweden -- are not part of the euro.
As for the strength of the euro this year, that is open to debate. Plenty of currency forecasters think the euro will be strong; others think it will be weak. The answer, Mr. Standing of Chase said, "depends on the views of where the two economies go."
Many forecasters expect growth to be stronger in Europe than in the United States, which would help the euro. But Paul Podolsky, a currency strategist at BankBoston, thinks growth in Europe will be slower. He also feels that the new European Central Bank will have a more difficult time navigating in its new environment than others expect.
Concerning yesterday's trading, Mr. Podolsky said European authorities got what they wanted: an "uneventful" session. He said they did not want the euro to fall in value nor did they want it to have a volatile day.
Within the foreign exchange trading community, the biggest significance of the start of euro trading has been how it will affect jobs.
The industry has been scaling back and preparing for the arrival of the euro for about a year, and with particular intensity since May when the starting date for trading in the new currency was set.
"We have been streamlining and adjusting for all of 1998," Mr. Standing said. Another factor that made life difficult for many foreign exchange traders last year, he said, was the crash of many emerging-market currencies. This forced many firms to cut back or get out of trading those currencies altogether.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Begin the Year Mixed, as Technology Issues Dominate

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In the first trading session of the new year, stocks jumped, then retreated and finally closed mixed yesterday, as traders and investors began to focus on coming quarterly earnings reports and a fairly hefty calendar of expected initial public stock offerings.
The flow of new stock offerings had slowed significantly after the market's steep selloff last summer, effectively capping the pool of securities from which investors could choose. Therefore, a rise in new supply would alter the equation. 
 "The market enjoyed four months of no new supply, a strong merger-and-acquisitions market and strong inflows of funds," said Michael Clark, head of United States stock trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"The new-issue calendar is as big as I have seen, which means things will not be so favorable as they have been," he said. "That will leave the spotlight squarely on earnings, and I don't think they will be so great."
Yesterday, for instance, Goldman, Sachs & Company sold 50 million shares in the MBNA Corporation, the big credit card company. Goldman had bought the block of new shares from the company, in a transaction that raised $1.2 billion for MBNA. Shares of MBNA, the session's most actively traded issue, closed at 24, down 13/16 on the day.
The Nasdaq composite index set a new closing high, propelled by expectations that when earnings are reported, they will show that the fourth quarter was a good one for technology companies. The Nasdaq index, which is heavily weighted with technology issues, rose 15.36 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,208.05. Intraday gains were even bigger -- early in the session the index traded as high as 2,233.57. Last year, the Nasdaq rose 39.6 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which gained 16.1 percent last year, began 1999 with a slim gain of 2.84 points, to 9,184.27. Before a number of computer-generated sell programs hit the blue-chip index, though, the Dow had been up as much as 168 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index posted a loss of 1.13 points, to 1,228.10. During morning trading, the index traded as high as 1,248.81. The S.& P. rose 26.7 percent in 1998.
Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,742 to 1,446. Volume on the Big Board was active, at more than 892.5 million shares traded.
Some analysts attributed the market's strong early advance to a surge in European stock prices.
Share prices on the Continent surged on optimism that the arrival of the euro, the common currency for 11 European nations, will help to increase economic efficiency and growth, developments that if realized would be beneficial for both American corporations and the United States economy.
Share prices on the French, German and Italian exchanges were up more than 5 percent yesterday. Of major European markets, only Britain, which is not adopting the euro, registered a decline.
Technology stocks, among the strongest market performers last year, retained their popularity yesterday. Microsoft rose 2 5/16 a share, to 141. Intel, the maker of computer chips, gained 2 1/4, to 120 13/16. Cisco Systems, the networking company, gained 2 1/2, to 95 5/16.
Internet companies also posted big gains. Amazon.com shares shot up 33 11/16, to 354 15/16. Those of Yahoo rose 11 1/16, to 248.
But America Online, trading for the first time as a component of the S.& P. 500 index, fell 6 5/16, to 148 13/16.
Shares of Spyglass, a maker of Internet software, declined 7, to 15, after the company said it expected to report a loss of 14 cents to 16 cents a share. Analysts had been expecting Spyglass to eke out a profit of about a penny a share.
Among the Dow stocks, AT&T gained 2 1/8, to 77 7/8, after the company said it had dropped a plan to separate its consumer and corporate businesses. Shares of DuPont, which ended a $750 million bid for a unit of Imperial Chemicals Industries, rose 2 3/16, to 55 1/4, on the expectation it would seek a more attractive acquisition candidate.
But International Paper fell 2 11/16 a share, to 42 1/8. And I.B.M., whose stock was one of the Dow's most impressive performers last quarter, fell 1 3/8 a share yesterday, to 183. General Electric also slumped, losing 1 7/16, to 100 9/16.
The day's big gainers also included E*Trade, the on-line securities broker. Its shares jumped 8 21/32, to 55 7/16, after the company announced a 2-for-1 stock split.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Trading Begins Smoothly As Euro Enters Markets
The euro had a nearly flawless debut in world markets as European financial institutions opened for business without a hitch and Europe's new single currency climbed in value against other major currencies.
In its first full day of trading, the euro opened at $1.17 and climbed to nearly $1.186 before falling back to about $1.18. Far from being unsettled by the uncertainty or technical glitches, the stock markets in Frankfurt, Paris, Milan and Madrid all jumped by 5 percent or more. But the reaction was much more subdued in the consumer marketplace, where there was little evidence of change. Page A1. 

It is unclear how the euro will fare against the dollar and what kind of challenge it will make against the United States currency. C6.
 
I.M.F. Chiefs Consider Changes
Leaders of the International Monetary Fund are proposing a major overhaul of the fund's operations that could permit it to intervene directly in the operation of national economies before they get into deep trouble. A8.
 
CBS in Deal With America Online
CBS News will announce a deal with America Online this week to become the exclusive broadcast news provider for the on-line service, executives involved in the deal said. C4.
 
A Request to Limit Microsoft
The head of Intuit, which makes the Quicken personal finance software, urged the judge in the antitrust trial against Microsoft to limit that company's use of its market-dominating Windows operating system to promote its other products. C2.
 
Network Solutions to Split Stock
Network Solutions, which has a temporary monopoly on the distribution of Internet addresses, announced plans for both a stock split and a secondary offering of 4.58 million shares. The proposed offering would reduce the ownership of the parent company, Science Applications International, to 45 percent from the 72 percent it owns now. Shares of Network Solutions rose $24.125, to $155. C2.
 
Rumors About Auto Mergers
The talk at the North American International Auto Show this year is about which auto makers will be the next to merge. Jacques Nasser, who became Ford's chief executive on Friday, declined to comment on rumors that Ford was talking with Volvo or BMW. C5.
 
Mergers May Reduce Donations
Many of the nation's arts organizations and nonprofit groups are concerned that the record number of corporate mergers last year may lead to a decline in donations. E1.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices for Treasuries Tumble As Investors Look Overseas

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as the dollar slumped and European stocks and bonds soared on the euro's first day of trading, curbing demand for Treasury securities.
"There's a lack of interest in U.S. Treasuries," as investors turn to European and other securities with the advent of the single currency, said Graham Allen, who oversees $33 billion of fixed-income securities at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond declined 27/32, to 101 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.15 percent, from 5.09 percent on Thursday.
Bonds followed the dollar lower, as the euro climbed in its first day of trading, and stocks from Frankfurt to Milan surged. That happened as the creation of a $10 trillion euro-denominated securities market increased demand for the currency on its first day of trading.
Most major stock indexes among the 11 European nations adopting the euro rose more than 3 percent, with Italy's benchmark index climbing more than 6.4 percent. European bonds also rose, driving yields to record lows, while speculation of selling by hedge funds also weighed on the market, traders said.
Gains in United States stocks for most of the day also hurt Treasuries.
Investors and bankers said that 1999 would probably start with as much as $40 billion of investment-grade and $15 billion of junk-rated bond sales in January.
While the names of many coming borrowers are yet to be announced, investors said that finance companies and borrowers with well-known names will top the list.
Treasuries slumped even after a manufacturing report suggested the economy was slowing.. The National Association of Purchasing Management index of manufacturing activity unexpectedly fell to 45.1 for December, from 46.8 in November.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Without a Hitch, the Euro Opens To Trading in World Marketplace

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The euro, Europe's new single currency, had a nearly flawless debut in world markets today as European financial institutions opened for business without a hitch and the euro climbed in value against other major currencies.
From London to Paris to Frankfurt and beyond, stock exchanges and banks opened serenely despite a grueling weekend in which millions of computers had to be reprogrammed to handle euros. 
 "What we are observing today is the natural and happy birth of the euro," said Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the Bank of France.
In its first full day of trading, the euro opened at $1.17, climbed to nearly $1.186 and by afternoon in New York was trading at $1.18060. Far from being unsettled by the uncertainty or technical glitches, the stock markets in Frankfurt, Paris, Milan and Madrid all jumped 5 percent or more.
Britain, which has thus far refused to adopt the euro, had a less euphoric day. The FTSE stock index ended up roughly even while the pound slipped against the euro.
On European streets, there was little sign that anything had changed. Even in downtown Frankfurt, which is home to the European Central Bank, few stores were posting prices in euros.
At Kaufhof, an upscale department store in the city's financial center, signs boasted, "We will make you ready for the euro," but none of the prices were listed in euros.
And plenty of people were befuddled. Because euros will be usable only for electronic payments until Jan. 1, 2002, some German bank customers did not understand why their banks would not give them euros in cash. Others were annoyed that banks were suddenly ordering them to identify the currency they were using when writing checks.
Even bank employees were perplexed about how, exactly, to open a bank account denominated in euros.
"This will be a sort of experiment," said Monique Pouzet, a teller at Credit Commercial de France in Paris, as she opened a binder marked "Memento euro." After a moment's study and a few key strokes, Ms. Pouzet reported with a smile that the experiment was a success. "You can pick up your euro checkbook in about one week, apparently," she told a customer.
Traders, bankers and Government officials warned that it would take several more days to know for sure whether the huge technical conversion was successful. But the evidence today pointed toward a remarkably smooth start for the euro and toward its acceptance as a serious competitor to the dollar as an international currency.
"Technically, there is absolutely no problem at all," said Michael Bartmann, a securities dealer on the floor of the Frankfurt stock exchange. "The only problem is that people have to get used to the new numbers. Trading volumes are very low right now, probably because people need time to get adjusted."
None of the elaborate "dress rehearsals" for the euro involved the full range of financial institutions at one time. So, although individual institutions seemed to function well today, the real test will come when all of them -- banks, brokerage firms and settlement systems -- have had a chance to thoroughly interact with one another in settling accounts, or processing their transactions, after the markets close. Bank executives said that would take several days of trading.
"Before we declare this a complete triumph, let's just wait until the settlement is done of the first few trades," said Graham Bishop, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "Once we have pushed through to the end-of-the-week settlements, then people will feel a lot happier."
Peter Wolf-Koppen, head of euro projects at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, said: "There are still two important milestones in front of us. One of them comes today when we have to post all the day's transactions to all the accounts. The other will be in settling transactions with other institutions."
One trader in Frankfurt commented: "There is definitely potential for problems. What could happen is that you get orders in euros and in marks, and in that case you would see complete chaos. We will have to wait and see whether the banks have fully implemented the conversion."
All in all, both industry executives and European central bankers said the conversion seemed a success. Most central banks, including the German Bundesbank and the Bank of Italy, said they had received no distress reports during the weekend conversion or today. And both big and small financial institutions said the conversion had been easier and faster than they had expected.
Deutsche Bank, which had more than 3,000 workers on duty over the weekend, said today that it had reprogrammed all its computers by 10 A.M. on Sunday. In London, Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan and Salomon Smith Barney had wrapped up their work by Sunday evening.
"It went absolutely perfectly, much faster than in our dress rehearsals," said Detlev Rahmsdorf, a spokesman for Deutsche Bank.
Mitchell Shivers, head of Merrill Lynch's euro conversion project, was equally optimistic. "It went tremendously and far exceeded our expectations," he said this afternoon in London. "It's been unprecedented -- very unusual to see an industry pull together and accomplish something like this."
Though many industry experts worry that smaller banks may turn out to be weak links in the chain of processing payments, executives at several smaller institutions said their conversion to the euro seemed to go smoothly, too.
Vincenzo de Bustis, chief executive of Banca del Salento in southern Italy, said all the bank's operations seemed to be function properly when business started this morning.
"We worked on the conversion all weekend," Mr. De Bustis said. As of early this morning, "exchange operations and transfers both within Italy and abroad went without any problems," he added.
Currency traders in Australia and Asia had already bid up the price of euros, and there was considerable evidence that Asian fund managers were buying euros as a hedge against global economic turmoil. The buoyancy continued after the European markets opened, though traders noted that the volume of activity in both stock and currency markets was very low.
Economists said it would be a mistake to read much significance into the rising price of the euro, but they said the activity today was consistent with the general strength that individual European currencies have enjoyed for much of the last year.
"We predicted that the euro will be a stable currency, and that is what we are seeing today," said Petra Koehler, a senior economist at Dresdner Bank. "I think there was also some relief that the conversion went well."
All the effort for conversion was of little interest to ordinary bank customers and shoppers, who have heard so much for so long about the euro but cannot feel the soft comfort of a thick wad of bills or drop a shiny new euro coin into a vending machine.
That most German stores continued to post prices only in marks today reflected, in part, a residual hostility toward the new currency among many Germans, who still treasure the mark as an anchor of stability.
But it also reflects the fact that most people do not really need to do anything in euros for the time being. Executives for both Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank said that far fewer than 1 percent of their customers had asked for euro-denominated bank accounts.
"The euro is a great thing for Europe, but it makes no difference to me in my daily life," said Egon Weber, a customer at the Frankfurter Volksbank. "If I had a lot of customers in other countries, a euro account might be useful. But for the moment, there isn't any point."
Many German bank customers may soon be furious about the euro. Some banks say they will not process bank transfers if customers forget to specify on the form whether the payment is in euros or marks.
"If a customer forgets to indicate the currency, we will have to clarify each case individually," said Herbert W. Staub, a board member at Frankfurter Sparkasse, a savings bank.
In France, where the dream of a single European currency first took hold, stores and banks were far more hospitable to the euro.
At the Virgin Megastore on the Champs-Elysees and at Galeries Lafayette, the flashy department store in downtown Paris, clerks said they had been taking euro-denominated checks since Saturday.
Michel-Edouard Leclerc, head of the Leclerc chain of stores, went so far last weekend as to take a group of journalists along on a shopping trip in which he paid for his purchases with euro-checks.
And Le Printemps, another big department store, is offering until Jan. 15 to deliver anything ordered from its Internet site anywhere in Europe for three euros, or roughly $3.50.

HEADLINE: Jerry Brown Sworn In as Oakland's Mayor

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 4

 BODY:
People here expect Jerry Brown to be a different sort of mayor. On his first day, he did not disappoint.
From morning meditation at his downtown loft to his earnest pronouncements of what "we can do together" before throngs of well-wishers outside City Hall on a windy, chilly afternoon, to his tieless suit -- the shirt, as usual, had a banded, priestly collar -- the three-time candidate for President and two-time Governor of California became the Mayor of the state's seventh-largest city in his classic, inimitable fashion. 
 Mr. Brown, the 60-year-old native San Franciscan who moved across the bay to Oakland five years ago, formed a research organization -- We the People -- and started a radio talk show, marched six blocks from the swearing-in ceremonies at the Paramount Theater to the rally at City Hall, escorted by a jazz band and what seemed like the entire city.
And despite pickets from a group that says the new Mayor's promise to reduce crime amounts to an order for the police to round up blacks, Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s inauguration was greeted with the wild enthusiasm that politicians' dreams are made of. He gave just a three-minute speech at his swearing-in -- after a tedious ceremony in which Board of Education members and City Council members took their oaths. But his words, judging from the audience's response, were inspirational. When he said, "Everything will be made right," the cheers had an almost religious zeal.
At his rally, Mr. Brown announced four goals: to reduce crime, to attract 10,000 people to live downtown, to help parents and teachers create public charter schools, and to encourage celebrations, festivals and artistic performances.
"There's so much that we can do together," Mr. Brown said, as the crowd shouted its approval.
Oakland has high hopes and expectations for its new Mayor. Mr. Brown won the nonpartisan primary with more than 58 percent of the vote, avoiding a runoff with 10 opponents. His ballot proposition to give the mayor more power than the city manager, was supported by 75 percent of voters. And his inaugural festivities, "Celebrating Oakland," which offered citizens a jam-packed schedule with scores of local acts -- musicians, visual artists, dancers and poets -- were touted today as a sure-fire sign that the new Mayor is planning to showcase the best Oakland has to offer.
"He's a breath of fresh air in the American political syndrome," said Tom Siporin, a poet and yogi who hobbled on a crutch to attend the rally in the City Hall plaza. "He's a great attempt to show there's hope in the inner city. He's a visionary."
Oakland, with nearly 400,000 residents -- 41 percent of them black, 26 percent white, 17 percent Hispanic and 16 percent Asian according to Census Bureau figures -- suffers from an inferiority complex. The city has been called homely and crime-ridden, a poor cousin to San Francisco, for so long that these have become its defining characteristics.
Meanwhile, the city's assets -- a thriving port, handsome neighborhoods high on the Oakland Hills, a growing community of artists and musicians, many of them refugees from San Francisco's sky-high rents -- have been largely ignored.
Residents believe that the new Mayor's political prominence and pull as a magnet for news coverage, could give the city the respect and attention it deserves.
"Oakland is a beautiful city," said Clement Sinclair, a teacher, "and with a strong Mayor we will have an even better Oakland. People who have run away from Oakland in the past will now be glad to come back."
Henrietta Hamilton, who has lived in Harlem and the Los Angeles neighborhoods of Watts and Venice, flew to Oakland for the inauguration.
"I would like to change the world," Ms. Hamilton said, "and I can't imagine a better person than Jerry Brown to do it here for Oakland."
Some Oakland political pundits are already criticizing Mr. Brown's plans as too vague. Skeptics doubt whether a would-be philosopher king once known as "Governor Moonbeam," with all his New Age-ish language, could also be a pragmatic nuts-and-bolts administrator.
"Jerry just doesn't have the mind for these everyday matters of city government," said Robert Warwick, a member of a local Democratic club that backed a Brown opponent. "I know Jerry well. He used to be involved with Zen Buddhism, and so was I. But he was a terrible Governor. That stupid tax reform proposition he pushed ruined the state for 25 years, and now he's here."
No matter what Mr. Brown accomplishes, Mr. Warwick said, given the expectations, it will not be enough.
"The idea that one charismatic guy could come here and turn things around is ridiculous," he said.
But Mr. Warwick's was a minority opinion, one that Mr. Brown surely did not hear above the roars of approval today.
"We all know politics is not doing too well in this country lately," Mr. Brown told the city. "But in Oakland, we're putting it all together. It's real in this town. We're going to break the mold."

HEADLINE: California's New Governor Promises to Overhaul Schools

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 4

 BODY:
Declaring "a time to do great things again," Gray Davis took office today as the 37th Governor of California, pledging to overhaul the troubled public schools of the nation's most populous state as the centerpiece of his efforts to shepherd its growth and preserve its prosperity in the coming years.
In his inaugural address, Mr. Davis, the first Democrat to hold the state's top job in 16 years, sounded forceful notes of contrast with his Republican predecessor, Pete Wilson, and to a lesser degree with his onetime boss, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., whose 70's-era skepticism led him to proclaim a time of lower expectations for the Golden State. 
 "Today we begin a new chapter in the history of California: the era of higher expectations," said Mr. Davis, who began his political career as Mr. Brown's chief of staff, but today sounded like a more optimistic Democratic forebear, Mr. Brown's father, Edmund Sr., who presided over the state's explosive growth in the 1950's and 60's. "We will embark in a new direction guided by our lasting values."
After thanking Mr. Wilson for cooperation in the transition to a new administration, Mr. Davis several times implicitly rebuked his predecessor's campaigns against affirmative action and illegal immigration, telling an audience at the Memorial Auditorium here that "you can finally ring down the curtain on the politics of division."
Those words left Mr. Wilson and his wife, Gayle, the only people seated on the stage amid a thunderous standing ovation.
But Mr. Davis, 56, who faces strong pressure from Democratic interest groups to deliver long-delayed raises and long-sought policy changes, made clear that he planned no radical departures, though Democrats control all three branches of state government for the first time since Jerry Brown's day. Instead, Mr. Davis, a cautious career politician who has spent most of his adult life aiming for the job he assumed today, repeated the moderate mantra that helped him win a 20-point victory over his conservative Republican opponent, former State Attorney General Dan Lungren, last fall.
"I will govern neither from the right nor the left, but from the center, propelled not by ideology, but by common sense that seeks better results," Mr. Davis told an overflow crowd that included Vice President Al Gore and former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.
Mr. Davis is to begin work in earnest this week, when he presents his first budget on Friday and, keeping a campaign promise, calls a special session of the State Legislature to focus on improving school accountability, increasing teacher preparation and assuring that every child learns to read by the end of the third grade. None of those tasks will be easy for Mr. Davis, who won office with strong support from the powerful state teachers union, which feuded bitterly with Mr. Wilson.
Mr. Davis fired a not-so-subtle warning shot across the teachers' bow today, saying, "Yes, there are some deficient teachers and principals out there," and adding, "Under my administration, they will either get better -- or they will be encouraged to find another line of work."
"The time has come to restore California's public schools to greatness," he vowed. "The voters demand it, our future depends on it, and I am determined to make it happen."
The Republican minority leader of the State Assembly, Rod Pacheco of Riverside, said he agreed with "a lot of what I heard."
"Republican themes," Mr. Pacheco said. "That's good. We'll do what we can to help him."
Just how much Mr. Davis can do about education in the short term remains to be seen. In the last two years of Mr. Wilson's administration, the Legislature or voters approved several changes, from smaller class sizes for early elementary grades to mandatory testing of students to an end to most bilingual education, that are still being phased in.
And despite a booming economy, state and local government budgets remain relatively tight, in part because of restrictions on taxation like Proposition 13, the 1978 ballot measure capping local property tax rates.
But while Mr. Davis has made it clear that he will not try to reopen past policy debates, like the ballot measure that overturned state affirmative action programs, he has already sent some signals of change, like appointing the state's first black and Asian-American Cabinet members. And with a 23-year career in state politics, Mr. Davis, who campaigned against a field of richer, flashier Democratic rivals with the slogan, "Experience Money Can't Buy," has a good idea of what he may be in for.
For much of his career, as a State Assemblyman, Comptroller and, for the last four years, Lieutenant Governor, Mr. Davis was mocked as a tireless fund-raiser who rode his staff hard and was as bland as his first name. But he is having the last laugh now.
"You know, sometimes a person meets his moment," Mr. Davis said in an article today in The Sacramento Bee. "I have always been a pragmatist and moderate by nature. I have always been more interested in solving people's problems than in espousing a rigid ideology.
"You read all these commentaries about me, and they're always saying how dull and stodgy and predictable, but that's just the way I am. Happily, the people were in the mood for the kind of person that I am."

HEADLINE: Merger Rumors Abound at Big Auto Show

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
When top auto executives gather here each winter for the North American International Auto Show, the talk in the halls is usually about the latest car or, more recently, the latest sport utility vehicle or pickup truck. But at this year's show, there is also another theme: merger rumors.
Ever since Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation announced their merger last May, and particularly since the two companies completed the deal last November, the industry has been full of speculation on who might link up next. But top industry officials here said today that while many auto makers were cautiously and tentatively holding discussions, that did not necessarily mean another deal was imminent. 
 The company most often mentioned as a potential acquirer is the Ford Motor Company, which has accumulated $22 billion in cash, a hoard equal to nearly a third of its market value. Just before Christmas, rumors started that Ford was in talks to acquire Volvo of Sweden or BMW of Germany.
Jacques Nasser, who became Ford's chief executive on Friday with the retirement of Alex Trotman, expressed amusement today at the rumors. "I was lying back on a beach over the Christmas period reading about all these wonderful strategic meetings being held that I clearly wasn't involved in," Mr. Nasser said in an interview at Ford's huge, two-level display here, which is almost as long as a football field.
Mr. Nasser declined to discuss either Volvo or BMW but did say, "Everyone's talking to everyone else." Yet Ford views the prospect of an acquisition as a potential opportunity rather than a necessity, and therefore is in no hurry, he said.
"Haste, in these circumstances, I wouldn't put a premium on," Mr. Nasser added.
BMW has insisted that it wants to stay independent and that the controlling Quandt family has no intention of even discussing a sale. "BMW will remain independent and, contrary to all the speculation and rumors in the industry, there have not been any discussions," said Helmut Panke, a member of BMW's management board.
Mr. Panke was particularly emphatic that BMW had not been negotiating any deals with Ford. "I can really confirm that there haven't been, are none and will be no discussions" with Ford, he said.
Bodil Eriksson, a senior vice president of Volvo, said today that while the company was willing to talk to other auto makers about cooperating on production and other ventures, it was not interested in being acquired.
Volvo is small by industry standards. In terms of sales, it is twice the size of the Microsoft Corporation but only one-seventh the size of Ford. Smaller auto makers that lack broad ranges of models and international operations are increasingly seen as the most likely to engage in mergers.
The General Motors Corporation, already the world's largest auto maker, has shown little interest in growing through acquisitions. G. Richard Wagoner Jr., G.M.'s president, said today that there had long been speculation that the auto industry would undergo considerable consolidation, but the DaimlerChrysler deal might yet turn out to be an exception rather than a new rule.
"We've been talking about this business getting down to 'X' major players -- 5 or 10, pick a number -- for a decade," he noted.
Jens Neumann, a member of Volkswagen A.G.'s management board, took a similar position, saying that informal talks did not automatically mean that more big transactions were on the way.
DaimlerChrysler officials started the current merger speculation by insisting that their transaction was necessary to achieve greater economies of scale. But even DaimlerChrysler has had trouble moving quickly on further deals.
Jurgen E. Schrempp, the company's co-chairman, said in mid-November that he expected a decision by the end of 1998 on whether to buy the Nissan Motor Corporation's stake in Nissan Diesel. But no decision has been reached, and Thomas Stallkamp, DaimlerChrysler's president for North American operations, said today that the company was concerned the Japanese economy might not have hit bottom.
Ford has also been rumored to be interested in Nissan, but Ford executives have become leery of any deal because of concerns that Nissan's balance sheet may not reflect the true extent of its debts.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Its Offer Spurned, Union Will Vote on N.B.A. Plan

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Calling the players' latest labor proposal inadequate, the National Basketball Association's negotiating committee voted unanimously yesterday to reject it, reaffirming that it would recommend the cancellation of the season to the league's board of governors when it meets in New York on Thursday.
Hours later, the union said it would put the league's most recent proposal -- one that Commissioner David Stern has said is final -- to a vote of the full membership at a meeting of players in New York tomorrow. Stern has been pressing the union's bargaining committee to do just that, but until yesterday it had refused. 
 Billy Hunter, the executive director of the players association, said the union had decided to call the vote even before Stern's comments last night. He said the players were changing their stance on a vote "to assure that the owners understand the level of player resolve and the degree of opposition to the N.B.A.'s onerous demands."
Hunter said the union would continue to recommend against accepting the proposal.
"I'm glad to hear the players will have an opportunity to be heard," said Russ Granik, the league's deputy commissioner. "I hope they don't vote thinking that the owners are not serious about the recommendation to the committee on Thursday."
League officials who spoke on condition of anonymity expressed concern about the format of the vote. The union will decide today how to hold the vote, in accordance with its bylaws; it is unclear whether the voting will be open or secret.
In his strongest comments yet regarding the potential loss of the season, Stern said the union's latest offer not only fell short of the league's desires but even represented a step backward. After meeting for an hour with Hunter and Patrick Ewing, the union's president, Stern said a settlement appeared unlikely.
After announcing the 9-0 vote by the league's labor committee to reject the players' offer, Stern talked about the stalemate in dire terms. "The N.B.A. owners are going to act on the recommendation," he said. "We're going to lose a season and probably the careers of 20 percent of our players. It's a terrible thing."
The commissioner also spoke openly about the future of the league in the event of a canceled season, adding that he could envision using replacements for the unionized players, whom the owners locked out more than six months ago.
Stern had already said that he would recommend the season be scrapped if the players did not accept the league's offer by Thursday. So his dire comments and the committee's vote may be part of an 11th-hour negotiating strategy intended to put pressure on the union. If so, it worked, at least as far as persuading the players' association to call for a general vote. More than 400 players have been invited to New York to take part tomorrow.
 If the players vote against their 19-member negotiating committee, the union would presumably rethink its position and agree to the league's proposal. If the players support their negotiators, it could fuel last-minute talks before Thursday's deadline.
"The player members of the N.B.P.A. negotiating committee previously rejected the N.B.A.'s final proposal unanimously," Hunter said in a statement. "The committee stands by that determination and will continue to recommend against acceptance of that proposal."
 "To assure that the owners understand the level of player resolve and the degree of opposition to the N.B.A.'s onerous demands, the negotiating committee will convene an all-players meeting in New York on Wednesday, Jan. 6, at which time the general membership will be asked to approve the negotiating committee's recommendation to reject the N.B.A.'s final proposal."
Not all of the union's members were convinced that Stern and Granik would recommend canceling the season before negotiating with the union. Buck Williams, a former union president, saw the management's action as a negotiating ploy.
"It's still Monday," he said. "I would caution that no one be alarmed until the 7th at least. I'm sure Stern wants to apply as much pressure as possible. David Stern is banking on a players' vote. My whole issue is that we shouldn't vote now."
Union officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, were concerned about putting the owners' offer to a vote of the general membership. The feeling was that the players would not be voting for the deal but instead voting to salvage what's left of the season and might therefore take any offer on the table.
But with several players recently publicly requesting a vote of the general body, Hunter and the negotiating committee decided to gamble. If the players do not accept the deal, it sets the stage for either a whirlwind last round of talks or it insures that the N.B.A. will become the first major sports league to lose an entire season to labor strife.
"We plan to educate them about the pros and cons of the deal and we will ask that they support the negotiating committee's decision to reject the proposal," Ewing said. "We'll see how the guys vote and then take it to the N.B.A."
Reflecting on the possibility of using replacement players in the 1999-2000 season, Stern said: "It's not necessarily a pretty sight early on, but obviously if we have to rebuild the league, we'll rebuild the league."
The announcement last night came after Ewing and Hunter had an almost fruitless meeting with Granik and Stern.
The union was hoping its most recent concessions, including agreeing to a maximum salary for players with at least 10 years' experience, would prompt the league to negotiate further.
The main stumbling block could be how much revenue would be paid to the players during the six-year deal. The sides also have differences on the length and terms of a new rookie salary scale and a number of other economic issues.
In its proposal, the union asked that 55 percent of revenue be devoted to salaries in the fourth year, while the owners have offered 53 percent. In the fifth year, players want 56 percent while owners are offering 53.5. And in the final year, players want 57 percent -- the amount they received last season -- while the league is offering 54 percent.
"I needed to see a proposal that reached for ours," Stern said. "Instead I saw one that went backwards." Stern added that another full bargaining session "doesn't seem likely at all."
More than three months of the season has been lost since the owners locked the players out. The players have lost about $500 million in salaries. Ewing alone has lost more than $8 million. "I don't think it's in the interests of the owners to blow the season up," he said. "I still believe we're going to have a season."
Stern was dubious. "Stay tuned and see on Thursday how close we are," he said. "In order to see who's more accurate in his depiction of where we are, we're going to have to lose a season."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1239 words

HEADLINE: U.S. READY TO EASE SOME RESTRICTIONS IN POLICY ON CUBA

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The United States is ready to let more people and more money flow to Cuba, senior American officials said today, while rejecting a fundamental review of American policy toward Cuba.
The moves would let Cuban citizens receive millions more dollars from American friends and family members, allow them to buy more American food and medicine, permit more direct flights between the two countries, renew direct mail service from the United States and let the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national baseball team play ball in March, the officials said today. 
 Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright formally recommended the steps to President Clinton today, and the White House is expected to announce them on Tuesday.
A senior Administration official, speaking in Ms. Albright's seventh-floor State Department offices, said the measures "are intended to strengthen support for the Cuban people," to allow them "some elbow room" and "some modicum of independence."
Other officials said the moves are intended to increase educational, religious and humanitarian contacts with Cuba.
There was no immediate reaction from the Cuban Government.
Reforms in American policy toward Cuba were under review three years ago, but were halted when Cuba shot down Cuban-American pilots for an anti-Castro group. The proposals moved forward after Pope John Paul II visited Cuba a year ago. "The Pope's visit created a wedge" through which political light and air can stream into Cuba, a senior Administration official said.
Another factor was the death last year of Jorge Mas Canosa, the leader of the Cuban American National Foundation and the most vocal and influential anti-Castro Cuban-American political figure in the United States.
The nature and timing of the announcement also arose in part from a report just completed by the Council on Foreign Relations, published under the signature of two former senior State Department officials. The report proposed essentially similar steps, and some bolder ones, such as granting some American businesses licenses to operate in Cuba and promoting Cuban-American military ties. The council's report said it was intended to "break the current logjam" in American policy toward Cuba.
Under the steps recommended by Ms. Albright, the American embargo against Cuba, imposed 37 years ago, would remain in effect. So would more restrictions added after the pilots were shot down. Individually, some of the changes would be incremental expansions of existing policies on private relief aid to Cuban citizens. Taken together they represent a consensus among top officials that, since the 40-year-old reign of Fidel Castro is likely to end soon, the United States must "promote a peaceful democratic transition" by injecting American money, culture and ideas into the isolated island.
"We are doing what we can to expand the space" in which Cuban citizens can breathe more freely, the official said.
The measures endorsed by Ms. Albright can be undertaken by Presidential order, without Congressional approval. Senator John Warner, a Virginia Republican, said he was "concerned that these efforts fall way short" of what could have been accomplished by a national commission he proposed to revise American policy toward Cuba. Ms. Albright recommended that no such commission be formed, saying it could never resolve the question of the economic embargo imposed by the United States against Cuba in 1962.
"It's a lost opportunity for America to review a policy of basic isolationism," Senator Warner said tonight. "We allow food and medicine to get into North Korea. We allow food and medicine to get into Iraq. And we still deny this tiny country basic things."
Reacting to the news in Miami, the Cuban American National Foundation issued a statement today saying that most of the measures to be announced are consistent with current policy and praised the Administration for refusing to re-evaluate American policy toward Cuba.
The most important proposal is to increase the flow of dollars to Cuba, officials said. Today these remittances are limited to $1,200 a year from a Cuban-American family to relatives in Cuba. The amount could increase sharply under the plan proposed by Ms. Albright: any American citizen could send $1,200 a year to anyone in Cuba except to senior Communist officials. Religious groups, human rights groups and other organizations may be able to send larger sums to sister organizations under proposals still in the works, officials said.
The most politically appealing of the proposals was for holding two exhibition games between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national team. Baseball is immensely popular in Cuba, a wellspring of baseball talent. However, a baseball official said tonight that fears of angering anti-Castro Cuban-Americans could delay or scuttle a trip to Havana planned for this week by members of the Orioles organization.
The Orioles have been privately discussing such an exhibition with United States officials since 1995. Their owner, Peter Angelos, is a major financial contributor to the Democratic Party.
But in February 1996 the Cuban Air Force shot down two unarmed civilian aircraft flown by Cuban exiles testing Mr. Castro's will. President Clinton almost immediately signed legislation to tighten the embargo and strengthen trade restrictions against Cuba. The moves, which pleased anti-Castro Cuban voters in Florida and New Jersey, froze attempts to thaw American-Cuban relations, including the idea of an American baseball team playing a game in Havana.
The Orioles organization received Washington's permission for a trip to Havana later this week to discuss how to schedule the games. If they can be set up so that the Cuban Government receives little financial benefit from them, and so that profits go to authorized charities benefiting Cuban citizens, Government officials will grant the teams the license to play ball -- once in Havana, once in Baltimore -- during the exhibition season in March.
At least one staunchly anti-Castro Senator, Robert Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, said tonight that he found the new steps unobjectionable. "Our ultimate weapon against Fidel Castro is the flood of ideas," he said. But he said the Administration's idea of sending American food to independent restaurants and independent farmers in Cuba was naive, since few such institutions exist and those that survive are tiny.
Mr. Toricelli, a Yankees fan, jokingly warned that "having the Orioles going to Havana may be good foreign policy, but it's bad baseball strategy." The Baltimore team finished fourth in the American League's East Division with a 79-83 record last year.
Administration officials said the forthcoming report from the Council on Foreign Relations helped to shape their new proposals, in part because it has received quiet support in conservative circles, leading them to believe that the steps put forth by Ms. Albright to the President today would be seen as bipartisan.
In an interview, one of the report's two principal authors, Bernard W. Aronson, a former Assistant Secretary of State, said: "American policy has succeeded in containing the spread of Cuban Communism. That battle is over. We can move to a new stage in our policy. We should, because within the shell of Communist society in Cuba there is a fragile civil society clawing its way to the surface."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Real Bulls Are Listless

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The running of the bulls? Sauntering, perhaps. Meandering, maybe.
As blase New Yorkers stole sidelong glances, 10 star-crossed bulls took Wall Street -- well, not exactly by storm. If the beasts' listless performance yesterday was any indication of what is in store this year, investors might want to bail out now. 
 The 8 A.M. spectacle was held outside the New York Stock Exchange building in frigid weather, attracting a smattering of bleary-eyed Wall Streeters.
"If this performance means anything, we could be in a lot of trouble," said a financial analyst, Josh Rappaport, 33, of Manhattan.
The bulls, owned by a company called Animal Actors in Glen Gardner, N.J., looked a bit sedate, and were certainly in no hurry to rush through the concrete canyons for the amusement of the harder-charging financial types who call Wall Street home.
They -- the bulls, not the financial types -- were kept away from pedestrians by a railing set up along Wall and Broad Streets. Both streets were closed to traffic during the "race," which took several minutes to finish.
The event, billed as "Bull Monday," also featured the prognostications of Ben Stein, a television personality and writer, who said, "I believe the bull is a much stronger predictor of the economy than groundhogs could ever be with the weather."
During last year's inaugural running of the bulls, the company says, the animals predicted the market's merger mania (when one bull "vigorously" pursued another) as well as the market's tumble and subsequent recovery (when another bull skidded and fell, threatening the rest of the herd before all eventually righted themselves).
So what did Monday's race foretell?
"Well, bull No. 5 won and No. 6 took second, so divide the five into six," Mr. Stein said. "Which means there will be a 12 percent gain in the Dow in 1999 and only a standard 30 percent deviation in that prediction."
In other words, absolutely nothing.
The event was sponsored by Bestfoods,an Englewood, N.J., company that makes Skippy peanut butter and other products.

HEADLINE: Now, Midsize Is Beautiful;
Cincinnati Exemplifies the Cities Driving the U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
When a recruiter offered her a job as a research specialist at a rapidly growing medical company, Kimberly Belknap grabbed it and moved here from Grand Rapids, Mich., to get herself, as she put it, on a more lucrative career path.
The new job, auditing doctors who test new drugs for pharmaceutical companies, pays nearly $60,000 a year. Ms. Belknap earned that much in Grand Rapids, but only by holding two jobs, and the long hours were getting to her. So was the lack of opportunity. As a 36-year-old physiologist, she had already risen, in her main job, to research coordinator at a local hospital. 
 "I liked the feel of this city," Ms. Belknap said. "It is much larger but very conservative, like Grand Rapids, and the cost is about the same." For $660 a month, she has a two-bedroom apartment with a fireplace. And there is opportunity in a city with a big university, teaching hospitals, a young biotechnology industry and other growing companies like Kendle, the one that employs Ms. Belknap. "I have already been approached," she said.
Cincinnati is prospering, drawing professionals like Ms. Belknap to companies that are expanding or putting new operations here. Jobs in this Ohio River metropolis are multiplying at a nearly 3 percent annual rate, on the strong side for cities its size -- higher, for example, than the 2.4 percent rate in Salt Lake City but lower than the 4 percent for Austin, Tex. The national average is 2.3 percent.
Midsize American cities -- not only Cincinnati, Austin and Salt Lake, but Denver, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Mo., Sacramento, Calif., Jacksonville, Fla., Charlotte, N.C., and more than a dozen others -- reflect the strengths that have sustained the American economy in the 1990's and, more recently, kept it growing in the face of economic turmoil abroad.
Corporate America has found in these cities a fertile ground for the service sector job creation that has played so big a role in the current expansion. AT&T, for example, has a huge telephone operator center in Jacksonville; Microsoft and Vanguard chose Charlotte for some of their new service operations and Integral Technologies, a new software company with 100 employees, came to life in Indianapolis, financed by a local venture capital company, one of many that have sprung up in midsize cities.
Public spending, particularly for downtown redevelopment, like the two sports stadiums and the riverfront highway under construction here, also plays a role in these cities' prosperity. So do tax breaks and other subsidies that the cities use aggressively to coax companies to move or expand there. But the main engine is a plentiful pool of workers who are not too expensive, even those who are college educated and highly skilled.
"Five years ago, everyone was predicting that companies would move to Montana or some other rural state," said Edward Glaeser, a Harvard economist and urban expert. "The key now is the middle-sized city, 750,000 to 2 million people, that can provide enough amenities, enough of the right sort of labor pool, to attract companies, encourage expansion and create jobs."
Greater Cincinnati, with 1.9 million people spread over 13 counties in southern Ohio and northern Kentucky, offers such a pool. Most of the nation's job creation in the 1990's has been generated by companies in the service and financial sectors, Labor Department data show. And they have hired mainly among two groups of workers. One group, near the high end, college educated like Ms. Belknap and very skilled, accepts $40,000 to $80,000 as a satisfactory wage. The other, at the low end, often fairly skilled but either just starting out or not as well educated, settles for less than $25,000.
Smaller cities, even if they have this mix of workers, lack the nexus of business services -- accountants, lawyers, advertising agencies and transportation -- that corporations need, said Mark Zandi, chief economist of RFA, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. And larger cities are saddled with the urban social problems and the unionized workers that corporate America tries to avoid.
The prosperity in Cincinnati could dissipate. Even as new companies arrive, long-established ones could falter. Auto sales, now strong, could fall, hurting the numerous parts suppliers here. China, a big customer of General Electric Aircraft Engines, could cease to be an enthusiastic buyer of the narrow-bodied airliners equipped with the jet engines that G.E. assembles here at a sticker price of $5 million an engine. Or stock prices, whose rise has encouraged a flourish of borrowing and spending, could falter, extinguishing wealth among thousands of shareholders here in such hometown companies as Procter & Gamble and Fifth Third Bancorp.
But if the booming stock market helps explain the spending and home construction so evident in this city, Megan McCoy helps explain why expanding companies like Fidelity Investments choose cities like Cincinnati to put new operations.
Ms. McCoy, 24, is one of the more skilled people at the low end. After graduating in May 1997 from Miami University in nearby Oxford, with a degree in finance, she joined Fidelity, the Boston-based mutual fund and financial services company that is a unit of FMR. Years ago, Fidelity had all its workers in Boston, and the most sophisticated operations are still there. But as Fidelity grew, it spread across the country, and now 60 percent of its 27,000 workers are in regional centers like the one here, which is Fidelity's largest, with 3,500 employees -- up from 300 in 1992.
Ms. McCoy is a phone operator, taking calls made to an 800 number by Fidelity clients who want to cash in their 401(k) plans. "I wanted to get into the securities industry, but I did not want to be thrown right away into cold calling," she said of her decision to join Fidelity.
She commutes from the Hyde Park neighborhood, where many young singles live, to a quiet, wooded campus of modernistic office buildings near the city's huge airport, on the Kentucky side of the Ohio, in one of the two Kentucky counties that are part of Greater Cincinnati. There, using answers that come up on her computer, she counsels Fidelity clients who are retiring or leaving a company.
For this, Ms. McCoy earns just under $12 an hour, or nearly $24,000 a year, although with regular overtime, her total pay in 1998 was roughly $28,000. With many other workers like Ms. McCoy eager to get started, other companies have also set up telephone operations here. Citibank, a unit of Citigroup, and G.E. Information Technology Solutions are the latest.
Distribution is another growing Cincinnati activity, because of the giant airport, which is the second-largest hub of Delta Air Lines. From its campus, Fidelity mails the monthly statements to all of its 12 million clients, as well as the checks they receive and a variety of other materials. Seven hundred people, earning $18,000 to $23,000 a year, work in mail. An administrative staff for the entire Fidelity operation, as well as a variety of technical workers -- more than 500 people in all -- earn between $40,000 and $75,000.
"The work ethic here is extremely strong," said Paul F. Smith, manager of the Fidelity campus.
The public subsidies are also robust. As a lure, Fidelity got tax relief equal to about 5 percent of the $100 million construction cost for its five-year-old campus, a free highway to its hilly site, and, starting in January, a telephone center at Northern Kentucky University, a state school 10 minutes away by car, where 200 students will do the same work that Ms. McCoy does -- for $2 or $3 an hour less in pay.
Indeed, no major corporate undertaking seems to happen in the Cincinnati area anymore without a public subsidy. That is true of other American cities, although Cincinnati, with strong support from the Kentucky and Ohio governments, is more aggressive than most. And the subsidies flow, whether the company is being drawn here, like Fidelity, or is long established, like Procter & Gamble, which gets property tax abatements for new investments, and Duke Realty Investment, a developer.
Duke built and recently opened a gray concrete and tinted glass shopping center on Fountain Square, the busiest downtown area. Palomino, a trendy, lamp-lighted restaurant, is a tenant. Tiffany's is another, and so are a Brooks Brothers clothing store and a Lazarus department store. But the city government, not Duke, purchased the choice site for $80 million and leased it to Duke for monthly payments that cover, in effect, only $10 million of the city's outlay.
"We could not have gotten into this," said James Gray, a Duke vice president, "if the city had not presented us with that modest lease."
A different view of Cincinnati's appeal emerges from the city's leaders. True, they say, wages are lower than in the Northeast, or on the West Coast or in Chicago and Detroit. But the cost of living is also much less. The hub airport, greatly expanded in recent years, plays a decisive role as a corporate lure, they argue. And the riverfront construction project, featuring new football and baseball stadiums for the Bengals and the Reds, each demanded by the teams, gives the city an indispensable lure.
"When we are talking to businesses about locating here," said Robert L. Wehling, a senior vice president at Procter & Gamble, the city's largest employer, "if you don't have professional sports teams, you are not going to make their cut."
The saucer-shaped foundation of the new football stadium is already in place and bulldozers have cut the wide swath of an eight-lane highway to replace a road now running through the riverfront site. Two thousand feet upriver, the Reds' new stadium will rise almost on top of the team's present stadium.
"Between these two bookends," said Andis Udris, director of economic development, "we will have retailers, restaurants, offices, a museum -- basically items that complement tourism."
In full swing, the five-year, $800 million construction project, financed through a half-cent increase in the sales tax, will generate 2,000 jobs, many at local supplier companies, city officials estimate. That is roughly 7 percent of the 25,000 jobs added in Greater Cincinnati in 1998.
"The riverfront stadiums are marketing," said Bob Bedinghaus, a commissioner of Hamilton County, which includes downtown Cincinnati. "They show that this is an exciting place to live and work."
But they are not what encouraged Candace Kendle Bryan and her husband, Christopher C. Bergen, to form Kendle, the medical company, after they moved here from Philadelphia to be near her mother. They have since expanded from 63 employees in 1991 to 350 today in Cincinnati. Many are nurses, pharmacists and physiologists like Ms. Belknap. They audit doctors who test drugs on patients before the Food and Drug Administration rules on licensing the drugs.
"There has to be a big enough health care industry, a critical mass, so that we have people to draw from," Mr. Bergen said, "and there has to be alternative jobs for our employees who don't work out or who want other opportunities."
Far from being attracted by the stadium development, Larry Martin, a 35-year-old molecular virologist from Seattle, was worried that Cincinnati might be too conservative, too straitlaced. But the opportunity for advancement and the salary at P.& G.'s new pharmaceutical research center -- more than $40,000 to start, a big jump from the $28,000 he had been earning in cancer research -- drew him. "It was a total career decision," he said. Although still a bachelor, he has already purchased a suburban home.
But for all the growth, there are caveats. The city's black population does not share equally in the prosperity. The black unemployment rate for the area is at least 8 percent, more than double the 3.4 percent rate for the work force as a whole. And some of Cincinnati's job gains, like those of other midsize cities, are someone else's losses. Ashland Oil, for example, is shifting its headquarters to Cincinnati from smaller Ashland, Ky.
Still, Mr. Zandi, the economist, said, "There are no hard numbers, but most of the new jobs in midsize cities seem to represent expansion rather than transfer."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the economic prosperity in many midsized American cities misstated the ownership of a telephone operator center in Jacksonville, Fla. It is owned by a subsidiary of Cincinnati Bell; AT&T sold it last March.
