HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE;
Best Memories Of a Musical Year Full of Echoes

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
Last year was a momentous one for the music business. Record stores, music labels and the concert industry all underwent massive consolidation putting them under the control of a shrinking number of corporations. And use of the computer for downloading and playing music exploded, particularly on college campuses, much to the chagrin of those few corporations.
Unfortunately 1998 was not momentous for the music itself, commercially or critically. Of the year's Top 10 recordings, 7 came out in 1997, including the best-selling albums, the "Titanic" soundtrack and Celine Dion's "Let's Talk About Love." 
 The year was one of waiting: for follow-up records that didn't materialize, for anticipated albums that disappointed, for next big things that never were.
Hip-hop albums flew to the top of the charts and then plummeted, while most albums with staying power were by manufactured teeny-bopper bands like 'N Sync. Promising groups whose first album didn't sell well enough didn't get a second chance, while performers whose albums sold well were sent on long tours that kept them out of the studio. The business focused on hit singles at the expense of complete albums and careers.
Reflecting a status quo year for popular music, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times selected few newcomers in their lists of the Top 10 releases of 1998, which appear below. Sometimes familiarity may breed contempt, but this year familiarity bred admiration as well-known performers took chances.
 
Jon Pareles
 
1. Lauryn Hill, "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill" (Ruffhouse/Columbia). Instruction and confession, righteousness and heartbreak -- along with hip-hop, reggae, rhythm-and-blues and touches of old-fashioned soul -- all swirl together on an album that lives up to extraordinary ambitions.
 
2. Bob Dylan, "Live 1966/The 'Royal Albert Hall' Concert" (Columbia). Friction produced incendiary sparks as Bob Dylan faced a heckling audience in Manchester, England. Goaded by the naysayers, he and the Hawks came up with molten, bluesy, savagely funny folk-rock. The music was supremely self-confident, inventing itself on the spot.
 
3. Carlinhos Brown, "Alfagamabetizado" (Metro Blue/Capitol). Melody and drive find new configurations in the music of Mr. Brown, the most important songwriter to emerge from Bahia, Brazil, in the 1990's. From rhythmic dynamos to tender ballads to carnival-propelled raps, he stays as graceful and smart as his finest Brazilian forebears.
 
4. Beck, "Mutations" (DGC). Jettisoning samples and looking past irony, Beck and his band took just two weeks to make an album that's both folksy and untraditionally warped. The lyrics ponder decay, exhaustion, funerals and endings; the music, gentle but sly, suggests that hope won't disappear.
 
5. Bloque, "Bloque" (Luaka Bop/ Warner Brothers). Rock still sounds wild and dangerous in the hands of this Colombian band. Mixing regional rhythms with funk and jazz, Bloque turns discontent into a party that could easily get out of hand.
 
6. R.E.M, "Up" (Warner Brothers). Audaciously reshaping its identity, R.E.M. turned to introspection for an album that reveals itself on repeated listening. Wandering from Stereolab to the Beach Boys to Leonard Cohen, the songs consider the global economy, love, death and faith.
 
7. Tricky, "Angels With Dirty Faces" (Island). Now that trip-hop is no longer new, Tricky tore new fissures in the music, coming up with some of the year's most disorienting grooves. The songs throb and totter, stutter and scrape; odd meters and Tricky's paranoid rasp pull listeners into a zone where every step could lead to a trapdoor.
 
8. Hole, "Celebrity Skin" (Geffen). Concealing her fury within gleaming pop tunes -- more Go-Go's than grunge -- Courtney Love made her own passage through notoriety, loss and stardom sound like something more than a California whine. She lashes out at celebrity culture as she acknowledges its temptations.
 
9. Elliott Smith, "XO" (Geffen). Years of making quick, cheap albums honed Mr. Smith's ingenuity so that "XO," his major-label debut, is filled with textural metamorphoses to match his restless harmonies and neo-Beatles melodies. He's still trouble, but his music reaches out more decisively than ever.
 
10. Air, "Moon Safari" (Caroline). Buzzing, burbling and sliding, sliding everywhere, analog keyboards have started to sound warm and endearing by contrast to the cool precision of digital sounds. Air, a French duo, used its collection of obsolescent keyboards to create serenely pensive music, making yesterday's futurism sound like a lost electronic Eden.
 
Peter Watrous
 
1. David Berkman, "Handmade" (Palmetto). Sad to say, but a jazz record that has rhythm as one of its priorities is a rarity. Mr. Berkman, a pianist, has convened an exceptional band, including Tom Harrell on trumpet, Steve Wilson on saxophones, Ugonna Okegwo on bass and Brian Blade on drums and percussion, and it moves, always rhythmically, from percussion workouts to quintet mainstream jazz.
 
2. Ravi Coltrane, "Moving Pictures" (RCA). This is the first album by a saxophonist who has promise. He has produced a recording of just that, plus some. There's a drum choir here, exploratory playing there and if it doesn't add up to the pungency of the band's live performances, few recordings ever do.
 
3. Jack DeJohnette, "Oneness" (ECM). The recording is spare and percussive and suggests the mainstream in Mr. DeJohnette's utterly swinging ride cymbal. The band, including Jerome Harris on guitar and bass guitar, Michael Cain on piano, Don Alias on percussion and Mr. DeJohnette on drums, makes music that could serve for film. It's atmospheric, gauzy and textural.
 
4. Herbie Hancock, "Gershwin's World" (Verve). Instead of trying to reproduce the intensity of a live performance, this album revels in its artificiality; each track features a different band, from Mr. Hancock and drummers to singing.
 
5. Sherman Irby, "Big Mama's Biscuits" (Blue Note). Soul abstraction: the recording, deep in the black jazz tradition, moves from the blues into striking, unfettered improvisations. Mr. Irby, an alto saxophonist, sounds loose and daring. And his control of dynamics is a wonder.
 
6. Ethan Iverson, "Deconstruction Zone (Standards)" (Fresh Sound). The pianist takes apart standards with a trio. Drifting chords enrich the changes, and a tune's basic form is the starting point of intense, complex improvisation.
 
7. Joe Lovano, "Trio Fascination" (Blue Note). Backed by Dave Holland on bass and Elvin Jones on drums, Mr. Lovano turns in a set of liquid improvisations. The pianoless trio format suits him, and he's rarely been recorded in such splendor.
 
8. Greg Osby, "Banned in New York" (Blue Note). This live album has Mr. Osby and his band at their rawest and finest. Tunes segue; Mr. Osby's serpentine lines clear the way for a type of formal improvisation that sounds, and is, new.
 
9. Tim Warfield, "Gentle Warrior" (Criss Cross). He's perhaps the most powerful tenor saxophonist of his generation. This is his best album, and he moves from cool ballads to free playing; it offers the pianist Cyrus Chestnut, relaxed and deadly serious in his playful improvisations.
 
10. Steve Wilson, "Generations" (Stretch). Mr. Wilson, an alto saxophonist, is in the company of elders: the pianist Mulgrew Miller, the bassist Ray Drummond and the drummer Ben Riley. His own generation has some formal tricks not heard on the album. Instead he turns up the intensity in his own solos."
 
Neil Strauss
 
1. Air, "Moon Safari" (Source/Caroline). The secret to this album of French electronic lounge-pop is not in the gurgling analog synthesizers, the robotic vocoders or the subdued grandiosity of the Burt Bacharach-style arrangements but in the tone and timbre: sweet, relentlessly seductive; everything old done right.
 
2. Lauryn Hill, "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill" (Ruffhouse/Columbia). This well-thought-out soulfully introspective album chronicles life's camouflaged traps and small triumphs, showing off Ms. Hill as a rap-pop syncretist wise beyond her 23 years.
 
3. Lucinda Williams, "Car Wheels on a Gravel Road" (Mercury). Six years in the making and without a weak cut, "Car Wheels" charts a South where towns, roads and songs exist only as markers memorializing relationships and memories. Ms. Williams futilely tries to return to these markers, knowing that what she's looking for has long since gone.
 
4. Tom Ze, "Fabrication Defect" (Luaka Bop/Warner Brothers). An odd yet accessible collection from one of Brazil's most consistent innovators, this is a politically and musically restless concept album about repression underscored by sharp guitar picking.
 
5. Herbie Hancock, "Gershwin's World" (Verve). On the occasion of George Gershwin's centennial, no musician managed to explore, elevate or respect him and his contemporaries as well as Mr. Hancock did, with some of his best piano work in recent years and mesmerizing contributions from Joni Mitchell, James Carter and Kenny Garrett.
 
6. Black Box Recorder, "England Made Me" (Chrysalis U.K.). "Life's unfair," whisper the angel-voiced Sarah Nixey and Luke Haines (of the Auteurs) on a beautifully macabre album in which contradiction is key. "Kill yourself or get over it."
 
7. Cornelius, "Phantasm" (Trattoria/Matador). This is the sound of one collector collecting, a Japanese studio savant (Keigo Oyamada), equal parts Beck and Brian Wilson, who helped prove that the future of music may lie in the East.
 
8. Outkast, "Aquemini" (LaFace/ Arista). Hip-hop fans spent millions on Jay-Z, DMX and No Limit records extolling the gangsta life, but this Atlanta duo brought something new to the genre, with fast-paced raps, clever wordplay and the feel of a live funk party.
 
9. Eels, "Electro-Shock Blues" (Dreamworks). This was one of the year's only fully realized albums, with a beginning (the singer E's sister lying dead by her own hand on her bathroom floor), a middle (E visiting his dying mother in the hospital) and a life-affirming ending. The tragedy is that for E, these events were not fictional.
 
10. Molotov, "Donde Jugaran los Ninos?" (Universal/Surco). Equal parts Beastie Boys and Rage Against the Machine, Molotov railed against the Mexican establishment on a hard-hitting hybrid album full of fat bass lines, growling guitars, hip-hop scratching, screaming Spanglish choruses and a sense of humor.
 
Top Singles The Beastie Boys, "Intergalactic"; Terry Callier, "Love Theme From Spartacus (4 Hero Main Mix)"; Arling and Cameron, "Speeding Down the Highway/We Love Dancing"; Madonna, "Ray of Light"; Dilated Peoples, "Work the Angles"; Swirl, "Hey Now Now"; Fatboy Slim, "The Rockafeller Skank"; Everclear, "I Will Buy You a New Life"; Brock Landars, "S.M.D.U."; R. Kelly, "If I Could Turn Back the Hands of Time."
 
Ben Ratliff
 
1. Carlinhos Brown, "Omelet Man" (EMI Brazil). This Brazilian pop factotum throws disparate cultural ingredients into one dish: funk, Bahian drumming, old-world hymns, booming reggae, rock anthems, orchestral ballads. The ambitious result was gorgeously produced by the singer Marisa Monte. (Available on Metro Blue/Capitol on May 4.)
 
2. Caetano Veloso, "Livro" (Mercury Brazil). Sonically modern without becoming producer-driven schtick, tender like a classic movie romance, it's the sort of record that a brilliant middle-aged pop singer-songwriter should be making.
 
3. Tom Ze, "Fabrication Defect" (Luaka Bop/Warner Brothers). A Brazilian master of eccentric pop returns with a set of strange songs, philosophical and deeply rhythmic, busting with impish humor.
 
4. Greg Osby, "Banned in New York" (Blue Note). The live sound on the saxophonist's new disk is cheap and a bit washed-out, and there's no overarching concept about repertory besides what Mr. Osby's quartet brings to the stage on a usual night.
 
5. Tortoise, "TNT" (Thrill Jockey). The new version of Tortoise, a two-bass, two-drums experimental Chicago jamathon band, both expands its palette with brass and guitar, and narrows its focus with a refinement of studio craft. The group no longer sounds provincial; this record kicks it up into the realm of the great.
 
6. Chris Potter Quartet, "Vertigo" (Concord). One of the tunes on the still-under-30 saxophonist's fifth album is a musical acting out of Hamlet's "to be or not to be" soliloquy: harmonically and rhythmically, he dives into the unresolvable with a strong poetic eloquence.
 
7. Sherman Irby, "Big Mama's Biscuits" (Blue Note). If, say, Lee Konitz had made this record -- and in places, with its spare trio lineup and Mr. Irby's willowy-with-an-edge alto saxophone sound, he could have -- it would have been the talk of the jazz world. But there's also some wonderful blues playing here.
 
8. Joe Lovano, "Trio Fascination" (Blue Note). 1998 was a year of great trio records, but the serenity and the slow-gathering tidal waves of improvisation on this one, with the bassist Dave Holland and drummer Elvin Jones, affirmed with an easy authority this saxophonist's status as one of jazz's greatest figures.
 
10. DJ Faust, "Man or Myth?" (Bomb Hip Hop). There are good reasons to be skeptical about the rise of turntablism: Is all that hand-eye coordination on the turntables and cross-faders art or parlor tricks? But the worthy documents are now slowly seeping out, and this one came with virtuosity and humor.
 
Ann Powers
 
1. Lauryn Hill, "The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill" (Ruffhouse/Columbia). In a year of shadows and complements, every outstanding album had its well-matched rival. The solo debut by this rapper and singer outdid the efforts of her fellow Fugees and helped stimulate today's hip-hop renaissance. But Ms. Hill ultimately stands alone as this year's legend in the making: a paragon of musicality, vision, and personal grace.
 
2. Lucinda Williams, "Car Wheels on a Gravel Road" (Mercury). The six years fans waited for this exquisite meditation on traveling among towns, lovers and life spans made its arrival feel like a literary event. But for all its novelistic carefulness, "Car Wheels" manages to be more than perfect because of the ambiguity that pervades Ms. Williams's writing and singing; it comes from learning to survive.
 
3. Billy Bragg and Wilco, "Mermaid Avenue" (Elektra). The communal counterpart to Ms. Williams's personal history lesson, this collection of Woody Guthrie lyrics, set to music by an English alternative folkie and a Midwestern band set on revitalizing roots rock, confirmed that great songs add up to more than the sum of their parts. "Mermaid Avenue" is a political act, but its messages never overwhelm its joy.
 
4. Duncan Sheik, "Humming" (Atlantic). Spirituality was big last year, with artists from Madonna to the Beastie Boys finding power in the quest for the sacred. This smooth melodicist best translated religious experience into sound. In songs that coalesce like so many drifting thoughts, he made a soundtrack for the examined life.
 
5. Rufus Wainwright, "Rufus Wainwright" (Dreamworks). These days music isn't often a family affair, but with several 1998 releases, the clan of singer-songwriters led by Kate and Anna McGarrigle and Loudon Wainwright 3d carved out a shining corner. Kate and Loudon's son Rufus stole the show with a starry-eyed debut that wanders from dance floors to the opera.
 
6. Black Star, "Mos Def and Talib Kweli Are Black Star" (Rawkus). As hip-hop flourished in the bright light of commercial triumph, its tendrils extended strongly and vitally underground. Outkast, from Atlanta, was a favored alternative; that crew's potential is matched in skill and superseded in resolve by this collaboration between Brooklyn's two wittiest freestyling wordsmiths.
 
7. Hole, "Celebrity Skin" (Geffen). Women continued to rule rock stardom, with Liz Phair, Tori Amos, and P. J. Harvey all releasing albums that furthered their brilliant careers. Courtney Love, leader of Hole, caused the biggest ruckus and showed the most courage by staunchly championing old-fashioned life-altering epiphanies.
 
8. Massive Attack, "Mezzanine" (Virgin). The most alluring music from Europe now is the spawn of dance music and rock-and-roll attitude. On "Mezzanine," the band that originated these mutations returned with the sound of a summer night at the end of the world.
 
9. Quasi, "Featuring 'Birds' " (Up). Forming a dialogue with the cruelly gorgeous "XO" by Elliott Smith, this duo's former Portland, Ore., neighbor, and the latest offering from the delightfully disturbed Modest Mouse, of Issaquah, Wash., this album of jagged little commentaries is marked by the honesty, black humor and rage-filled independence of the Pacific Northwest.
 
10. Pernice Brothers, "Overcome by Happiness" (Sub Pop). With so many musical asteroids breaking off from pop's shattered planet, serious listeners can each treasure a private favorite. Mine might have been "Deserter's Songs" by Mercury Rev, if not for this startling slice of beauty masterminded by Joe Pernice of the Scud Mountain Boys. Its sweet melodies and bitter undertones surface like classics from the radio that plays for but one lucky listener.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Many of those headed to Europe are a bit bewildered about coping with the euro.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
ONE of the first phone calls Alami Driss received yesterday morning was from someone asking how he could buy euros for a planned trip to Europe. Responding as he had done to similar phone calls for more than a month, Mr. Driss explained that the euro is not available for purchase anywhere for three more years.
"A lot of people think that by this Jan. 1, European currencies just vanished," said Mr. Driss, senior vice president of People's Foreign Exchange, a money exchange in midtown Manhattan. Meanwhile, he is awaiting a supply of explanatory brochures about the euro to give to walk-in customers, both as a service and in hopes of forestalling a rash of similar phone calls. 
 "Although people come in here worried and confused," Mr. Driss added, "it doesn't take long to explain the situation to them."
The 11 so-called euro zone nations are Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain. For now, at least, Britain, Denmark and Sweden have opted out, while Greece did not meet economic requirements for membership.
Many visitors to American Express offices the last two days also have the impression that the French franc, German mark, Italian lira and the currencies of the other eight member countries are extinct, according to company officials. "So we have to tell them that the euro is a virtual currency for the next three years," said Chris Levite, a spokeswoman for American Express.
Not every potential traveler to Europe is confused about the euro, which has been the official currency of the 11 participating countries since midnight in Brussels on New Year's Eve. "We got a check for $10,000 about a month ago from a man in Long Island wanting to buy the first printing of our euro-traveler's checks," Ms. Levite said.
While euro notes and coins will not go on sale before Jan. 1, 2002, and will not formally replace local currencies before July 1, 2002, the euro exchange rate can be used for traveler's check payments, credit card purchases and other noncash transactions. While still too early to know how avidly Americans will take to euro-traveler's checks, they are not likely to set any sales records, mainly because for now they are readily accepted only in Europe's bigger shops, restaurants and hotels.
Many establishments in the 11 countries already post prices in euros as well as local currencies, and most are expected to do so before long.
Corporate travelers usually have at least a passing familiarity with the euro, but Mr. Telford said they wanted reassurance about how to pay bills quoted in both euros and local currencies. They are told they can pay in either euro-traveler's checks or with major credit cards, whose purchases will be converted by the card's issuing bank and billed in dollars or the card user's home currency.
Travel officials in the United States generally agree that in the future the euro will benefit American travelers by allowing them to pay just one commission for any or all 11 currencies, and will save them money when they reconvert leftover currency at the end of a trip.
The ease of comparing hotel rates in different countries will benefit leisure travelers, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, as well as corporations and associations looking to book meetings. Travelers will also have a better idea of the costs, if not necessarily the value, of restaurant meals, souvenirs, clothing and any number of other purchases.
Even smaller companies that do business in countries using the euro can expect to save time and money on overhead by not having to reconcile bills and receipts issued in many currencies. And corporate travel managers say they expect the simplicity offered by a single currency to make it easier for big corporations, especially multinationals, to negotiate preferable rates with European airlines, hotels and rental cars -- or, at the very least, to extract lower fares and rates from current suppliers by threatening to negotiate with their European rivals.

HEADLINE: Cubans Skeptical About Expanded Contacts

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Cuban officials reacted with cool skepticism today to President Clinton's decision to expand contacts between Americans and Cubans, while the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, maintained a pointed silence.
Cuban officials and economists said they doubted that the decision to allow additional people and organizations to send money to Cuban families and charities would ease the deep economic crisis here. 
 Most Cuban officials, from Mr. Castro down, fault the embargo for this nation's dismal economic performance.
Cuban officials also said it appeared that the Clinton Administration had given up on the idea of a bipartisan commission to consider lifting the embargo, a signal that there would be no fundamental change in policy under Mr. Clinton.
"This is nothing surprising, just more of the same," said a high-ranking official who insisted on anonymity. "The purpose of the embargo was always to undermine the revolution from within."
Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina said on his arrival on a visit to Haiti that the measures announced by Mr. Clinton "don't really go to the root of the problem."
"The root of the problem is still a blockade that is unjust," Mr. Robaina said.
Payments to Cubans from family members make up one of the country's largest sources of hard currency, estimated from $500,000 to $800,000 a year. They have fueled a growing dollar-based economy. Mr. Clinton's proposals would be expected to increase the flow of cash to the island.
Cuban officials said, however, that the changes were cosmetic and would neither influence the economy nor public opinion here.
Antonio Romero, an economist with the University of Havana, said an increase in payments from abroad might help individual families but would not cure the underlying malaise. "It will have an economic impact, but only at the micro level," Mr. Romero said.
The American embargo, he added, makes Cuba less attractive to foreign investors and keeps interest rates on bonds in the high teens, making it almost impossible for Cuba to obtain capital to modernize its aging Soviet-style factories.
Most people in the capital knew little about Mr. Clinton's overture by late evening. The state-controlled television broadcast a short report that outlined the proposals, saying they would ease the blockade "very little."
Some people with family members in the United States said they were happy to hear that additional people could send them money, though it was unclear to many who in addition to their relatives would be willing to do so.
Juan Miguel Carmona, 21, a chemistry student at the university, said although he would be happy to receive additional money from his uncle and other relatives in Miami, he would be even happier to hear that the embargo had been lifted.
"It would not only be very good for us, but it would be the just thing to do," he said. "The whole world outside the United States has realized there has to be a change toward Cuba."
Stalwart members of the Communist Party, many of whom have survived on meager Government salaries while watching other citizens receive cash from abroad, reacted to the news with predictable bitterness.
"All they want is that our opposition has more money to fight against the revolution," said one low-level official over a beer at a bar.
Another Government employee, who insisted on anonymity, said the proposals from Washington continued the same patronizing attitude that the United States had taken since the early 1960's. "For 40 years the United States has been imposing conditions on us," the official said. "They do not respect us. If the blockade had never existed the revolution would have solved all the problems we have now."

HEADLINE: Tenneco Expects Earnings Below Estimates

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Tenneco Inc. expects to report fourth-quarter earnings "substantially below" consensus estimates, primarily because of weak performance in its automotive aftermarket business and several charges related to the automotive business.
In a statement late today, the company said that Tenneco Automotive's original equipment business and Tenneco Packaging's specialty packaging businesses remained strong and would "essentially meet expectations." 
 Tenneco said consolidation among North American and European customers had delayed orders, which combined with an unseasonably warm winter worldwide and softness in South American and Asian economies, would reduce fourth-quarter operating income by about $25 million to $30 million from current estimates.
The company's announcement came after its shares rose $2.1875 today, to $35.9375.
Tenneco has 50,000 employees worldwide. Tenneco Automotive's brand names include Monroe and Walker. Tenneco Packaging makes Hefty trash bags and Baggies food storage bags.

HEADLINE: Economists Reject Notion Of Stock Market 'Bubble'

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In all the talk at their annual meeting about the United States economy and what keeps it so robust, the nation's economists gave short shrift to one concern -- that the soaring stock market might be a speculative bubble that could burst, damaging the economy.
The stock market is neither a principal reason for the economy's strength nor a big threat to the nearly eight-year-long expansion, the economists said in their various sessions at the American Economic Association's three-day meeting, which ended yesterday, and in interviews. The majority view was that high stock prices probably reflect not a bubble but the economy's actual strength, although no one said that categorically. 
 "Is it a bubble?" said N. Gregory Mankiw, a Harvard economist. "If the people here really thought this was a bubble market about to crash, that would have been a big topic of conversation at this meeting."
A bubble, if one exists, raises the odds that stock prices will eventually plunge and extinguish the wealth of millions of shareholders. They will respond by pulling back suddenly on their spending, damaging the economy. The Asian economic crisis raised concern that the market might be ignoring danger and thus in bubble territory. The spectacular run-up in the share prices of some high-technology companies also fed talk of a bubble market.
But the bubble talk largely disappeared after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates three times late last year. That action convinced many on Wall Street -- and also many of the economists gathered in Manhattan -- that the Fed stood ready to sustain the expansion, and stock prices, by cutting rates again if necessary.
"There is a sense now that if this is a bubble and it bursts, the Fed will lower interest rates and everything will be fine," Mr. Mankiw said. "Many economists have confidence in Alan Greenspan as the Fed's chairman."
In the minds of many economists, the stock market serves mainly as a gauge of the real economy and a stimulus for spending. What accounts much more for the strong economy, in this view, is the happy combination since 1995 of four factors: robust job creation, rising output, falling unemployment and minimal inflation. Usually the first three produce a rise in the fourth, the inflation rate. The Federal Reserve then raises interest rates to subdue inflation by slowing the economy, and the expansion ends or becomes much less vigorous.
This time, inflation has not risen, as it so often did in the past, particularly when the unemployment rate dropped below 5.5 percent. It is now 4.4 percent.
And the reasons? Considerable credit went to "lucky shocks," as Alan Blinder of Princeton University phrased it -- falling oil prices, for example, falling import prices, smaller-than-expected increases in health care costs and ever sharper declines in computer prices.
"There is absolutely no reason to predict that these favorable supply shocks will continue over the next year or two," said James Stock of Harvard.
But structural changes might be more enduring, allowing perhaps for a jobless rate of less than 5 percent without a rise in inflation. The growing use of part-time and temporary workers may help to explain the combination of low unemployment and minimal upward pressure on labor costs and prices, Mr. Stock said. Greater labor mobility may play a role, as well as job insecurity and the aging of the baby boomers. Older workers are less inclined to leave a job. Or so the reasoning went.
Only Edmund Phelps of Columbia University argued that the rising stock market played a leading role in driving the current expansion. "Rising share prices," he said, "create the incentive for enterprises to invest in more employees and more fixed capital. The worth of workers has gone up," when measured as the rising value of a company's stock.
But have share prices gotten too inflated? "I am an agnostic on that issue," Mr. Phelps said. "Maybe this is a time in which a big error is being made. But I don't think so."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Making New Yorker Hotel New Again

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
The New Yorker Hotel -- yes, the New Yorker -- is a major tourist hotel again. A four-year, $20 million renovation is nearing completion, and the building at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street, which was once the largest hotel in the city and for many years housed followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, now has 860 functioning guest rooms -- with a total of 1,005 expected by June.
The elevators have been renovated and the lobby of the 69-year-old building, which once welcomed music lovers eager to hear the giants of the Big Band era, is being refurbished. There are three restaurants, four deluxe suites with terraces and 35 new tower minisuites with views of the river and downtown. 
 "Every time we open another floor, we sell out," said Barry S. Mann, the hotel's general manager. "Our occupancy rate last year was 88.6 percent."
The New Yorker is a midrange hotel that attracts many foreign tourists, with room rates for the winter season ranging from $129 to $169 and suites going for $225 to $595. About 60 percent of the hotel's business comes through travel brokers and wholesalers, "and that business is divided equally between Europe, South America and Asia," Mr. Mann said.
"We're also close to the Javits Center," he added, "and that is starting to give us corporate business."
Sean F. Hennessey, the New York director of the hospitality and leisure practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, said that the hotel was benefiting from the positive economy and the city's tourist boom. "It's a good time to be offering additional rooms in New York," Mr. Hennessey said, adding that the city's hotel occupancy rate in the fourth quarter of 1998 was about 83.5 percent, "which is pretty close to capacity."
"The demand remains pretty strong," he said. "We continue to see many hotels in town reporting a lot of turn-away demand every night. And there certainly continues to be a lot of demand for midpriced rooms like the New Yorker's. So much of the emphasis in New York is on the luxury side of the business. But a lot of average tourists want to stay here as well."
He added that the New Yorker's neighborhood had also improved. "I think that side of town has become a lot more desirable over the last several years," he said.
When the New Yorker opened on Jan. 2, 1930, the 43-story, $22.5 million Art Deco tower was the biggest hotel in the city and one of the largest in the world. It had 2,500 rooms, 3 ballrooms, 10 private dining salons and 5 restaurants with 35 chefs. There were 92 telephone operators, 150 laundry workers handling thousands of articles daily, and a 42-chair barber shop with 20 manicurists. Benny Goodman, Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey and Woody Herman played at the hotel, and the Brooklyn Dodgers used it as their headquarters for their losing battle against the New York Yankees in the 1941 World Series.
But beginning in the 1950's, as the area around 34th Street became less desirable, the hotel's fortunes began to decline. It had several owners and went through a foreclosure, finally closing in 1972. It was bought in 1976 by the Unification Church, which used the hotel as its headquarters and housed its followers there. But in 1994 the church began turning part of the building back into a hotel again, renovating rooms, polishing the lobby's elegant crystal chandeliers and removing old yellow paint to reveal green marble underneath.
The renovation stemmed partly from the church's demographic changes. Many of the missionaries who used the New Yorker as a dormitory had paired off -- some were among the 2,075 couples married en masse at Madison Square Garden in 1982 -- and had moved to apartments and suburban homes.
At first only 175 rooms were converted, but as they kept being filled, more rooms were added to the hotel. Now the church uses only about 100 rooms for housing, Mr. Mann said, and about half a floor for office space. The church's headquarters are at 4 West 43d Street in a building that was once the Columbia University Club.
The 7th through 17th floors of the New Yorker building are commercial office space. The hotel's offices are on floors 5 and 6, the third floor is being converted to seven meeting rooms, the second floor has the hotel's two remaining ballrooms, and what was once the Terrace Room, where couples danced as the Big Bands played, is used by MSG cable television as a studio.
Next up, Mr. Mann said, is an exterior renovation that is scheduled to begin in 2000 and is to include new sidewalks, new marquees and restoration of the limestone facade on the lower floors.
"Our goal is to be the best three-star hotel in the city," Mr. Mann said. "There's no shame in being a three-star hotel as long as you're good at what you do."

HEADLINE: Miami Generally Welcomes Easing of Ban

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Hemley Gonzalez calls an aunt in Cuba every weekend, and he travels to the island once a year to take medicine and clothes to the scores of relatives he left behind when he moved here 10 years ago.
Mr. Gonzalez favors the American economic embargo against Cuba, he said, but that does not deter him from his personal mission, helping to ease his family's financial hardship and giving them a glimpse of "what's going on in the outside." 
 "My opinion has always been put people first and worry about politics later," he said.
For Cuban-Americans like Mr. Gonzalez, 23, a real-estate agent in Miami Beach, the Clinton Administration decision to allow additional contact between Americans and Cubans supports many individual efforts to sidestep the Cuban Government to break through the isolation of their families and friends.
But the announcement also pleased those who advocate keeping Cuba isolated because of the Administration's refusal even to study changing relations with the island.
The Cuban American National Foundation, the most politically prominent exile group and an unwavering advocate of the embargo against Cuba, was among those relieved that the policy was not fundamentally altered. The foundation objects to proposals to sell agricultural supplies to nongovernmental entities on the grounds that Cuba has "no true private businesses."
The organization has also opposed bills to allow the sale of food and medicine to Cuba by American companies, fearing that such a move would weaken the 37-year-old embargo.
"Unfortunately what these steps may produce is that in the end American taxpayers would subsidize the Cuban regime," said the vice chairman of the foundation, Jorge Mas. "The Government can't pay. There'll be a need for credit and subsidies. It's a very dangerous step that may have the opposite effect than promoting democracy in Cuba."
Those who want to end the ban called the steps positive but said they fell short. Bishop Thomas Wenski, the auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami who has visited Cuba several times, called the restrictions Fidel Castro's "whipping boy" and "dull instruments that hurt the people."
"The embargo cannot be sustained morally," Bishop Wenski said. "Lifting the embargo would be both smart policy and a powerful humanitarian effort."
Silvia Wilhelm, executive director of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, a Cuban-American group that opposes the embargo, said lifting restrictions that had failed in their goal for 37 years would spur change in Cuba more quickly than gradual measures. Cuba would no longer have the United States to blame for all that is wrong with the country, Ms. Wilhelm said.
But she welcomed the Administration's announcement. "Anything that brings less dependency of the Cuban people on the Government is a step in the right direction," Ms. Wilhelm said, "because ultimately what we want is the people in Cuba to be empowered."
The relaxation will make a practical difference to Cubans on both sides of the Florida Straits. Vivian Mannerud, owner of one of two companies that offer charter flights to Cuba, said allowing flights from cities other than Miami would increase the number of flights and lower the cost of travel. Her Airline Brokers Company offers four Miami-Havana flights a week and carries a third of the estimated 100,000 Cuban-Americans who fly to Cuba each year, she said.
"Our passengers are not wealthy people," Ms. Mannerud said. "It costs them to come out from the West Coast just to catch the flight here."
Mr. Gonzalez, the real estate agent, predicted that rules allowing more cash to go to Cubans would expand capitalism in the midst of socialism.
"You can send a Cuban $1,000," Mr. Gonzalez said, "and he'd buy three VCR's in an electronics store and sell them on the street in the black market for $100 to about $150 more in Cuban currency. It will create more underground business, money for the people, not the Government."

HEADLINE: AT&T Wins At Home Deal and a Foothold as a Data Carrier

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Advancing its aspiration to become a major carrier of Internet data, the AT&T Corporation has won a long-term contract to provide the At Home Corporation, the nation's largest provider of cable modem service, with 15,000 miles of high-speed fiber optic lines.
The companies intend to announce the deal today. 
 At Home connects consumers to cyberspace using cable television systems, but it uses long-distance telephone systems to transmit huge amounts of data to local cable operators around the country.
AT&T is the nation's biggest communications company, but it has lagged in offering the high-speed data links used by Internet providers. C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman since 1997, is trying to change that.
So while the deal with At Home is marginal in immediate financial value for AT&T -- worth up to $100 million, according to analysts and to executives close to the deal -- it is a big leap strategically. The executives said the deal's financial value could increase if At Home exercised options to expand it in the future.
"This is a blue-chip Internet reference account for AT&T, which has not been an especially visible player in making backbone wholesale deals with new-age Internet companies," said Christopher Mines, an analyst for Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass.
The deal is also a big technical step forward for At Home. Using the AT&T systems, At Home intends to become one of the first major data communications companies to connect Internet routers directly to fiber optic lines. That could give At Home an especially fast and advanced network.
Until now, At Home has mostly used systems provided by the Sprint Corporation that incurred a cost to At Home for each unit of data transmitted. Under the AT&T deal, however, At Home will essentially own an entire communications pipeline.
"They probably just bought themselves a 5 percent increase in their operating margin," said Richard A. Bilotti, an analyst for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He estimated that those margins now are between 25 and 30 percent for At Home's residential business.
According to executives close to the deal, At Home asked long-distance companies to submit bids for its business last June, and other bidders were Sprint, Qwest, Level 3, Frontier, Williams and IXC.
But not all the bidders were on an equal technical footing when it came to winning the At Home contract, and that is not just because some of the new carriers have not yet completed their fiber optic networks.
At Home wants to connect Internet routers directly to a sort of fiber optic transmission gear known as wave-division multiplexing, or W.D.M., equipment. It is suited to systems that carry only data but also to those that carry voice traffic.
Some telecommunications equipment companies, primarily Northern Telecom of Canada, tend to build into their W.D.M. gear another sort of fiber optic technology known as Sonet, which facilitates voice traffic but costs more.
At Home, which only transmits data, did not want to pay for the use of Sonet, so carriers like Qwest, which uses a lot of Northern Telecom equipment, found themselves at a disadvantage, according to executives close to the deal.
Tele-Communications Inc., the big cable television company that has agreed to be acquired by AT&T, is also the largest shareholder in At Home. But Milo Medin, At Home's chief technical officer, said that was not a factor in its choice of AT&T.

HEADLINE: Qualms Over UConn's Big Plans

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: STORRS, Conn.

 BODY:
At the main campus of the University of Connecticut here, a building boom is under way that would be the envy of most university presidents.
UConn has built or will soon complete a $13 million fine arts center, a $56 million chemistry building, a $40 million library renovation and a $43 million residential complex. It is spending millions more for new satellite campuses in Stamford and Groton, and aims to upgrade three other branches to offer a variety of four-year degrees. 
 But across Connecticut, some educators are viewing UConn's expansion with more fear than envy. They say the growth, financed with $1 billion provided by the State Legislature, could threaten small private liberal arts colleges and the Connecticut State University system (the former state teachers colleges), which have long provided the state with institutional diversity.
Herman Lujan, the chief academic officer of the state university system, said he was concerned about competition from the expanded UConn satellites, and had registered a protest, which he expected to be taken up by the State Department of Higher Education at its next meeting on Jan. 20.
Speaking for the private colleges, Anthony J. Cernera, president of Sacred Heart University in Fairfield and chairman of the 16-member Connecticut Conference of Independent Colleges, said the expansive plans of UConn, especially the upgrading of branches in Waterbury, Torrington and West Hartford, "duplicate what already exists" and "don't make a whole lot of sense."
Philip E. Austin, UConn's president, answered, "We are not trying to compete unfairly with anyone, but are responding to demographic changes in the state and following what the elected leadership and the business leadership have asked of us."
The struggle being played out in Connecticut is mirrored in many states, said Edward R. Hines, a senior associate of the Center for Higher Education at Illinois State University, who conducts an annual survey of state higher-education officials.
"We'll see more and more of a gap -- more stratification -- between, on the one hand, flagship institutions, and on the other hand the old regional former teachers colleges," he said. "All across the country, there's going to be intensive competition for students and for a share of the state budget pie."
As recently as three or four years ago, according to surveys, UConn students gave high marks to the university's academic programs but were put off by the "dilapidation" of the campus. Responding to these complaints, and news that Connecticut had become a leader among states that shipped college-bound students out of state, a coalition of university administrators and influential state legislators came up with a proposal, called UConn 2000, to rebuild the state's system of higher education.
The Republican Governor, John G. Rowland, who had come into office pledging to go slow on state borrowing, hesitated at first. But the plan gained momentum thanks to the much heralded success of UConn's basketball teams. In 1995, the university's men's and women's basketball squads were both ranked No. 1 in the nation, as they are again this year, and Husky fever gripped the state. UConn applications soared, and when the athletes appeared before the state legislators, it was the latter who asked for autographs.
That, plus an understanding of the symbiotic relationship between higher education and economic development, finally loosened the purse strings in Hartford, and the remaking of UConn began to take shape.
The payoff came last fall when UConn's admissions office reported a 17 percent increase in freshman enrollment, to 3,225 in 1998-99 from 2,760 in 1997-98.
Cries of pain from private and state institutions have been muted because, at least so far, the supply of college-age students -- swollen by the children of baby boomers -- has been large enough to insure plenty of applicants to go around.
The only private college in the state that lost enrollment this year was Wesleyan University in Middletown, where admissions dipped 1.19 percent -- and that was a deliberate effort to cap the incoming freshman class in the interest of improving the faculty-student ratio. Almost all private institutions in the state have seen their enrollment grow by at least 5 percent over last year.
Still, many educators -- especially those associated with less well-known institutions like Quinnipiac College in Hamden, for example, and state institutions like Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven -- look ahead with apprehension.
Some expect to be forced to accept less-qualified students in the future and, accordingly, are developing survival strategies like "niche marketing" -- offering specialized academic programs that will draw students with specific career objectives.
The University of Bridgeport, a small private institution that since 1992 has been affiliated with the Unification Church headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, practices this strategy with considerable success. As far back as the 1960's, the university swelled its enrollment by recruiting foreign students, chiefly from India and Japan. That practice established a path for many Asian students, and today fully 40 percent of the student body comes from other countries.
But even the parade of foreign students has not been enough to satisfy the university's needs. "The expansion of UConn forced us to do more aggressive niche marketing," said Donna Marino, a spokeswoman for the university.
The result is that the University of Bridgeport has recently developed a number of academic specialties in the health sciences, including a school of dental hygiene and a college of chiropractic medicine, both of which have drawn well.
"Last year," Ms. Marino said, "we started the College of Naturopathic Medicine, a four-year program which trains physicians in natural remedies. It's doing nicely because there are only three other such schools in the country."
Such strategies may work for some small colleges, but could undermine the tradition of the small liberal arts college that turns out broadly educated students.
"Niche marketing is a little frightening," said Barbara-Jan Wilson, dean of admissions at Wesleyan. "I don't think 18-year-olds really know what they want to do with their lives. These niche programs may help students to get their first job, but leave them unprepared for a second or third."
The University of New Haven, another small private school, is also engaged in niche marketing -- offering career-focused programs in sports management, forensic science, and music and sound recording -- but the school's main strategy this year is to reach beyond the borders of Connecticut.
"Yes, we feel the pressure from UConn, and we expect it to be even stronger in four or five years," said Patrick Quinn, dean of admissions at the University of New Haven.
"That's why we have just decided to recruit on Long Island, throughout New England and elsewhere," he added. "About 70 percent of our students are from Connecticut, but we expect competition from UConn to bring that down to 60 percent in a few years. Consequently, we will have nine recruiters next year, and only two of them will work Connecticut."
In-state tuition, room and board at UConn come to about $10,875 a year while the state universities charge an average of $9,000. But even with that price advantage, the state university institutions fear the UConn juggernaut.
It is not merely competition from the flagship campus in Storrs that worries them, but the UConn satellites in Stamford, Groton, Hartford, Waterbury and Torrington.
Since 1981, four of the five satellites have had the authority to grant only one four-year bachelor's degree created for adult students. (Stamford has had more latitude.) Today, however, Stamford and the Avery Point branch in Groton occupy new, multimillion-dollar campuses, and UConn is pressing the State Department of Higher Education to adopt proposals that would remake the satellites as mini-UConns, squeezing the state university system.
As a result, the state university leaders are preparing to fight. Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic is striving to carve a niche for itself as a small public liberal arts college. Western Connecticut State University at Danbury hopes to benefit from its location in a population center.
"Don't count us out," said Bill Cibes, chancellor of the C.S.U. system and a former member of the State Legislature. "We got a lot less from the state than UConn, but we never said we wouldn't keep asking."

HEADLINE: Japanese Is Sorry He Called U.S. a Bully

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The Japanese Government backed away today from remarks by a Cabinet member suggesting that Japanese were unhappy with their "Peace Constitution" and that the United States bullied other countries.
The Cabinet member, Justice Minister Shozaburo Nakamura, apologized for his remarks and said he had not meant them. The comments were the latest in a long tradition of top Japanese officials making incendiary statements and then sheepishly retracting them after they become public. 
 "The so-called free-market economy cited by the U.S. is not real freedom," Mr. Nakamura told several hundred ministry officials at a New Year's party, Japanese newspapers reported. "It is a kind of freedom that lets loose atom bombs and missiles just when another country appears to gain an advantage."
Mr. Nakamura, 64, did not elaborate. But he specifically denounced the United States for threatening sanctions against countries accused of unfair trade practices.
To many Japanese the most striking comments by Mr. Nakamura were his suggestions that the Constitution was burdensome and should be changed to give Japan the right to use military force.
"We are struggling under a Constitution that prevents us from having an army and denies us the ability to revise" it, Mr. Nakamura was quoted by the daily Asahi Shimbun as saying. He added that the Constitution "was handed down by the Allied forces to the Japanese people" after World War II.
Hiromu Nonaka, the chief Cabinet secretary, said at a news conference today that Mr. Nakamura had made "very inappropriate remarks" and that the matter was serious. But he added that Mr. Nakamura had shown remorse, and the Government seems to regard the matter as closed.
Most historians agree with Mr. Nakamura's view that the Constitution was imposed on Japan by the United States in the aftermath of World War II, but legally Japan has every right to amend it. Such a move, though, would lead to protests around Asia among countries that Japan invaded during the war.
At a Cabinet meeting today, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi raised the matter of Mr. Nakamura's remarks and asked him to explain.
"The true meaning of these remarks I made on the occasion of the New Year ceremony at the Ministry of Justice was to explain various issues facing our country as well as the complicated international situation, in the context of emphasizing the need for judicial reform in Japan," Mr. Nakamura told the Cabinet. "I would like to apologize sincerely for the inappropriateness of my remarks, and I withdraw them."
Countries including China and South and North Korea get nervous whenever Japanese talk about changing their Constitution -- especially Article 9, which forever renounces "the threat or use of force." The article also says Japan will never maintain "land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential."
In fact, Japan manages to have Asia's most impressive armed forces and the world's third-largest military budget by deploying what it calls self-defense forces, which it says are not banned by Article 9.
It is difficult to gauge how widespread Mr. Nakamura's views are. Many conservatives in Japan say that such views are common but that politicians do not feel free to express them because they get in trouble whenever they say such things.
Particularly in rural areas, which are hugely overrepresented in Japan's political system, Mr. Nakamura's sentiments seem to resonate with many ordinary voters.
There is deep resentment at what is perceived as American bullying and insistence on ruthless market policies, and many people also feel that half a century after World War II, it is time for Japan to stand up and adopt a more muscular constitution and foreign policy.
There have been growing calls for revision of the Japanese Constitution, but the issue is so sensitive at home and around Asia that it is expected to be many years before any changes might actually be enacted.

HEADLINE: Changed Terrain on Cuba

 BODY:
When the White House endorses the idea of a visit to Havana by the Baltimore Orioles it is clear the ground is starting to shift in United States relations with Cuba. After four decades in which Washington successively tried to remove Fidel Castro by invasion, assassination plots and rigid economic isolation, signs are multiplying that the long American siege of Cuba is starting to wind down.
There are good reasons for this welcome change. With the end of the cold war, Cuba no longer serves as a base for potential Russian military operations against the United States. American business leaders have become increasingly interested in the profit potential of Cuba as it moves toward the post-Castro era. Conservatives have taken up the plea made by Pope John Paul II to ease the American economic embargo for humanitarian reasons. Finally, generational changes in the Cuban-American community have increased the influence of those interested in easing the privations of ordinary Cubans, rather than worsening them in hopes of sparking a popular revolt. 
 The pity is that the Clinton Administration has been hesitant about seizing this opportunity. The steps it has proposed, including the visit by the Orioles and a return engagement in America by the Cuban national baseball team, fall well short of the change in direction that is now politically sustainable in Washington.
Athletic and cultural exchanges, more charter flights, direct mail service and broader permission for Americans to send food and money to Cuban families are fine. But the White House rejected appeals from prominent Republicans to form a bipartisan national commission on Cuba policy that might have proposed phasing out the embargo and moving toward normal diplomatic relations.
America should be doing all it can to break down the cultural and intellectual isolation of Cuban society through increased tourism, business and cultural and sports contacts. It should be defending human rights by strengthening its diplomatic presence in Havana. Mr. Clinton must go beyond useful tinkering with an outdated policy. He must lead the way to a more promising approach based on deeper American engagement, not continued isolation.

HEADLINE: Engineering School Names Its Founding President

 BODY:
The nation's newest engineering school, which will admit its first class in fall 2001, has announced that its founding president will be Richard K. Miller, the engineering college dean at the University of Iowa.
The college, the F. W. Olin College of Engineering in Needham, Mass., is being built adjacent to Babson College, the business institution. It will charge little or no tuition because of its healthy founding endowment, and it will take a new approach to engineering education, combining the standard science and math courses with entrepreneurship, marketing and product research. The colleges plan to share support services and certain facilities. 
 Frustrated with the state of engineering education, the F. W. Olin Foundation financed the new school with $300 million. The foundation -- not related to the John S. Olin Foundation, which supports conservative causes -- was established in 1938 by Franklin W. Olin, who died in 1951 after having made a fortune in the 1930's with a diversified industrial company that makes chemicals, munitions, sporting goods and metals.
At Iowa, Dr. Miller conceived the nation's first technological entrepreneurship certificate program for engineers. "It is an exceptional privilege and challenge to help Olin College achieve its vision of preparing the next generation of gifted engineers for leadership in the new global economy," Dr. Miller said.
The college plans to have an initial enrollment of 50 to 100 students and to grow to some 600 students by 2006.
The announcement regarding the founding president was made by Lawrence W. Milas, president of the F. W. Olin Foundation, who said Dr. Miller "has a very special commitment to integrating entrepreneurship into technological studies as a major component of the Olin College program."
Dr. Miller's background combines business with theory. His specialties include earthquake engineering and spacecraft structural design. With a Ph.D. from the California Institute of Technology, he has taught civil, mechanical, environmental and aerospace engineering at the University of Southern California and the University of California and has been a consultant to the Aerospace Corporation, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Hughes Aircraft Company and the Astro Aerospace Corporation.
Dr. Miller said the combined approach of theory and practice improved learning.
"Undergraduate engineers will have their eyes opened to the economic potential of their work," he said. "When students see the importance of their work in the broad sense, it increases their excitement and motivation."

HEADLINE: Pricing at Issue As U.S. Finishes Microsoft Case

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR and JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The Government called its last witness in the Microsoft trial today after presenting 110 pages of his written testimony that amount to a summation of -- and economic justification for -- the Justice Department's sweeping antitrust suit against the software giant.
Much of the testimony by the witness, Franklin M. Fisher, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was a detailed review of major allegations in the Government's case. But he also sought to advance the case and strengthen the argument for strong sanctions against Microsoft with his analysis of Microsoft's pricing tactics. 
 Mr. Fisher asserts that Microsoft commits predatory pricing by giving away its Internet Explorer browser. The doctrine of predatory pricing -- defined as a monopolist selling goods below cost -- has been generally rejected by courts in recent years on the theory that it is difficult to prove both the practice and any resulting harm to consumers.
But Mr. Fisher argued that Microsoft decided to give away its browser software only to thwart the threat to its dominance posed by its main rivals in Internet software, the Netscape Communications Corporation, developer of the Navigator Web browser, and Sun Microsystems Inc., creator of the Java programming language.
Besides, he added, the tricky matter of trying to determine if a price is below some technical definition of its cost to produce does not apply because "Microsoft distributes its browser at a zero price," though it has spent more than $100 million a year since 1995 on browser development.
"Classifying Microsoft's pricing as predatory and anti-competitive," he stated, "does not require reaching the difficult questions that are usually faced in predatory pricing cases."
Mr. Fisher also provided a pre-emptive rebuttal to an M.I.T. colleague and former student, Richard Schmalensee, who will testify next, as Microsoft's expert witness on economics. In his own report to the court, which has not been released, Mr. Schmalensee argues that the price of Microsoft's industry-standard Windows operating system is too low for Windows to be legally classified as a monopoly. The comparatively low price of Windows -- less than 5 percent of the total cost of an average personal computer -- has been cited by many economists as inconsistent with the Government's allegation of an enduring monopoly.
But Mr. Fisher contends that such analysis means only that Microsoft's management is taking the long view of monopoly. "The proper conclusion from Schmalensee's argument cannot be that Microsoft lacks monopoly power," Mr. Fisher wrote in his testimony. "If any conclusion can be drawn, it would be that Microsoft is not maximizing its short-run profits."
Microsoft's product pricing, Mr. Fisher testified, should be viewed as part of a "broader campaign to eliminate Netscape's browser and Java as sources of potential competition to Microsoft's operating system monopoly -- a campaign characterized by actions by which Microsoft lost money in order to raise rivals' costs and exclude them from the market."
In court today, a Microsoft lawyer, Michael Lacovara, opened his cross-examination of Mr. Fisher with more than an hour of detailed challenges to the methodology Mr. Fisher used to determine the market shares of competing Web browsers. Mr. Lacovara also introduced criticisms of Mr. Fisher by judges in previous cases in which he appeared as an expert witness.
Mr. Fisher, an assertive, 64-year-old economist, has testified in dozens of antitrust cases in the computer industry -- though he was on the other side the last time, as the chief economic witness for the International Business Machines Corporation in its marathon antitrust confrontation with the Justice Department, a case the Government dropped in 1982 after 13 years.
Microsoft's lawyers say the company is being attacked by Mr. Fisher for being much the kind of company I.B.M. was when he was defending it. "Monopoly profits are earned through high prices and inferior products," Mr. Fisher wrote in a 1983 book about the I.B.M. case. "The notion that acts showing a pattern of lower prices and better products are the behavior of a monopolist is a confusion of the workings of competition with its opposite -- monopoly."
Microsoft said in a statement that "Professor Fisher's testimony would give readers of his 1983 book whiplash."
This morning, Microsoft ended the cross-examination of William H. Harris, the chief executive of Intuit Inc., which makes the industry-leading personal finance software, Quicken. The Government also played excerpts from the taped deposition in which William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, was questioned last August about the company's dealings with Intuit.
Though Mr. Gates professed no knowledge of any of the interactions with Intuit that are at issue in the case, the Government introduced E-mail messages in which employees had briefed him on the negotiations in exhaustive detail.
Shown one such message and asked if he had been informed of its subject, Mr. Gates said, "In the sense that one of the E-mails that may have come into my mailbox might have related to that, I don't doubt it."
Much of the questioning of Mr. Harris had centered on Intuit's interest in becoming an even larger player in Internet commerce. Microsoft's lead trial lawyer, John Warden, asked him about America Online's proposed purchase of Netscape, a deal that Microsoft argues is proof of healthy competition in the software industry.
"Doesn't that change the entire landscape of the Internet industry?" Mr. Warden asked.
"No, I don't believe so," Mr. Harris said. "There's a great deal of merger activity in this industry. Microsoft is rumored to be in discussions for acquisitions. I don't think the AOL-Netscape deal will be the last one we hear of."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stocks Lift Nasdaq to 3d Straight High
Propelled by a ravenous appetite among investors for technology shares, stocks soared, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to its third consecutive record and 11th since Thanksgiving. The Nasdaq jumped 43.22 points, or 2 percent, to 2,251.27.
The Dow Jones industrial average, helped by a strong performance from I.B.M., rose 126.92 points, or 1.4 percent, to 9,311.19. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.67 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,244.77, also a record. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as the yield of the 30-year issue rose to 5.20 percent. Page C7. 

No Red Alerts From Economists
The prevailing view at the three-day meeting of the American Economic Association was that high stock prices probably reflect the economy's actual strength and not a speculative bubble that could burst. C2.
 
AT&T Wins Contract With At Home
In a deal expected to be announced today, AT&T has won a long-term contract to provide At Home, the nation's largest provider of cable modem service, with 15,000 miles of high-speed fiber optic lines. The deal is an important move for AT&T, which wants to become a leading carrier of Internet data. C3.
 
Apple Introduces Colorful iMac's
Unveiling a colorful array of sleek machines that more closely resemble a pack of Life Savers than a new computer line, Apple Computer's interim chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, introduced the second generation of the company's popular iMac computers. C2.
 
Strong Sales by Chrysler and Ford
DaimlerChrysler and Ford beat analysts' December sales forecasts, benefiting from strong truck demand and heavy discounts as the industry's second-best United States sales year ended. Ford said sales of domestic car and light-truck sales rose 6.1 percent, while Chrysler sales rose 6.9 percent. C3.
 
Construction Spending Rises 0.9%
Construction spending rose in November for the sixth consecutive month, led by continuing gains in single-family home building and a jump in spending on public works, the Commerce Department said. Construction spending rose nine-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $677.8 billion. C18.
 
Too Early for Pocket of Euros
Some travelers have been confused about the debut of Europe's single currency, not realizing that euro notes and coins will not go on sale before Jan. 1, 2002. The euro exchange rate, however, can be used for traveler's check payments, credit card purchases and other noncash transactions. While it is too early to know how avidly Americans will take to euro-traveler's checks, which are available worldwide, they are not likely to set any sales records, mainly because they are readily accepted for now only in Europe's bigger shops, restaurants and hotels. Business Travel. C5.
 
Hewlett-Packard Forms Ink-Jet Unit
Hewlett-Packard said that it had formed a subsidiary, Apollo Consumer Products, to enter the market for computer ink-jet printers that cost less than $100. C18.
 
Tenneco Warns of Lower Earnings
Tenneco expects to report fourth-quarter earnings "substantially below" consensus estimates, primarily because of weak performance in its automotive business. C18.
 
U.S. Considers Selling Ginnie Mae
The Clinton Administration is considering a plan to raise $2.5 billion by selling the Government National Mortgage Association. C2.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
'Little Push' Helps Family to Begin to Right Itself

BYLINE: By ADAM GERSHENSON 

 BODY:
Edward Hillman apologizes when visitors arrive at his family's basement apartment in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.
He says he is sorry that there is no doorbell, that the place is so small, and that guests have to duck on their way down the stairs. Yet, once he settles into his living room, with his wife, Ines, on the couch, and his 2-year-old son, Edward Jr., seated on his lap, Mr. Hillman starts to see things from a different perspective. 
 "It's not the lap of luxury, but it's a home, and we're together, and that's the most important thing," he said on a recent Sunday afternoon.
Mr. Hillman might have neither a home nor an intact family were it not for the help he recently received from the Community Service Society of New York, one of seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
When Mr. Hillman, 32, arrived at the charity's offices on Park Avenue South in August, he was visibly distressed. His troubles had begun in April, when, after months of working two full-time jobs, he collapsed from exhaustion. It took him weeks to recover, and by the time he did, he had lost his day job with a shipping company and his night job at 7-Eleven.
Ines found work as a cashier at a supermarket. The $6 an hour she earned was not enough to cover the $800 rent on their two-bedroom apartment in Jackson Heights where they lived at the time, but she was able to put food on the table.
Mr. Hillman said he had felt too ashamed to eat it. He felt he was draining resources that should have gone to his wife and child. Mr. Hillman tried to find a new job -- without success -- and by August became convinced that he was nothing but a burden to his family. Without warning, he left home.
He spent a few days walking through Manhattan, applying for jobs. Initially he spent his nights curled up in the shadows of the United Nations building on 42d Street, until he found short-term shelter in a church-run mission on the Lower East Side. Still unable to find work, Mr. Hillman was desperate, knowing that Ines needed money for rent. Finally, he went to the Community Service Society.
Ivette Gongon, a case manager at the agency, was determined to help.
"He was so distraught," she said, "and he kept talking about his wife and kid, and I really believed that if he got a little push, good things would happen to him."
Paying the Hillmans' back rent would have just postponed their problems, Ms. Gongon said. A steady income was essential. She suggested places where Mr. Hillman could find work, and assured him that if he found a job, the agency would help him with his financial problems.
With his spirits lifted, Mr. Hillman returned to the job search, and within days he had again taken two full-time jobs. He stocked sporting goods at a ski shop in midtown Manhattan in the daytime, and worked nights at a shipping company in Kearny, N.J.
When Mr. Hillman received his first pay check, he went to the supermarket where Ines worked and explained his absence. Ines said that he had behaved foolishly, but she loved him, and their son missed him badly. She took him back.
Yet there was little time for a romantic reunion. Ines and Edward Jr. were scheduled to be evicted in two weeks. Mr. Hillman quickly found the basement apartment on 121st Street in Richmond Hill. Together, Edward and Ines had the first month's $500 rent, but they had no money for a security deposit. The Community Service Society, which relies on the Neediest Cases Fund to provide direct services, supplied $500 to help the Hillmans start over in a place they could afford.
Last month, Mr. Hillman helped Ines get a job at the ski shop where he works, and then quit his night job in New Jersey so that he would not exhaust himself again.
The Hillmans' apartment is small, but they are comfortable there, and they pay all their bills in advance. On the rare occasions when Mr. Hillman has a little extra money left over at the end of the month, he takes Edward Jr. to McDonald's, or buys lilies and roses for Ines.
"I have to admit, I like it," Ines said. "It makes the house smell nice."
