HEADLINE: Gun Marketing Is Issue in Trial Against Makers

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
On the night of July 27, 1993, Njuzi Ray, 17, was fatally shot in a dispute on a Brooklyn street. A suspect was later acquitted, and nobody else has been arrested for the killing.
Normally a case like this would have long disappeared from public awareness, lost in the city's crime statistics and recalled only by the victim's family and friends. But the slaying in Bedford-Stuyvesant is once more in the spotlight, as a subject of a potentially precedent-setting lawsuit against the gun industry. Opening arguments in the suit could begin today in United States District Court in Brooklyn. 
 In the case, Mr. Ray's mother, Freddie Hamilton, and the relatives of five other people killed in separate shootings in New York City and Yonkers in recent years are seeking to hold the gun industry collectively liable for the deaths, just as many recent suits have attacked the tobacco industry as responsible for deaths and illnesses from smoking.
At the heart of the claims is the argument that more than 30 gun manufacturers and distributors have marketed and distributed handguns so negligently that dealers in states with lax gun control laws are oversupplied with them. Many of those guns, in turn, end up in the hands of criminals and youths in states with tough gun laws, like New York, the suit contends.
The suit is considered potentially precedent-setting because it invokes the theory of "negligent distribution" of guns, rather than charging liability on the basis of the product's inherent harmfulness, said David Leebron, the dean of Columbia University Law School and an expert in tort litigation.
Or, as one supporter of the suit boiled down the argument, the defendants -- including Smith & Wesson, the Colt's Manufacturing Company and Beretta USA -- "knew or should have known that they were oversupplying the legitimate market, thereby creating a pool of weapons available for the illegitimate market."
That supporter, Joshua Horwitz, executive director of the Washington-based Educational Fund to End Handgun Violence, said past suits seeking to hold gun makers and distributors liable for intentional killings often focused on narrower issues, like whether a single gun was marketed in a way that made its producer or distributor culpable. These suits have been repeatedly defeated in court.
The trial will be closely watched not only by the gun industry and gun control advocates, but by lawyers for municipalities across the nation.
The City of Chicago, for instance, recently filed suit against nearly 40 gun manufacturers, distributors and retailers, accusing the industry of flooding suburban stores with many more guns than the lawful market could absorb, allowing many of the weapons to supply the illegal market in Chicago, where gun control laws are among the country's strictest.
Philadelphia, Boston, Miami, San Francisco and Los Angeles are among cities considering similar suits. And New Orleans has filed suit on different grounds, contending that gun makers failed to include enough safety devices in their weapons.
Dean Leebron of Columbia said, however, that the theory of negligent distribution "is a difficult theory to prevail." While he said the argument was not without legal foundation, the applicable laws in the case do not "particularly favor collectively imposing liability or imposing special duties on manufacturers regarding the distribution of the product."
And one of the defense lawyers in the suit, Anne G. Kimball, contended in an interview on Monday that there was no evidence of any illegal or careless sale by any manufacturer or distributor in any of the shootings, and that the plaintiffs had "no facts that connect" any of the gun makers or distributors to any of the seven crimes cited in the suit. They include the six homicides and a case in which a young man survived a brain wound in a Queens shooting. He, like the relatives of the murder victims, is seeking to hold the firearms industry collectively responsible.
But Mr. Horwitz said he was optimistic, contending the argument about the gun industry's marketing practices was easy to grasp and likely to persuade the average juror.
The Brooklyn suit was filed in 1995. A year later, Judge Jack B. Weinstein rejected the gun companies' motions to dismiss it, saying it was possible that the plaintiffs would "be able to show that a substantial cause for the killings that are at the heart of this suit is the operation of a large-scale underground market" stemming from a handgun sales system that is "without adequate concern over the channels of distribution and possession."
Among the evidence that Elisa Barnes and the three other plaintiffs' lawyers are expected to offer are economic consultants' statistics that show, the consultants say, that handgun sales in states with weak gun control laws -- like Virginia, Florida, Georgia and North and South Carolina -- "are higher than can be explained by legitimate demand, suggesting that a substantial proportion of sales in such states are not for legitimate purposes but for resale to the criminal market."
But Richard Feldman, executive director of the American Shooting Sports Council, an Atlanta-based gun industry group, said in an interview that to hold makers, distributors or sellers liable "for the criminal misuse of a lawfully sold product is to turn our whole tort system upside down."
Ms. Barnes said the suit did not state a figure for damages in the trial, in which about a dozen lawyers are representing the gun companies.Jury selection began Monday.
Meanwhile, the woman who helped start it all, Freddie Hamilton, said on Monday that she was "apprehensive but optimistic" as she awaited the opening arguments and testimony.
Speaking by telephone from the office of a Brooklyn child welfare group where she is the executive director, she said the case was "about the number of young people who get murdered by guns." Her goal, she said, was "keeping guns out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them."

HEADLINE: Texaco Is Said To Set Payment Over Sex Bias

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Texaco Inc. has agreed to pay $3.1 million to 186 women who were found by the Labor Department to have been systematically underpaid relative to their male counterparts, people involved in the case said today.
The agreement is the largest under a Labor Department affirmative action compliance program. It was signed by Labor Department officials today and is scheduled to be made public on Wednesday. The agreement follows several years of efforts by Texaco to deal with separate allegations of racial discrimination made by minority employees. 
 The agreement covers women who were employed between 1993 and 1996 in managerial and support jobs at the petroleum company's headquarters in White Plains and in offices in seven other cities across the country.
It is based on an examination begun in May 1995 as part of a program under which the Labor Department audits employment practices of companies that do business with the Federal Government. Documents outlining the settlement stated that it was a result of a "joint effort" by Texaco and the Labor Department and that it "does not constitute an admission by Texaco" of violations of any laws or regulations.
In draft documents describing the settlement, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said the review "found that women in mid-level positions throughout the company were underpaid as a matter of course for years."
The 186 women found to have been underpaid represent 2 percent of the 9,000 women employed by Texaco in the United States. Texaco's total work force in the United States is 19,800.
Kelly McAndrew, a spokesman for Texaco, said the company "did work cooperatively with the Labor Department," and that Texaco was pleased that the agreement cited no violations of employment laws or regulations.
The agreement calls for $2.2 million in back pay to be distributed to the 186 women, in amounts from $1,500 to $51,000, depending on salary, length of employment and other factors. A further $816,000 has already been distributed as salary increases to bring the paychecks of the women into line with those of male counterparts, and a further $84,000 has been set aside to deal with any future claims of salary inequity.
The $3.1 million package is the largest resulting from an audit by the Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs, which monitors affirmative action programs in companies that do business with the Government. Last spring, the Corestates Financial Corporation agreed to pay $1.5 million in back pay and salary adjustments after the Labor Department found a pattern of inequities affecting women and minority employees.
Those agreements, though, are dwarfed by settlements reached in civil lawsuits and in other Government actions against employers. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission agreed to a $81.5 million discrimination settlement in 1997 with Publix Super Markets Inc. And Texaco itself settled a racial discrimination lawsuit in late 1996 for $176 million.
The racial discrimination allegations led Texaco to adopt a program aimed at promoting equality, diversity and tolerance within the company. Last month it hired Deval L. Patrick, a former head of the Justice Department's civil rights division, as its general counsel, making him the company's highest-ranking black official.
People involved in the Labor Department investigation said that it had no connection to the racial discrimination allegations, which drew wide attention two years ago after a former Texaco official provided lawyers with tapes of Texaco executives speaking contemptuously of minority employees and planning the destruction of documents demanded in the discrimination lawsuit.
The agreement signed today by the Labor Department requires Texaco to analyze the compensation of its entire salaried work force every year, and in particular to look at the salaries paid to men and women in the midlevel pay grades covered by the settlement.
The company also agreed to take steps to expand opportunities for women and to submit a report within 45 days discussing what it has done to bring more women into upper-level managerial jobs and to recruit more women.
Under the agreement, Texaco has 30 days to notify the 186 eligible women that they are owed money. The Government audit covered Texaco headquarters in White Plains and offices in Dallas; Houston; Denver; New Orleans; San Antonio; Belair, Tex., and Beacon, N.Y.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Neighborhood Is the Source Of Real Capital

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ON Saturdays, the checkout line at the Elmhurst branch of the Queens Public Library looks like a rush-hour token booth crowd. Nearby every seat is taken at the tables, where Asian and Latino readers pass the time. A few people browse through the racks of compact disks in Korean, Spanish and Chinese.
Among the new books displayed by the entrance was Michael Walsh's "As Time Goes By: A Novel of Casablanca." Makes sense, since this neighborhood -- where there are more new arrivals browsing through the shelves than on them -- has a mix of nationalities that would rival Rick's Cafe Americain. Since 1960, Elmhurst and Corona have undergone such a transformation from being nearly all-white to being Latino, Asian, white and black, that some demographers call them the world's most ethnically diverse community. 
"As time goes by" is a fitting sentiment for Roger Sanjek, an anthropologist who spent 13 years in Elmhurst and Corona, studying their ethnic makeover and the lessons they have for the rest of the country where immigration will have similar effects. In his book "The Future of Us All" (Cornell University Press, 1998), Mr. San jek says that residents of these communities bridged ethnic divides to work for neighborhood improvement through community boards, neighborhood groups and business associations. In doing so, they reaffirmed his belief that nurturing a neighborhood's social and economic life is more vital to the city's future than giving billions of dollars in tax and real estate breaks to huge companies that hold city officials hostage with threats to move out of state.
"People here are making changes in a daily and ongoing way," Mr. Sanjek, a professor of anthropology at Queens College, said on a recent walk through Elmhurst and Corona. "They meet each other in day-to-day problem-solving situations, they go to school, they go to the library. In this city the power of the neighborhood, in schools and on shopping strips, is enormous and has staying power. Yet the city's policies seem to work against them."
Consider the recent deal to keep the New York Stock Exchange from becoming the Jersey City Stock Exchange. (There ought to be a law: If they leave town, they should leave the name, too.) City and state officials ponied up $900 million in cash, tax breaks and subsidies to seal the deal, which has the governments buying an entire city block, where they will build a new trading complex. Supporters of the deal said the new digs would give the currently-cramped exchange plenty of room in which to stay competitive and preserve lower Manhattan as the world's financial capital.
THAT depends on your perspective, which, if it happens to be from Queens, might make you wonder. Cramped space? Just take a stroll through the bustling shopping strips in Elmhurst and Corona, where shopkeepers and customers would like to see an end to their subsidizing local government by way of constant parking and sanitation fines. Staying competitive? Tell that to the mom-and-pop merchants -- of all nationalities -- who banded together to defeat city-sponsored zoning changes that would have allowed megastores in their neighborhoods. That's why Mr. Sanjek dismisses "Capital of the World" justifications for big-bucks corporate retention deals as taking money that could be better used in neighborhoods.
" 'Capital of the world' ideology is harmful if we're talking about the economic future of the city," he said, "because the transfer of technology has made it possible to be anywhere to do business that used to be in lower Manhattan alone. We are bribing people to stay, but the result is seen in library cuts, schools that are not built, parks that are not maintained and a neighborhood that becomes a place that nobody wants to live in."
Then again, just looking at the Elmhurst library and seeing how people came from all over to this swath of Queens, the title of "Capital of the World" might be right for this neighborhood. Mr. Sanjek's field work at civic meetings, community rallies and everyday interactions in schools and stores proved to him that at their best, residents of Elmhurst and Corona have a sense of the world that makes them as cosmopolitan as any high-society globe-trotter.
"They live in a neighborhood where their neighbor is Chinese or Dominican and deal with each other as individuals," he said. "They see other people as more than just bearers of exotic cultures."
They see them as neighbors. It's a fundamental thing that applies as time goes by.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HAYES CORP., MODEM INNOVATOR, IS GOING OUT OF BUSINESS

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Hayes Corporation, a company that once dominated the personal-computer modem business, is shutting down after failing to find a buyer. About 250 employees were laid off on Monday, leaving only a handful. The company sought protection from creditors in October, in its second trip to bankruptcy court in the 1990's, and attempted a reorganization under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code as it talked to potential buyers. But its primary lender notified the company that it would not continue efforts to keep Hayes alive. Hayes owes some $42 million to creditors that include Nationscredit, Lucent Technologies and Rockwell Semiconductor Systems.

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Players Vote Today on Endorsing Their Negotiators

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
In the most chaotic day of the six-month-old lockout, the National Basketball Association players' union was trying to arrange an almost impossible travel schedule for its 400-plus members while trying to prevent the group from falling into disarray on the eve of the threatened cancellation of the season.
Nearly 250 players are expected to vote in Manhattan today whether to endorse their negotiating committee's recommendation to reject the owners' latest proposal. 
 That decision could either seal the fate of the season or spur last-minute negotiations with Commissioner David Stern and the league.
Stern and his negotiating team have said that if no agreement is reached by tomorrow they would recommend to the league's board of governors that the season be canceled.
Some players arrived in Manhattan last night, unsure of how the vote would be taken. Only players who make it to Manhattan will be allowed to vote, and the ballot will not directly address the owners' offer. Instead, players will be asked whether they support the union negotiating committee's recommendation to reject that proposal.
Repudiating the committee would be tantamount to acceptance of the league's proposal.
"We're going to put it to the test," Patrick Ewing, the union president, said, "but we're going to make sure they stand by their negotiating committee."
The union will decide this morning how to conduct the vote. Union officials last night appeared to be leaning toward an open vote rather than a secret ballot.
Isiah Thomas, the former union president who has been openly critical of Billy Hunter, the executive director of the union, and its negotiating committee, was catching a flight to New York last night.
Thomas, the former All-Star guard who was a part owner of the Toronto Raptors and is now an NBC analyst, said he had been contacted by 30 to 40 players yesterday about taking a stronger role in the labor dispute. "I will do whatever they want me to do," he said. "My role will just be to help some of the players really understand the process and understand the deal."
Thomas implied he would assume an active role if the union's negotiating committee was repudiated.
League officials said they had heard reports that a number of players had trouble contacting the union regarding the time and place of the vote and that field representatives for the union had called designated players and told them that the specific purpose of the vote was to endorse the negotiating committee.
Jeffrey Mishkin, the league's chief legal officer, said, "If that's what's going on, then this so-called vote sounds more like a bargaining tactic rather than a striking example of a union democracy."
A union official, speaking on condition of anonymity, responded: "The N.B.A. has openly solicited for a vote and now it's a bargaining tactic? This is a simple case of, you better be careful of what you ask for because you might just get it."
Though the movement for accepting the owners' offer continues to grow, both sides were expecting the union to reaffirm its solidarity before requesting a last round of bargaining with Stern and the owners' negotiating committee.
Stern has said the deadline he imposed is firm but did not discount the possibility of a last-minute negotiating session if the union backed on his final offer. Yet the pervading sentiment among many union officials was that regardless of the deadline, a deal could be reached in the next two days. Stern characterized today's union meeting as a "pep rally."
One way that could unfold is if the union relents on its desire to receive 57 percent of revenue in the last year of a six-year agreement and gives in to the owners on a new rookie system. In exchange, the union will most likely want several exceptions to the salary cap that deal with player flexibility and free agency.
The two sides are moving to within striking distance on minimum salaries and capping the high-end players, though they remain nearly $3 million apart on the highest-salaried contracts.
Of course, there are issues other than economics that remain outstanding. The agent Keith Glass said the league's image had been severely hurt in the players' eyes. "If they're successful in ramming this deal down the throats of the players, no one wins," Glass said. "Let's face it, the damage has been done. The N.B.A. is no longer fantastic. Stern's attitude has alienated most of the players. Whether they vote yes or not, that's not going to quell that animosity. We're not the feel-good kind of league anymore. Those days are over."
Both sides will have their full negotiating committees in town by tonight, and the league's board of governors has scheduled a meeting for 11 A.M. Thursday.
Thomas said: "The players need to take control of their own union again and remember that all the people who supposedly are making their decisions were hired by them to work for them. I hope they can resolve this inside their union, without having to go outside. However, if they are willing to go outside, I would be more than willing to help."
 The union's negotiating committee met yesterday afternoon and then began telephoning as many players as possible with the intention of swaying them toward coming to Manhattan. But several agents wondered whether a representative body of players would be voting.
For example, Kebu Stewart, a second-round pick of the Philadelphia 76ers last season who made the minimum salary, was having a hard time finding a round-trip ticket from Los Angeles for under $1,800, according to his agent, Eric Rudolph.
"I'm not saying he would vote for the deal, but he is an example of somebody who hasn't gotten a paycheck in a long time," Rudolph said. "Right now, he's in California. His voice won't be heard from because he can't come."
The union is expected to hold the vote this afternoon after a series of slide presentations of both the union's and the league's final offer.
P. J. Brown of the Miami Heat said: "If you're going to speak out, just do it because this is the time. It's not the time to hold back. I do have a couple of things on my mind. I'm not going to be intimidated by anyone."
Stern has been pushing for a player vote, and the union finally agreed to one after the owners' negotiating committee voted, 9-0, Monday to reject the union's latest offer.
One member of the union's negotiating committee, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: "It's a gamble, but it's time to take the pulse of our guys. Now we'll see how all those rah-rah types on the conference calls will respond. I just hope they're coming to New York to vote for a deal, not whether or not they need a paycheck today."
 Jayson Williams said he was leaning toward voting yes on the proposal by the owners. "I think the meeting is going to be interesting," he said. "I have gotten about 40 calls over the last two days from guys who all feel the way I feel. Billy Hunter has been good, and so we all need to listen to what he says and the committee says. But we should vote."
Asked how the vote would come out, he said: "If it's a secret vote, I think it will be close. And if it's an open vote, then the union will win. It's hard to say without knowing how the vote will be done."
Keith Askins of the Miami Heat told The Miami Herald: "I'm upset because you're asking guys to come from around the country on a day's notice when there are quicker means to do this. I think the union negotiating committee knows a lot of players won't be able to make it."
Askins is already on the record as favoring the owners' proposal and was one of the first to come out and ask for a vote on the proposal.

HEADLINE: In Euro's Leap, Some Look for Net

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The future of the euro, the new currency for most of Europe, may require a "great leap of faith" (Op-Ed, Jan. 4), but a more compelling reason for concern is the fact that two former chairmen of the Council of Economic Advisers cannot agree on the precise risks created by the new currency. 
 Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the first Clinton Administration, worries that by focusing on inflation to the exclusion of growth when the two are perceived to be in conflict, and by insulating the European Central Bank from national leaders, Europe is placing itself in peril of a social crisis triggered by what would otherwise be a small recession.
On the other hand, Martin Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration, worries that by replacing the discipline of the German central bank with a bank that is equally responsible to each country and that is without any power to prevent violations of the euro's charter by national legislatures, Europe is heading down the path of higher inflation. This presumably could lead to lower growth and political turmoil.
The stakes are high. Weakness in the European financial system would place far greater strains on the American economy than recent problems in Asia.
 
MARTIN SPERLING
Solana Beach, Calif., Jan. 4, 1999

HEADLINE: To Vestige of Black Farmers, Bias Settlement Is Too Late

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: GREENSBORO, Ga., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Willie E. Adams, a fourth-generation black farmer, is raising 48,000 chickens here on the same land that his ancestors farmed, some 85 miles east of Atlanta. But with $150,000 in debt, $90,000 to the Federal Government and $60,000 to banks, Mr. Adams says he is "just keeping my head above water."
By Mr. Adams's reckoning, he could be raising more than twice as many chickens if only the United States Department of Agriculture had been more fair and more efficient in processing the farm loans he has applied for over the last 22 years. Three of his five chicken houses, each longer than a football field, have stood empty for more than three years because Mr. Adams cannot afford -- even with commercial loans that also carry a higher interest rate -- to modernize his feeding and watering equipment to meet the standards of poultry processors. 
 Like thousands of other black farmers, Mr. Adams maintains that he has not gotten a fair shake from Federal farm loan officials because of his race. Today, the Federal Government all but conceded as much when the Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman, announced the settlement of a class-action discrimination lawsuit that black farmers filed against the Government in 1997.
Though pleased by the public acknowledgment of their plight, many black farmers said today that the settlement would do little to reverse the stunning decline of independent black farming, a livelihood that has carried a special nobility ever since freed slaves were granted 40 acres and a mule.
The relief, which makes farmers who claim they were discriminated against eligible to receive $50,000 tax-free and to be forgiven their Federal debt, is too little, they said, and it has come too late, particularly for those who have lost their farms to foreclosure or whose children soured years ago on a life of farming. The settlement, granted preliminary approval this afternoon by a Federal judge in Washington, does not free the farmers of the burden of commercial debt they took on when they could not get Government money, nor does it punish the mostly white county agents who for decades denied them loans, they said.
In 1920, 14 percent of the nation's farms were owned by blacks, according to Federal statistics. By 1992, the number had dwindled to 18,816, or 1 percent, and now, hobbled by age, racism and corporate competition, even fewer blacks till the land.
Already, the black young people raised on farms have fled for other professions in other places, and nothing may lure them back.
"I want to see my children and other young blacks be able to have pride in agriculture," said Mr. Adams, while touring the rank-smelling sheds where his roosters are fattened before being processed into chicken nuggets. "But with the way the U.S.D.A. treated us, young people don't see any future in farming."
Mr. Adams, 48, and several other black farmers said today that the settlement did nothing to address the paradox created by the Government's discriminatory practices. When denied Federal loans or granted loans insufficient to meet their needs, black farmers often went to banks. But with the higher rates, the farmers' debt accumulated quickly.
Though the settlement will eliminate the farmers' debt to the Government, which typically ranges from $75,000 to $150,000, the $50,000 payments may not be enough to pay off or restructure the bank loans.
Black farmers have the option of forgoing the $50,000 and negotiating a higher settlement through an arbitrator, but that requires extensive documentation of discrimination.
"As far as the settlement, it's not going to be of help to me," said Charles Dennard, 47, a farmer in Pineview, Ga.
Mr. Dennard said that $72,000 of his $160,000 in debt is with the Government and presumably would be forgiven. That still leaves him with $88,000 in debt to private lenders. Had he been granted the Government loans he sought in the first place, he would never have applied for the commercial money, he said.
"They're on my neck at the bank to foreclose," Mr. Dennard added.
John DeCourdreaux, a blueberry farmer from South Haven, Mich., said he, too, was not satisfied with the settlement. "To me," Mr. DeCourdreaux said, "this is a pat on the back from the Agriculture Department, saying: 'We acknowledge what we did. Here's enough money to get out of our hair.' "
Mr. DeCourdreaux said $50,000 may appease those who are no longer farming. "But for people like me who are still currently farming and have all the documentation, $50,000 isn't going to buy me a good truck."
Gary R. Grant, 55, a farmer in Tillery, N.C., said it was unjust that the settlement did not include punishment for the Federal officials who denied loans to black farmers.
"These folks took our homes, took our credit rating," said Mr. Grant, president of the Black Farmers and Agriculturists Association. "These folks are not even getting slapped on the wrist as far as we know."
In most of the documented cases, racial discrimination came not from the Department of Agriculture bureaucracy in Washington, but from committees of local agents who administer Federal farm programs in their counties. These county committees, known as Farm Service Agencies, are usually elected and are usually all-white in the South, where most black farmers live.
In hundreds of complaints filed in Washington over the last 15 years, black farmers say they were routinely denied the aid granted almost automatically to whites. Sometimes, they say, Federal officials demanded evidence of agricultural and financial expertise that was not required of white farmers, or delayed processing loans until after the planting season had arrived. Other times, they contend, their applications were rejected with overt racial rebuffs.
The Farm Service Agencies lost much of their say over who is eligible for Agriculture Department aid in December 1997, when Mr. Glickman, seeking to repair the department's civil rights record, announced that decisions on loans would be made in Washington. He also required state executive directors of the department to review half of all rejected loan applications to minorities and women to insure that denials were for legitimate reasons.
At a news conference in Washington on Monday night announcing the settlement, Mr. Glickman said that he was embarrassed by the discrimination and that the department had a great deal of repair work to do. Though the settlement does not admit or deny any discrimination, he called civil rights the most important single issue facing the department.
He said the agreement "will close a painful chapter in U.S.D.A.'s history and open a more constructive front in our efforts to see this department emerge as the Federal civil rights leader in the 21st century."
Civil service rules make it difficult to discipline current employees who participated in the discrimination or oversaw it, Mr. Glickman said.
He said that the final cost to the Government would not be known until it was clear how many farmers would file claims, but that the 1,000 farmers now part of the class-action lawsuit were likely to receive about $200 million in payments and debt forgiveness. If, as expected, another 1,000 to 2,000 farmers file claims, that amount could double or triple.
Even those black farmers who were disappointed in the financial package praised the Government for seeking to redress past wrongs.
"I think it takes a lot of courage for the Government and Secretary Glickman to acknowledge that people have been treated poorly, and they should be commended for that," said Gary Cornelious, a vegetable grower in Boone, Iowa. "The act of discrimination is a devastating thing for any farm family to have to go through, and it can literally wipe a farm out."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about the Agriculture Department's settlement of a discrimination lawsuit filed by black farmers in 1997 referred incorrectly to bonuses offered some black farmers after the Civil War. Although Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman set aside thousands of acres of confiscated and abandoned land in Georgia and South Carolina for settlement by blacks, with each family also receiving an Army mule to work it -- a program known as "40 acres and a mule" -- the offer was canceled by President Andrew Johnson, who returned the property to its prewar owners.

HEADLINE: How Much Military?

BYLINE: By Michael O'Hanlon; Michael O'Hanlon, a fellow at the Brookings Institution, is the author of "How to Be a Cheap Hawk."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
C ritics have likened today's United States military to the post-Vietnam "hollow force" of the 1970's. They are wrong, though they are right to point out that the military is in worse shape than it was a few years ago.
A decline in new recruits is a problem, along with cuts in training for some units and aging equipment. But the answer is not a drastically inflated Pentagon budget. In fact, President Clinton's proposed small increase for the year 2000 -- some $4 billion -- and slightly greater amounts in the years after for mundane things like spare parts should be enough to shore up military readiness. 
 Why, then, is he calling for an additional $110 billion in increases over the next six years? To please defense hawks. But it is really Mr. Clinton's successor who will be stuck with the bill -- and with a Pentagon expecting to have the money to buy all the gold-plated weapons still on its wish lists.
True, in recent years the Pentagon has spent about $45 billion a year on procurement, half what it averaged in the 1980's (adjusted for inflation). Just to keep the force reliable and safe, that figure needs to climb by more than $10 billion. However, existing Pentagon plans for new weapons will cost at least $70 billion a year in the next decade. That spending cannot possibly be offset by base closings and personnel cuts.
Congress, which is holding hearings on the matter, should urge a more sensible approach to updating the armed forces. We are already far ahead of our foes, real and potential, without stockpiling next-generation weapons like F-22 Raptor fighters, Comanche helicopters, Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft and joint-strike fighters. Instead we should adopt a "high-low" technology mix, purchasing modest numbers of advanced weapons while also buying or refitting more of the kinds of weapons we already have.
The Pentagon's plan to modernize the force through better munitions, communications systems and reconnaissance systems like satellites and unmanned aircraft makes sense, as those improvements can be made economically.
Today's armed forces may be showing signs of strain, but their equipment remains safe and effective. They are suffering historically low casualty rates on test and training ranges and are still getting the job done when called to respond to crises in the Persian Gulf or the Balkans. Without a more realistic strategy for replacing and upgrading aging military equipment in the next decade, these accomplishments could be put in jeopardy.

HEADLINE: Arts Council Chairman Resigns

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
Earle I. Mack, an arts patron and former real estate developer who helped restore financial aid to the arts in New York State to a level not seen in nearly a decade, has resigned as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts.
Mr. Mack, who was appointed in 1996 by Gov. George E. Pataki, said he would remain on the board but would resign as chairman as of Monday to spend more time with his family. 
 In his resignation letter to Governor Pataki, Mr. Mack said that the council had met virtually all of the goals that Mr. Pataki had envisioned. He said that before Mr. Pataki's first inauguration, the state arts budget had been cut by 56 percent over a five-year span, morale was low and the arts infrastructure at the council and around the state was eroding.
When Mr. Mack became chairman the council's budget stood at $31.6 million, after a series of cuts during the state's economic downturn; it now stands at $46 million. The increase "has not only resurrected the nonprofit cultural sector in New York State," said Mr. Mack's letter, dated Monday, "but also the council as well."
The council distributes grants ranging from hundreds to many thousands of dollars to more than 1,000 museums, cultural heritage groups and performing arts companies around the state. From April 1995 through December 1998, it gave $138.5 million for 9,000 grants to 1,300 arts organizations.
Norma P. Munn, the chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, a citywide advocacy group, said the general consensus among her colleagues was that Mr. Mack had served the council and the arts world well. A deliberately low-key man, he won a reputation for being energetic and finding common ground with upstate and city legislators for financing and programs, despite the initial suspicion that his appointment was a favor for financial support of Mr. Pataki's campaign.
"I found Earle to be extremely hard-working," Ms. Munn said. "I found him sophisticated about the political atmosphere in Albany. One would expect him to have connections to the Governor, but he had connections to the legislators."
"I'm devastated he's leaving," said Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts, an advocacy group in New York City. "He understood the bottom-line need was for a restoration of funding. In three years he's accomplished an incredible amount."
Because of his political connections, Mr. Mack assumed his post under the skeptical eye of many artists and arts organizations, who were well aware of his role in organizing a major fund-raiser for and making a $25,000 contribution to Mr. Pataki's 1994 campaign and top contributions to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's 1993 campaign. Although he served on the board of the City Ballet and Dance Theater of Harlem, Mr. Mack was better known as a senior partner of a family-controlled real estate and investment business, the Mack Company of Rochelle Park, N.J., and for serving on the board of the state's Racing Association.
He also became chairman of the council at a time of intense frustration with Republican cuts to the arts at the national and local level. He had the additional challenge of succeeding the immensely popular Kitty Carlisle Hart, who served on the arts council through five administrations and was described once in The New York Times as "the state's premier campaigner for rural string quartets and inner-city dance troupes."
During Mr. Mack's tenure, though, Mrs. Hart called his budget increase victories "nothing short of miraculous." He also won points for organizing the first state arts technology conference; putting together three studies on the economic impact of the arts; establishing an arts partnership program in the public school system and helping to make available a license plate to salute and promote the arts in New York State. The $39.50 "State of the Arts" plate includes a $15 contribution to the council.

HEADLINE: Baltimore's Push on Crime Creates Backlog of Cases

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Jan. 6

 BODY:
More aggressive efforts by the Baltimore police to reduce the rate of homicides and other serious crime in the city has created such a backlog of cases that a circuit judge has dismissed first-degree murder charges against four men who had been awaiting trial for almost three years.
The Deputy State's Attorney for the city, Haven H. Kodeck, said today that his office intended to appeal the decision, by Judge Roger W. Brown. But Mr. Kodeck also said Judge Brown's ruling reflects "an overburdened court system" and an unintended consequence of recent efforts by Baltimore's Police Commissioner, Thomas C. Frazier, to drive down crime rates as the city tried to polish its image to attract new residents and economic development. 
 Mr. Kodeck applauded the police work but conceded: "There's not a whole lot we can do, and when the system fails, it's regrettable. We feel that that judge's decision was wrong."
Judge Brown's ruling, issued on Tuesday, followed a decision last month by a Maryland appeals court to overturn a sex-charge conviction against a man whose trial had been postponed nine times over 13 months because no judge was available on the next scheduled day for the trial to begin. In general, a felony trial is supposed to begin six months after arraignment, the court appearance in which charges are filed.
But as the Baltimore police grapple with about 300 homicide cases a year, as many as 1,500 nonfatal shootings and thousands of cases in which people are arrested for involvement with illegal drugs, the demand for judges, prosecutors and public defenders has grown to an overwhelming level.
The case on which Judge Brown ruled involved four men -- Jay Anderson, 30; William Harrison, 21; Donte Spivey, 22, and Stacey Wilson, 29 -- who were accused of shooting to death Shawn L. Suggs in October 1995, when he was 21.
The four men spent several months in jail and then were released on bail. While free, Mr. Spivey was arrested for another killing and was held, pending trial.
But Judge Brown dropped charges against them in the Suggs case after the trial date was postponed 12 times because of the unavailability of a judge, a prosecutor or a defender.
Judge Joseph H. H. Kaplan, chief judge of the Circuit Court for Baltimore, said in an interview that the current backlog of felony cases exceeded 5,000, "and it is not inconceivable that some of them go back more than a year."
Contributing to the backlog, Judge Kaplan said, is the availability of only 11 courtrooms and a limited number of prosecutors and public defenders, who are vastly overmatched by the number of cases.
Mr. Kodeck said his entire office comprised 170 lawyers, only 18 of whom were assigned to violent crimes, each of them carrying as many as 18 homicide cases.
Michael N. Gambrill, the District Public Defender for Baltimore, said his office had only 109 lawyers, with 31 of them assigned to felony trials. Their average case load, Mr. Gambrill said, is 67 open cases, and some of the defenders are handling more than 100 open cases.
"We have to cover district courts, circuit courts and central booking," he said. "The need is tremendous."
Judge Kaplan said he tried to ease the pressure last May by adding two courtrooms for felony cases, only for them to go unused because the public defender's office, which is financed by the state, did not have the personnel to take advantage of them.
"There's a shortage on both sides," Judge Kaplan said. "It's more critical on the public defender side, but it's certainly a serious situation. It's like trying to put 10 gallons in a 2-gallon jar."
Mr. Gambrill said -- and Judge Kaplan agreed -- that much of the backlog had evolved from aggressive efforts by the police to reduce the level of illegal drug activities.
But problems arise, they said, when the police make sweeps, arresting dozens of people at one time and charging all of them with felony-level crimes, when the offenses by some might only be less serious misdemeanors. Unlike in some other jurisdictions where prosecutors determine the charges, in Baltimore the police do.
Those kinds of arrests, Mr. Gambrill said, "are clogging up the court."
"If one addict is passing a capsule to another addict, the police charge both with distribution, a felony," he said. "Technically, it is distributing, but the question is, do you want to put that case on the circuit court docket? We've got 60,000 drug addicts in the metropolitan area. You can't arrest all those people and not clog the system."
Robert Weinhold, a spokesman for the police department, disagreed with Mr. Gambrill's assertion, saying, "Officers are charging individuals within the legal framework set forth by state legislators."
Mr. Weinhold also said the police found it extremely frustrating that an overworked criminal justice system was allowing defendants to go free.

HEADLINE: The Great Pork Gap;
Hog Prices Have Plummeted. Why Haven't Store Prices?

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: PARK RIDGE, Ill.

 BODY:
Inside a giant Dominick's Supermarket here, Sam Ventura was buying some high-grade pork chops.
At $3.99 a pound, Mr. Ventura was not fretting. "This isn't a steal, but the price is fine," he said, unloading a cart of groceries at the checkout counter as his 5-year-old son, Vinnie, looked on. "We eat pork every week, and you never hear bad things about it -- none of that mad-cow stuff." 
 But to Rick Dean, a hog farmer in Leroy, Ill., two and a half hours south of this Chicago suburb, the price was a disgrace. While the pork products from just one of his hogs yields about $304 at the supermarket, he was paid just $29 apiece when he took his hogs to market a few weeks ago -- down from about $110 a year ago. "We've got a lot of financial stress," said Mr. Dean, a third-generation hog farmer. "It's pretty discouraging."
What is happening to all that money? Federal officials are looking into that question after hog farmers around the nation complained that something unusual was going on, something unfair -- perhaps even illegal.
For more than six months, a glut in the number of hogs being raised sent hog prices plummeting to Depression-era lows. Yet the price of pork at the meat counter has barely budged.
So while much of the nation is splurging on pork chops, ham and bacon, allegations of price-gouging are being leveled against the meatpackers that turn hogs into pork products, and to a lesser extent against the giant supermarket chains that sell them.
"We're very concerned about the prices producers are getting paid," said Cynthia Cunningham, a spokeswoman at the National Pork Producers Council in Des Moines. "Something isn't right."
Meatpackers and retailers counter that Government figures fail to reflect a significant drop in prices because they do not measure the amount of pork sold at a discount.
"Almost everything we sell moves at a special price," said Tim Hammonds, president of the Food Marketing Institute in Washington, a trade group that represents some of the nation's largest grocery chains. "Retailers are aggressively featuring pork."
They also argue, with the support of many economists, that the traditional market forces of supply and demand largely explain why hog prices have plunged even though the price of pork has not fallen nearly as much.
 Prices for live hogs have bounced off their lows in recent days, with prices reaching 19 cents a pound on Tuesday, according to the Department of Agriculture -- up from a low of 10 cents a pound in December.
 It is no surprise that the farmers' crisis has caught Washington's eye. Federal officials acknowledge that some pricing data could be faulty, but they are also concerned about the growing gap between hog prices at the farm level, which are down 65 percent, and pork prices at the retail level, which are down just 2 to 3 percent -- a spread that economists say is one of the widest on record.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has asked the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission to look into possible price-fixing or anticompetitive pricing by meatpackers.
And the National Farmers Union is urging Federal officials to investigate competition in the pork industry, where 75 percent of the packing is controlled by just six companies -- Smithfield, IBP, Swift, Excel, Farmland and Hormel Foods.
Several large meatpackers say that they have cut prices about 30 percent from a year ago, and that they are working overtime to slaughter and process a record number of hogs, more than two million a week -- 10 percent more than a year ago.
"There are hogs everywhere," says Jens Knutson, a spokesman for the American Meat Institute in Washington, which represents meatpackers. "The prices are really what is necessary to clear the market; these are market forces at work."
Because of that glut, meatpackers are bidding down the prices when farmers call to say they want to deliver a truckload of pigs. Some farmers say they no longer shop around; they simply ask if and when a packer will take delivery. This gives packers tremendous leverage -- leverage that industry officials say may be battering farmers and enriching packers.
Several big meatpackers acknowledge that for them these are good times indeed. "There's no question packers are making good money," said Gary Mickelson, a spokesman at IBP in Dakota City, Neb., one of the nation's largest meatpackers. "But ultimately it's the law of supply and demand."
As a result, after two years of losses, IBP has been posting record profits, up more than 125 percent in the third quarter of 1998, and its shares jumped more than 37 percent in 1998. Hormel, the large meat processor based in Austin, Minn., also reported record profits of nearly $140 million in 1998.
Pure greed is hardly the issue, though. Economists say that a more complicated set of factors is at work.
"The probability of collusion or anything like it is near zero," said Glenn Grimes, a professor of agricultural economy at the University of Missouri at Columbia. "I just think the American people aren't that price-conscious."
One reason retail prices have not fallen sharply, economists say, is that soaring demand for pork means retailers are under less pressure to lower prices. But that is only part of the answer.
Much of the dispute can be traced to the data. According to the Agriculture Department, the price of live hogs -- which the farmer sells to the meatpacker -- has fallen as much as 65 percent from a year ago. The wholesale prices that the meatpackers get for their pork products, though, are down 30 percent. And the retail price of pork (an average of several products: ham, pork chops, sausage, bacon and pork roast) is down just 2 to 3 percent from a year ago, at $2.26 a pound.
Retailers said that the grocery-store data failed to reflect that most pork was sold at discount. Pork prices, they said, are actually down 13 to 19 percent from a year ago. Even so, the drop-off is nowhere near the plunge in farm prices.
Economists noted that farm and retail prices did not usually move in lockstep, because the cost of the raw commodity was only one component in the cost of delivering meat to consumers. But -- even if the retailers' figures are correct -- economists also said that the spread between the two did not usually bulge as large as it had been.
"There is reason to be concerned that retail prices are not behaving as they have in the past," said John Lawrence, a professor of agricultural economics at Iowa State University. "There's usually a two-to-four-month lag in the change in prices. But it's been over a year now and it's still not following."
Agriculture Department officials acknowledged that their data were incomplete, possibly even flawed. But economists said that data for 1994 -- when farm prices also declined sharply -- showed that the spread between retail and farm-level prices was far narrower, and the two sets of prices moved more in tandem than now.
But what really bothers hog farmers -- even those who say their production boom sparked this crisis -- is the way revenue has been divided.
In recent years, retailers received about 47 cents for every dollar of pork sold, while meatpackers took in 16 cents and hog farmers, who were enjoying hefty profits, 37 cents. But now, with live hog prices down from about 35 cents a pound a year ago to about 11 cents today, those percentages have been turned on their head.
Retailers now get about 60 cents of that dollar, meatpackers 22 cents and hog farmers just 18 cents, according to the Agriculture Department.
Meatpackers have taken the brunt of the criticism, but retailers are also coming under scrutiny.
"There are a segment of retailers who are taking advantage of the equation," said Dallas Hockman, a vice president at the National Pork Producers Council. "Right now, all the cards are in their favor. But I say to them, 'Are you willing to take significant margins today to disrupt the supply chain and hurt margins down the road?' "
Retailers dispute any suggestion of price-gouging. "We don't see anyone taking excess profits," said Mr. Hammonds of the Food Marketing Institute. "And the exercise in finger-pointing is not the way to solve the problem. We are conscious of what pork producers are going through. And we're trying to move pork.
"We are saying to consumers: 'Add ham and pork.' "
Indeed, when retailers met not long ago with Mr. Glickman, the Agriculture Secretary, they brought a large supply of grocery-store circulars promoting pork specials.
It's the same at many stores. At a Hyvee Foods supermarket in Iowa, for example, the meat section was plastered during the Christmas weekend with hand-written signs urging shoppers to "Try Our New, Low, Low, Low Pork Prices!"
Nearby, a Fareway's supermarket initiated "Operation Pork," offering pork loins with bones for 69 cents a pound.
But just as often, consumers say, they are seeing stocks of pork that are not discounted. Consequently, some shoppers here in the Midwest -- where hog farms are integral to the economy -- have begun to ask why the price of pork has not fallen as sharply as, say, the price of gas, which is now as little as 80 cents a gallon.
"None of us understand why they haven't lowered their price even more," said Jan Kline, who was shopping with her family at a Cubs Food outlet in Ames, Iowa, shortly after Christmas. "I guess they're just keeping the price up to make a profit."
John McMillin, a food-industry analyst at Prudential Securities, said prices may fall now that the holiday rush is over. But he also said supermarkets had every right to profit in good times, because they suffered when the meat or dairy or poultry equation turned against them.
"The hog growers of America have made inordinately high returns for several years," he said. "One reason there are so many hogs right now is that returns have been so high."
Another reason retailers have not been cutting prices more aggressively, Mr. McMillin said, is that consumers dislike price volatility, particularly in the meat aisle.
Still, the pork industry finds itself in a quandary. While officials would like to see lower prices help sell more pork -- and thus eliminate it from the supply chain -- pork consumption is soaring even at relatively high prices.
If pork industry officials press too hard for lower prices, some economists say, it could move the supply faster, but consumers could also get used to cheap pork -- pork that is less profitable for farmers and retailers.
So industry officials have been careful about attacking the retailers that are helping push pork consumption to record levels.
"We want people to buy pork because they like it and because it's a good value," said John Hargerla at the National Pork Producers Council. "We don't want to be the cheapest meat on the block."

HEADLINE: Northrop to Take a Charge; Profits SeenBelow Analyst Forecasts

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The Northrop Grumman Corporation, the nation's largest maker of airframes for commercial aircraft, said yesterday that it would take a $125 million fourth-quarter charge and that 1999 annual profits would be about 20 percent below expectations because of the downturn in demand by Asian countries for Boeing 747's.
The Los Angeles-based Northrop produces the fuselage for the Boeing 747 jumbo jet, popular with Asian airlines. Last December, as Asian countries saw a dramatic downturn in air traffic as the region's economy weakened, Boeing announced it was cutting 747 production to two airplanes a month, from five a month just two years ago. 
 The ripple effect of the Asian economy has hit Northrop as it regroups after a proposed takeover by the Lockheed Corporation was called off last July because of Government objections. Northrop's stock traded as high as $108 a share just before the takeover was halted.
It then tumbled and had begun to recover slightly last fall before the Boeing announcement in December knocked it down again. Yesterday, the stock closed at $69.3125, down $3.9375.
For 1999, Northrop projected it would earn around $6.33 a share, or $1.18 a share less than the $7.51 consensus of equity analysts. "We believe the current analysts' consensus estimate of $7.51 is overstated," said Kent Kresa, Northrop's chief executive. The company will announce its 1998 earnings on Feb. 3. In 1997, the company had sales of $9.2 billion.
Of the $125 million fourth-quarter charge, a total of $105 million is due to the 747 production cutbacks along with an increase in costs of fuselages currently in production. The rest is due to delays in a series of tests on a joint defense program with the British and United States defense departments that have resulted in $20 million in unrecoverable costs.
"Northrop is being pretty up front in defining these numbers," said Howard Rubel, an aerospace analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The hardest part was coming to a conclusion of what the numbers would be and Northrop has done a good job of quantifying it." Each of the 153-foot main 747 fuselages that Northrop makes generates around $10 million for the company, which has been the 747's principal airframe subcontractor since the 747 program began in 1966.
The new write-off adds to a previously announced 1998 accounting charge of $60 million.
The company is also in the midst of reducing its work force of 54,000 by about 17 percent, or 9,000 workers, in 1999, through layoffs and attrition.
The Asian downturn also caused Allied Signal Inc., the world's 10th- largest aerospace company, to realign its aerospace business to save $30 million to $50 million. The Morris Township, N.J., maker of aircraft equipment, facing the same slowdown in global demand for commercial aircraft, said it expected to reduce costs through layoffs and consolidation in its supply chain.
The company did not provide information on how the aerospace business would be realigned. But investors reacted more favorably, with the stock closing at $44.6875, up 87.5 cents.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Pledge $7 Billion For Missile Defense System

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Sixteen years after President Ronald Reagan envisioned a "Star Wars" program to protect the United States from ballistic missile attacks, President Clinton plans to pledge about $7 billion over six years to build a limited missile defense system, even though he will leave a final decision on whether to build it until later, officials said.
Mr. Clinton is not expected to decide whether -- and how -- to build a system until the summer of 2000. And at this point, no one has proved that such a system will work. 
 But the officials said the decision to set aside money in the Pentagon's budget now was meant to underscore the Administration's political commitment to the idea and to head off growing criticism from Republicans in Congress that Mr. Clinton was not doing enough to defend the nation from a missile strike.
Since Mr. Reagan unveiled his dream of creating an impenetrable shield against nuclear missiles in 1983, the nation has spent some $55 billion trying to develop a workable weapon -- so far to no avail. But never before has any money been put in the budget actually to build one.
The money, which officials put at roughly $7 billion, is part of the more than $100 billion in new spending Mr. Clinton is expected to propose giving the Pentagon between now and 2005 when he submits his budget to Congress next month.
The White House and Pentagon declined to discuss the spending proposal today, but the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, signaled the Administration's intent at an appearance before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday.
General Shelton said the Pentagon had the resources to continue to develop the program. The Administration is "also putting money into the program so that at the time that we have the technology, if in fact the threat justifies it, then we could go ahead with the fielding," he said when questioned about Mr. Clinton's commitment to a missile defense system.
The system now being developed and tested is a mere shadow of the space-based network of satellites and lasers that Mr. Reagan envisioned to knock out even the largest Soviet nuclear strike. The Pentagon officially abandoned that concept in 1993 and has since concentrated on using ground- or sea-based missiles to intercept perhaps a few missiles launched either accidentally from a superpower like Russia or deliberately by a hostile nation like North Korea.
Even with a pledge of money, the effort remains burdened with economic, technological, political and diplomatic problems. And there are lingering doubts that one will ever be feasible.
The system faces a pivotal test in June. The program's developers, led by the Boeing Company, plan to launch a dummy missile from Vandenberg Air Force Base, in California, and try to destroy it in space over the Pacific Ocean with an interceptor missile fired from Kwajalein Atoll, in the Marshall Islands.
Three more tests are scheduled before Mr. Clinton makes a decision next year. Previous tests of interceptor missiles have failed, as have tests of shorter-range missiles, like those in the troubled Theater High-Altitude Area Defense program, or Thaad, run by the Army. But officials at the Pentagon express confidence that a limited system may at last be technologically at hand.
"Those of us who work in the program are very confident we're going to have a working system, and we're going to have it soon," Lieut. Col. Richard A. Lehner, a spokesman for the National Missile Defense Program, at the Pentagon, said today.
Republicans in Congress have long wanted to revive at least part of Mr. Reagan's original vision. Faced with Republican-sponsored legislation mandating the creation of a national system, Mr. Clinton promised to proceed with research for three years and decide in 2000 on whether the threat justified building a system by 2003, a policy referred to a "three plus three."
A Pentagon official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the Administration had to include money in the Pentagon's future budgets or its promise to consider building a system would ring hollow.
"This is a recognition that we can't have our cake and eat it, too," the official said.
Others said the White House and Pentagon had concluded that the threat from intercontinental missiles from hostile nations was growing, noting North Korea's test of a three-staged missile on Aug. 31. Although Mr. Clinton and his aides have not yet made a decision, one senior Administration official said, "they're coming closer."
Representative Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania, a Republican and one of the strongest proponents of a national missile defense, said he would welcome a decision to put money in the budget. But Mr. Weldon said he remained skeptical about the President's motives and vowed to press again for legislation to build a system as soon as possible.
"It's certainly grudgingly coming around," Mr. Weldon said of the Administration. "I'm still not sure there's a solid commitment there."
Many arms control advocates argue that a system -- if someday workable -- would violate the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty signed by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1972, which sharply limited the number, type and placement of missiles that could be used to counter enemy missiles.
Other critics argue that the effort squanders resources that could better spent trying to keep terrorists or hostile nations from ever acquiring the technology to develop weapons in the first place. And even within the Pentagon, there are those who argue that the real threat of nuclear attack against the United States is a terrorist armed with a warhead in a car or truck, not a nuclear-tipped missile fired from thousands of miles away.
"This does not seem to be a wise and balanced approach to U.S. defense needs," said Spurgeon M. Keeny Jr., president of the Arms Control Association in Washington.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
TheN.B.A. Finally Returns and Marketers Yawn

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
The agreement in principle reached yesterday to salvage the National Basketball Association season is being welcomed by most marketers and agencies, particularly those that covet the younger male consumers who fervently follow the Bulls, Knicks, Lakers and all that Jazz.
But in an ominous sign for the long-term advertising appeal of the league, apart from those executives directly involved in marketing footwear and apparel, many others described little if any significant damage from the six-month lockout. And they expressed concern that the late start to the season, as well as lingering perceptions of players and officials more concerned about salaries and selling than statistics and scoring, would alienate fans. 
 "The N.B.A. got confused, thinking the fan base was the television audience," said Jon Mandel, co-managing director of Mediacom, the media services agency in New York owned by Grey Advertising, which buys time and space for marketers like Reebok International Ltd.
"But it's the fans who follow the game who are really in charge of your brand image," he added. "So if you tell them, 'Let 'em eat cake,' it's more than just a labor issue."
Donny Deutsch, chairman at Deutsch Inc. in New York, the agency for the Foot Locker and Lady Foot Locker athletic retail chains owned by Venator Group, echoed Mr. Mandel's cautionary comments.
"All this bad will has the N.B.A. in trouble," Mr. Deutsch said. "I'm a huge fan, but I will not go to a game this season."
"Basketball is driven by individual athletes, more so than other sports," he added. "But the players are looking unlikable, like fools."
Gene DeWitt, the chairman at DeWitt Media in New York, a media services agency, compared the dispute between the players and league officials to "two sets of bankers having a battle."
The public's attitude, he added, "is like a pox on both their houses."
"People have formed other habits without N.B.A. games," he said. "The damage to the sport, certainly for this year, could be tremendous."
There were two reasons given for the widespread opinions that the difficulties inflicted upon advertisers were minimal. One was the breadth of media alternatives to professional basketball, particularly in an era of manufactured sports like the Winter X Games and myriad cable and broadcast networks.
"There's a variety of other male-targeted, very male-oriented programming," said Monica Karo, the Los Angeles media director for TBWA/Chiat/Day, a unit of Omnicom Group. "For clients like Sony, Apple, Kinko's, Nissan and Infiniti, we found other places to advertise.
"To reach men 18 to 24, 18 to 34, 25 to 49 and 25 to 54," she added, "we've used other sports, primarily college basketball and football, some cable like CNN and Discovery and syndication."
Andy Donchin, the vice president and director for national broadcast at Carat North America in New York, a media services arm of Aegis Group P.L.C., said that for advertisers like Alberto-Culver and Midas, "we re-expressed the money into appropriate programming to give us male viewership." He said that included the "male-oriented movies" scheduled by the TNT cable network, part of Time Warner Inc., in lieu of the N.B.A. games that were to have appeared on the network.
Bob Igiel, executive vice president and broadcast director at the Media Edge in New York, the media services unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., said: "Some clients just wanted pro basketball and held money back until play resumed. For those who needed media weight in January and February, we used prime time, football and college basketball."
"That tightened up the first-quarter TV market," he added, referring to the shrinking inventory of commercial time that has produced more robust demand than is usual for the post-holiday season. Indeed, the trade publication Mediaweek reported this week that commercials during network prime-time programs in the so-called scatter market -- the spots that were not bought before the 1998-99 season began -- were nearly sold out.
The other main reason given for the commonly held belief that the effect of the lockout on advertisers was slight was the rhythm of the pro basketball season: Earlier games attract less attention than later games and later games attract less attention than playoff games.
"Most of our attention is focused on the playoffs," said Brad Shaw, a spokesman for the Pepsi-Cola Company unit of Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., "so the impact on us was minimal." To help introduce the Pepsi One soft-drink brand, aimed at younger men as well as women, "we've been largely on network prime time," he added, "which was the plan anyway."
A competitor that rarely agrees with Pepsi-Cola did so this time. "Ratings climb as the season progresses," said Scott Jacobson, a spokesman for the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta, which bills its long-term sponsorship agreement with the league as a "100-year partnership."
"In most seasons, we tend to have heavier media weight toward the end," he added, "so while we'll be figuring out a way to make up for some lost time, it was kind of business as usual; this was not disruptive at all."
Aware before the lockout began that "there might be a labor situation," Mr. Jacobson said, Coca-Cola executives planned so that their annual professional basketball promotion, for the Sprite soft-drink brand, would work with or without games being played. In fact, the promotion, called the Sprite Salary Cap, capitalized on the publicity for the dispute with satirical spots by Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York -- part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies -- showing players like Grant Hill and Tim Duncan pretending to need work.
One commercial, which showed players performing chores for callers to a make-believe job referral service, 1-800-TALL-MEN, generated "between 300,000 and 400,000 calls," Mr. Jacobson said, adding that callers heard a recorded message from Hill in which he said: "I can't believe you really called. It's a joke, a joke," then described details of the Sprite promotion.
Some advertisers, of course, need the N.B.A. more than others. Sales of sneakers and other athletic paraphernalia, especially for marketers that sponsor the N.B.A. or have a stable of player-endorsers, have been weakened by the lockout.
"It certainly has hurt the industry over all," said Vizhier Mooney, a spokeswoman for Nike Inc. in Beaverton, Ore., "and Nike is included in that." She said it was impossible to quantify the sales decline "because the industry was flat to begin with."
Nevertheless, Ms. Mooney said, "We're looking forward to being able to showcase again our footwear and apparel and our relationship with the athletes and the league."
Nike, too, parodied the lockout problems in advertising, running a campaign by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., in which celebrity fans of pro teams, like the director Spike Lee and the actress Dyan Cannon, delivered spoof tributes to neighborhood pickup games and eighth-grade girls' basketball.
"There's nothing that will replace professional basketball," Ms. Mooney said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
As StocksRise on the Continent, Euro Falls Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The euro fell sharply against the dollar yesterday, marring what was expected to be a pleasant honeymoon after the currency's introduction on Monday. A drop of 1.5 percent to a value of $1.15920 left the new currency below the initial reference rate of $1.16675 set on Dec. 31.
Its decline came despite a continued rally in European stock markets, some of which are up 8 percent in just the first three trading days of the year. 
 Analysts and traders said the euro selling was caused by several factors. One was rumors -- which were not confirmed -- that there were problems in settling trades in the new euro. A spokesman for the European Central Bank denied there were any problems.
In addition, the dollar rallied against the Japanese yen after a seven-day decline, a move that seemed to spill over into euro trading. And trading in the new euro is still cautious and relatively light, which means that its moves during one day can be exaggerated.
The dollar also got a boost from a sharp rise in United States stocks, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average and other indexes to new highs, and from automobile sales and housing data that showed that the American economy is still healthy.
"I don't think it means it has emptied the tank of the euro," said David Gilmore, a partner in Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn. "There is still an argument for a stronger euro. But it is a setback."
He said he had expected the euro to climb steadily and quickly to a value of $1.20. So the decline was a surprise.
Another analyst said that traders were "jumpy" but that it was too early to say the decline would set a trend for the euro's value.
Given that the euro has not been able to hold its own in its first three days of trading -- its only up day was Monday -- Friday could be very important for the new currency. That is when the Labor Department releases the December employment report and Germany announces its employment data.
Given current expectations -- for a weak German report and moderately robust American data -- the euro could face some more selling pressure. "I would argue at this point that the U.S. economy has more momentum going into 1999 than Euroland does," Mr. Gilmore said.

HEADLINE: Chase Bank to Levy Fees on A.T.M. Users Without Accounts

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Chase Manhattan Bank, the largest bank in New York City, said yesterday that it would impose fees for non-Chase customers who use its automated teller machines. Chase had been one of the last holdouts among banks in the city in not imposing the fees.
Beginning on Saturday, Chase will charge a fee of $1 or $1.50 at its 1,499 A.T.M.'s in New York and New Jersey, but not in Connecticut, where laws bar such fees. Yesterday's announcement does not affect Chase's banks operated under a separate subsidiary in Texas, where fees are already imposed. 
 "What we charge will depend on what other folks are charging," said Jack Stack, executive vice president for consumer banking, referring to other banks.
In New York City, the fees will be $1, but they will be $1.50 in New Jersey and elsewhere in New York. Bruce Zimmerman, senior vice president for consumer banking, said the move was justified because "Chase customers shouldn't be subsidizing non-Chase customers."
There are exceptions to the fee. Of Chase's 430 branches in New York and New Jersey, 60 branches will not impose the fee.
In those branches, chosen on the basis of census data, 50 percent or more of the residents of the immediate area, in the words of a Chase prepared statement, belong to low- and moderate-income households. Non-Chase customers who receive public-assistance payments electronically will also not be charged, the bank's statement added.
Nationwide, as interest rates have stayed at historically low levels, banks have sought new sources of income to supplement interest from consumer loans like home mortgages.
Banks operating A.T.M. networks have been able to impose fees since April 1996, after settlement of a lawsuit challenging the fees.
"This is disappointing," said Jules Polonetsky, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs. "Banks may claim that bank customers using A.T.M.'s subsidize nonbank customers, but it's the banks that really benefit because A.T.M.'s are more efficient than human tellers. Now they are charging a fee that is probably far more than their operating costs in order to turn A.T.M.'s into profit centers."
Mr. Polonetsky said a recent consumer affairs survey of 39 New York City banks showed that 30 of them imposed A.T.M. surcharges on noncustomers.
