HEADLINE: Office Maintenance Strike Is Averted

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
After 25 straight hours of talks, negotiators representing the managers of 1,000 New York City office buildings averted a strike yesterday by reaching a tentative agreement with the union representing about 30,000 building maintenance workers.
Negotiators for the city's real estate industry agreed to a contract that gives janitors, handymen and elevator operators in office buildings a wage increase of 3 percent a year for the next three years without substantial union givebacks. That makes the contract considerably more generous than the agreement negotiated three years ago after a painful monthlong strike that created chaos in the city's office towers. 
 "It wasn't the same atmosphere as three years ago," said James F. Berg, chief negotiator for the Realty Advisory Board, the industry's bargaining group. "The industry is a little healthier, and we were able to find a solution where we were willing to go a little further."
Real estate industry officials said they did not feel the same pressures to demand major concessions as they did three years ago when the vacancy rate in Manhattan was nearly twice current levels and office rents per square foot were about 25 percent below today's.
Mr. Berg, an executive vice president at the Realty Advisory Board, acknowledged that in this year's talks, the industry gave up its demand to further reduce the workers' starting salary from the lower starting rate obtained in the 1996 round of talks.
Under the new agreement, the union gained a higher maximum pension after 20 years, rising to $1,000 a month from $850. The new contract does not apply to residential buildings.
Mr. Berg began a marathon negotiating session at noon on Tuesday with Gus Bevona, president of the building workers' local, and they ended their talks around 1 P.M. yesterday at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in midtown Manhattan.
The previous three-year contract expired at 12:01 A.M. Jan. 1, and Mr. Bevona was threatening to begin a strike at 7 A.M. yesterday if no accord was reached by then.
Mr. Bevona, president of Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, issued a news release saying he was "delighted with the results."
The union has long boasted that its workers are among the highest-paid janitors in the country -- a fact that industry officials complain pushes up their operating costs and rents, contributing to making the city's real estate industry uncompetitive.
The union's janitors earn about $32,000 a year on average, although in the last contract, the industry won the right to pay new workers 20 percent less than experienced workers, with new workers graduating to the rate of other workers after 30 months.
Under the new contract, which runs from the first day of this month to Dec. 31, 2001, the janitors' salaries will increase to just under $35,000 in the third year.
"We'd like to think we both kind of won here," Mr. Berg said. "We were pleased that we were able to achieve a settlement that is within national norms and that we were able to afford."
He said that one modest achievement for the industry was the clarification of some contractual language that he said would give building managers some more flexibility in holding down costs.
Union officials said they planned to poll their members over the next few days in a ratification vote. The real estate industry ratified the agreement yesterday, at a meeting held right after the talks ended, when the Realty Advisory Board's 37-member board of directors approved the agreement.
The contract was negotiated with a healthier backdrop for the city's real estate industry. Three years ago, the contract talks broke down and a strike erupted when Mr. Bevona balked at the industry's demands for a lower starting salary as a way to hold costs down.
The strike left the workers picketing for weeks in withering January cold and left office buildings in chaos as managers scrambled to find people to shovel snow and asked office tenants to carry their own wastebaskets to central garbage collection areas.
At the time, the industry was worried about a soft rental market, a high vacancy rate and competition from lower-rent communities like Jersey City and Stamford, Conn.
But with the city's economy doing better than three years ago, there is less concern about competition from the suburbs. Barbara Byrne, director of research at Colliers ABR Inc., a commercial real estate brokerage firm, said that the vacancy rate had declined to 8 percent for prime Manhattan office buildings, down from 15.2 percent three years ago. And the average rent per square foot in prime Manhattan commercial buildings has climbed to $44.80, up from $31.25 three years ago.
According to industry officials, when all wages and benefits are factored in, the workers' compensation will rise in the new contract by 2.9 percent in 1999, 3.02 percent in 2000 and 2.85 percent in 2001.

HEADLINE: November New-Home Sales Hit a High

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Sales of new homes rose in November to a record, which should bolster economic growth in coming months.
Low mortgage rates and consumer optimism pushed up sales of new single-family houses a stronger-than-expected 7.6 percent in November, to 965,000 units at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, after a 6.4 percent gain in October, the Commerce Department said. That was far above expectations of a rate of 860,000. 
 "This isn't a fluke," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y. "This should give a big boost both to consumer spending on furniture and appliances in the first half of the year and to construction."
Through November, new-home sales are running 9 percent ahead of the 753,000 sold during the first 11 months of 1997.
When sales of existing homes are included, the housing market is on track to register a third consecutive yearly record in 1998.
Underscoring the housing market's vitality, October new-home sales were revised higher to a pace of 897,000 units from 851,000 units.
Unseasonable warm weather in October and November -- temperatures in the Midwest were 30 percent higher than normal -- also contributed to the stronger sales, analysts said, and the dry, mild December probably meant there were further gains last month.

HEADLINE: Financiers Plan To Put Controls On Derivatives

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON and TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
With the blessing of the Federal Government, some of the world's largest financial institutions reached an agreement today to try to set their own industrywide standards in the huge and volatile market of the complex securities known as derivatives.
By setting its own voluntary guidelines, the industry hopes to both lessen the chance of recurrences of problems in the derivatives markets and keep stricter regulations from being imposed by Washington. But previous attempts at self-regulation in the derivatives markets have met with limited success. They did little to stave off the near-collapse last September of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., the huge Connecticut hedge fund. Long-Term Capital had invested heavily in derivatives, which are financial contracts that are supposed to manage a company's risks, particularly during turbulent changes in the economic climate. 
 Executives involved in drawing up the agreement, which will be formally announced on Thursday, said that by late spring the group would begin to write a set of industry guidelines governing everything from trading practices to lending standards and disclosure requirements.
The agreement, which was reached in Manhattan at a meeting of top executives from 12 leading foreign and domestic institutions and senior Federal officials including Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was warmly embraced by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary. Mr. Rubin heads an interagency group that is considering what changes may be necessary in the largely unregulated and steadily growing market in derivatives, so named because their value is derived from underlying products such as stocks, bonds or currencies.
The agreement also reflects a decided policy position by the Treasury Department and regulators that both the underwriters and the traders of these financial instruments have a pivotal role in policing themselves, a view shared by Wall Street.
"This will enable practitioners to implement the latest improvements in risk management and to begin the cycle of innovation all over again," said one senior executive on the committee, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Thomas A. Russo, an authority on derivatives regulation and managing director at Lehman Brothers, one of the companies serving on the group, said the formation of the group "is highly significant and a credit to the Government regulators for encouraging a private initiative to have global best practices in the risk-management area."
But some analysts disagreed and were either critical of the effort or skeptical of what it would ultimately achieve.
"I think it's the fox guarding the henhouse," said Charles Peabody, a banking analyst with Mitchell Securities Inc. in New York. "There's an inherent conflict because you won't police something too carefully if you're making a lot of money on it. That was the lesson of Long-Term Capital, and that's why you need an independent outside regulator."
Henry Hu, a derivatives expert and professor at the University of Texas Law School, said: "To the extent that it establishes norms about how people should behave, I think it is a good thing because the people being regulated know more about the products than the regulators. But a lot depends on whether it's merely aspirational or meant to be mandatory."
Others questioned whether a group of companies with deeply conflicting financial interests would be capable of mustering consensus on regulatory issues where agreement has proved to be elusive.
Government officials and industry executives praised the idea today. Administration officials involved in an interagency group set up after the collapse of Long-Term Capital and led by Mr. Rubin said that its conclusions would not be affected by the industry's work. Washington has so far moved cautiously in formulating any new regulations on the industry.
E. Gerald Corrigan, the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who is now a senior executive at Goldman, Sachs, and Stephen G. Thieke, a top official at J. P. Morgan, will be co-chairmen of the industry group. The other members of the group are Barclays, Bear Stearns, Chase, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and UBS.
Most of the group's members were involved in the bailout of Long-Term Capital. Th hedge fund, which borrowed heavily and threatened to wreak havoc on the financial markets when its investments began to sour, was rescued by Wall Street at the intervention of officials from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Several of the companies involved in the new group have recently taken significant hits on their earnings from either their investments in Long-Term Capital or their investments in derivatives.
In derivatives markets, an American company doing business in Britain, for example, might buy an option on the pound to protect itself against a decline in the currency that could hurt its profits, posted in dollars. Such a derivative is a standardized contract that trades on regulated financial exchanges. But many other kinds of derivative contracts are tailored for specific parties. In interest rate swaps, for example, one party agrees to exchange a fixed interest rate for a floating rate with another specific party for a specified period. These kinds of contracts are traded over the counter and remain off banks' balance sheets, making them difficult for regulators to handle.
The derivatives market has boomed over the last decade to become one of the most lucrative activities on Wall Street. About $37 trillion worth of privately traded derivatives contracts are outstanding, up from $865 billion in 1987, according to the International Swap and Derivatives Association. That figure, however, represents the paper, or "notional," value of all of the underlying financial products used to create a derivatives contract. The actual exposure of most banks to the derivatives contracts they carry is only a small percentage of the paper value, in most cases well less than 1 percent of that amount.
The impetus for the banks' derivatives proposal was a meeting convened in December by Mr. Levitt at Morgan Stanley's New York headquarters. Two other investment banking firms -- Goldman, Sachs and J. P. Morgan -- also were represented at that meeting, where it was decided that Mr. Corrigan and Mr. Thieke would oversee the working group assigned to create the self-regulatory proposal. Today's meeting was also held at Morgan Stanley's headquarters, and many of the group's chairmen attended.

HEADLINE: Republicans to Push for a Tax Cut of Up to $500 Billion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Key Republicans in the House and the Senate said today that they planned to push for a tax cut of as much as $500 billion over the next decade, including cuts in income tax rates, to take advantage of Federal budget surpluses that appear to be growing faster than previously projected.
Even a general agreement on an approach would be a marked change from the bitter fight among House and Senate Republicans last year over how hard to push for tax cuts. The proposals are still in tentative form, and aides said working out the details would be difficult. 
 But the effort represents a concerted challenge to President Clinton's strategy of blocking any substantial tax cuts until after Congress and the Administration settle on a plan to shore up Social Security.
The tax cuts would probably be dependent on the surpluses actually materializing, and would be financed only by that part of the surpluses that does not come from excess Social Security tax revenue, members of Congress and their aides said.
Until now, nearly all of the surpluses over the next decade have been projected to come from Social Security taxes beyond what is needed to pay current beneficiaries. As a result, Republican tax-cutting plans have been attacked by the President and Congressional Democrats on the ground that they would endanger the retirement system, which is already facing long-term financial problems.
But new estimates of the surplus being developed by the Congressional Budget Office suggest that about $500 billion of the $1.8 trillion in surpluses likely to materialize in the next decade could come from outside Social Security, and that the non-Social Security surpluses could begin showing up in sizable amounts as soon as 2001, Republican aides said.
There is also mounting political pressure on Republicans. With their poll ratings plummeting as they pursue the ouster of Mr. Clinton, Republicans are scrambling to present a positive agenda. Most of the party's leaders see tax cutting as the most potent tool available.
But if they press ahead, they could find themselves in a heated battle with the White House.
The President announced today that the White House now expected the surplus for the current fiscal year to be $76 billion, as compared to the last estimate from the Congressional Budget Office of $63 billion. But Mr. Clinton vowed to continue opposing tax cuts and spending increases that use the surplus until the Government deals with Social Security's looming financial problems.
"Like any family with long-term financial needs and a little more earnings than expected, we can't go out and spend the surplus today," the President said in announcing the surplus forecast at the White House. "We have to plan for the future."
If the 1999 fiscal year ends in a surplus, it will be the second consecutive year after 29 years of deficits. In the fiscal year 1998 the Government recorded a surplus of $70 billion.
Republicans, whose tax-cutting efforts were paralyzed last year by Mr. Clinton's Social Security strategy, now say they are increasingly comfortable that they can cut taxes while assuring voters that they are setting aside more than enough money for any overhaul of Social Security. The White House had hoped to reach a bipartisan agreement early this year on dealing with Social Security, but negotiations on the issue have all but ceased because of the impeachment proceedings against the President.
Under a plan being considered by Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, across-the-board reductions in income tax rates could be phased in as the non-Social Security surplus grows in coming years.
Aides said one idea under consideration was to create a "trigger" that would put the tax cuts into effect only when the surpluses actually materialized, so the cuts would not push the budget into deficit if the economy and tax revenue faltered. The Congressional Budget Office will release updated surplus estimates at the end of this month.
House Republicans pushed hard last year for a big tax cut, but found little support from their colleagues in the Senate, who were more cautious about crossing Mr. Clinton on Social Security. Senator Domenici and his counterpart in the House, Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, were at odds throughout much of the year. Because of the impasse, Congress failed for the first time in 25 years to adopt a basic tax and spending blueprint.
But the approach being developed by Mr. Domenici and his staff appears to have support in the House as well. Mr. Kasich said in an interview that he had spoken with Mr. Domenici about the plan on Tuesday, and that although it was too early to say how House Republicans would respond, he was encouraged.
"The idea that Senator Domenici wants not only to reform Social Security but to have substantial tax relief is music to my ears," Mr. Kasich said, adding that an across-the-board cut in income taxes of as much as 10 percent "is something I believe in very strongly."
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has argued since last year that there is enough money to deal with Social Security and cut taxes at the same time. Although they would not be specific, aides to Mr. Archer said he wanted to focus this year on tax cuts that would promote economic growth, a phrase usually used to refer to rate reductions.
There is likely to be continuing tension among Republicans, though, over how hard to push for across-the-board tax cuts at the expense of tax breaks favored by social conservatives, particularly a reduction in the marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples.

HEADLINE: French Premier Assails U.S. Over Iraq Air Strikes

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
France's Prime Minister criticized American and British air strikes against Iraq in an interview published today and said that France would soon be ready to propose ways for ending the impasse with Saddam Hussein.
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin told Le Monde, "The United States often acts in a unilateral way that undermines its ambition of mobilizing the international community." 
 "That was clear in the conflict with Iraq," he said. "What's the reality after the Anglo-American strikes? We've gone from a situation where the entire international community, with the United Nations, was reminding Iraq of its obligations, to a direct confrontation between the Baghdad regime and our American and British friends. I don't see how that's progress."
France, he said, was working on ideas to end the crisis in a way that would insure "lasting regional security" but permit Iraq to resume oil exports.
"In general," Mr. Jospin said, "I believe there is a need for France to assert itself more on the international scene, not because of its power or wanting to teach anybody lessons, but because it has a different way of seeing a certain number of international realities."
"France, a friend of the United States, does not automatically share that great country's point of view," he explained.
President Jacques Chirac and other French officials expressed disappointment at the British and American decision to bomb Iraq last month after it stopped cooperating with United Nations arms inspectors, but the official French reaction held Mr. Hussein to blame for the crisis.
Mr. Jospin, a Socialist, observed in the interview with Le Monde that presidential pronouncements on policy did not carry the same weight now as they did when Mr. Chirac's conservatives controlled both the presidency and the Government, from 1995 to mid-1997.
Mr. Jospin is widely expected to run against Mr. Chirac in the next presidential election in 2002.
Put on the defensive by Le Monde about what effect his Government's plan to move to a 35-hour workweek would have on France's 11.5 percent unemployment rate, Mr. Jospin replied that joblessness stood at 12.6 percent when he was elected, with 190,000 more people on the unemployment rolls than at the end of last year. Healthy economic growth stimulated by Government measures created 350,000 jobs in 1998, he said.
As for the 35-hour week, he said it would encourage negotiations between workers and managers at all levels of the economy on all kinds of questions.
"But the 35-hour week is not the only way to reduce unemployment," he said, adding that the Government would use Government money to create jobs for young people who have the most trouble finding work.
Mr. Jospin said that reducing juvenile delinquency and crime would be his highest priority this year, after jobs. And asked about growing strains within his leftist coalition, which includes Communist and Greens ministers as well as Socialists, he said, "Maybe we've accomplished more in 19 months than wearing ourselves out."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Governor's Address to the Legislature

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
New York must have a constitutional amendment that says that if any legislature wants to raise taxes on the people of New York, if state government wants to take more of the people's hard-earned money, if the bureaucracy wants to get bigger and costlier and wants the families of New York to pay for it, it can't do it easily. It will take a two-thirds vote of each house of the Legislature for each and every state tax increase. . . . 
 As part of our ongoing efforts to fuel the economic engines of New York's tourism industry, we've launched an unprecedented effort to restore and to promote our state's historic landmarks. . . . That is why I will propose legislation and funding to create a New York Heritage Trail. From the French and Indian War to the American Revolution, from Fort Ticonderoga to the Erie Canal, from Washington's headquarters in Newburgh to Walt Whitman's birthplace on Long Island, from John Brown's farm in Lake Placid to the Michigan Avenue Baptist Church in Buffalo, which served as a stop along the road to freedom through the Underground Railroad, these are sacred places. They tie us to our past and make us proud. . . .
In a month we'll be selecting the best 30 Build Now construction-ready sites, bringing this unique job-creation tool to virtually every corner of our state.
To add to that success, I will propose targeted tax incentives to make these and other development sites more attractive to businesses looking to expand and create jobs in New York. . . . And one of the most fertile areas of high-tech job creation is in biotechnology. That's why today, I am proposing a plan that will make the city of Buffalo a national leader in biotechnology research and business development. . . .
We need meaningful court reform and we need to clean up the political process with campaign finance reform. We need to keep the doors of our schools open until 7 o'clock at night by expanding advantage schools. And we need to clean up the air we breathe inside as well as outside by providing tax credits for businesses that create environmentally sound "green" buildings.
If we convince ourselves that New York is the best that it can be, if we convince ourselves that we've changed all that needs changing, if we convince ourselves that the prosperous times we've created are prosperous enough, then we draw bounds around a people who are boundless and place limits on a destiny that is limitless. But if we have the wisdom to understand that we are only as good as what we leave behind, then one day, what you and I do here will help to fulfill the dreams of a child we'll never know in a time we'll never see.

HEADLINE: 4 Childbirth Specialists Challenge U.S. Goal of Reducing Caesarean Births

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
Four leading childbirth specialists in Boston are challenging the Federal Government's goal to reduce the rate of Caesarean births, saying the effort could in fact be endangering some mothers and their babies.
In 1990, the United States Department of Health and Human Services, concerned about unnecessary surgery and health care costs, set a goal to reduce the national Caesarean rate to 15 percent by 2000. At the time, 23.5 percent of babies were delivered by Caesarean section. The current rate hovers around 21 percent, down from a high of 25 percent in 1988 but still way above the 5 percent rate in 1970 and not likely to reach 15 percent anytime soon. 
 The Boston experts, who published their views as an opinion article in today's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, fear that economic forces are driving efforts to reduce the number of operative deliveries without sufficient study of how a lower rate of Caesareans would affect the well-being of mothers and babies in different situations.
"The assumption that lowering the Caesarean section rate would reduce costs and represent better care is too simplistic," said Dr. Benjamin P. Sachs, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and chief author of the journal paper. "To go above the current rate is probably unacceptable, but if we're going to go below that, we have to have a monitoring system and safeguards in place to assure the safety of mothers and babies. Quality of care, not costs, should matter first and foremost."
His collaborator, Dr. Frederic Frigoletto, chief of obstetrics at the Massachusetts General Hospital, said, "We should begin by identifying what the rate should be for given conditions: multiple births, breech presentation, diabetes in the mother, etc. We need data to determine this so we can establish rates based on the best outcomes, not rates set by bureaucrats with economically driven motives."
Dr. Sachs and his colleagues agree that a vaginal delivery is better and cheaper than an operative one, "but only if it is safe." For example, they said, the use of vacuum extraction to assist in cases of difficult labor results in brain bleeding in 6 percent of births.
Asked to comment on the views of Dr. Sachs and his colleagues, Dr. Roger Freeman, an obstetrician and perinatologist at Long Beach Memorial Hospital in California, agreed that in some cases, hospitals had "gone too far" in trying to bring down Caesarean rates.
Dr. Freeman said, however, that there was clearly room for improvement. He pointed out, for example, that in low-risk patients, "there is great variability in the Caesarean rate -- from a low of 5 percent to a high of 40 percent -- from doctor to doctor, hospital to hospital and region to region."
"This tells me," he said, "there is probably an opportunity to lower the rate of Caesareans, at least among ordinary low-risk patients. But what that rate should be, I have no idea."
A spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, Damon Thompson, told The Associated Press that the 15 percent goal was based on consultation with hundreds of groups, and was only a target, not a quota. Mr. Thompson said studies had shown that hospitals could lower the C-section rate without compromising safety.
The 15 percent goal, established in the report Healthy People 2000, grew out of concern that far too many operative deliveries were being performed in this country, often for reasons not medically justifiable, like the convenience of the doctor or the pregnant woman. These reasons added to an already rising rate prompted by the growing use of fetal monitoring during labor. Monitors reveal when a fetus's health and survival are being jeopardized by letting labor continue toward a vaginal delivery, but they also sometimes falsely indicate difficulties, prompting Caesarean deliveries that turn out to have been unnecessary.
In addition, obstetricians facing skyrocketing malpractice costs and lawsuits when a delivery went awry, increasingly began practicing defensive medicine. Rather than take a chance that a baby would be injured during a difficult vaginal delivery, many doctors elected to perform Caesareans when faced with the slightest doubt about the baby's well-being.
Managed care companies are playing a major role in current efforts to reduce the rate of Caesarean births, which usually result in higher hospital and physician costs than a simple vaginal delivery. While agreeing that vaginal births were generally safer and cheaper, Dr. Sachs and his colleagues said growing pressures to avoid Caesareans were resulting in some ill-advised efforts at a vaginal delivery that often end up costing far more than a Caesarean and risk the health of mother and baby. They expressed particular concern about pressures on doctors to encourage every woman who has had a previous Caesarean delivery to try a vaginal birth.
"If the woman's uterus ruptures, which happens in 1 percent of these cases, the mom hemorrhages and may need a hysterectomy and the baby may end up brain-damaged or dead," Dr. Sachs said. Even if the baby is O.K., he said, the costs would be much greater than if a Caesarean had been performed.
Dr. Bruce L. Flamm, an obstetrician-gynecologist at the Kaiser-Permanente Medical Center in Riverside, Calif., said that "the cheapest way would be to operate electively in every case, not that I'm an advocate of more Caesareans." Dr. Flamm explained that in calculating the costs of vaginal versus operative deliveries, experts often failed to take into account the time a woman having a vaginal delivery spent in the hospital in labor.
Several factors now stand in the way of a sharp reduction in the Caesarean rate. One is the growing number of women having medically assisted multiple pregnancies resulting in high-risk births and those having first babies late in life. Older women are more likely to encounter difficulties in labor and to have underlying medical conditions that warrant an operative delivery. In addition, they and their doctors tend to be less willing to risk fetal injury during a vaginal delivery.
"Anxiety definitely plays a part in the decision to do a Caesarean," Dr. Sachs said. "If a woman is having her first child at 46, neither she nor her doctor is willing to take any chances."
Both Dr. Flamm and Dr. Freeman pointed to yet another obstacle: the still large number of obstetrician-gynecologists who are in solo or small practices. A doctor facing a complicated operation or an office full of patients the next day is not going to want to stay up with a woman in labor all night awaiting a vaginal delivery. In a large group practice, one physician can be on call for deliveries at night and then go home to rest the next day because there are other doctors available to handle office and hospital demands.

HEADLINE: Sworn In as Senator, Schumer Promises Money for New York

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
With his left hand on his silver-and-jade-trimmed bar mitzvah Bible, Charles E. Schumer was sworn in today as New York State's newest United States Senator, vowing to be a legislator who not only passes bills but also -- in the tradition of the man he defeated, Alfonse M. D'Amato -- delivers money and services to the state.
On a bracingly cold and brilliantly clear day, Mr. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn, also vowed not to let "the cloud of impeachment" distract him from working on what he said he considers the state's top issues: health care, crime, jobs, Social Security, education and campaign finance reform. 
 "Whether the trial lasts six days, or six weeks or even six months, I have six years to do the things that I want to do," Mr. Schumer told a group of about 50 friends and relatives at a cookies-and-coffee reception sponsored by the National Soft Drink Association on Capitol Hill.
Though he served nine terms in the House, Mr. Schumer sounded every bit the freshman legislator today, looking wide-eyed as he pumped well-wishers' hands and confessing to feeling "tingles down my spine" after passing the lighted Capitol dome the night before.
"I'm ready, excited and awe-struck at the chance to legislate," Mr. Schumer, 48, said at a news conference before he was sworn in by Vice President Al Gore.
Mr. Schumer was one of eight new Senators, four Democrats and four Republicans, sworn in to Congress today. On the House side, 40 new members were sworn in, 23 of them Democrats and 17 Republicans.
Mr. Schumer is the only new Senator from New York, New Jersey or Connecticut. There are six freshmen representatives from the region: four from New York and one each from the other two states.
It was a bit like homecoming week for several of the new members from the New York metropolitan region today outside the ceremonial room where representatives were being photographed with the newly elected Speaker of the House, Dennis Hastert, a Republican from Illinois.
There was Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat and former City Council member from Brooklyn who was elected to Mr. Schumer's old seat, talking to Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican who represented Staten Island in the City Council before being elected to Congress in 1997.
Farther down the line, Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, a Republican from the Buffalo area, slapped backs and shared congratulatory chatter with two other New York freshmen: Representative Joseph Crowley, a Queens Democrat, and Representative John E. Sweeney, a Republican from Troy. All three had been in Albany until they were elected last November, Mr. Reynolds and Mr. Crowley in the State Assembly, and Mr. Sweeney as an aide to Gov. George E. Pataki.
"It's good to be working again," Mr. Crowley said as he left the House chamber after casting his first vote. "I had been unemployed for five days."
Mr. Weiner, 34, gave his inaugural floor speech today, urging his colleagues to vote against reappointing the House managers who will argue the impeachment against the President in the Senate. But Mr. Weiner tripped a bit by calling for a no vote on the motion when he wanted a yes one. (The managers were reappointed).
"It's a shame I'll be revising my first remarks, but it was a bit of a nerve-racking experience," Mr. Weiner said.
Most of the new members brought bus loads of friends, relatives and former campaign workers to Washington to witness the solemn oaths, and then party afterward.
One of the largest contingents -- about 350 people -- came from New Jersey with Representative Rush D. Holt, 50, a physicist from the Princeton area who upset a Republican incumbent last November. During a midday reception, where the guests could be heard chatting about atomic elements and ocean warming over sandwiches, Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, quipped that 60 years after the Manhattan project was inaugurated to build an atomic bomb, "We finally have someone in the House who understands it."
Later, Mr. Holt, a Democrat, visited Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican from Stamford, to endorse Mr. Shays's efforts to enact legislation to toughen Federal campaign finance rules. "This is an issue that is particularly relevant to freshmen," said Mr. Holt, whose father was a one-term Democratic Senator from West Virginia during the 1930's. "We are the ones with the most recent exposure to the excessive demands of fund-raising."
Mr. Schumer, already known for his prowess as a bill writer, said today that he would work hard to help individual communities with their problems, echoing a theme President Clinton raised while campaigning for him in New York.
"One thing I never did was demean the title 'Senator Pothole,' " he said, referring to Mr. D'Amato's sobriquet. "I think that is an important role for a Senator."
Mr. Schumer then announced that he had already delivered for the town of Ogdensburg, near the Canadian border, by getting Clinton Administration approval for the town to use Federal transportation funds to renovate a Post Office into a commercial center.
Mr. Schumer, who received a relatively small share of the vote from north of New York City, said he had spent much of the post-election period traveling upstate and would make it one of his priorities to bring new jobs to that economically hard-pressed region. Among other things, he said, he would urge companies in New York City and other states to open branches in that region.
Mr. Schumer, who supports censuring but not removing the President, said he was deeply concerned that a drawn-out impeachment trial would leave a bitter partisan divide in the Senate. "It left a tremendous amount of rancor in the House," he said. "And one of my jobs, I think, is to try and prevent that from happening in the Senate. I think you can have strongly held views on this, which I do, without letting it get in the way of bipartisan relationships on other issues."
The new Senator, known for his aggressive pursuit of headlines, said he would try to hold regular news briefings with members of the New York press corps, as his fellow Democratic Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, did for many years. "I don't think too many people in the media are going to be griping that I'm not available," he said, prompting peals of laughter from the gathered reporters.

HEADLINE: THE 106TH CONGRESS;
Remarks to Congress by Dennis Hastert in His First Day as Speaker of the House

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Following are the remarks today by Representative Dennis Hastert, the Illinois Republican who was elected Speaker, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency:
Thank you, Mr. Speak -- Mr. Leader for your kind and thoughtful remarks. I'm going to break tradition, and at this point I am going to ask you to hold the gavel so that I may go down to the floor. 
 Customarily a new Speaker gives his first remarks from the Speaker's chair. And while I have great respect for the traditions of this House and this institution, I am breaking tradition this once because my legislative home is here on the floor with you, and so is my heart.
To you, the members of the 106th Congress, to my family, friends and constituents, I say thank you. This is not a job I sought, but it is one I embrace with determination and enthusiasm. In the next few minutes I will share with you how I plan to carry out the job you have given me.
But first, I think we need to take a moment, and I want to say goodbye to a member of this House who has made history. Newt, this institution has been forever transformed by your presence. For years to come, all Americans will benefit from the changes you have championed -- a balanced budget, welfare reform, tax relief. In fact, this week families all over America are beginning to calculate their taxes and, to help them, they will find a child tax credit made possible by the Congress you led. Thank you, Newt. Good luck. And God bless you in your new endeavors.
Those of you here in this House know me, but Hastert is not exactly a household name across America, so our fellow citizens deserve to know who I am and what I'm going to do. What I am is a former high school teacher, a wrestling and football coach, small businessman and state legislator. For the last 12 years I have been a member of this House. I am indebted to the people of the 14th District of Illinois who continue to send me here to represent them.
I believe in limited Government, but when Government does act, it must be for the good of the people. Serving in this body is a privilege -- it is not a right -- and each of us was sent here to conduct the people's business. And I intend to get down to business. That means formulating, debating and voting on legislation that addresses the problems the American people want solved.
In the turbulent days behind us, debate on the merits often gave way to personal attacks. Some here have felt slighted, insulted or ignored. That is wrong, and that will change.
Solutions to problems cannot be found in a pool of bitterness. They can be found in an environment in which we trust one another's word; where we generate heat and passion, but where we recognize that each member is equally important to our overall mission of improving the life of the American people. In short, I believe all of us -- regardless of party -- can respect one another, even as we fiercely disagree on particular issues.
Speaking of people who find ways to work together across the political fence, let me bring the analogy to a personal level. Two good Illinois friends of mine, George Ryan, the Republican Governor-elect, and Richard Daley, the Democratic Mayor of Chicago, are in the visitor's gallery, and I'll ask them to stand to be recognized.
Those who know me well will tell you I am true to my word. To me a commitment is a commitment. What you see and hear today is what you will see and hear tomorrow.
No one knows me better than my family. My wife, Jean, and our sons, Josh and Ethan, are here today. They are my reason for being. And Jean, she keeps me -- helps me keep my feet on the ground. She and the boys are my daily reminder that home is on the Fox River, not the Potomac River. To Jean, Josh and Ethan, thank you for everything. I love you.
As a teacher, I explained the story of America year after year. I soon came to realize that it was a story, but a story that keeps changing, for we Americans are a restless people. We like to tackle and solve problems. And we are constantly renewing our nation -- experimenting and creating new ways of doing things. I like to work against a backdrop of American basics: freedom, liberty, responsibility, opportunity. You can count on me to be a workhorse.
My experience as a football and wrestling coach taught me some other lessons that apply here. A good coach knows when to step back and let others shine in the spotlight. President Reagan for years had a plaque in his office that said it all: "There is no limit to what can be accomplished if you don't mind who gets the credit."
A good coach doesn't rely on only a few star players. Everyone on the squad has something to offer. You never get to the finals without a well-rounded team. Above all, a coach worth his salt will instill in his team a sense of fair play, camaraderie, respect for the game and for the opposition. Without those, victory is hollow, and defeat represents opportunities lost. I've found this to be true around here, too.
So, where do we go from here?
Some media pundits say that we'll have two years of stalemate because the Republican majority is too small. Some say that a White House bent on revenge will not give us a moment's peace. And some say the minority in this House will prevent passage of serious legislation so they can later claim this was a do-nothing Congress.
Washington is a town of rumors, guesses and speculation, so none of this comes as a surprise. But none of it needs to come true -- that is, if we really respect the voters who sent us here.
To my Republican colleagues, I say: It is time to put forward the major elements of our legislative program. We will succeed or fail depending upon how sensible a program we offer.
To my Democratic colleagues, I say: I will meet you halfway, maybe more so on occasion, but cooperation is a two-way street, and I expect you to meet me halfway, too. The President and a number of Democrats here in the House have been saying it is time to address several issues head on. I'll buy that, but I think we should agree that stalemate is not an option; solutions are.
To all my colleagues, I say: We must get our job done, and done now. We have an obligation to pass all the appropriation bills by this summer, and we will not leave this chamber until we do.
I intend to be a good listener, but I want to hear ideas and the debate that flows from them. I will have a low tolerance for campaign speeches masquerading as debate, whatever the source.
Our country faces four big challenges which we must address. And next -- not next month, or next year, or the year after that, but now. Each challenge involves an element of our security.
First is retirement and health security. Both our Social Security and Medicare programs will run into brick walls in a few years if we don't do something about them now. We must make sure that Social Security is there for those who depend upon it and those who expect to. We must also consider options for younger workers so they can look forward to an even brighter retirement.
Nearly a year ago, President Clinton came here to give his State of the Union address. He called for reform of Social Security. This year, I invite him to return to give us his reform plan. He has my assurance that it will be taken seriously.
Second, we must insure a secure future for America's children by insisting that every child has a good school in a safe, drug-free environment. In my 16 years as a teacher, I learned that most of the decisions having to do with education are best left to the people closest to the situation: parents, teachers and school board members. What should the Federal Government's role be? It should be to see that as many education dollars as possible go directly to the classrooms, where they will do the most good.
Next is economic security. In the early 80's, we adopted policies that laid the foundation for long-term growth. And except for one brief period, that growth has continued ever since. And we want our economy to keep right on growing. Well, toward that end, it is time for us in Congress to put a microscope to the ways the Government takes money from our fellow citizens and how it spends it.
There is a culture here in Washington that has grown unchallenged for too long. It combines three notions. One is that Government has a prior claim to the earnings of all Americans, as if they worked for the Government and not the other way around. Another notion is that a Government program, once begun, will never end. The third notion is that every program must grow with each passing year. Well, to borrow a musical line, it ain't necessarily so. At least it won't be as long as I'm around here and have anything to say about it. We must measure every dollar we spend by this criterion: Is it really necessary?
This is important. For most Americans, money doesn't come easy. When I was a kid, to make ends meet, my dad had a feed business and he worked nights in a restaurant. My mom raised chickens and sold the eggs. When tax time came around, our family really felt it. What we need is a leaner, more efficient Government, along with tax policies that spur and sustain growth by giving tax relief to all working Americans.
Finally, there is the challenge of America's security in a world of danger and uncertainty. Without it, the other elements of our security won't be possible. And we no longer worry about Soviet nuclear bombs raining down on us. Today, there are different worries: the sudden violence of a terrorist bomb; the silent threat of biological weapons; or the rogue state that aims a deadly missile at one of our cities. We need a defense capability that matches these turn-of-the-century threats. We have asked the men and women of our armed forces to take on assignments in many corners of the earth. Yet, we have not given them the best equipment or preparation they need to match all those assignments. That must be corrected.
These are not Democratic or Republican issues. They are American issues. We should be able to reach agreement quickly on the goals. And yes, we will argue about the means, but if we are in earnest about our responsibilities, we will find common ground and get the job done. In the process, we will build the people's faith in the United States Congress.
As a classroom teacher and coach I learned the value of brevity. I learned that it is work, not talk, that wins championships. In closing, I want you to know I am proud to have been chosen by you to be your Speaker. There is a big job ahead for all of us, so I ask that God bless this House as we move forward together.

PUB-DATE: January 7, 1999

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1123 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
A Robust Start To '99 Dazzles Stock Investors

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Nothing but up. So said stock markets around the world yesterday, wowing investors with one-day gains of better than 2 percent and in some markets, more than 3 percent.
Three days into 1999, the bull market in equities is alive and very well. The Dow Jones industrial average has risen 3.96 percent. The Nasdaq composite index, which gained just under 40 percent last year, is up 5.84 percent. Germany's benchmark DAX index has risen 8.28 percent, and the Bovespa index of Brazil, beaten down in 1998, has leapt 7.97 percent. 
 All the major United States stock gauges -- the Standard & Poor's 500, the Nasdaq composite index and the Dow industrials -- are trading at their highs. The Dow closed yesterday at 9,544.97, up 1.8 percent from its former peak of 9,374.27 on Nov. 23.
Driving this euphoria is investors' conviction that gloomy economic predictions have been overstated. "It's a show-me market," said John L. Manley Jr., senior equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "Investors are saying, 'We've been waiting for this recession for so long now and it hasn't materialized.' Now they're saying, 'Prove to me we're going into a recession or I'm going to buy stocks.' "
Early January jumps in stocks are not unusual. In 1988, according to Birinyi Associates, the Greenwich, Conn., money managers, stocks rose 3.9 percent in the first day of trading. And in the first two days of 1987, stocks began the year up 3.9 percent.
One reason prices often rise in January is a tendency among investors to change where they put their retirement accounts when they open a new calendar. Though most can make changes in their asset allocation any time, investors often decide to switch investments with the new year.
The most common change is to shift more money into whatever performed best the previous year. It is likely then that investors who are moving money around are doing two things. They are probably increasing their holdings in technology stocks, which dominate the Nasdaq, and have given the biggest boost to that index. And they are likely shifting money from funds that have lagged behind the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- more than 90 percent of actively managed funds underperformed their benchmarks last year -- into those like the Vanguard 500 fund that mirror this index.
Evidence of these kinds of changes can be found in the disparity in the performance of big-company stocks and the small-company stocks in the Russell 2000 index, the "small cap" benchmark. While the Dow Jones and the S.& P. 500 have both blown through their former highs, the Russell 2000 is still 7.7 percent below its peak of last July, and is up less than 1.4 percent so far in 1999.
And although yesterday's advance in big stocks was fairly broad, it did not lift all boats. Roughly for every two stocks that gained, one declined; I.B.M. fell slightly. Mexican shares are down; Japan is barely even.
Several factors contributed to the broad market rally. The Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes rose in November to a record high, indicating the economy is strong and demand for appliances, furniture and other goods to fill these houses will continue to be robust.
Another lift came from oil prices, which rose more than 3 percent after news that inventories in the United States had taken their biggest decline in 18 years. "Higher oil prices, while a pain in the neck for consumers, are a positive for developing countries," said Jack Shaughnessy of Advest Inc. in Boston. "Anything that tends to ease their financial stress is good for world markets."
Indeed, the free fall in commodity prices, a sign of slow or no growth around the world, seems to have halted, leading some to conclude that the worst of global economic turmoil is behind. The Commodity Research Bureau's index, which stood at 187 on Dec. 15, closed yesterday at 197. "The C.R.B. was the last thing hanging out there that indicated a problem in world economic growth," said James Paulsen of Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. But firming commodity prices will also help American corporations, he argued, by allowing them to increase prices and bolster their profit margins. Companies have found it difficult to raise prices in recent years, which has slowed earnings growth.
Because corporate earnings felt the pinch of Asia's woes in the first quarter of 1998, investors suspect that the first quarter of this year will look good in comparison. For those who still care about old-fashioned things like earnings growth, improvements from a year earlier translate into higher stock prices.
As stocks ran away yesterday, some strategists speculated that the overall market had been infected by the fever that has Internet stocks sizzling. The reasoning? When investors are willing to pay 80 times revenue for Amazon.com or 366 times sales for Ebay, why not push Microsoft shares to 64 times estimated earnings?
Stocks and bonds also benefited yesterday by a sharp rise in the dollar against the euro. When traders in European markets went home, a lot of the support for the currency disappeared. When trading shifted to New York, the market dipped. With the dollar rising, the Treasury market bounced as well, and bonds closed at the day's highs. The move in the dollar also buoyed stocks.
But the biggest propellant for stocks so far this year is the explosive growth in the supply of money circulating in the United States -- a factor that has contributed to higher stock prices for months. The money supply is growing at an annualized rate of 11 percent, far above what's needed to finance the growth in the gross domestic product. An enormous amount of the excess money is finding its way into the stock market.
This makes for an interesting situation for the Federal Reserve, said Ned Riley, chief investment officer of BankBoston. "The Fed has resurrected the irrational exuberance it was trying to temper earlier," he said. "The creation of all this money and lower interest rates have tended to fuel more speculation." The next meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee, in February, "is going to draw a lot of attention to this speculative frothy market," he said.
Almost no one thinks the Fed will change its stance on interest rates, which is toward lower rates, not higher. And as long as the Fed isn't going to step in and spoil the party by raising rates, stocks seem likely to go up.
Still, many professional investors were puzzled by yesterday's move in stocks. Frederick E. Rowe Jr., head of Greenbrier Partners, a money management firm in Dallas, echoed the views of many big investors when he said, "I don't pretend to understand it, but I don't want to get in the way of it."
